ANGELS OF NUCARREO

FULL STORY

Posted by Shaun
Last Updated:

The full story of Angels of Nucarreo. This story was run from September 25th 2023 to December 6th 2024 and was originally posted on the Clockworksun Stories Discord server.
This story is a whopping 206 updates long, plus an epilogue, spread over 746 standard pages with a total of over 240k words. At the time of writing, it was my longest story yet, over double the word count of second place.
Note that some reaction counts may not be exact, as voters may have changed their reactions between the close of voting and the time this story was scraped from the server.
Mxblah 9/23/2023 12:21 PM
@Story Notifications Alrighty then, time for some more writing! We've got two on the docket this time, which was going to be three until I decided to drop one at the last minute before posting this. I just wasn't as interested in it as these two, so you get two prompts and that's it; vote for the one you want! As usual, the one that isn't picked might come back later, be rewritten, or never be seen again. Without further ado, the prompts: [NOVEL?] Angels of Nucarreo Mystery / Grimdark Steampunk(?) - Urban [Part of the Nucarreo canon] Congratulations. You are the newest member of the Cathedra, the order of clergy and divinely-empowered superhumans charged with keeping the city - and everyone in it - safe. You will be pushed to your limits in Body, Mind, and Soul to serve your greater purpose. The job is difficult and dangerous, but you will wield powers beyond mortal beings, commanding respect and gratitude from those you defend. ... But where do these monsters we fight come from, really? What actually happens to new Angels during their Ascension? Why are we given these banal or seemingly-arbitrary tasks between combat duties? Why aren‚Äôt we allowed into those few hidden locations, even though we are the shining heroes of this city? What is really going on here? [NOVEL?] Big City Witch Mystery / Horror / ... Slice of Life? Near-future - a big city [Part of the Kronwae canon] You are a witch. You see things that others can't, face dangers ordinary people never know, and wield powers rare among humanity. Moving to the big city has been a heck of a change; besides the obvious, you also see far more supernatural activity here than your hometown. And that means it's time to get to work helping people deal with it. Whether for altruism or profit is up to you to decide. Just be careful to keep yourself safe as well... both from the monsters you face and the humans who would use your abilities for their own ends. (Winner: ) (edited)

Mxblah 9/25/2023 6:19 PM
@Story Notifications It‚Äôs time to descend into a universe we haven‚Äôt yet seen. One of steam, divinity, and darkness. Nucarreo. Who is our main character? This story will be told either primarily or entirely from their viewpoint, so choose carefully. The information given is only their initial personality and skills; you will have a chance to change certain aspects later with training and experience. The sibling not picked will still have a role in the story (more details in the next batch of pre-story choices), but will not be an Angel. Ô∏è - Jessamine Laura Goodall. Seth‚Äôs older sister, by about twelve seconds. Thoughtful and withdrawn; a little socially anxious and kind of a bookworm due to an extended illness and quarantine when she was little. Due to required classes for all young girls in the city, she is skilled in reading, writing, math, and other mental arts. Innately talented with magic themed around light and illumination, though she doesn‚Äôt know this yet. [Jessamine would make an excellent Angel focused around magic and investigation, though her combat ability will suffer.] - Seth Ivan Goodall. Jessamine‚Äôs younger brother, by about twelve seconds. Dedicated but friendly; strongly protective of Jessamine (partially due to her illness) and, to a lesser extent, other young people generally. Due to required classes for all young boys in the city, he is skilled in basic combat, manual trades, and other physical arts. Is particularly compatible with Angelic physical changes, though he doesn‚Äôt know this yet. [Seth would make an excellent Angel focused around combat and conversation, though his magical aptitude will suffer.] ‚Äã
6:19 PM
And what perspective shall be primarily used? 1Ô∏è‚É£ - First person (past tense). ‚ÄúGod answered my pleas. My Calling was to be an Angel.‚Äù 2Ô∏è‚É£ - Second person (present tense). ‚ÄúGod answers your pleas. Your Calling is to be an Angel.‚Äù [If you really want third person, we can talk, but I think first or second will work better in this style of story.] (Winners: Ô∏è , 2Ô∏è‚É£ ) (edited)

Mxblah 9/27/2023 6:38 PM
@Story Notifications Man, it‚Äôs a good thing you folks picked Jessamine, because I had already guessed you would and put her on the cover drawing. And boy did I not want to redo all that work with Seth instead. I think he will probably do better than Jessamine (with his personality and skills) as a non-Angel as well, so it probably all works out. Anyway, let‚Äôs determine a few more details. Seth will not become an Angel. So what will he become? - A constable, detective, or other cop keeping people safe within the city. - A soldier, driver, or other operator working in the wastes outside the city walls. - A government inspector, enforcer, or other agent brushing shoulders with politicians. ‚úùÔ∏è - An acolyte, deacon, or other member of the clergy helping to maintain the city‚Äôs faith. What is the city‚Äôs primary power source? The two options are fairly similar; the main differences are whether cars and electricity exist. In either case, there will be some magical augmentation, but not for ordinary citizens. Ô∏è - Coal-fired steam. Automobiles do not yet exist; carriages and steam locomotives move people and goods. Electricity is unknown, but networks of steam pipes transport power, of a sort, regardless. - Oil-based products; gas, diesel, and the like. Early automobiles putter around the streets. Generators belch smoke into the air and electrical wires begin to appear around buildings. (Winners: , Ô∏è ) (edited)

Mxblah 9/29/2023 6:26 PM
@Story Notifications Angels of Nucarreo
6:26 PM
Scene 0 ‚ÄúJessamine Laura Goodall,‚Äù Father Turner calls, his voice echoing briefly in the mostly-silent church. You scramble to your feet, shuffling past your mom and two other families in the row before emerging into the aisle and hurrying towards the pulpit. Most everyone remains quiet as you walk, white slippers padding on the dull, worn carpet. The church is full today, March 1st, the Calling Day for all children who have turned twelve since February 1st. You are one of them, your birthday falling on February 20th and making you finally old enough to know your future path. You - and every other child to be Called today - are wearing pure white tunics and pure white slippers, the better to display your own purity to God. You were careful to be on your best behavior for the last month and you followed the preparatory instructions perfectly. You are as ready as you can be, and everyone else in the church is here to support you. Still, you‚Äôre nervous. How can you not be? You‚Äôre about to be presented to God Himself and judged either worthy to Ascend... or worthy to follow a mortal Calling instead. You know there‚Äôs hardly a chance that God will pick you - of the thousands and thousands of children to be Called in any given year, He typically only chooses one or two. Rarely, up to four, and sometimes even zero if there are no worthy children in the lot. No one has yet been picked in the two previous Calling days this year, and no one has yet been picked today - here or in any of the churches spread through the city. You know that you won‚Äôt be picked either, or at least you‚Äôve tried to convince yourself that you won‚Äôt. ... But there‚Äôs still that tiny, tiny chance that you could be the one judged worthy. Your heart is racing. ‚Äã
6:26 PM
Father Turner smiles at you from the pulpit. He‚Äôs a kindly man in his late 30s, muscular from volunteering in construction during his free time. You know him well, as he helped your family a great deal during your sickness. He was only a deacon then, but was promoted to full priest shortly after you recovered. He‚Äôs had a soft spot for you and your brother ever since, passing you toys and treats and putting in good words with your teachers. Today, though, there are no extra words. Everything must be done with ritualistic precision, or God may deem you unworthy before you even enter the chamber. Priests like Father Turner hold a great deal of responsibility due to this, but you trust him to do his part just as he trusts you to do yours. He dips his fresh fern - plucked from the ground just this morning - in the small bowl of blessed water and anoints your forehead with it, tracing a small circle with the tip. Then, each bare shoulder in turn gets the same treatment. Left, then right. Soul, then Mind, then Body. Opposite of the usual order, but today is hardly a usual day. You shiver despite yourself. ‚ÄúChild of pure Body, Mind, and Soul,‚Äù he announces. ‚ÄúGo now with my blessing and learn your true Calling!‚Äù You steady your breathing as you walk measuredly past the priest and push open the plain wooden door to the Calling room. Behind you, Father Turner begins to speak again. ‚ÄúSeth Ivan Goodall.‚Äù Your brother. The ceremony moves quickly; most Callings take only moments and there are many children to get through. You close the door, take a deep breath, and walk to the tiled circle in the center. ‚Äã
6:27 PM
The room is near-empty. There is a stained-glass window in the ceiling, currently letting in rosy orange light from the midmorning sun. There is a black-tiled circle set into the floor and a white cloth pad where you are to kneel. There is a simple wooden matan - an equilateral triangle inscribed in a circle - fixed to the opposite wall. That‚Äôs it. You kneel on the pad, clasp your hands together, and look at the matan. The symbol of God. Divinity wrought from simple geometry. You find yourself tracing the triangle‚Äôs lines for a moment. Start at the bottom right and move left. Body, the basis for the other two aspects. Move up the left side to the apex. Mind, the channel through which Soul and Body meet. Finally, move down the right side from the apex, completing the triangle. Soul, your true self. Most days, Body and Mind are key. Today, it‚Äôs all about your Soul. You have no further instructions. Father Turner had just said to kneel in the circle and your Calling would come to you in a matter of moments. Not knowing what else to do, you close your eyes and pray. ... God, if you‚Äôre there, please send me a sign. Tell me my Calling. ‚Äú...‚Äù There is no divine vision; no supernal voice or sudden, shocking revelation. You feel a little warm, but the room is warm. Nothing. God, if He‚Äôs watching, remains silent. Please! You try again, suddenly terrified that something has gone wrong. I need to know! Please, tell me... Silence for many seconds, then a knock on the door. Your brother‚Äôs voice carries through the wood. ‚ÄúUh, Jess? Are you... done?‚Äù You stand up, distraught and not sure how to answer. Did the Calling ceremony just... not work for you? What would that mean? That God Himself has no plans for you? Were... a horrible thought strikes you. Were you... not meant to survive your illness? You almost didn‚Äôt; was your miraculous recovery against God‚Äôs will? ‚Äã
6:27 PM
An older voice; Father Turner. ‚ÄúJessamine, are you alright? Please leave the Calling chamber. We can discuss your results after the ceremony.‚Äù You almost shudder at his concern, but try to shake off your growing anxiety. Maybe this is just how it works if you weren‚Äôt judged worthy to Ascend. Maybe you‚Äôre the only one who would overthink it so badly and everyone else just left like normal. That wouldn‚Äôt be too bad, right? You take a deep breath, then walk over to the door. And open it. Brilliant white light washes over Seth and Father Turner, spilling out and illuminating the church proper. A gasp rises from many throats; your brother and the priest step back, shielding their eyes. From you. The light is coming from you. You hold up your arms in wonder, staring at the dazzling glow. Father Turner shouts to an acolyte, but the younger man is already moving, running to the heavy rope behind the pulpit that leads to the church‚Äôs roof. In moments, the enormous brass bell begins to toll, signaling that the most momentous of events has come to pass. It tolls for you! ‚ÄúJessamine, congratulations; oh congratulations!‚Äù Father Turner is saying, tears in his eyes. ‚ÄúYou have been chosen for the Lord‚Äôs greatest honor. You will Ascend to join the Cathedra as an Angel.‚Äù As the other nearby churches begin to ring their own bells, spreading news of your Ascension throughout the city; as Seth and your parents rush to you in astonishment; as the assembled congregation breaks out into shouted celebration and fragments of song; as the world goes to chaos around you, all you can do is stand rooted in place, bewildered by your own steadily-dimming glow. God answered your pleas. Your Calling is to be an Angel. - Your parents are overjoyed. - Your parents are happy, but it‚Äôs bittersweet. - Seth is thrilled for you. - Seth is worried about you. (Winners: , ) (edited)

Mxblah 10/1/2023 9:46 AM
@Story Notifications Scene 1 Your first duty as an Angel, Father Turner says once things start to calm down, is not to leave the church. You and your family - once Seth has gone through his Calling as well and come out without a blast of holy light - are sent to sit in one of the back offices to wait for someone as the priest finishes the ceremony. One of the church‚Äôs two deacons and the acolyte from earlier wait just outside the doorway, polite and pleasant... but very clear that you are not to go anywhere for the time being. It doesn‚Äôt take long at all for the ‚Äúsomeone‚Äù to show up; you‚Äôve hardly had a chance to say anything to your parents before an older man in the signature blue-striped coat of a bishop arrives, converses briefly with the deacon in a low voice, then enters the room. He has to shield his eyes from your glow as he comes in; it‚Äôs dimmed a little, but it‚Äôs still far too bright to be comfortable. ‚ÄúGood morning,‚Äù he says, making the sign of the matan and bowing to you. His voice is a little unsteady, as if he‚Äôs out of breath. ‚ÄúNew Angel Jessamine Laura Goodall, correct?‚Äù You open your mouth, but your mom answers first. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs right.‚Äù ‚ÄúGood, good.‚Äù The bishop taps his satchel as he continues. ‚ÄúMy name is Bishop Ashel Spencer; I‚Äôm here to get all the paperwork settled before your daughter‚Äôs official initiation. With Angels, we need to get started right away, so if you two wouldn‚Äôt mind following me to fill out some forms?‚Äù Your parents stand at the bishop‚Äôs gesture, though your dad puts a hand on your shoulder and doesn‚Äôt step forward. ‚ÄúWill Jessamine be coming along?‚Äù ‚Äã
9:46 AM
‚ÄúOh, no, that‚Äôs not necessary. We just need signatures from her legal guardians; the details she needs to know will be provided during her initiation.‚Äù Seeming to notice his concern, the bishop picks up his sentence awkwardly. ‚ÄúThe forms should only take fifteen minutes or so; your daughter will be right here when you‚Äôre done. You will have time to speak with her afterwards, of course.‚Äù ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs okay, dad,‚Äù you say quietly. Your voice sounds different, though you can‚Äôt quite pin down how. He raises his hand. ‚ÄúAlright, alright. We‚Äôll be right back, okay?‚Äù ‚ÄúOkay.‚Äù Bishop Spencer leaves with your parents; you can hear them speaking in the hallway, already going over the legal ramifications of your Ascension. You don‚Äôt need to know about that, you suppose. Though it might be nice. With the room now quiet and the promise of fifteen minutes before their return, Seth nudges you with his shoulder, sporting an enormous grin. ‚ÄúJess,‚Äù he whispers. ‚Äú... What?‚Äù you whisper back, half-smiling yourself just because of how contagious that big dumb grin is. ‚ÄúWhat do you mean what? You‚Äôre an ANGEL, that‚Äôs what!‚Äù ‚Äú... Yeah?‚Äù ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt even know where to start! This has to be the best thing that‚Äôs ever happened to you, or me, or mom and dad! You know that Angels don‚Äôt get sick ever, right? No more doctors for you!‚Äù ‚ÄúI - you‚Äôre right.‚Äù That hadn‚Äôt sunk in until now. You had technically recovered from your brutal childhood illness, but lingering symptoms had persisted for years afterwards. You had been a frail child even after leaving the hospital, getting sick more often and more seriously than anyone else your age. Seth had done his best to help, bringing you notes and assignments when you had to miss school - or just medicine and dumb jokes on the worst days - but the constant struggle had worn on you. As you got older, your health slowly improved, but even now, a moderately bad cold would knock you out for a week. After today, you would never have to deal with that again. ‚Äã
9:47 AM
‚ÄúI feel... good,‚Äù you admit to Seth, taking a deep breath. Your lungs don‚Äôt hurt at all. ‚ÄúReally good, even.‚Äù ‚ÄúSee? And you‚Äôre really tough now, too! I bet you‚Äôre never gonna get hurt again.‚Äù ‚Äú... Maybe.‚Äù You don‚Äôt actually know a lot about what Angels are or what they do. You‚Äôve only seen a few in your life, mostly during district assemblies where they didn‚Äôt do anything besides look perfect. You‚Äôve never heard of an Angel dying, but they do take on the toughest, most dangerous jobs that regular humans can‚Äôt handle. ... You keep saying ‚Äúthey,‚Äù like you aren‚Äôt one of them now. You will have to take on those jobs now. A few prickles of anxiety prod at your stomach, nerves breaking through even your new divine glow. Good to know you can still worry, you suppose. ‚ÄúHey, Jess, what was God like?‚Äù ‚ÄúHuh?‚Äù ‚ÄúDuring your Calling. For me, I just went in, sat in the circle, and then I just kinda knew it wasn‚Äôt me.‚Äù Seth glances at you, though he can‚Äôt look for very long with your glow still so strong. ‚ÄúOf course, going right after you kinda made that obvious already, but... I just knew anyway. It felt really sure and almost, uh, calm, I guess? But yours must‚Äôve been different, right? Did you talk to God?‚Äù ‚ÄúEr...‚Äù For some reason, even though you don‚Äôt know what an Angel‚Äôs Calling should be like, you feel a little embarrassed about yours. ‚ÄúI mean... I didn‚Äôt talk to God, really, but there was a... a sort of, um... like a feeling of a really bright light...‚Äù It‚Äôs almost relieving to still be unable to come up with a convincing lie in time, just like normal. Maybe that‚Äôs an Angel thing too; lying is bad and you‚Äôre supposed to be perfectly good, right? Seth doesn‚Äôt even have to say anything to disbelieve you; he just rolls his eyes. ‚Äã
9:47 AM
‚ÄúOkay, okay!‚Äù You lean closer and lower your voice, not wanting the deacon to overhear. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt feel anything. I just went in, sat down, and nothing happened at all. That‚Äôs why it took so long; I was just sitting there thinking it didn‚Äôt work! Then, well, you know.‚Äù ‚ÄúN-nothing? Really?‚Äù ‚ÄúKeep your voice down!‚Äù you hiss, glancing at the door. The acolyte scratches his nose absently. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know if that‚Äôs normal or something weird, and I really don‚Äôt want anyone to...‚Äù ‚ÄúWhat are they going to do? You‚Äôre literally glowing! Of course it worked!‚Äù ‚ÄúI - I mean, yeah, but...‚Äù You can feel your face heating up; the glow brightens. Seth nudges you again, laughing. ‚ÄúSame ol‚Äô Jess. Some people talk about how Angels are all different from the people they used to be and I was worried for a bit, but you‚Äôre still the same!‚Äù ‚ÄúY-yeah.‚Äù You try to dampen the glow, but don‚Äôt know how. The room continues to be about three times brighter than it needs to be. ‚ÄúBut seriously,‚Äù Seth says, nudging your shoulder for the third time. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm really happy for you. I think you‚Äôre gonna be a great Angel, and I‚Äôm gonna make sure I can help!‚Äù That big dumb grin is back and bigger than ever; you have to smile back. All you can say is ‚ÄúThanks,‚Äù but that‚Äôs okay. He knows what you mean. - You have to leave before Father Turner comes back. - Father Turner has time to talk to you briefly before you leave. - Father Turner will be accompanying you to the Cathedra. (Winner: ) (edited)

Mxblah 10/3/2023 10:00 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 2 After a while, Bishop Spencer comes back with your parents. ‚ÄúI will return with Father Turner once his part in the Calling ceremony is complete, as it is tradition for the uplifting priest to accompany new Angels to their initiation.‚Äù Then, for the first time, he actually addresses you directly. ‚ÄúAngel, you will leave for the Cathedra once we return. Please say your farewells and prepare to depart before then.‚Äù He nods to you briefly, then turns and leaves. A few seconds pass. You have a question. ‚ÄúWait, now? I thought - maybe tomorrow, or... How long am I going to be gone? Do I get to visit, at least?‚Äù The bishop has left, but your dad knows. ‚Äú... Yes, now. You‚Äôre important now, Jessamine, dreadfully so. The Cathedra wants to start your training immediately.‚Äù A beat; you feel your mom stroke your hair just like she did years ago when you were little. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôll be able to visit for holidays, but I‚Äôm afraid that‚Äôs it.‚Äù Mom is crying. Dad is trying to hide it, but he is too. Just a little. You trade worried looks with Seth, the mood taking an abrupt turn. ‚ÄúI-it‚Äôs okay,‚Äù you say, trying to be reassuring while also remembering the next holiday. ‚ÄúFounding Day isn‚Äôt that far away.‚Äù ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not just that,‚Äù your mom says, recovering somewhat. ‚ÄúThese are happy tears too, sweetie. You - an Angel - I just can‚Äôt believe it... Please, work hard and be happy... but stay safe.‚Äù ‚ÄúJess isn‚Äôt gonna get hurt again!‚Äù Seth chimes in. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs sick-proof and really tough now; no more doctors or anything!‚Äù You try to look tough. Your parents chuckle a little, but dad elaborates. ‚ÄúJust be careful, kiddo. You are going to be really tough, but they‚Äôre going to give you tough jobs because of it. I know you‚Äôre more than capable; just please promise you won‚Äôt ever get overconfident, okay?‚Äù ‚ÄúOkay, dad. I‚Äôll be careful; promise.‚Äù He lets out a breath. ‚ÄúGood. You‚Äôll do great. I know you will.‚Äù ‚Äã
10:00 PM
The acolyte pokes his head into the room. ‚ÄúFather Turner‚Äôs on his way, Miss Angel. You ready to go?‚Äù ‚ÄúAh, er-‚Äù ‚ÄúCouple minutes; just be ready, please. The bishop‚Äôs a punctual fellow.‚Äù You look back at your family. Mom‚Äôs curly brown hair and reddened eyes. Dad‚Äôs calloused hands and gentle smile. Seth‚Äôs boundless energy and positivity. It‚Äôs not like you‚Äôre going away forever. You‚Äôve just been chosen for the highest honor possible at such a young age. Joy; optimism. Right? You‚Äôre wrapped in a hug and feel some of your anxiety recede. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôll be okay,‚Äù you whisper again, though you don‚Äôt know who exactly you‚Äôre trying to reassure. Not long after, the priest arrives. You say your last goodbyes... and leave the room. That‚Äôs it. You won‚Äôt be seeing your family again for months at least. Instead, you will be training to be an Angel. Father Turner leads you out the church‚Äôs rear doors to an ornate carriage pulled by pure white horses. Bishop Spencer is already there, along with a driver and a group of other clergymen you‚Äôve never seen before. You‚Äôre directed to the cushioned rear seat with the windows down, the better to display you as you travel. You‚Äôre still glowing, though it‚Äôs less visible in the foggy daylight of the city proper. ‚ÄúJessamine,‚Äù Father Turner says, sitting across from you and speaking softly as the carriage begins to move. ‚ÄúThe people of the city will be watching as we make our way to the station. This ride is your first appearance as their future guardian and protector; people will cheer and try to speak to you. The acolytes below will keep them away from the carriage, so please just try to look pleasant but somewhat distant, if you can. Smile and wave occasionally, but don‚Äôt address anyone directly. You are not yet able to give Blessings, no matter what anyone on the streets may think. Okay?‚Äù ‚Äã
10:01 PM
Your anxiety is back. You can already hear the crowd; how did they know where you would be so fast? It‚Äôs only been... less than an hour, probably? ‚ÄúUm, pleasant but distant. Don‚Äôt say anything, smile sometimes? Right?‚Äù ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs right. Just take it in. We‚Äôll speak more on the train in a few minutes.‚Äù With that, the priest leans back, almost disappearing into the shadowy depths of the carriage. You can still see him perfectly fine - especially with your glow - but he‚Äôll be a lot less visible to anyone outside. Instead, they‚Äôll see you. The carriage rumbles onto a main street and the roar of the crowd engulfs you. It‚Äôs astonishing just how many people have managed to assemble in such a short time. The sidewalks are packed; people lean out of windows and throw flower petals down; the acolytes walking alongside your carriage have to actively push citizens out of the way so the horses won‚Äôt trample anyone. It‚Äôs so loud you wouldn‚Äôt be able to pick out any individual shouts to respond to even if you hadn‚Äôt been cautioned against doing exactly that. Experimentally, you smile nervously and give a little wave out the window. There‚Äôs an obvious roar as people cheer even harder for you. For you! You haven‚Äôt even done anything yet! Somehow, your gaze lights on a woman in a dirty green dress clinging to a lamp post with one hand and holding a crying baby with the other. She‚Äôs shouting with the rest of the crowd, seemingly oblivious to the baby‚Äôs screams and trying to get it to look at you. You look away, uneasy, and shuffle to the other window. Another little wave; another huge cheer. Someone near the front is scuffling with one of the acolytes, screaming so loud you can actually make out some of his words even through the overall roar. ‚ÄúPLEASE!‚Äù he‚Äôs yelling. ‚Äú-BLESSING - WIFE! JUST - TIME-‚Äù Another acolyte makes his way over and shoves the man back. He vanishes into the crowd. ‚Äã
10:01 PM
It‚Äôs not just concerning sights, though; you just happened to notice those two since they stood out. You spot a group of schoolkids singing something to you, protected from the greater crowd by a constable or two in their distinctive rounded hats. An older couple standing contentedly in a rowhouse‚Äôs doorway; the gentleman throws a handful of flower petals as you pass. A few lesser clergymen in white robes, presumably from other nearby churches. Then, an even less common sight: a group of four weathered men in drab brown fatigues and armored helmets. They raise their fists as you pass, raising a collective shout before bowing in respect. Soldiers from the wastes. You know Angels often accompany men like that outside the city, but no more. The land beyond the walls remains a mystery to you. The crowd lessens as you get further from the church, and is almost manageable by the time you arrive at the nearest train station. The acolytes surround you and the two ministers, escorting you from the carriage up the steps to the elevated tracks where a gleaming brass locomotive is waiting. The station platform is empty aside from a few constables keeping the crowd back, the closest of which make the matan sign and step back deferentially. You‚Äôre led to the train‚Äôs first car, all ornately decorated with rich wood and brass accents. Both ministers join you, but the regular clergy take the second - much more ordinary - car instead. In mere moments, the doors shut and the brakes release. You‚Äôre on your way. The train isn‚Äôt exactly quiet - the track clatters beneath you and the locomotive itself puffs just ahead - but in comparison to the crowd, it feels like dead silence. The bishop sits down near the rear of the car; you and Father Turner take seats near the middle. ‚ÄúAh, what an experience, eh?‚Äù he asks. ‚ÄúHow are you feeling?‚Äù ‚Äã
10:01 PM
The train sways as you switch tracks just outside the station. The locomotive speeds up; soon, you‚Äôll be rocketing down the rails more than twenty times faster than the carriage. You‚Äôve only taken the train a few times in your life, and never in such comfort. ‚Äç - ‚ÄúA little overwhelmed.‚Äù - ‚ÄúA little excited.‚Äù - ‚ÄúA little sad.‚Äù - Ask about Blessings. - Ask about the shouting guy. - Ask about the soldiers. Ô∏è - Ask what happens next. - Let Father Turner guide the conversation. [Or something else; specify in #story_discussion ] (Winners: ‚Äç , Ô∏è > > = ) (edited)

Mxblah 10/5/2023 8:50 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 3 ‚ÄúA little overwhelmed,‚Äù you admit. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs only been... an hour?‚Äù He chuckles gently. ‚ÄúI understand. It‚Äôs my first time helping anyone to Ascend as well, though my part is much less stressful than yours.‚Äù A pause; he glances at something out the window as the train continues to accelerate. ‚ÄúTake some time to relax here. Nothing is expected of you until we arrive in twenty or so minutes.‚Äù You try to take his advice, settling back into the deep, plush seat. The car rattles as you pick up speed, but somehow the vibrations aren‚Äôt transferred to the chair. At least, not enough to be uncomfortable. It‚Äôs a very pleasant ride, really, and you can see out over the city in a way you‚Äôve rarely been able to. The fog is omnipresent, of course, blanketing every building and limiting your view to only a few blocks. You‚Äôve heard that there used to be less of it, and that there are some places in the wastelands that don‚Äôt have any at all, but to you, it‚Äôs just a fact of life. Air just looks like that. But what you can see still looks different from above. Smoke-stained chimneys, discolored rainwater tracks on roofs and taller walls, and the bulky steel rail infrastructure supporting your heavy train. You‚Äôre heading towards the center of the city - the Cathedra itself - so new construction grows more common as you travel. As the population grows amidst limited space, architects are building up rather than out, letting older buildings rot abandoned while converting stable foundations into tall apartment blocks reaching nearly a dozen stories high. A dozen! So tall the skeletal steel frames tower over even the elevated tracks you‚Äôre riding on right now. ‚Äã
8:50 PM
The construction logistics baffle you; how could anyone raise so much material so high and so efficiently to build so many of these towers? Mechanical engines, wheels, and cranes hint at the answer, but you‚Äôre whipping by so quickly now it‚Äôs impossible to catch more than a glimpse of anything. You spare a moment to wonder how deafeningly loud your passage must sound to those on the ground below. ... Some time later, you realize you‚Äôve gotten distracted just watching the city pass. A portion of your nervousness returns, though thankfully not as much as before. At least you won‚Äôt be out in a crowd again after this. Er, right? Will you? ‚ÄúUm,‚Äù you begin, getting Father Turner‚Äôs attention. ‚ÄúWhat happens after we get there?‚Äù ‚ÄúAh, eager to arrive?‚Äù ‚Äú... A little nervous...‚Äù ‚ÄúOh, Jessamine, don‚Äôt worry. Here‚Äôs what the rest of your day will hold.‚Äù Father Turner is briefly interrupted as the car jostles and heavy support beams whip past on both sides. You turn back to the window momentarily to watch a stretch of dull water pass beneath the train; you‚Äôre crossing the Endle River, the deep waterway that cuts through the city. You‚Äôve seen it before, of course, but rarely at such speed. ‚ÄúS-sorry,‚Äù you say once the bridge crossing is complete and you‚Äôre back above solid ground. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm listening.‚Äù The priest smiles, but doesn‚Äôt comment on your distraction. ‚ÄúWhen we arrive, you will be escorted to the Lordstone Cathedral, where you will meet with the Emissary.‚Äù ‚ÄúW-what?! Right away?‚Äù The Emissary is the leader of the Cathedra and arguably the most important man in the city - or the world. He is the only person alive who can speak to God even indirectly, surpassing even Angels. You‚Äôve heard he wields incredible powers and has the ability to vaporize people on the spot for any infraction. And, worse... ‚Äã
8:50 PM
‚ÄúRight away. As you know, the Emissary must decide whether to confirm your Ascension before anything else can happen. Don‚Äôt worry, though; the last time any new Angel was rejected has to have been nearly a thousand years ago.‚Äù Bishop Spencer interjects from the other end of the car. ‚ÄúFalse Angel Erejil. Just about nine centuries ago now. Bishops have to learn the signs the Emissary at the time used to detect Erejil‚Äôs corruption and look out for them in any new Angels we bring in. I wouldn‚Äôt be here if you had shown such darkness; an Archangel would have been sent in my stead to bring you in for execution. So don‚Äôt worry about being rejected; it‚Äôs all but a formality these days.‚Äù ‚Äú...‚Äù You don‚Äôt feel very reassured. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs interesting, isn‚Äôt it?‚Äù Father Turner muses. ‚ÄúGod chooses Angels, but the Emissary - a mortal man - has the power to confirm them. It truly shows the love He holds for us, by placing so much trust in our hands. If you get the chance later, you should read one of the histories on the turmoil surrounding Erejil‚Äôs execution; some scholars consider it to be...‚Äù You stare at him. ‚ÄúSorry, Jessamine. Us stuffy old ministers can get a little carried away with religious theory. Isn‚Äôt that right, Bishop?‚Äù ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre 37. Stuffy young ministers aren‚Äôt immune either.‚Äù Father Turner laughs. ‚ÄúThe point is, Jessamine, you‚Äôll be fine. The Emissary isn‚Äôt nearly as scary as his reputation.‚Äù ‚Äú... Okay.‚Äù ‚ÄúAh, let‚Äôs just move on, shall we? After your confirmation, you will be taken on a brief tour of the Cathedra campus, be measured for your uniforms, and will meet some of your future tutors. After that, you will be shown your room and given some free time to adjust. Then, starting tomorrow and continuing for the next six years, you will train to become the best Angel and servant of the Lord you can be.‚Äù ‚ÄúWhat kind of training?‚Äù ‚Äã
8:51 PM
‚ÄúWell, all kinds. You‚Äôll continue your normal education, but additionally strengthen your Body, Mind, and Soul.‚Äù The priest touches his shoulders and forehead in the correct order as he says that; you find yourself almost unconsciously mirroring his actions. ‚ÄúPhysical strength and endurance, mental acuity and resilience, and your divine connection to God. As well as learning of the...‚Äù He glances as Bishop Spencer, choosing his words carefully. ‚ÄúThe darkness that you will fight. You‚Äôll even be able to choose a few classes of your own; whatever suits you! I‚Äôm certain you will find your training very fulfilling.‚Äù You sit there for a moment, willing yourself to ask about the ‚Äúdarkness you will fight,‚Äù but you‚Äôre too late. The train starts to slow and both ministers look up. You follow their eyes to a huge, dark mass slowly appearing from the fog and splitting into individual shapes. Tall, elegant spires. Brutal, blocky towers. Greenery weaving between the two. It shouldn‚Äôt seem cohesive, yet it somehow does. The Grand Cathedra. ‚ÄúHere‚Äôs our stop,‚Äù Father Turner notes, getting to his feet. ‚ÄúThe Cathedra station is just outside the campus gates and is connected to every other station in the city by a direct line. Angels often use the trains here to get around quickly. At least, before they get their wings.‚Äù Indeed, your train has hardly slowed to a stop before another locomotive pulls out, quickly accelerating on a parallel track to the one you had just left. Only one car. Presumably an Angel on their way to some important task. That could be you one day. Will be. You disembark, noticing another locomotive idling at the platform and a handful of regular constables speaking quietly nearby. One of them glances over at you, but looks away again after realizing you‚Äôre going the other direction. Not the Angel they‚Äôre waiting for. ‚Äã
8:51 PM
True to the priest‚Äôs word, the Cathedra campus gates rise only a short walk across the street outside the station. You and the two ministers go first, nodded through by a pair of armored guards, but the rest of your group of clergy have to produce regular identification documents. Presumably another benefit to your still-dimming glow. Maybe by tomorrow morning it‚Äôll be gone entirely. Discreetly, you try again, but you still can‚Äôt control it; you don‚Äôt even know how you would. ‚ÄúThe Lordstone Cathedral is just ahead and to the right,‚Äù Father Turner tells you, walking slightly behind the bishop. ‚ÄúYou can have a few minutes to prepare to meet the Emissary, if you want, or we can go in right away. I wouldn‚Äôt worry about him either way; he‚Äôs a perfectly reasonable man.‚Äù - Take a few minutes first. - Just go right in. - Your confirmation is perfectly normal, just like Father Turner said. ‚ùì - The Emissary finds something... odd about you. Mxblah 10/7/2023 2:07 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 4 ‚ÄúEr... I‚Äôll, um...‚Äù You can‚Äôt decide if it‚Äôs better to have extra time to prepare (but extra time to worry), or if it‚Äôs better to just get it over with. ‚Äú...‚Äù ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs take a few minutes, shall we?‚Äù Father Turner suggests after several seconds of silence. You nod in agreement, not entirely sure why you‚Äôre so nervous. Everyone‚Äôs telling you it‚Äôll be fine, right? Bishop Spencer enters the cathedral to inform the clergy there, so you and Father Turner sit down on an ancient stone bench in a secluded little garden just to the side. Thick, woody vines or roots climb its legs, carving smooth channels in the stone. Someone has trimmed away anything that would cross the top, though, keeping it clear. ‚ÄúWater?‚Äù the priest offers, producing a cup from somewhere you didn‚Äôt see. ‚ÄúAcolytes at the cathedral gave it to me.‚Äù You hadn‚Äôt noticed, but your throat is dry. You accept the cup, feeling your glow strengthen just a little as you drink. Wait... feel? What did it feel like? You close your eyes and try to focus, but can‚Äôt get a grip on the glow anymore; you‚Äôre not sure. A fat, fuzzy bee drifts sedately from flower to flower on the other side of the garden and you let your attention be pulled away by it instead. ‚ÄúThere are a lot of gardens here,‚Äù you say thoughtfully, watching the bee. ‚ÄúWhy? The rest of the city doesn‚Äôt have this many.‚Äù ‚ÄúIn brief, because plants are expensive to maintain,‚Äù he answers. ‚ÄúThe Cathedra can afford to hire a large number of groundskeepers, but extending efforts like that to the rest of the city would be very difficult. Most of the city‚Äôs budget for greenery goes to the outer farms, since they provide food at scale. Smaller parks like this just can‚Äôt do that.‚Äù ‚ÄúBut those look like fruits over there,‚Äù you say, pointing. ‚ÄúIsn‚Äôt that food?‚Äù ‚Äã
2:07 PM
‚ÄúWell, yes. All plants in the city have to be capable of growing at least something edible, as you know, and the Cathedra‚Äôs gardens do help feed the Angels and clergy who reside here. What I meant before was about scale - the outer farms can be much more efficient since they‚Äôre so large. Gardens like this have to be tended by hand, but the farms can use machinery to harvest more food more often.‚Äù ‚ÄúI see...‚Äù You‚Äôve never been to the outer farms, actually, so you‚Äôre not sure what they look like. Maybe you‚Äôll have a reason to go with your new duties. You stay in the garden a little longer, watching the bees work and thinking about plants and food in general. Your worries about the Emissary seem more distant... right up until Bishop Spencer returns and asks if you‚Äôre ready yet. You don‚Äôt think so, but doubt it‚Äôs going to get any better if you keep putting it off. Besides, you don‚Äôt want to make the most powerful man in the Cathedra wait. He might vaporize you for the annoyance. ... Why do I keep thinking about that? You can‚Äôt get the image of yourself exploding into a cloud of dust out of your mind. The imaginary Emissary shakes his distinguished head and calls for an acolyte with a broom. You shake your own head in turn, trying to pay attention to reality as the ministers lead you through the entryway and into the Lordstone Cathedral proper. The first thing you notice is the Lordstone itself, a twenty-foot tall obelisk of deep blue crystal looming over the chancel. Its facets are dotted with thousands of lighter specks that almost seem to twinkle and shift, together forming an image that resembles the starfields and galaxies said to be visible above the permanent fog. You can‚Äôt tell how close the resemblance is, but soldiers and Angels who have been to the wastes - where the fog is thinner - claim it‚Äôs a perfect replica. ‚Äã
2:07 PM
The Lordstone is a portion of God‚Äôs Body, cast down from heaven in order to lend His strength to protect humanity. The specifics are somewhat vague beyond that, but you more or less understand that the Emissary can use the Lordstone to channel God‚Äôs will into physical effects. Such as confirming new Angels, or the vaporization that you keep worrying about. You‚Äôre not sure what else he can do; the Emissary is rarely seen beyond the scope of his edicts. Speaking of, the Emissary himself is not what you expected. A very old man sits in a simple throne of dark wood and silver accents just before the Lordstone. He wears white robes with long sleeves, a sleek black necklace bearing the matan symbol, and a silver circlet on his thinning white hair. You knew he was mortal - no Angel can become the Emissary - but... he just looks like a grandpa. Your stomach starts to untwist; a man like this couldn‚Äôt possibly vaporize you, right? You kneel before the pulpit, bowing your head in deference. Father Turner and Bishop Spencer do the same on either side; the Emissary far outranks all of you. ‚ÄúJessamine Goodall,‚Äù the Emissary calls in a thin, wavering voice. ‚ÄúRaise your head.‚Äù You do. He‚Äôs looking directly at you. His irises are pure gold and his gaze seems sharper than any blade; it‚Äôs all you can do to not flinch as he searches for any mote of corruption hiding in your Soul. Finally, he breaks eye contact and stands, using the chair‚Äôs arms for support. ‚ÄúJessamine Goodall,‚Äù he repeats, still avoiding calling you an Angel. ‚ÄúYou have been Blessed for Ascension by Father Carlos Turner, accepted for duty by Bishop Ashel Spencer, and chosen by the Lord God Himself. Tell me, are you pure of Body, Mind, and Soul?‚Äù You find your voice stronger than expected. ‚ÄúI am.‚Äù ‚ÄúDo you swear your immortal, divine loyalty to the Cathedra and God above?‚Äù ‚ÄúI do.‚Äù ‚ÄúAnd do you promise to protect the citizens of this city and this world, though it may cost you your life?‚Äù ‚Äã
2:07 PM
You hesitate for a moment. The possibility that you may someday have to sacrifice your life seems unreal; far away. ‚Äú... I do.‚Äù He makes the sign of the matan and slowly descends the steps towards you. ‚ÄúI witness and honor these oaths, sworn before our most holy relic. Rise, Angel Jessamine Goodall, and take your place among God‚Äôs most honored servants.‚Äù You stand. The Emissary touches you on the right shoulder, then the left, then the forehead. Body, Mind, Soul. He smiles kindly, but says nothing more, instead simply climbing back up the stairs to his wooden throne. The two ministers stand as well and you are escorted out of the Lordstone Cathedral as quickly as you entered. ‚ÄúCongratulations, Jessamine,‚Äù Bishop Spencer says as you emerge back into foggy daylight. ‚ÄúYou are a true Angel now.‚Äù ‚ÄúSee, I told you there was nothing to be worried about!‚Äù Father Turner chimes in. ‚ÄúYour ceremony went as by-the-book as it could.‚Äù You smile weakly, still feeling drained from... being looked at? Whatever the Emissary did to you, it was definitely a real, physical thing. No mere anxiety could tire you out this much. ‚ÄúThanks for... everything, really.‚Äù Father Turner chuckles, seeming much more energetic than just before the ceremony. ‚ÄúYou are so very welcome. Oh, I‚Äôm just so pleased; an Angel from my own church after only four years, and it was Jessamine Goodall, of all people. You certainly deserve it; I hope you find your time fulfilling and that you serve God well.‚Äù ‚ÄúThank you,‚Äù you say again. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll do my best.‚Äù ‚ÄúAh, here‚Äôs your next escort,‚Äù Bishop Spencer says, noticing an approaching woman in a dark grey robe trimmed with silver. You don‚Äôt know what the outfit means; it‚Äôs outside of the normal minister hierarchy. ‚ÄúWith that, I will take my leave. Serve well, Angel. We will speak again.‚Äù ‚Äã
2:07 PM
You‚Äôre not sure what to say, so you just bow. The bishop leaves. The strange-robed woman arrives, bowing to you in turn. ‚ÄúWell met, new Angel,‚Äù she says, then makes the sign of the matan to Father Turner. ‚ÄúAnd you as well, Father.‚Äù ‚ÄúSister.‚Äù He returns the sign. ‚ÄúJessamine, this is Sister - apologies, I don‚Äôt believe we‚Äôve met before?‚Äù ‚ÄúVeriline Noll, Father. I don‚Äôt believe we have.‚Äù ‚ÄúGlad my memory isn‚Äôt failing me. Sister Noll, then. She will help you get settled in and prepared for the start of your training tomorrow, as well as a number of other things she is much more qualified to explain than I am.‚Äù ‚ÄúAre you leaving too?‚Äù ‚ÄúI must get back to my church, unfortunately. We ordinary priests don‚Äôt visit the Grand Cathedra for long.‚Äù ‚ÄúAh.‚Äù It makes sense, of course. Father Turner has other duties to attend to; he can‚Äôt be shepherding you around all day. But still, with him gone, that will leave you all alone in this vast, confusing place, without a single person you know. ‚ÄúWell, er, goodbye, then.‚Äù Another kindly smile. He crouches a little to be more on your eye level. ‚ÄúGood luck, Angel. Though I‚Äôm sure you‚Äôll hardly need it.‚Äù You don‚Äôt know what to say, so you just go with ‚Äú... Thanks.‚Äù And off he goes. You‚Äôre left alone with Sister Noll on the worn path just outside of the Lordstone Cathedral. Your new life begins tomorrow, and you only have the rest of the day to prepare for it. That being the case, you feel... - Drained. - Nervous. - Curious. - Excited. (Winners: > > ) (edited)

Mxblah 10/9/2023 9:27 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 5 ... curious, mostly. The bulk of your anxiety seems to have passed with the initiation ceremony, and after a few minutes of walking, the strange exhaustion from before mostly fades as well. So now it‚Äôs time to take in as much information as you can so you don‚Äôt make a fool of yourself tomorrow. Your first stop is the two-story wooden general services building tucked away behind a copse of evergreens near the middle of the Cathedra campus. This is apparently where the mundane tasks required to support the campus are completed, such as food preparation, laundry, and - relevant to you right now - measuring for your new uniforms. This goes relatively quickly and you‚Äôre out the door again before too long - someone will deliver your outfits before you need them in the morning. You hardly spoke to the workers inside; you were just too nervous about their obvious deference to say anything. ‚ÄúEr, Mi - Sister Noll, is everyone like that around Angels? Even here?‚Äù She glances back at the building, hidden behind its barrier of trees. ‚ÄúNo, not everyone. Even among the support staff, you‚Äôll find people willing to speak up and treat you like a human rather than a divine being - if that‚Äôs what you want, of course. Many Angels prefer it the other way, which is why it‚Äôs usually safer for the staff to assume excessive respect until they know what your specific preferences are.‚Äù ‚Äú... Safer?‚Äù ‚ÄúAs an Angel, your word now carries immense weight. If you were displeased, you could request any of the staff you just met to be dismissed simply by speaking to a brother or sister such as myself. With even a trivial grievance, your request would likely be granted.‚Äù ‚ÄúBut... no one would do that, right? You don‚Äôt get to be an Angel unless you‚Äôre...‚Äù You trail off as Sister Noll shakes her head slowly. ‚Äã
9:27 PM
‚ÄúLesson one: despite what the Cathedra and its ministers might wish the general population to believe, Angels are not chosen for their pure and good Souls. No one really knows the true criteria that allow a child to Ascend, but Angels are just as likely to be petty bullies as kind-hearted softies.‚Äù A glance to you; she seems to guess which side of the divide you might fall on. ‚ÄúOf course, we do our best to get you all into shape by the time you turn 18, but it takes time and no training is perfect.‚Äù ‚Äú...‚Äù ‚ÄúListen, I‚Äôm not saying that most - or even many - Angels are jerks. Just... new trainee Angels are twelve year old kids who suddenly get blessed with power and importance beyond any of their peers. The Ascension process doesn‚Äôt change your Mind or personality - at least not immediately - so they‚Äôre still just children. And kids aren‚Äôt well known for using power responsibly. No offense, of course, Miss Angel.‚Äù ‚Äú... That‚Äôs okay...‚Äù ‚ÄúSoft spoken, aren‚Äôt you? You might get along with Serri; I‚Äôll see if I can track her down for tomorrow. Anyway, just remember one of the core tenets that‚Äôs going to get drilled into your head over and over for six years. You may be an Angel, but you‚Äôre still only human despite your blessings. You‚Äôre fallible. Everyone is, whether they‚Äôve got a divine Soul or not. Even God makes mistakes, and we are far less than God. Got it?‚Äù You nod, but have a question. ‚ÄúGod... makes mistakes?‚Äù ‚ÄúAh, do they not talk about that part in normal mass? Where the corruption came from?‚Äù ‚ÄúFrom another world, right? On a falling star that... uh... no, huh?‚Äù Sister Noll seems amused. ‚ÄúFlaws in our Souls. God made us wrong on His first try. He fixed us later, of course, but it was too late to stop the corruption without destroying the world and starting over. But as you might guess, He loves us too much to do that.‚Äù ‚Äã
9:27 PM
‚ÄúFlaws? But - wait, how does that work? How did He make us? The church never goes into any detail about the original creation - do we really know more about what happened? How? Did-‚Äù ‚ÄúSorry, I‚Äôm not the right person to answer all those questions. If you‚Äôre really into history, though, you‚Äôll love your classes with Brother Trigg. I swear, that man could tell you five interesting things that happened in any year from Genesis to now without even consulting a book. Interested?‚Äù You duck down, faintly embarrassed at your obvious enthusiasm. ‚ÄúMaybe a little.‚Äù Then, feeling a need to explain, you continue. ‚ÄúI had a... lot of time to read when I was little. I got really sick for two years and couldn‚Äôt go out, so I was given a lot of books.‚Äù ‚ÄúAh, sorry to hear that. I‚Äôm sure you‚Äôre feeling much better now, right?‚Äù ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs...‚Äù You can‚Äôt really sum up just how good it feels to not have that constant ache in your lungs; that constant shortness of breath that reminds you the sickness could come back at any moment. Force you back into bed for the day or the week. All it needed was a chance; another illness to open the door. All gone, now. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs wonderful.‚Äù ‚ÄúFirst stop on the tour,‚Äù she tells you a few minutes later. ‚ÄúThis is Oth Hall, named after Archangel Din Oth. He was a master of the Mind and one of the first pioneers to explore how to combine internal and external mental manipulations. If you ever decide to learn telepathy, you‚Äôll have him to thank. Anyway, this hall is where you‚Äôll fortify your Mind and practice mental miracles. Potentially under my training, if you so desire.‚Äù Oth Hall is one of the blockier, more modern buildings, all brick and metal and glass. Decorative ivy climbs the walls in a way that seems like it‚Äôd be hard to maintain. You‚Äôre distracted from your original questions about the building‚Äôs namesake by Sister Noll‚Äôs last sentence. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre a tutor?‚Äù ‚ÄúI did say we try to get you into shape by age 18, didn‚Äôt I?‚Äù ‚Äã
9:28 PM
‚ÄúI thought you meant everyone here, not just...‚Äù ‚ÄúWell, you caught me. I teach trainee Angels how to strengthen their Minds... and also how to swing a sword without hurting themselves. And with hurting whoever they‚Äôre trying to hit, ideally.‚Äù ‚ÄúThose... go together?‚Äù ‚ÄúBody, Mind, Soul,‚Äù she says, forming the triangle. ‚ÄúEverything goes together; it‚Äôs just a matter of finding the connections. If you take my advanced course, it‚Äôll make sense why I combine them. But of course, you‚Äôll be spending the next year learning the basics, so don‚Äôt worry about it too much now. You‚Äôll get there.‚Äù Sister Noll next introduces you to Forger Hall, named after Archangel Phineas Forger, who mastered the Body in a similar way as Din Oth had mastered the Mind. It has an older, more traditional design, with pointy spires and wide training grounds around the outside. This is where you catch your first glimpse of other Angels on the grounds - or at least the first ones that have been obviously more than human. You slow to a stop on the path just outside, staring as a pair of radiantly beautiful young adults spar with shimmering, crystalline blades. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs caught your - ah, those two. Yes, it‚Äôs always a spectacle to see Angels fight, even for training like this. Enjoy it while you can; the groundskeepers are planning on replanting the trees around that area before winter this year. Some Angels don‚Äôt like being observed.‚Äù You quickly turn away, blushing. ‚ÄúSorry, sorry-‚Äù ‚ÄúOh, not these two. That‚Äôs Zeke on the right and... Stella on the left? Yeah; that‚Äôs her fighting style. They‚Äôre both fairly pleasant to talk to, though Zeke can be a little intense and Stella can be a little uptight.‚Äù ‚Äã
9:28 PM
You look back towards the sandy field, taking in the unbelievably quick jolts of frenetic energy, followed by graceful dodges and sweeping blows. Melodious chimes echo with each clash of the swords, sounding more like bells than the much less pleasant sound of steel on steel that regular blades make. You‚Äôve never seen a fight like this - though you‚Äôve never really seen a fight at all. Unless Seth standing up for you in the school yard counts. ‚ÄúHey, you want to go meet them once they‚Äôre done? Typically you meet your fellow trainees first, but I don‚Äôt see why not; they won‚Äôt hassle you.‚Äù You almost panic at the thought of approaching these two perfect, holy people... but, well, you‚Äôre one of them too. Sort of. Maybe... no; you‚Äôd just bother them. Plus, what would you even say? But... - Go meet the adult Angels. - Stick to the plan; meet your fellow trainees first. (Winner: ) (edited)

Mxblah 10/11/2023 9:55 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 6 ‚ÄúN-no, that‚Äôs okay. I don‚Äôt want to bother them.‚Äù ‚ÄúOh, no, it wouldn‚Äôt be - ah, right. No problem; let‚Äôs just carry on.‚Äù She starts to lead you towards another nearby building, this one seemingly a converted cathedral with several modern additions and extra towers bolted onto it. ‚ÄúThis is Illim Hall; can you guess what it‚Äôs named after?‚Äù ‚ÄúA master of the Soul?‚Äù ‚ÄúGot it in one. Archangel Ananiah Illim, inventor of the modern Blessing. She experimented with Soul manipulation to such a degree that some in the Cathedra dubbed her a heretic and called for her expulsion or execution, but the Emissary at the time didn‚Äôt agree. History seems to have taken her side, given the giant building named after her.‚Äù ‚ÄúSoul manipulation...‚Äù you whisper. You almost agree with the detractors; it seems almost heretical to think about. The Soul is your divine, immutable, true self. To... manipulate it just feels... unholy. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt worry; you‚Äôll learn more about it. Souls are an aspect of the self, just as Body and Mind. It‚Äôs not an inherently bad thing to change them or channel energy into someone else‚Äôs Soul - that‚Äôs how Blessings work and how Angels can cleanse corruption.‚Äù Her expression hardens a little, glancing up to a sculpture above the main entrance that depicts an Angelic woman with long, flowing hair. ‚ÄúJust know that there are some boundaries that must not be crossed when touching others‚Äô Souls. You will learn where to stop. And if you don‚Äôt...‚Äù There‚Äôs a very long pause. You almost say something, but something about her tone stops you. ‚ÄúThere are very few crimes that always result in execution. Purposeful damage or destruction of human Souls is one of them. But don‚Äôt worry; you won‚Äôt be at any risk as long as you follow the guidelines for how to handle your powers safely. And just remember what you‚Äôre touching when you Bless someone: the Soul is a person‚Äôs innermost self. Be respectful.‚Äù ‚Äú...‚Äù ‚Äã
9:55 PM
‚ÄúSorry; I know that was a little much with the ‚Äòexecution‚Äô talk. Looking at that building just gets me riled up. Not your fault; you‚Äôll be fine.‚Äù You half-raise a hand, about to ask the obvious question, but Sister Noll turns aside before you can say anything. ‚ÄúApologies, but I don‚Äôt wish to discuss it. Let‚Äôs move on.‚Äù You move on. There are a few other notable buildings on the Cathedra grounds, but you spend less time on them than the main three Halls and don‚Äôt speak to anyone there. A number of smaller cathedrals, churches, and lesser shrines are dotted around to pray to different aspects of God. Auxiliary buildings handle various tasks like maintenance of equipment, mundane office space, and housing for non-Angelic staff. Then, there‚Äôs the wide brownstone building that Sister Noll calls the Center. Counterintuitively, it‚Äôs nowhere near the center of the campus; instead, it‚Äôs situated near the edge, close to the train station. You had passed it on the way in and just hadn‚Äôt noticed. ‚ÄúThis is where all the issue reports in the city come in, get sorted, and are assigned an Angel, if one is needed,‚Äù she explains. ‚ÄúConstabulary precinct offices have pneumatic connections to this building and can send in requests for assistance for anything beyond their normal capabilities. That, combined with the trains and occasional Angelic patrols in the field near known locations of interest, helps ensure that you all can make it to anywhere you‚Äôre needed in time.‚Äù You try to imagine how many tubes must run beneath the city streets, but can‚Äôt quite grasp it. A lot. ‚ÄúSo do Angels have to stay here so they‚Äôre ready to go when anything comes in?‚Äù ‚Äã
9:56 PM
‚ÄúNot quite. There‚Äôs a rotation, so you‚Äôll be on call for a certain amount of time on certain days. Some Angels do stay around the Center for most of their time on call, and most stop by when their turn in the rotation is coming up soon, but there‚Äôs no hard requirement to be there. The only requirement is that you‚Äôre on the Cathedra grounds while you‚Äôre on call, so you can hear the bells when your turn comes up.‚Äù ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs what those are?‚Äù You had heard a few seemingly nonsensical chimes over the course of the day, but had written them off as unusual church bells. Apparently not. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs right: Center staff calling in Angels for their assignments. You don‚Äôt hear a lot of them since most Angels are pretty good about getting to the Center before their turn comes up, but sometimes they run late or are distracted or busy or whatever. With the bells, we‚Äôre covered anywhere on campus. You‚Äôll be expected to memorize your unique chime sequence, then drop everything and run to the Center immediately if you hear it. Though not until your training is complete, of course.‚Äù ‚Äú... What if I‚Äôm asleep?‚Äù The bells were loud, but not that loud. Sister Noll raises an eyebrow. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt sleep when you‚Äôre on call.‚Äù ‚ÄúG-got it.‚Äù After a simple dinner of bread, water, and steamed vegetables, your last stop on the tour is also your last for the day. The sun - itself invisible behind the fog - is dipping below the horizon, and as such the night is creeping close. Flickering lights - some true flames and some mechanical - begin to appear in the shadows. Hearth Hall is another of the blocky, modern buildings - it somewhat resembles the tall apartment blocks you saw on the train ride in, though wider and decorated with the silver and dark wood accents that seem typical of the Cathedra. It‚Äôs - you count briefly - eight floors tall, putting it among the tallest buildings you‚Äôve ever visited. As long as you don‚Äôt count the spires of churches and such, but you can‚Äôt actually stand on those. ‚Äã
9:56 PM
‚ÄúHearth Hall is where trainee Angels live, as well as most of the other Angels who wish to live on the Cathedra campus. There are several other Angelic residences around the campus, so all together I‚Äôd say maybe three quarters of Angels have a permanent residence here. Of course, that doesn‚Äôt mean they stay all the time - and some Angels do live in the city proper. Those are typically the ones stationed near the walls who fight in the wastes.‚Äù You try to count the windows. ‚ÄúHow many are... here?‚Äù ‚ÄúThere are about sixty apartments in Hearth Hall, and I believe most of them are currently occupied. So, about that many.‚Äù Sixty Angels, all in the same place. For some reason, it seems strange to you. What if something goes wrong? Even one Angel is so important that whole systems are built around Calling Days and ensuring every single child has their chance to Ascend. Sixty... the number makes sense for things like students or workers, but Angels? You‚Äôre used to thinking about one or two; not so many at once. You stare up at the building, unable to really explain your own thoughts even to yourself, let alone Sister Noll. You‚Äôre getting worked up over nothing again. She has a key for you. ‚ÄúRoom 302. Third floor, obviously; it should be on the left side. Think you can handle having the rest of the night all to yourself?‚Äù You take the key, caught somewhat off guard. ‚ÄúY-yes.‚Äù A pause. ‚ÄúUm, is there anything else I should do tonight?‚Äù ‚ÄúNope; just get comfortable. You can stay in your room, wander around campus, or whatever you want. Just don‚Äôt leave the Grand Cathedra, alright? Tomorrow morning, you should report to Oth Hall at 8am sharp for your first day of training and to meet the other trainees. Any questions?‚Äù ‚ÄúNo?‚Äù ‚ÄúExcellent. Well, Miss Angel, you have a good night. I won‚Äôt see you in the morning, but I will see you again soon. Farewell!‚Äù She leaves. ‚Äã
9:56 PM
You stand there in the deepening dusk for some time, just clutching the key and listening to nothing in particular. Eventually, a bell sequence chimes and you shake yourself out of it by imagining some other Angel rushing frantically to the Center in order to get their mission. It‚Äôs gotten very dark very quickly; sunset doesn‚Äôt last long due to the fog. You go inside. There‚Äôs a minimal sort of lobby area with some lights and a desk, then a much more inviting common area just behind. No one‚Äôs there at the moment, so you head to the rear where there‚Äôs a door to the stairs. It pushes open without resistance, so you step into- ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre new around here, aren‚Äôt you?‚Äù You spin around with a legitimate ‚Äúeep!‚Äù of surprise, scanning the room for whoever could have spoken. After a moment, a pile of blankets catches your eye as somewhat out of place. ‚ÄúUm?‚Äù you gesture in a questioning manner. ‚ÄúAh, sorry, just a moment.‚Äù The pile shuffles and a young man‚Äôs head emerges. Maybe late teens, medium length brown hair, and as radiantly handsome as the two Angels you had seen sparring earlier. A pair of hands follow, then the book they had been holding, and finally a glimmering orb of yellow luminance that fades into nothingness as it rises into the room. Magic? Magic! ‚ÄúVery rude of me; my apologies. I‚Äôm told I often fade into the furniture around here.‚Äù You step away from the stairway door, still too bewildered to say anything. ‚ÄúGoodness; I just keep making blunders, don‚Äôt I?‚Äù The Angel stands up, letting the blankets fall to reveal perfectly normal clothes beneath. Simple white cotton; they could be pajamas. Possibly are; given the time of night. Still, something about the way he wears them makes the outfit fashionable. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm Yara Conner. Fifth year trainee Angel, aspiring Soul channeller, and, of course, earnest servant of God. I presume you must be the newly Ascended Angel everyone was so excited about?‚Äù ‚Äú...‚Äù You‚Äôre starting to calm down. He‚Äôs not so intimidating. ‚Äã
9:56 PM
‚ÄúOr am I mistaken? Surely I haven‚Äôt forgotten any of the existing trainees...‚Äù He almost seems to doubt himself. You‚Äôd better say something quick. - You successfully recover and introduce yourself properly. ‚Äç - You screw up your introduction and look like a dork - at least, to yourself. @Story Notifications Scene 7 ‚ÄúEr - y-yes, I am!‚Äù Yara‚Äôs eyes widen. ‚ÄúReally? 8:55 PM

8:56 PM
‚ÄúUsually Mindless, due to God‚Äôs - sorry, I need to leave some things out or I‚Äôll never finish - let‚Äôs just say usually Mindless, for reasons. 8:56 PM
‚ÄúThat‚Äôs the spirit!‚Äù Yara glances up at a clock on the opposite wall and leaps to his feet again. ‚ÄúGood heavens it‚Äôs later than I thought. You‚Äôre not sure what to make of all that, so you quickly rush into the stairwell and head to the third floor before anyone else can show up and start a conversation. It‚Äôs fully dark outside now and fog presses up against the windows with hazy tendrils, seeking the building‚Äôs light and warmth. Thankfully, no one else appears before you make it to room 302 and let yourself in. Close the door. Fall down against it, exhausted. Not physically, just socially. Even at school, you don‚Äôt think you‚Äôve ever talked so much to anyone outside of your family in a single day. It‚Äôs late, but not that late; you‚Äôve still got time in the evening. Still, you‚Äôve got to be up and ready to go early tomorrow morning. @Story Notifications Scene 8 Take just a few moments to lean against the door, then push yourself upright again and go investigate your new room. It‚Äôs big. Your house - you suppose you should call it your parents‚Äô house now - is larger, but only because it has a second floor. Here, all this space is just for you. There‚Äôs a narrow hallway from the main entrance to an open area near the exterior windows. Some dark wood cubbies and hooks along the passage‚Äôs right wall seem to be for coats or shoes or the like, and some decorations hung on the left wall depict the matan as well as some other, more abstract designs. You peer up at one of the most complicated ones - it seems to contain the matan near the center, but the geometry around the edges escapes your description. You‚Äôre not sure what it is, or what it might mean. Because you might as well make use of the cubbies, you store your shoes and light coat (Sister Noll gave it to you, as it was a breezy day and your tunic doesn‚Äôt even have sleeves) before continuing down the hall to reach the main room. There‚Äôs a sofa along the left wall - you had seen it from the entrance - as well as a low table in front of it and a desk plus chair along the right wall. A set of dark wood cabinets stands along the inner wall next to a matching door that you‚Äôll check out shortly. The outer wall is mostly window; you peek under the curtains to look outside, but there‚Äôs not much to see in the foggy darkness. You‚Äôll check again in the morning. ‚Äã
1:00 PM
The door by the cabinets leads into your new bedroom. There‚Äôs a set of shelves and a full-length mirror on the right wall, a set of closet doors in the far left corner, and a bed with pristine white sheets in the far right. To your left, another door leads into a spacious bathroom finished with clean tile of the same color palette as the rest of the room. White, grey, or silver with dark wood and occasional golden-brass accents. The sink countertop even looks like marbled stone, but it‚Äôs so smooth! It‚Äôs such a difference from the home you woke up in just this morning and its worn-down wooden everything. Is this what all the new apartment blocks are like as well, or is it just the Cathedra that‚Äôs so fancy? You almost sit down on the bed, but notice a neatly-folded uniform resting on the pillow before you get there. The tailors work fast, it seems; you pick it up and unfold it to get an idea of what you‚Äôll be wearing. Thankfully, it‚Äôs only three pieces and doesn‚Äôt seem to be too elaborate. There‚Äôs a simple white top of similar design to your tunic, but with actual sleeves and made of a thicker material. A pair of close-fitting grey trousers with fairly stretchy fabric and a few silver accents. And a white outer coat - surprisingly light for its thickness - with more silver designs than the other pieces. Definitely more practical than the one-piece almost-dress of a tunic you‚Äôre wearing now; you‚Äôll be able to move around pretty easily in it and won‚Äôt get cold from a March breeze. You are a little concerned about all the white and light grey, but figure maybe the Cathedra has some advanced laundry technology. Surely they wouldn‚Äôt want Angels to go out into the city in easily-stained uniforms. ‚Äã
1:00 PM
You open the closet, intending to hang your uniform in there so you can go to sleep later, and discover several more copies of it already on hangers. There‚Äôs even a variation with a heavier coat, presumably for cold weather. How could they possibly have tailored all these for you in the few hours since you arrived? And they‚Äôll have to do it again before too long - you aren‚Äôt done growing yet! Uniform successfully stored, you turn off the mechanical lamp before leaving your bedroom. You know you‚Äôre not paying for the steam to run it, but twelve years of growing up where your parents do means you‚Äôre conscious of this sort of thing. Someone‚Äôs paying for it, after all. At least it‚Äôs not an actual flame-based lamp; you could never get the hang of pouring the oil in and kept spilling it on the table. The mechanical ones are much easier, though of course they can‚Äôt move because of the pipes. ... You‚Äôre all fired up again after exploring your room. It‚Äôs still not late late and you‚Äôre not tired yet. Sister Noll did say you could do whatever you wanted tonight, as long as you got to Oth Hall on time in the morning. It might be a little scary to go wandering around the darkened campus in the nighttime fog, but you can at least go look around the rest of Hearth Hall, right? Having forgotten your earlier trepidation of running into someone and having to hold a conversation, you go put your shoes back on and leave your room. The interior hallway is quiet and moodily lit this time of night; the mechanical lights in the ceiling seem to be glowing more dimly than they could, casting the whole building into partial shadow. A portion of apprehension returns, but your curiosity remains stronger for now. The little edge of worry almost makes it more exciting, especially since you know you‚Äôre actually completely safe. Probably. No, definitely. ‚Äã
1:00 PM
First, you walk to the outer edge of the building, which isn‚Äôt very far. Your room is right on the end, across from 301 and directly next to the stairwell you hadn‚Äôt known existed when you went up the central one. It looks basically the same as the central stairs and there‚Äôs not much else there, so you leave it alone and walk the other way instead. You had been rushing too quickly to make note of it on the way up, but there‚Äôs a common area on this floor as well. Unlike the one downstairs, there‚Äôs no one here - you check for any errant blanket piles to be sure - but the rest of the room is pretty much the same. Comfy seating, a few tables, some miscellaneous books or other items that someone probably left behind. It suddenly occurs to you to wonder where everyone is getting these books; you don‚Äôt recall a library on your tour. Maybe you should ask tomorrow. Yara would probably know, if he‚Äôs that much into reading. You distract yourself for a few minutes by wandering around the room and checking the titles of the books on display. Most of them are annoyingly practical - history, magical theory, or combat techniques - but you do spy a few fiction texts lurking beneath other volumes. You suppose maybe people are just more likely to leave certain kinds of books behind and the rest would be in their rooms. As you‚Äôre pondering, you hear a door opening down the hall. You half-jump as if you‚Äôre about to be caught doing something bad and scramble for some sort of excuse or reason you would be just poking around the common area. 1:00 PM

@Story Notifications Scene 9 ‚ÄúW-well, sorry to bother you I‚Äôll just be on my-‚Äù ‚ÄúEr, hang on; you know Yara? ‚ÄúBetter at what?‚Äù You realize a second too late that might be a rude question when Serri looks even further away from you, taking an outsized interest in the doorway. ‚Äú... Channeling my Soul. And if I still can‚Äôt by June, then...‚Äù A pause, she opens the stairwell door for you. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think he‚Äôll want to train someone who can‚Äôt even turn off her glow.‚Äù Ah! So maybe Yara wasn‚Äôt glowing at all. ‚Äú... Sorry,‚Äù you say automatically, following Serri to a double-wide doorway you had vaguely noticed earlier, but really had been more focused on going upstairs. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs still lots of time before June, though. I bet you‚Äôll be able to do it.‚Äù The room isn‚Äôt large, and looks more like a cafe than a cafeteria. A few tables are scattered around, but not enough to seat more than three or four groups. There‚Äôs a counter where someone would presumably prepare and provide food during the day, but at this time of night there‚Äôs no one there. Instead, Serri walks to a strange glass-fronted cabinet that appears to be stocked with various entrees. It‚Äôs also producing a humming noise, which strikes you as a thing cabinets don‚Äôt usually do. ‚ÄúMaybe,‚Äù she says, examining the selection for a few moments before opening the door. You almost jump at a wave of cool air; is the cabinet creating its own cold to keep the food for longer? ‚ÄúYara tries to help, but it comes so naturally to him that he‚Äôs almost useless. ‚ÄòJust feel for it!‚Äô Feel for what? Ugh, I‚Äôm sorry; now I‚Äôm just complaining. Do you want anything?‚Äù ‚Äã
8:19 PM
You pick out a small frosted cake, because you‚Äôve already had dinner and there‚Äôs no one to tell you that you shouldn‚Äôt have dessert. Serri picks some sort of paste-filled bun and you sit down at one of the tables to eat. You‚Äôre still bursting with curiosity about Souls and magic and everything, but Serri seems pretty upset about it, so instead you ask ‚Äúwhy June? Aren‚Äôt all these courses personalized? I mean, there are only two new Angels a year or so; you can‚Äôt do normal school-sized classes.‚Äù She‚Äôs starting to seem a little more relaxed after working on the sandwich for a bit. ‚ÄúSome of them are; some of them aren‚Äôt. Some courses work better when you‚Äôre paired up with someone, so they only hold those every year or something to try and make sure there are enough Angels. The basic magic course is one of them, since it really helps to work with a partner - especially for defensive practice. So Brother Cobb starts it every June on Founding Day and it goes through the end of the year. I‚Äôm in this June‚Äôs course - at least if I can figure out my Soul before then - and so is the previous new Angel from August. You probably will be too, at least if you want to learn magic right away.‚Äù ‚ÄúYes! Who wouldn‚Äôt?‚Äù Serri actually half-smiles at that. ‚ÄúYara says only one Angel since he got here didn‚Äôt take it as soon as they could. Of course everyone‚Äôs going to be excited about it.‚Äù ... Okay, she‚Äôs not as sad anymore and you really want to know. ‚ÄúThis, uh, glow,‚Äù you begin, pointing to your still-shining arm. ‚ÄúYou said... um, is it related to... Soul channeling? What does that mean?‚Äù The smile was short-lived. ‚ÄúY-yeah. That glow is... I, uh, don‚Äôt freak out, but that is your Soul.‚Äù You blink. Look at your arm. Look at Serri. She doesn‚Äôt seem to be kidding. ‚ÄúWhat?!‚Äù ‚ÄúLook, don‚Äôt worry; it‚Äôs - when you Ascend, your Soul gets a lot stronger, right? That‚Äôs how Angels are different from normal humans, mostly.‚Äù ‚ÄúR-right...‚Äù ‚Äã
8:19 PM
‚ÄúBut your Body (and Mind) isn‚Äôt used to that strength right away, so it...‚Äù She almost winces before saying the next part. ‚ÄúLeaks? Out of you, a little?‚Äù ‚Äú... My Soul is... leaking? Out of my arms?‚Äù ‚ÄúNot in a dangerous way, and it all comes back! But, um, yes, I think so. When you get better at Soul channeling, you can sort of reshape it and make it fit your Body better - and training your Body to be able to handle your Soul also helps - so most adult Angels don‚Äôt have to glow unless they want to. Even if you don‚Äôt do anything to channel it, your Body should adjust in less than a year anyway.‚Äù You still can‚Äôt quite get over the idea that your Soul - the very culmination of your being - is just leaking onto the table. It feels almost blasphemous. ‚ÄúUnless they want to?‚Äù you repeat. ‚ÄúWhy would someone want to... uhm...‚Äù ‚ÄúMaybe if they‚Äôre somewhere really dark?‚Äù ‚Äú...‚Äù ‚ÄúOnly sort of kidding. But Yara is the Soul channeler, not me. You know I can‚Äôt even turn it off, let alone know why you‚Äôd want to turn it back on.‚Äù ‚ÄúI‚Äôll help you,‚Äù you say impulsively (and a little bit self-importantly, you realize a moment later). ‚ÄúEr, I don‚Äôt know if I‚Äôll be any good at Soul channeling either, but you said with magic it helps to practice with someone else, and... Yara is, um... too good at it...‚Äù You kind of lose momentum and just trail off. Serri stares at you for a few seconds before looking back down with a soft exhale and another half-smile. ‚ÄúYou should at least wait until your first day before making promises like that. But... if you still want to after tomorrow, then... thanks.‚Äù You hang out with Serri for a little longer, then you both head back upstairs to your respective rooms. At this point, it is definitely late and you‚Äôre feeling the strain of a long day. Time to wash up, sink into bed, and do your very best to get some sleep before tomorrow. ‚Äã
8:20 PM
- You wake up refreshed and ready to go. - You wake up exhausted, unable to sleep well. ‚è© - Start to speed things up. [Skips through your first day and instead begins the segment I will lovingly call the training montage. We‚Äôll still do some montaging later even if you don‚Äôt pick this; this choice is just if you‚Äôre getting impatient.] (Winner: ) (edited)
