Mxblah 10/19/2023 8:22 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 10 You thought being your own nightlight might cause some trouble falling asleep, but it‚Äôs dim enough not to bother you with the covers muffling your glow. No dreams disturb you either and - after a brief moment of confusion in the morning before you remember where you are and why you‚Äôre not at home - you wake up rested and brimming with energy. Your face looks slightly strange in the mirror; you briefly wonder if you‚Äôre already changing to look more divine, but manage to convince yourself it‚Äôs still just the glow making the shadows weird. It hasn‚Äôt dimmed much at all overnight, but at least it‚Äôs only barely visible in the window‚Äôs foggy sunlight. Under mechanical lights, though, it‚Äôs pretty obvious. The cafe is much more obvious this morning and you have to try not to stare at all the Angels while you pick your way through the crowd to get some breakfast. You‚Äôve never seen so many in one place. Then again, you had hardly seen any at all before coming here. There are a few Angels who look younger than the rest, closer to your age. Presumably these are your fellow trainees, but no one seems particularly interested in talking to you at the moment. Maybe you just blend in. ‚ÄúOh, Jessamine, there you are.‚Äù You spin around to spot Yara, now in his uniform and looking much more put-together than last night. 8:22 PM
‚ÄúImportant things. Like...‚Äù He glances around for a moment. ‚ÄúWell, I was going to say something that isn‚Äôt very important, but it‚Äôs too early for that sort of thing. Or too late. 8:23 PM
‚ÄúBut you sure like reading about it.‚Äù Etalyn holds up her hand to stop Yara‚Äôs next rebuttal, instead rubbing the bridge of her nose. ‚ÄúLook, sorry. I know you wouldn‚Äôt do anything like that. @Story Notifications Scene 11 ... Maybe you shouldn‚Äôt ask anyone, at least not yet. 6:35 PM

He notices your arrival and beckons you forward; Yara waves and joins the rest of the group to let you approach alone. ‚ÄúGood morning, Angel Jessamine Goodall,‚Äù he says, greeting you with the sign of the matan. His voice is scratchy, like he needs some water. ‚ÄúI am Brother Lemuel Cobb, head instructor of trainee Angels. I also teach a number of basic and intermediate courses on magic and Soul. 6:35 PM

I will go over some important information, then we will design your schedule.‚Äù You follow. 6:35 PM

Mxblah 10/23/2023 8:52 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 12 On second thought, he‚Äôs been pleasant enough to you so far, and it‚Äôs not like there‚Äôs anything secret about these people walking about in public. ‚ÄúEr, Brother Cobb, what are those people doing with the... cases?‚Äù He half-turns, but doesn‚Äôt slow. ‚ÄúResearch, young Angel. Tell me, what is a Mind?‚Äù ‚ÄúUm...‚Äù You hesitate, trying to come up with something brief but useful. Ah, the church‚Äôs definition? ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs the connection between your Soul and your Body.‚Äù ‚ÄúA reasonable answer, but incomplete. Tell me, do animals have Souls?‚Äù ‚Äú... No?‚Äù That‚Äôs one of the church‚Äôs foremost teachings. Humankind is unique among all life on the planet in possessing Souls; they are what separate people from beasts. ‚ÄúBut they do have Minds. How would a chicken or a dog recognize their human master without one? But without a Soul, there is nothing for the Mind to link to the Body. So your definition needs some revision; try again.‚Äù ‚Äú...‚Äù It‚Äôs hard to come up with anything while you‚Äôre still walking, and relatively quickly to keep up with the taller monk‚Äôs strides! ‚ÄúUm, a Mind is what tells the Body what to do?‚Äù Brother Cobb seems pleased; his tone changes slightly. ‚ÄúBetter. The Mind, as best we can tell, is the aspect of the self that stores memories and personality, and the aspect that directs the Body‚Äôs conscious actions. If a being possesses a Soul, such as a human, the Mind links Body and Soul in order to channel one‚Äôs true self into their everyday actions, filtered through the lens of their personality and experience. For those with no Soul, the Mind still performs this task - merely without a higher authority to guide its decisions. Yes?‚Äù ‚ÄúY-yes.‚Äù ‚ÄúSo, what are these researchers studying? They are studying the Mind.‚Äù He seems to consider the question answered, but you‚Äôre still curious about the cases. Hesitantly, you- ‚Äã
8:52 PM
‚ÄúThe cases, then,‚Äù he continues, interrupting you before you could even start speaking. You had already forgotten he‚Äôs prone to long pauses. ‚ÄúMerely blessed containers used to transport various tools from place to place. Certain implements used for examining or manipulating the Mind must be kept pristine - free from any contamination - in order to ensure the safety of those performing experiments, as well as those undergoing treatment. Just as a physician of the Body must purify his tools before operating, so too must a surgeon of the Mind keep his tools clean.‚Äù ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt know you could operate on the Mind like you can the Body,‚Äù you admit, not sure what you think about that. It seems dangerous, but at least it‚Äôs not... ‚ÄúC-can you operate on the Soul, too?‚Äù ‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Brother Cobb says sternly. ‚ÄúThe Soul is one‚Äôs immutable true self, and it cannot be tampered with by similar processes. Anyone who says otherwise is lying, misinformed, or delving too deeply into the techniques of the corruption we fight. You shall speak no more of such matters.‚Äù You shut up, but don‚Äôt stop thinking about it. The corruption is a sickness of the Soul, Yara had said. Etalyn‚Äôs accusation of his interest in external Soul transmutation. Even Sister Noll‚Äôs explanation of Blessings leads you to think that the Soul is much more changeable than you had always been told. You know there‚Äôs more to the story, but clearly Brother Cobb isn‚Äôt interested in telling it. You‚Äôll have to find out more on your own later. ‚ÄúYou seem to be the inquisitive sort,‚Äù he notes as he finally leads you out of the hallway and into a much larger room packed with books; this must be the library Yara told you about. It‚Äôs well-frequented, based on the number of people currently poking through the shelves or reading at various tables throughout. ‚ÄúThat curiosity will serve you well at the Cathedra, so long as you take care to avoid chasing after secrets that have been forbidden.‚Äù ‚Äã
8:52 PM
A breath; you don‚Äôt try to speak this time. ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt restrict knowledge lightly; any topics that have been removed from the general archive have been the direct cause of serious harm. Soul transmutation, as I mentioned earlier, is one of those topics. Its domain lies within the darkness; only expert Angels with decades of magical experience have any hope of finding useful secrets in that field. Anyone without that experience will cause grievous harm to themselves or others, and some topics are even worse.‚Äù Another pause. ‚ÄúAnything in the general archive is open to you at any time, however, including all manner of mundane topics and a vast array of magical texts. Many have been penned by Angels like yourself and will be a great help in your practical studies. Please make use of this library to better yourself and serve God as the best Angel you can be.‚Äù ‚ÄúI-I will.‚Äù Well, it seems you were right about Soul transmutation being more than a little restricted. Maybe there‚Äôs something about the general idea in the regular archive, at least. You‚Äôre starting to get really obsessed with the topic, even though you shouldn‚Äôt. Probably because you shouldn‚Äôt. Brother Cobb really should understand that. ‚ÄúAnyway, here are a few foundational texts you should pursue during your first weeks here. I would recommend Angelic Biology as the one to start with; it is written by an Angel and describes the changes you should expect as you grow into your new form.‚Äù He hands you a relatively slim book, then goes back for more. ‚ÄúThen, there‚Äôs basic Soul theory - useful if you intend to delve into magic as soon as possible - as well as similar introductions to Body and Mind.‚Äù Another three onto the pile, all much thicker. ‚ÄúOf course, your mundane studies shouldn‚Äôt be neglected either...‚Äù Texts on math, language, sciences, and the like make their way onto the stack. You‚Äôre starting to struggle to keep your grip. ‚Äã
8:52 PM
By the time he‚Äôs done handing you everything, you have a stack of twelve books that you have to maneuver carefully in order to even see over. Your arms feel maybe a little stronger than normal (though you may be deluding yourself), but even so, you can‚Äôt hold them all for long. Thankfully a nearby monk (librarian?) offers to deliver them to your room; you gratefully accept. Finally, Brother Cobb takes you over to a smaller office-like room not far off the library, nodding at the papers and writing implements someone has left here for you. ‚ÄúTime to work out your initial schedule. But first, I am required to inform you of four major changes that you underwent the moment God chose you in the Calling chamber. Most changes to your Body, Mind, and Soul will be more gradual, but these four are boons that all Angels share.‚Äù Another pause. ‚ÄúOf course, Angelic Biology does a much better job explaining, but here we are. ‚ÄúFirst, Bodily perfection. You must have already noticed that all Angels are young and of flawless appearance; this is no mistake. Your aging will slow over the next one to two decades until it finally stops, keeping your Body in its physical prime indefinitely.‚Äù You open your mouth, but Brother Cobb waves you down. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs all in the book; just let me get through the requirements, please. ‚ÄúSecond, divine immortality. The Emissary asked you to swear your immortal, divine loyalty to God and the Cathedra, and that was not an exaggeration. You will not die unless you fall in battle or to the corruption; ordinary illness and old age hold no power over you.‚Äù ‚Äú-‚Äù ‚Äã
8:53 PM
‚ÄúThird, a second chance. I personally am against you young Angels hearing about this at all, but it‚Äôs better to learn about it - and its limitations - properly than from hearsay. The first time in your - theoretically infinite - life that you would die, God will save you. You will return to perfect health over several seconds, but that is it. Nothing will stop whatever killed you from doing it again after those few seconds, so do not rely on this. Too many young Angels think they‚Äôre invincible and get themselves into impossible situations.‚Äù A pause; he stares at you. ‚ÄúDo you understand?‚Äù ‚Äú... Y-yes?‚Äù He sighs. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs in the book. Why do we even - ahem. Fourth, a divine Soul. Obviously, your strong Soul is what allows you to harness magical effects, but it can do more than that. When under great stress, you can manifest your Soul physically, converting your Body into - simplifying dramatically - an avatar of the Lord Himself. Almost nothing will be able to stand up to you in that form, but it will burn away your Soul in only minutes, leaving you nearly dead at the end of it. You‚Äôll need weeks to recover, at the very minimum. Just like the second chance, you should never rely on this last, desperate ability.‚Äù ‚Äú...‚Äù He rubs his temples. ‚ÄúRead the book; it will make more sense. Honestly, why they consider this to be day-one information...‚Äù ‚Äú... I-if I have questions, should I, er-‚Äù ‚ÄúYes, please hold them until you have done your reading. I will be willing to answer once you have.‚Äù You awkwardly sit down and look over one of the papers; it‚Äôs a block of information on a course about swordplay. You wonder if maybe the reason Brother Cobb doesn‚Äôt like giving out this information is because he rushes through it and doesn‚Äôt take any questions. Treacherously, you wonder what he possibly could have done to earn the ‚Äúhead instructor‚Äù position, but you quickly try to banish that thought. You don‚Äôt know him very well yet; maybe he can still surprise you! ‚Äã
8:53 PM
‚ÄúLet us move on. There are a few required courses in the fundamentals, but you are able to select some that match your own interests. Take your time; is there anything here that you would like to learn about?‚Äù [Would you like to sign up for the basic magic course starting in June?] - Yeah, obviously! - Maybe you should wait... Mxblah 10/25/2023 9:13 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 13 There‚Äôs a lot you‚Äôd like to learn about, but unfortunately there‚Äôs only one slot to fill. Well, there were two, but of course you signed up for the basic magic course immediately. So, one. Still, after sorting through the descriptions for all the available courses, you end up picking history for... pretty much the same reasons as Yara told you he had. Brother Trigg‚Äôs description promises not only information on Nucarreo‚Äôs founding through the present day, but also how the corruption started and what happened to get to today‚Äôs relatively stable state. Given all the conflicting information around it, you‚Äôre hopeful to get a fuller understanding. Brother Cobb seems to approve. Then, after your schedule is settled, you... go back to school. Well, sort of. It‚Äôs more like tutoring than a traditional classroom - one monk instructs either just you or a small group of trainee Angels. Aside from that, it‚Äôs basically the same mundane subjects you were learning just a few days ago. You suppose it‚Äôs probably good to make sure you still get an ordinary education too, but it‚Äôs hard to be excited about ratios and equations when you could be studying magic or the corruption. You learn that Oth Hall has a cafe too - most of the main buildings seem to have one - and sit down for lunch amidst a number of monks, regular staff, and other Angels. Despite your best efforts to look friendly (or at least unintimidating), the staff keep their distance. Most of the monks do the same, though more out of deference than concern; these seem to be mostly the lighter-robed researchers rather than the seemingly more important dark-robed instructors. The Angels, in contrast, are more intimidating to you than the other way around (presumably despite their own best efforts!), so you end up by yourself. Well, you do for a few minutes, at least, until Serri shows up and quietly asks if she can join you. Of course you don‚Äôt mind and slide over a bit to make room. ‚Äã
9:13 PM

I‚Äôm... not.‚Äù ‚Äú...‚Äù You would say something about how she was almost late this morning, but you don‚Äôt want to be mean just for the sake of having something relevant to say. 9:13 PM
‚ÄúA-anyway, it‚Äôs usually pretty interesting when Yara is involved. Etalyn is really good with her sword, but Yara uses all kinds of magic. Still, you have more courses in the afternoon, so you say goodbye to Serri and head off to learn about the fundamentals of Body, Mind, and Soul. ‚Äã
9:13 PM
Or rather, Mind, then Soul, then Body. Apparently. Your first course of the afternoon is the fundamentals of Mind, which means you have to make your way through the maze of Oth Hall to find it. Here, you start with (oddly enough) some perception games; you have to identify hidden sights, sounds, or other effects as quickly as you can. It‚Äôs tough work, especially when they start making noises behind your back and asking you to turn around just before someone is about to bonk you with a fake wooden sword. This... you are uniquely bad at, failing to catch your instructor every single time. He tries to reassure you - ‚Äúit‚Äôs okay; most new trainees take months to develop their senses sufficiently‚Äù - but you‚Äôre upset anyway. Soul fundamentals are taught in Illim Hall - or rather, in the garden just behind it. Your instructor asks you to look at a candle flame dance in the breeze, then describe how it interacts with the glow that still spills from your Body. You... don‚Äôt see anything, really - it‚Äôs too bright outside - so you move on to a few other mediums. Leaves, water, fat little bees; you still don‚Äôt understand what you‚Äôre supposed to be looking at. After that, you‚Äôre given some water and crackers; asked to take tiny sips or nibbles and focus on how your glow reacts to the nourishment. This time, you almost feel like you get something - there‚Äôs a sensation of... well, something! - but you can‚Äôt quite describe it. Your instructor seems pleased enough that you felt anything at all, at least. ‚Äã
9:13 PM
You didn‚Äôt sign up for any of the optional combat courses, but it looks like you‚Äôll be getting basic training in weaponry anyway. You‚Äôre presented with a heavy steel (real! sharp!) sword as soon as you enter the grounds for Body fundamentals at Forger Hall, and spend the next hour or so learning how to handle it without hurting yourself. You‚Äôre not very good at it, and despite your best efforts (and the training guard on the sharp edge) you do somehow manage to clobber yourself with the blade and walk away with a hefty bruise on one arm. Being an Angel does not automatically make you graceful and perfect, you repeat to yourself. No, clearly not. Ow. Your instructor says you should be pretty well healed by the morning, at least; your Angelic Body is really good at repairing itself. - Well, that was a mess. You hardly got anything right. - You did fine; you shouldn‚Äôt expect to be perfect on your first day. - You‚Äôll do better tomorrow, for sure! (Winner: ) (edited)

@Story Notifications Scene 14 Well, you did... okay, you think. Certainly not a prodigy, but you‚Äôre just starting out. No one can expect to be perfect right away. The fog glimmers with yellow-orange light as the sun begins to set somewhere far above. You‚Äôve got to get to Forger Hall if you want to see the match. The, uh, fight. That still makes you a little uncomfortable, but you suppose you had better get used to it. Serri‚Äôs right; the primary duty of you as an Angel is to fight against the darkness. Mxblah 10/29/2023 10:23 AM
@Story Notifications Scene 15 ‚ÄúProbably... not.‚Äù Everyone else seems to agree, and you really don‚Äôt know anything about how well either of them might do. Besides, it‚Äôs not like Yara can get upset about your lack of belief in him; he‚Äôs all the way over there. ‚ÄúUm, by the way, your eyes are...‚Äù ‚ÄúOh, this?‚Äù She points at her face and does a long blink; her eyes are now a much more natural shade of light green. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs just practice! She pulls a section of it aside so you can get a good look, then concentrates and returns its fiery color, following up with her eyes a moment later. ‚ÄúWh - how... it‚Äôs magic, I think, but is that... permanent?‚Äù ‚ÄúSort of? Clarity cuts herself off - ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs starting!‚Äù - and hurriedly turns towards the field. You follow suit, ready to see what the fight will be about. The tall Angel from before stands on the opposite side of the field from the crowd. Yara and Etalyn both stand in small marked circles a fair distance apart, warily facing each other. There‚Äôs a pause, then a whistle. ‚Äã
10:23 AM
Etalyn draws her blade and rushes forward, sprinting across the sandy field with astonishing speed and balance. Maybe she‚Äôs trying to finish the fight before Yara can try his secret technique? If so, even the few seconds it takes is too slow. Yara pushes both arms out in a wave, releasing a whirling shockwave of air. Etalyn has to leap aside to avoid being blown away; the blast hits the sand near the field‚Äôs center instead and throws up a massive dust cloud. Yara doesn‚Äôt slow down either; he swivels and fires another airblast, then another, and several more. Etalyn gets closer with each blast, moving towards him in a sort of spiral pattern, but there‚Äôs so much dust in the air now that you‚Äôre having a hard time seeing what‚Äôs going on. Then, after one more blast, everything goes quiet. There‚Äôs too much sand; you can hardly see the field and have lost track of both fighters. Clarity murmurs something beside you. ‚ÄúI wonder what he‚Äôs trying? She can‚Äôt see him, but he can‚Äôt see her either. Maybe something with the Mind - but, no, that‚Äôs... hmm!‚Äù You cough in the dusty air, bringing your shirt up to cover your nose. A number of spectators are moving away from the field to get out of the cloud. Suddenly, Yara appears on the very edge of the field, hands outstretched towards the center and focusing intently. There‚Äôs a long, drawn-out pause, then... Spreading from his hands and extending to every corner of the cloud, dust particles turn from brown to black and fall from the sky with an ever-increasing splattering roar. You gasp and take several steps back, but it‚Äôs too late; you and everyone else in the crowd are sprinkled with black goop that somewhat resembles tar as the dust transforms. Still, it‚Äôs much more concentrated on the field - a sticky layer of the stuff reaches several inches thick across most of the former sand. And a human-shaped lump in the opposite corner suggests that Etalyn has definitely not gotten away from the downpour unscathed. ‚Äã
10:23 AM
You start to get excited despite yourself as Yara drops his hands, scans the field, then runs off towards the corner. He‚Äôs struggling to keep his footing on the tar, though, alternating between sliding and getting stuck on the surface. The lump wriggles more violently as he gets closer, particularly along one side where - just a few steps out - a sword manages to break free. She scrambles out of the layer of tar only an instant before Yara arrives, absolutely coated in the stuff and clearly heavily weighed down by it. He manages to score a hit as Etalyn spins to face him; she takes a deep gash down her side that paints the black, sticky floor with shockingly deep red blood. You look around frantically, watching for someone to call the match, but no one does. She fights on regardless, slowed and grimacing against the wound but skill undiminished. From there, it only takes maybe twenty seconds to finish it. Yara fights decently, but Etalyn isn‚Äôt as hurt as she looks - or maybe she‚Äôs just really good at ignoring the pain - and fights much better than ‚Äúdecently.‚Äù Neither Angel uses any more magic, and even with the wound and sticky coating, Etalyn manages to drive her blade home in short order. You wince, then cover your eyes entirely as a brilliant burst of golden-white light flashes out. Yara and Etalyn are both thrown away; he picks himself up moments later - tar coating the back of his uniform - and laughs heartily. The tall Angel swoops in, blowing the whistle to declare the match over - and then a second burst of light explodes from where Etalyn had landed. She stands up as well, wiping goop off her face and uniform, and marches over to Yara as the tall Angel proclaims her the winner. She looks far more angry than you would expect since she just won, but Clarity thankfully has you covered with her post-match commentary. ‚Äã
10:23 AM
‚ÄúWow!‚Äù she exclaims, eyes sparkling with excitement. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs the closest he‚Äôs ever gotten! No wonder she‚Äôs so mad; she ‚Äòdied‚Äô just a few seconds after he did! If he‚Äôd been able to hold out just a little longer with that sword fight, or maybe if he‚Äôd been a little quicker getting over there-‚Äù She shakes her head appreciatively. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm impressed; that‚Äôs one cool trick he pulled off.‚Äù ‚ÄúTh-the second light was... er-‚Äù ‚ÄúYeah, that was her ward going off too. Means her injuries were bad enough the spell thought she might die if it didn‚Äôt do something, so it blew up and healed her just like Yara‚Äôs did. New experience for her, you know?‚Äù ‚ÄúY-yeah.‚Äù ‚ÄúHey, here comes your other buddy now. Serri, what‚Äôd you think?‚Äù You glance out to the field again as Serri arrives from the other side of the crowd. Etalyn and Yara bow to each other under the tall Angel‚Äôs instruction, then start making their slow, difficult way off the tar field. He seems to be animatedly telling her something, and you can see her responding in some way even though she still looks quite angry. What is their ‚Äúweird rivalry,‚Äù as Clarity put it? [Not necessarily mutually exclusive. Pick as many as you‚Äôd like.] ‚úã - You congratulate Yara on his narrow loss. - You congratulate Etalyn on her narrow victory. Ô∏è - You ask about the secret technique‚Äôs... well, technique. ‚Äç‚Äç - You‚Äôre still wondering about their relationship. - You‚Äôre still a little preoccupied by the violence on display. Mxblah 10/31/2023 8:31 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 16 ‚ÄúReally impressive,‚Äù Serri says quietly. ‚ÄúThat was transmutation, right? So it must have been really hard.‚Äù ‚ÄúYeah, probably! Unless he figured out how to turn sand into gloop just by pushing energy into it, and something tells me he didn‚Äôt.‚Äù They chat a little more about magical mechanics you don‚Äôt understand quite yet, so you just listen without saying anything. You‚Äôre good at that. After a bit, Yara and Etalyn show up too and he immediately joins the conversation. ‚ÄúAh, Jessamine, you did make it after all! Well, how did I do?‚Äù ‚ÄúEr, I haven‚Äôt seen any other matches, but, uh, congratulations on your, um, almost-win?‚Äù Feeling like everyone‚Äôs been emphasizing Yara‚Äôs accomplishments without acknowledging Etalyn‚Äôs skill, you turn to her as well. ‚ÄúAnd... good job to you too, on, er, your actual win.‚Äù She rolls her eyes, but nods anyway. Yara does a miniature bow. ‚ÄúMuch appreciated. Any comments on my brand-new secret technique? Improvements?‚Äù ‚ÄúTry not to hit the spectators next time,‚Äù Clarity offers, showing off her speckled sleeve. ‚ÄúBut it was very exciting to see; I didn‚Äôt know you could do transmutation like that!‚Äù ‚ÄúAh ha! I‚Äôve been branching out from my traditional projections for even greater flexibility! You see, it turns out that there‚Äôs actually very little manipulation needed to adjust the ‚Äòstickiness‚Äô of dust like this; I happened across a manuscript a while ago that...‚Äù You kind of lose focus. On top of not really understanding the complicated terms he‚Äôs using, you keep finding yourself glancing at Etalyn‚Äôs side or Yara‚Äôs stomach where their uniforms are torn from blades. The skin beneath is perfectly intact, but the white fabric is stained with blood. Everyone seems so casual about it, so you‚Äôd feel weird bringing it up, but... Etalyn waves a hand and you blink, snapping your gaze back to eye level again. ‚ÄúHey, you okay, new kid? Spacing out a little.‚Äù ‚ÄúEr, sorry... I was just, er... it‚Äôs nothing important.‚Äù ‚Äã
8:31 PM
She seems to put it together. ‚ÄúNot used to blood like this?‚Äù ‚Äú...‚Äù You‚Äôre not sure, actually. Maybe it‚Äôs the blood, but maybe it‚Äôs just... ‚ÄúI - I don‚Äôt know. It just seems so...‚Äù You break off again, still trying to figure out what you‚Äôre thinking. ‚ÄúAngels are supposed to be holy, even in battle, but, er...‚Äù ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a bit more brutal than you thought, right? And the real thing‚Äôs even worse, accordin‚Äô to the soldiers. Doesn‚Äôt seem to add up, huh?‚Äù You nod slowly. It makes sense; maybe that was the... dissonance you were feeling? It‚Äôs still hard to tell for sure. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt know what was going to happen. For a moment there, I thought, you know; there was just so much blood... Maybe something had gone wrong? Maybe you were in real danger? B-but, no, it was fine.‚Äù You‚Äôre not sure what point you‚Äôre trying to make anymore. Etalyn pats her side. ‚ÄúGood as new; promise. 8:31 PM

@Story Notifications Scene 17 Well, you did promise and it‚Äôs not like the book will vanish before you get back. Better get going... Still, you don‚Äôt want to be the first one there. Maybe you‚Äôll just take your time putting the book away and getting your shoes on before finally (slowly) making your way to the door. Yeah, that‚Äôs a good idea. You‚Äôll do that. It turns out your sluggishness wasn‚Äôt necessary; when you emerge from the stairwell into the ground floor common area, it‚Äôs obvious that several Angels have been here for a while already. There‚Äôs Yara and Etalyn over on the other side of the room, both with hair still damp from cleaning off all the tar. Clarity is nearby, telling some sort of story to the first year you recognize as Erich and one of the Angels whose name you forgot. Finally, there‚Äôs the fifth year named Sims, one of the other Angels you don‚Äôt recognize, and... that‚Äôs not one of the trainees. You try to slip past the closer group to make it to the people you know, but aren‚Äôt sneaky enough. It doesn‚Äôt help that there aren‚Äôt many people walking around the room at the moment, though there are a few other Angels getting dinner nearby. In any case, Sims spots you and waves you over before you can get away. ‚ÄúWell met, Angel Jessamine,‚Äù he says in his deep, loud voice. It‚Äôs hard to believe that he‚Äôs only 16; he‚Äôs even taller than the adult Angel sitting next to him... who seems very familiar for some reason. ‚ÄúMay you serve the Lord well.‚Äù The sign of the matan; one of the more traditional greetings. He talks of a Shade - a general of the darkness and a creature of grey-black ash and soot in its natural form, but able to shape and color its Body to resemble a human being. He recounts the creature raising waves of Mindless darkness from the ground, pulling sticky threads of tar-like substance directly from the scorched, poisoned earth. You can‚Äôt help but half-glance in Yara‚Äôs direction at that, remembering his ‚Äúsecret technique.‚Äù It doesn‚Äôt seem like there‚Äôs a connection, but he certainly doesn‚Äôt need any more negative attention given his interest in Soul transmutation. He‚Äôs back into his story, looking down as he acts something out with his hands. Not even facing in Yara‚Äôs direction. You‚Äôre not sure you even saw anything to begin with. Why are you so on edge now? ‚Äã
10:03 PM
Anyway, Zeke is explaining how he fought the Shade to a standstill in order to give the ordinary soldiers time to retreat and regroup at a defensible location away from its hordes. Finally, he managed to escape himself with a feint that took one of the creature‚Äôs arms off and bought him an opportunity to manifest his wings. Apparently he‚Äôs quite proud of how quickly he can do that now, and hopes to make them permanent in the near future. You don‚Äôt care about that; you‚Äôre more curious than ever about what a Shade actually is and why a single one of them is dangerous enough to nearly overpower a full Angel and a squad of wasteland soldiers. Well, you‚Äôve already learned that Angels are far from the perfection that the church portrays. Perhaps you aren‚Äôt as surprised as you could be. ... Is Zeke... looking at you now? Apparently you hadn‚Äôt been quite as thorough as you had thought, though to be fair you wouldn‚Äôt have been able to see that angle in the mirror. @Story Notifications Scene 18 Thankfully, that feeling starts to fade over a few minutes as Zeke chats with Sims and you sit there awkwardly, no longer part of the conversation but not having explicitly exited the interaction. Mxblah 11/16/2023 10:08 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 20 Conveniently, a new question occurs to you as you glance around the room for ideas of how to change the topic. ‚ÄúWhere are the last two trainees?‚Äù you wonder aloud. ‚ÄúThere were only...‚Äù A quick count (remembering to include the missing Naoriel) confirms it. ‚ÄúNine of us here.‚Äù ‚ÄúOh, who‚Äôs missing?‚Äù Erich looks around, but Denn beats him to it. ‚ÄúEmmett and Rhysa?‚Äù ‚ÄúAh, those two. They‚Äôre training with the district constables, I believe. Should be back in a week or so.‚Äù ‚ÄúWhat sort of training?‚Äù You want to stay away from uncomfortable topics for Serri, but you are also legitimately curious. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs nothing special,‚Äù Erich assures you. ‚ÄúJust spending some time embedded in a precinct office to better understand how to work with regular constables. Supposedly it‚Äôs intended to improve goodwill and coordination between Angels and ordinary people. Really, though, it just helps us learn how to keep them out of our way.‚Äù ‚ÄúY-you don‚Äôt know that,‚Äù Serri interjects. ‚ÄúYou haven‚Äôt done it yet.‚Äù Erich shrugs. ‚ÄúTrue. But I have seen my fair share of the corruption even before I Ascended. Of course, you know that darkness tends to cling to places of suffering, and even the best hospitals are full of people in pain. I visited my father many times at work, and witnessed several incidents. Every time, the constables‚Äô only job was to clear the area and keep people away so the real heroes - Angels - would have room to work.‚Äù You frown, thinking back to your time in the hospital. You don‚Äôt recall anything like that happening, but you had been pretty out of it at the time. Maybe you had just been too sick to notice; it was a pretty large complex, after all. Still, you‚Äôre not sure you like how he‚Äôs talking about ‚Äúordinary‚Äù people so negatively. ‚ÄúWell, th-they can‚Äôt purify monsters like Angels can, so it m-makes sense for them to stay back.‚Äù ‚ÄúI never said it didn‚Äôt. Just that the constables are objectively less important than any Angel.‚Äù ‚Äã
10:08 PM
Great. Now you‚Äôve got to come up with another change of topic before things get even worse. You glance over to Denn, sitting peacefully beside Erich, as if maybe he can help you. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre still human, too,‚Äù he says calmly, patting Erich‚Äôs shoulder. ‚ÄúD‚Äòspite all our blessings.‚Äù The younger Angel rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt go spouting that line at me again. I‚Äôm not saying anyone‚Äôs less of a human than anyone else, just that some people are better at some things than others. In this case, that Angels are better at fighting monsters than anyone else.‚Äù ‚ÄúConstable‚Äôn is a big job too,‚Äù Denn reminds him. ‚ÄúThey gotta deal with all the human monsters.‚Äù ‚ÄúWell, not all of them. Depending on what you count as a monster.‚Äù ‚ÄúNot a human.‚Äù ‚ÄúA dog criminal?‚Äù Denn nods with a look of absolute seriousness. ‚ÄúProblem for an Angel.‚Äù ‚Äú...‚Äù No one laughs, exactly, but there are several exhales and the tension lessens a bit. You shoot Denn a grateful look; he nods serenely. Seems like he must be used to this kind of thing by now. You stay downstairs for longer than you thought, joining the older Angels‚Äô game after a few more minutes and getting absolutely destroyed by Yara‚Äôs ridiculous strategies. At least, during the first round. He doesn‚Äôt seem to get as lucky later on and you pick up on a few tricks of your own. ‚Äã
10:09 PM
Other adult Angels come and go for a while, some stopping by for a brief introduction or to chat with one of the trainees for a few minutes. The common area is much more lively than it was yesterday, even around the same time as night closes in around the building. You bring that up and learn that the first of every month - Calling Day for ordinary children - typically involves a few hours of solitary reflection for Angels after the evening‚Äôs mass. You had been so busy with your tour and such that you hadn‚Äôt even noticed all the Angels disappearing shortly after dinner. Yara, of course, had decided to do his ‚Äúsolitary‚Äù ‚Äúreflection‚Äù in the common area, with a book. You suppose it‚Äôs close enough. Some Angels come in with hair and clothes disheveled, sharing tidbits of missions they had just completed. You don‚Äôt hear much, but it seems one of the most common duties involves purifying Mindless darkness creatures inside the city before they can do any damage. It makes you wonder how common that sort of thing is. You‚Äôd never heard of any corruption making its way into the city before, essentially, today, but here are a number of Angels just returning from dealing with exactly that. Maybe it‚Äôs localized to a handful of places, and your neighborhood just never had much of a problem? It‚Äôs hard to know. Eventually, it gets late and you get tired. You say your goodbyes and head upstairs, relishing the quietness of the stairway and upper halls after the raucous gathering downstairs. Ah, you don‚Äôt have to talk to anyone. Glorious. Not that you didn‚Äôt enjoy your time downstairs; you‚Äôre just... socially exhausted. You slip into your room and close the door before anyone else can show up. Glance at the book you had neatly put into a shelf before heading down. You‚Äôre... maybe a little too tired to read that properly right now. Tomorrow. ‚Äã
10:09 PM
Wash, change, crawl into bed. Your face definitely looks different in the mirror tonight. Cleaner; sharper, yet somehow softer. You‚Äôre already visibly changing and it‚Äôs only been two days. So much happened today, and you‚Äôre on schedule for even more to happen tomorrow. You‚Äôre starting your history course, for one, and that‚Äôs probably going to involve even more reading. Better get started quick. Still, you‚Äôve got so many questions you want to answer and so many people to get to know. So much to do, and you just won‚Äôt have time for everything. So. What do you want to prioritize? [Obviously, you‚Äôre not going to neglect any of these to an unhealthy degree.] - Your courses and training. - Your personal investigations and curiosity. ‚Äç‚Äç - Your social relationships and friends. [Choose however many you want. Friendship Points‚Ñ¢®© are allocated based on the ratio of votes. Well, mostly. You should be friends with...] - Yara. - Serri. Ô∏è - Etalyn. - Clarity. Mxblah 11/18/2023 3:39 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 21 ‚ÄúWe will start today with a one-minute recap,‚Äù Brother Trigg calls, sliding a piece of mostly-transparent film atop the projector. You‚Äôve never seen anything like it before, but through a combination of lenses, mirrors, and a powerful mechanical lamp, the shadows of his normal-sized images and writing are expanded to fill the opposite wall. You‚Äôre not alone here, either. Brother Trigg himself is present, of course: a squirrely old man with thin hair and thick glasses, he couldn‚Äôt look more like a historian if he tried. But although you‚Äôre the only Angel in the room, there are about a dozen monks-in-training and other Cathedra staff learning the same history as you. You do feel a little uncomfortable at the deference everyone but Brother Trigg shows you, but there‚Äôs only so much you can do. Yara told you he has the same problem in his more advanced course. ‚ÄúGenesis to year zero in one minute! Any volunteers?‚Äù The monk always starts each session the same way, by asking a student for a one-minute recap of the entirety of history up until whatever point you‚Äôve currently reached. It‚Äôs already getting difficult to summarize and you‚Äôve only reached year zero so far; there are still over 1200 years to go if he intends to catch up to the present. ‚ÄúAngel Goodall! Thank you for volunteering!‚Äù You wince briefly, but you were half-expecting him to pick you anyway. He‚Äôs a lot more demanding of your work than any of the other students (even though you‚Äôre many years younger than most of them!) and he‚Äôll often single you out if no one else is responding. Not always, but certainly more often than if he were choosing at random. Of course, he‚Äôs not picking on you; he‚Äôs just ‚Äúensuring your time in the course is as useful as it can be.‚Äù ‚Äã
3:39 PM
‚ÄúEr, yes.‚Äù At least you‚Äôre getting over your discomfort of speaking in front of groups in record time; no one makes fun of you for getting things wrong, or even seems disappointed. That could just be the deference you had already noted, but you choose to believe otherwise. He starts the clock. ‚ÄúGod originally came down from a higher dimension and created the world and life by dreaming it into existence. He watched from above for a long time before eventually giving humans Souls so we could have true selves as reflections of Him. Our Souls were originally open and allowed us to use magic and connect with everything else freely, but this was a mistake since the open Souls could mutate too freely, which created the corruption!‚Äù Thirty seconds left. Hurry! ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt know much about what happened as the corruption spread because so many records from that time were destroyed by war or the year-zero cataclysm. But we do know that the first Angels were blessed by God sometime a few centuries before year zero, though they were too few and inexperienced to fight back effectively.‚Äù Fifteen seconds; you try to talk faster! ‚ÄúThe darkness made an all-out attack on humanity in year zero, but God broke the darkness‚Äôs Mind by sacrificing His own in order to stop it. That means as we started to rebuild, we didn‚Äôt have to face coordinated attacks, and Angels were able to defend us and create the Cathedra!‚Äù You quickly sit down and Brother Trigg stops the clock. Two seconds left; just in time! ‚ÄúGood, Jessamine. I believe there were two major events you missed in your summary, however; does anyone believe they know?‚Äù Silence for several seconds. No one wants to correct an Angel, even indirectly. Finally, one of the younger monks speaks. ‚ÄúS-she didn‚Äôt talk about God closing our Souls or the darkness infecting the planet.‚Äù Ack! You knew that; you just got flustered with having to speak so quickly- ‚Äã
3:39 PM
‚ÄúGood! Of course, it‚Äôs difficult to bring all the important facts together in such a short period of time - which is why we do these summaries. As we learned last week, God closed off our Souls when He created the first Angels, in order to prevent further corruption of humanity. However, the darkness then fled from our Souls into the planet itself, where it remains today. Very good, both of you.‚Äù Brother Trigg slides a new transparency onto the projector, showing a drawing of a shattered landscape. ‚ÄúThis is an artist‚Äôs impression of Nucarreo during the year zero cataclysm, drawn from the testimony of an Angel who survived it. If you look carefully, you may be able to match up the background mountains and the Endle River to conclude that the original city must have stood here in the image.‚Äù He swaps it for a closer-up view of that section. Pitiful, fragmented blocks are visible. ‚ÄúNothing but ruins. All major cities resembled this in year zero, but why? How? Today, we‚Äôll start by going over what evidence remains of the corruption‚Äôs last great attack and what the cataclysm is likely to have actually been.‚Äù You settle into the now-familiar rhythm of class as Trigg displays ancient historical documents and artifacts, correlates them with information from various modern texts (some of which he wrote himself), and encourages you all to summarize and discuss what it all means. It‚Äôs a lot of work, especially with all the assigned reading and writing that now occupies much of your evenings, but you‚Äôre really enjoying the chance to get actual historical answers to what had previously been the realm of religious myths. ‚Äã
3:39 PM
It‚Äôs been two weeks since your Ascension and you‚Äôve mostly gotten the hang of your new life. Your Body has continued to change rapidly; the twinges of jealousy you had felt initially at everyone else being so pretty all the time have faded as now you too look good basically no matter the situation. It‚Äôs not all looks, either - you‚Äôre already faster and stronger than before. The pile of books Brother Cobb had to get someone to carry for you now seems light enough that you were able to bring them back unassisted. (You still struggled, but at least you could!) Your Mind hasn‚Äôt changed as obviously as your Body, though you have to assume you‚Äôre smarter than you were. It seems crazy that you could keep up with a class of highly-educated monks in their late teens to twenties otherwise, and that‚Äôs to say nothing of your other courses. As for your Soul... Well, you were just about to go practice after Trigg‚Äôs class, weren‚Äôt you? - Meet up with Serri for Soul practice. - Meet up with Yara for Soul practice. ‚Äç‚Äç - Actually, is that Naoriel over there? Maybe she‚Äôll come along. Ô∏è - No, today you‚Äôre on your own. You‚Äôre close to a breakthrough. (Winner: ) (edited)

Mxblah 11/20/2023 7:15 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 22 You spot Naoriel on your way over to Illim Hall, as you often do this time of day. Seems she‚Äôs got some sort of course in there that finishes at the same time as your course with Brother Trigg, though you have so far been unable to get her to tell you what it is. You give her a wave and she waves back with a smile, but doesn‚Äôt slow down to chat. You half-frown as you consider her. Naoriel has been fairly amenable to your attempts to befriend her, waving at you as you pass and even occasionally having lunch together. But - just as you were warned by Clarity and the rest of the trainees - you still hardly know her. Well, you know that she likes fizzy drinks and has really pretty handwriting, for example, but you don‚Äôt know anything important about her. She just doesn‚Äôt talk about herself, pretty much no matter the situation. She has a right to privacy, you suppose, but it‚Äôs a little grating for someone as naturally inquisitive as you. Oh, that reminds you: at some point you want to bring up the etymology (is that the right -ology?) of her name with her. One of the texts you read for Trigg‚Äôs course discussed the original twelve Angels, who all Ascended at once and all took on new names after their transformations. The practice of renaming yourself fell out of favor after a few centuries and now Angels just keep their own names, but in the old days, the -iel and -riel suffixes (is that the right -ffix?) were distinctly popular with newly Ascended Angels. Nowadays, such names are very rare, as they‚Äôre still associated with the Angels of old - it‚Äôs sort of considered minor blasphemy to name your child like that? It‚Äôs like declaring from birth that your child will be an Angel, when obviously you can‚Äôt know for sure until their Calling ceremony. Anyway, that long-winded reminiscence basically boils down to ‚Äúnames ending in -riel are super rare because they‚Äôre considered Angelic, so you‚Äôre curious how she got her name.‚Äù ‚Äã
7:16 PM
You actually dug around a bit about Zeke - Ezekiel - for the same reasons, but as far as you can tell, his name wasn‚Äôt originally Ezekiel. It looks like he was actually named Zachary, shortened it in a somewhat unusual way to Zeke, then re-longened it to Ezekiel after he became an Angel. You had to dig through a bunch of legal records for that one, but thankfully Yara, Clarity, and Serri all helped you look (none of them like him either). Honestly, you‚Äôre not even sure why you bothered, but at least it‚Äôs interesting! So, yeah, you‚Äôre kind of wondering if Naoriel has a similar story going on. Maybe you should just ask for help sifting through another batch of census documents, but you only have time for so much unimportant research. Seriously, why did you go to all that trouble with Zeke‚Äôs name? You almost missed turning in a paper! Man, you are distracted today. Good thing you don‚Äôt have any more coursework to do until later tonight when you‚Äôve got to read another chapter for Trigg. ‚ÄúSerriiiii,‚Äù you call, slipping around a hedge into the secluded corner of the Illim Hall gardens the two of you have chosen as your practice spot. It‚Äôs surrounded by tall hedges on three sides and only has a somewhat non-obvious entrance on the fourth. There‚Äôs a little pond fed by a trickling spout and a few slow, colorful fish to occupy it. They‚Äôve got little whiskers, which you still find adorable. Fish with whiskers! What will God think of next? Serri waves from her perch on a smooth, flat rock next to the water. ‚ÄúFish time.‚Äù ‚ÄúFish time!‚Äù you echo, hopping onto a rock next to her. You often stare at the fish to help your focus, hence the name. It‚Äôs a bad name and you‚Äôre both aware of that, but neither of you care. ‚Äã
7:16 PM
You‚Äôve made about average progress in the last two weeks, according to your instructor. You‚Äôve progressed to the point where you can - with considerable difficulty - feel your own Soul at will, most of the time. You no longer need a focus like eating or drinking to sense it, though something like that does help you feel any changes to it. Currently, you‚Äôre working on reliability and intuition, but you‚Äôll be starting on trying to harness it before too long. It‚Äôs a little weird to think of your Soul with terminology that describes it as almost separate from you. Having to explicitly focus to even sense it at all, then needing to go out of your way to harness and manipulate it. Switch out the word ‚ÄúSoul‚Äù with ‚Äúliver‚Äù or something and it feels even weirder. At least you‚Äôre able to assign some words to the sensation now, instead of just the vague ‚Äúsomething‚Äù from the first few days. You suppose, if you had to describe it (and you did, for your instructor), you would say the sensation is sort of like feeling the sun on your skin, except without the physical warmth. More like... the emotional warmth? And it‚Äôs backwards, so instead of feeling it from the outside, it‚Äôs glowing on the underside of your skin and everything inside you. It‚Äôs... weird, but not unpleasant. Like looking really, really close at yourself in a mirror and noticing something nice about your face that‚Äôs always been there. Your Soul feels just right, and you‚Äôre definitely glad for that. ‚Äã
7:16 PM
Serri, thankfully, has made some progress as well. Her biggest hurdle for months had been that she just couldn‚Äôt consistently feel her own Soul, but when the two of you started practicing together, it turned out that she could feel yours a lot more easily. Which kind of freaked you out at first. It surprised her instructor as well, but apparently this sort of thing isn‚Äôt entirely unheard of. Some people are extroverts personality-wise, and some (very rare) people are... extroverts Soul-wise? You‚Äôre... not entirely sure that metaphor holds up, but the very broadest strokes make sense. Somehow, in a way that she struggles to explain and you don‚Äôt really understand either, having you around (or any other particularly strong Soul, which basically means an Angel) makes it easier for Serri to sense her own. You don‚Äôt even have to do anything; just being around is enough. And, as you might expect, having her reaching out to your Soul as she practices also means you‚Äôre starting to get a vague sense of hers as well. You‚Äôve even been able to start broadening your senses to feel other Angels‚Äô Souls if you really, really try, but they do have to be basically touching you. Your instructor says you‚Äôll get better at that over time. Anyway, today you‚Äôre just working on your own Soul, since you really want to start trying to do things with it. You‚Äôre both still glowing, and you‚Äôve only got a little over two months to stop it. You pick your favorite fish - small and silvery, with a stripe of vibrant orange - stare with your physical eyes, and struggle to open your... Soul... eyes. They‚Äôre the same eyes, you think. You‚Äôre not really sure how sensing different aspects works. - You‚Äôre focused. Dedicated. Not distracted at all. ‚Äç - Okay, no you aren‚Äôt. You‚Äôre still thinking about something. Maybe Serri has some input? [Suggest a topic. Otherwise, I‚Äôll pick.] (Winner: a tie between and ‚Äç . Options are combined.) (edited)

Mxblah 11/22/2023 10:35 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 23 You‚Äôre still distracted from earlier, thinking about names and history and even your earlier courses. Your arms still hurt a little from sword practice, though not as bad as last week. More benefits to your Body growing stronger, you suppose. After a while, you manage to get your Mind under control and settle down to look inwards. It doesn‚Äôt take you long today before you have a reasonable awareness of that inner glow to match your outer one; you just try to hold onto it as long as possible. According to your instructor, you‚Äôll need to be able to do this almost unconsciously if you want to be able to use magic in fights - and you do! - since you‚Äôll need that focus to keep a grip on any spells you might have cast. Many minutes pass. You feel a neighboring glow a few times and try to sort of ‚Äúlook over,‚Äù as it were, but get lost somewhere in the transition. You know that you‚Äôll have to figure that part out as well if you want to do anything that affects the Souls of others around you, including the famous Blessings that Angels can bestow on the city‚Äôs population. Speaking of which (thinking of which?), you know what a Blessing actually is now. As far as normal citizens are aware, an Angel‚Äôs Blessing is essentially a mantle of divine protection, capable of curing various ills as well as providing good luck for a few weeks. No one really knows how Angels can do that, but everyone wants to be Blessed. Now you know that it‚Äôs a moderately advanced form of Soul magic - advanced external Soul projection to be specific - that basically involves infusing the target‚Äôs Soul with some of your own divine energy. The practical benefits are mostly the same as what everyone already knows, but now you‚Äôre aware that the good luck actually comes from the target‚Äôs Soul becoming able to nudge the world around it in order to better realize the person‚Äôs true self. A weak and unconscious version of magic, sort of? ‚Äã
10:35 PM
The other thing that Blessings do is purify the corruption. Angels are uniquely able to burn away most forms of the corruption with a touch, and that ability extends to your Soul and the energy it can provide to ordinary people. If someone is in danger of succumbing to the corruption, a Blessing from you can reverse it and protect them for weeks to come. Additionally, there‚Äôs a weaker sort of knock-on effect where the energy leaking out of that Blessed person will heal other Souls they come into contact with, forming almost a kind of herd immunity situation if you collectively Bless enough people. It‚Äôs not enough to make the city immune to the corruption, but combined with humanity‚Äôs innate resistance after God‚Äôs change to your Souls, it‚Äôs enough to dramatically reduce the number of corruptions in the city. Which is good, because people would panic if they knew there were any outside of extremely rare incursions. There‚Äôs a lot that the Cathedra keeps from ordinary citizens. Mostly information about just how thin the razor‚Äôs edge is (that the city is balanced on), and just how imperfect the Angels are (who maintain that balance). (Im)perfection has been a recurring theme in your dreams recently. You don‚Äôt want to talk about it. Or think about it, really. Thankfully, you‚Äôve now been sitting here for long enough that the evening bell rings and releases you from your thoughts. You stand and stretch. No breakthroughs today, but just a little more progress all the same. ‚ÄúFood time,‚Äù Serri announces, getting up as well. ‚ÄúFood time,‚Äù you agree. You spent the last few hours speaking exactly four words each, so now you‚Äôve got to make up some of that difference. So it seems, at least. Serri‚Äôs really warmed up to you over the last two weeks; she‚Äôs much less shy around you and much more likely to chat about anything that‚Äôs on her Mind. Or yours, as she‚Äôs often curious. ‚Äã
10:36 PM
‚ÄúI ran into Naoriel today,‚Äù she says as you make your way out of the gardens. The mist is turning golden with sunset. ‚ÄúYou too? Did she say anything?‚Äù ‚ÄúJust a quick hello. She‚Äôs always running off whenever I try to talk.‚Äù ‚ÄúYeah, I think that‚Äôs just how she is.‚Äù A beat. ‚ÄúWait, do you not run into her all the time here? I figured maybe it was the basic magic one, but Denn told me it isn‚Äôt running right now, so I guess she took it last year with him and the third years.‚Äù Serri cocks her head. ‚ÄúNo? I kind of thought she‚Äôd be taking it with us.‚Äù ‚ÄúHuh? But she hasn‚Äôt mentioned that at all, and Erich would have said something otherwise, right?‚Äù ‚ÄúHe does have that weird grudge against her...‚Äù You both stay quiet for a few moments, pondering. ‚ÄúShe can‚Äôt just not take it,‚Äù you decide. ‚ÄúI mean, you can‚Äôt be a good Angel without some magic.‚Äù ‚ÄúMaybe she is going to take it with us, but just isn‚Äôt saying anything? I mean, she does really like to keep secrets.‚Äù ‚ÄúWell, yeah, but it‚Äôs not like she can hide taking a course from the people who are also taking that same course with her. 10:36 PM

Mxblah 11/24/2023 5:31 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 24 On your way back to Hearth Hall, you spot a familiar figure emerging from one of the smaller cathedrals nearby. ‚ÄúBe right back,‚Äù you tell Serri, then jog over to catch up with Brother Cobb before he can get away. ‚ÄúJessamine?‚Äù he says by way of greeting, slowing his pace somewhat. He doesn‚Äôt really need to - he may have longer legs, but he‚Äôs old and doesn‚Äôt move very fast - but it‚Äôs the thought that counts. ‚ÄúBrother Cobb! I was just doing some Soul training with Serri and I wanted to ask who‚Äôs actually going to be in your magic course in June?‚Äù ‚ÄúHum? At the moment, only Mr Haskell is signed up. Why do you ask; are you concerned about the two of you getting in?‚Äù You nod, though that‚Äôs mostly a lie if you‚Äôre being honest with yourself. You‚Äôre already well on track, according to your instructor, and Serri isn‚Äôt far behind. Really, you just wanted to know if Naoriel was signed up. She doesn‚Äôt glow, so she should have been with Erich (‚ÄúMr Haskell‚Äù) if she was enrolled. Brother Cobb smiles patiently. ‚ÄúI have faith that God will guide both of you in time. I‚Äôve been told you are already making good progress and that Ms Ambrose has begun to show improvement. Persevere and you will succeed.‚Äù It seems to be kind of a toss-up what mood Brother Cobb is in whenever you talk to him. He can be pretty grouchy, like on your first day with the paperwork and course selection, but he can also be patient and gentle, like right now. You feel a little bad for sort-of-almost lying to him, but not quite bad enough to say anything besides ‚Äú... Yeah, you‚Äôre right. It‚Äôs just the timing seems so tight... it‚Äôs okay, we‚Äôll make it.‚Äù ‚ÄúIndeed. Was there anything else? I do need to return to-‚Äù ‚ÄúTh-that‚Äôs it. Thanks; see you in June!‚Äù You rush off and return to Serri, who looks back curiously as you arrive. ‚ÄúWhat was that about?‚Äù ‚Äã
5:31 PM
‚ÄúI just... saw an opportunity. We were talking about Naoriel taking Cobb‚Äôs course, right? So I asked him who‚Äôs going to be in it, and she isn‚Äôt.‚Äù Serri frowns thoughtfully. ‚ÄúWell, I really don‚Äôt know what she‚Äôs doing then. You can‚Äôt take any of the advanced magic courses until you‚Äôve taken the basic one. Maybe she‚Äôs just not doing any magic at all? But that seems crazy; you‚Äôd be missing out on a huge part of being an Angel!‚Äù ‚ÄúAnd she doesn‚Äôt glow,‚Äù you add. ‚ÄúSo she must have done at least some Soul training.‚Äù ‚ÄúYeah...‚Äù Well, you learned a little more, but the fact remains that neither of you have any real idea what‚Äôs up with Naoriel and she‚Äôs not going to tell you. And if you dig too much deeper into this, you‚Äôre going to seem obsessed. Maybe you should cool off a little and think about this again later. It‚Äôs probably none of your business, anyway. The two of you meet up with Yara for dinner, and Etalyn shows up not long after. She‚Äôs been hanging around your little group more often since Yara‚Äôs latest face-off against her, though you‚Äôre of course taking Serri‚Äôs word for it that this is a change. She‚Äôs still a little intimidating and a little brusque, but you don‚Äôt think she actually dislikes you. It does make it a little tough to talk to Yara when she shows up, though, since he‚Äôs usually distracted trying to impress her with some new trick or another. She usually rolls her eyes or otherwise doesn‚Äôt seem impressed, but she does keep coming back. You‚Äôre pretty sure at this point that they actually are friends, though neither of them seem willing to actually admit that - Etalyn says he‚Äôs too ridiculous, while Yara says she‚Äôs too cool. Well, whatever. You and Serri agree on this one. ‚Äã
5:32 PM
After dinner, you head upstairs to work on your reading for Trigg. It‚Äôs usually interesting enough that you don‚Äôt have any issue finishing on time, and today isn‚Äôt any different: it‚Äôs all about the great year-zero cataclysm. There aren‚Äôt many surviving physical records from the time, but some Angels did survive the disaster and passed on their memories of the event to scribes later. You assume some regular people also survived, but civilization wasn‚Äôt in any condition to properly take care of written records until well after any mortal survivors would have died of old age. Unfortunately, these Angels‚Äô testimonies are all contradictory. Some describe an overwhelming army of darkness assaulting every major city at once, while others recall a single blast of corrupting force, and still others claim the very earth rose up against humanity. It‚Äôs unclear whether these differences were present in the original testimonies or if they were introduced later, and modern historians can‚Äôt just go ask these Angels to check; they all died fighting the corruption before year 200. You pause there, thinking again about your own lifespan. Immortality. You will not die of old age or disease, but you will still die. No Angel has avoided death forever; the oldest on record lived over six centuries before perishing to their own magic in a catastrophic backfire. Your immortality will extend your life, but it also guarantees that it will end in violence. Passing away peacefully in your sleep is not an option; you will die on the battlefield. Whether that be to a darkness creature‚Äôs claws, a Shade‚Äôs blade, or your own magic, you don‚Äôt know. Just that it will happen someday, unless the corruption is purified and the world made safe. ‚Äã
5:32 PM
That promise still feels unreal to you. You‚Äôre still twelve years old; you still look and feel like an (admittedly not very ordinary) kid growing up at an ordinary rate. Maybe it‚Äôll really start to sink in once you stop aging, when you can look in the mirror one day and a decade later and see the exact same face looking back. Maybe it‚Äôll suddenly make sense when you first leave the city and come face to face with the darkness in the wastes. Maybe you‚Äôll never understand until you lie bleeding out on the packed-hard wasteland dirt, begging for God to save you. ... You get up and pace around your room. That last image is a little too morbid for you; where did that come from? After a minute‚Äôs break, you successfully stop thinking about it, shoving the thoughts about your immortality into the same mental compartment as the ones about perfection, fighting for real, and other hefty worries. You‚Äôll get around to figuring them out in a more productive manner later. For now, you gotta learn your history. [Weeks later...] - You agreed to help Yara with a somewhat-sketchy endeavor. - You agreed to help Clarity with a somewhat-sketchy endeavor. - You agreed to help Naoriel with a somewhat-sketchy endeavor. - You didn‚Äôt agree to any of this, because you‚Äôre a good Angel who would never break a rule! Mxblah 11/26/2023 5:17 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 25 It‚Äôs now late April. The mist is growing thinner as spring trundles on towards summer. Temperatures are getting warmer and many Angels are going around with their outer coats partially unbuttoned. You have been training at the Cathedra for almost two months. Naoriel still remains a mystery; you haven‚Äôt made much progress since mid-March. You did end up asking her about the basic magic course during lunch one day - and she did admit that she wasn‚Äôt planning on taking it in June - but she stopped short of explaining what she was going to do instead. You pushed a little, but all she did was produce a little shower of glittery sparks from her finger and say she‚Äôd be fine. So clearly she‚Äôd already had some training from somewhere, but you don‚Äôt know where or why. Well, whatever; you‚Äôve got plenty of your own work to focus on. You‚Äôve made some real progress on your glow in the past month; you‚Äôre now able to suppress it entirely for several minutes at a time before the strain gets to be too much and you have to release it again. Your instructor says you should be able to get permanent control in another few weeks as long as you practice, so you‚Äôve regularly been doing just that, flickering on and off like a broken lightbulb whenever you have the strength. It turns out that imposing control over your glow actually works similarly to real magic - it‚Äôs all just directing your Soul in various ways - so working on suppressing it like this is exercising your magic-casting ‚Äúmuscles.‚Äù That means you‚Äôve regularly been suffering from the scarily-named ‚ÄúSoul fatigue‚Äù as you constantly overdo it in your impatience. It‚Äôs not as bad as it sounds, though; you just struggle to feel emotions and motivation until your Soul recovers some energy. There‚Äôs no serious concern for your health; you‚Äôre not practiced enough to drain your Soul to the point of doing real damage. ‚Äã
5:17 PM
Granted, it doesn‚Äôt feel good and the motivation part can be a real issue, but by and large you‚Äôre doing okay. There‚Äôs also a huge sense of accomplishment as you can literally measure your Soul growing stronger every day: how long you can keep the glow off. It‚Äôs even starting to seem a little more natural to not be glowing, and according to your instructor, it‚Äôll eventually be effortless either way. The strain right now is because you‚Äôre ‚Äúmolding‚Äù your Soul to your Body, but once it fits properly, you‚Äôll be able to switch back and forth with no stress. Serri is having more trouble than you - she can only manage a few seconds - but she can turn off her glow now! Brother Cobb has provisionally added you both to his course, though he cautions that you should still work hard to get to that effortless stage before June. You don‚Äôt want to have to expend focus and energy on both your Soul and the magic you‚Äôre trying to cast. So, what does all this have to do with the imposing metal door you‚Äôre standing in front of, brightening your glow to read the number on it? Well... it‚Äôs the wrong door anyway, so not much. But the right door... ‚ÄúSay, Jessamine,‚Äù Yara had asked a few days ago as you were working together on a pretty hefty assignment for Brother Trigg. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre making exemplary progress on your Soul control and, if I recall, you‚Äôre quite interested in magic.‚Äù ‚Äú... Yes?‚Äù ‚ÄúWell, I have a major practical coming up for my Soul course and I really could use an assistant to help with the experiment. It‚Äôs nothing difficult; I just don‚Äôt have enough hands for all the equipment. I don‚Äôt suppose you‚Äôd be willing to assist?‚Äù Of course you were willing; he‚Äôd been helping with your assignment at that very moment anyway. But after some more explanation as to what the experiment actually did, you started to wonder if it was actually sanctioned by his instructor. The plan seemed a little... ambitious. ‚Äã
5:18 PM
Well, despite your nagging doubts, you‚Äôre here now - or you would be, if you could find the right door. The basement of Illim Hall is a labyrinth of strange metal hallways, most either dimly lit with mechanical lamps on their lowest setting or completely dark due to the sensitivity of the experiments. Apparently light is a major component in many Soul-related mechanisms, which makes its control a high priority. It sure makes the place extremely creepy, though, as you nervously walk down long, quiet corridors in near-darkness. At least this proves another use for your glow. B...46. This is the right door. You knock and hear a muffled ‚Äúcome in,‚Äù so you do. Thankfully, the room itself is well-lit and Yara quickly emerges from a tangle of complicated-looking prisms and mirrors suspended by metal rods. ‚ÄúJessamine, welcome to my lair!‚Äù He cackles for a moment, then leans down in a quieter voice. ‚ÄúOr rather, my lab. The Cathedra‚Äôs lab, really. Which I am using. Is this your first time down here?‚Äù ‚ÄúY-yes. It‚Äôs... very dark.‚Äù ‚ÄúAh ha! Imagine coming down here late at night to check on a long-running experiment. Total silence; no one around; utter darkness. They turn off even the dim lights at night, you know. Once heard someone else opening a door at two in the morning and just about ran right back out.‚Äù You shiver, imagining it as requested. ‚ÄúAt least, I assume it was someone else and not a ghost. Anyway, I‚Äôm just about ready to get started here, so let me explain what this is supposed to do.‚Äù ‚Äã
5:18 PM
You carefully follow him further into the room, looking around as you do. There‚Äôs a simple wooden stool sitting in the middle of a chalk-drawn circle decorated with many geometric symbols, including the matan in several configurations. Nearby is an odd box again covered in symbols, with a protrusion facing the chair and several openings on the opposite side. The assembly of prisms and mirrors is close behind the box, and you note a number of flexible-armed mechanical lamps carefully arranged just behind that. ‚ÄúThis apparatus is designed to visibly reveal Souls!‚Äù Yara states theatrically, waving his hand at the mess. ‚ÄúWorry not about the details - for if you understood them already, I would feel terribly incompetent - but the basic idea is that light comes in here-‚Äù He points at the mechanical lamps. ‚Äú-passes through here-‚Äù A gesture to the prisms, mirrors, and box. ‚Äú-and reveals the Soul of the target on the chair, there.‚Äù ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt know you could do... magic(?) with things like this.‚Äù ‚ÄúWell, the mechanisms don‚Äôt provide any of the actual Soul energy; they merely focus it in a way that‚Äôs precise enough to be near-impossible to do manually. Almost every portion of this apparatus has been infused by me in some way or another to alter its properties, so please be very careful not to touch anything.‚Äù Thankfully, you already had been. - Hang on, isn‚Äôt this Soul transmutation? Isn‚Äôt that super not allowed? - Okay, sounds good; let‚Äôs do it! Ô∏è - Yara wants you to manipulate the controls. - Yara wants you to sit in the chair. (Winners: , Ô∏è ) (edited)

@Story Notifications Scene 26 ‚ÄúAnyway, enough about that,‚Äù he declares, leading you around to a small selection of levers haphazardly connected to the box and the lights. ‚ÄúI‚Äôd like you to operate the controls, if you please. There‚Äôs no better way to prove your faith in a procedure than to use it on yourself. Besides, there‚Äôs no way I would consider putting someone else in that chair before I‚Äôve proven it 100% safe.‚Äù ‚ÄúS-so you‚Äôre not, er 100% sure that-‚Äù ‚ÄúNothing is ever certain!‚Äù He gets a little more serious for a moment. ‚ÄúReally, it‚Äôs not going to do anything bad. The energy levels in play are simply too low to hurt me, even if something were to malfunction catastrophically. 10:02 PM
‚ÄúThe part that people really disapprove of is when you start making permanent changes. Extracting, splicing, transferring, and - worst of all - trying to manipulate a Soul‚Äôs connection to God. Alright, suppress your glow and pull lever one, please.‚Äù ‚ÄúG-glow? Oh, right.‚Äù That makes sense; having your Soul light up the experiment to see Souls might interfere a bit. It takes you some time, but you eventually get it turned off (for a few minutes, at least). Now, lever one. You grasp it, glance up at Yara one more time, then carefully pull it down. Two of the lamps turn on and the box begins to hum. Nothing else seems to happen. ‚ÄúHmm, mm hm...‚Äù Yara peers towards the other box he previously flipped open, then scribbles something down and nods. ‚ÄúLever two, please.‚Äù ‚Äã
10:02 PM
You comply. Two more lamps turn on and the box‚Äôs hum lowers in pitch. You start to feel a little uncomfortable, as if your bones are rattling, but it‚Äôs not any worse than standing near the train tracks when a heavy locomotive is rushing by. Yara appears to be glittering now; he looks at the back of his hand curiously. Another check with the open box, another scribble. Actually, the air between him and the light box seems to be glittering too; it‚Äôs not just his Body. ‚ÄúLever three, please.‚Äù ‚Äú...‚Äù Lever three it is. The last three lamps turn on and the box‚Äôs hum drops in pitch again to the point where you can‚Äôt hear it anymore. You feel an uncomfortable pressure on your eardrums, but it lightens up when you swallow. ‚Äú... Yara?‚Äù ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs fine; it‚Äôs fine.‚Äù The glittering hasn‚Äôt changed, but as he quickly notes down some more observations, you can tell he‚Äôs not completely comfortable either. His brow is a little furrowed; he‚Äôs moving with a little bit of strain. You eye the ‚ÄúX‚Äù lever, but don‚Äôt touch it yet. ‚ÄúFourth lever, please.‚Äù That‚Äôs the last one. You pull it. No more lamps light, but two of them change color subtly enough that, on second thought, you‚Äôre not entirely sure they actually changed. The box clanks softly, then returns to a loud silence. You dry-swallow several times to relieve the pressure on your ears. Yara... doesn‚Äôt look any different, really. The glittering has faded somewhat and you can‚Äôt see anything that‚Äôs obviously his Soul. He checks the side box one more time, writes down a few more things, then shakes his head. ‚ÄúDarn. I don‚Äôt suppose you see anything? No? Alright, shut it down, if you would.‚Äù You‚Äôre fairly relieved to pull the ‚ÄúX‚Äù lever, watching the lamps shut off and the box‚Äôs sound climb back up into audible range before slowing to a truly silent stop. No more bone rattling or pressure spikes; everything‚Äôs back to normal. ‚ÄúJessamine, I do apologize for that resonance. You aren‚Äôt injured, right?‚Äù ‚Äã
10:02 PM
You don‚Äôt think so. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm okay. Are... you?‚Äù ‚ÄúFine, fine. I believe the introduction of a test subject in the path of the beam must have caused some reflection... Perhaps I should design a shield of some sort. But, I suppose that hardly matters as it, well, did not work. To put it bluntly.‚Äù The strain is getting too much. ‚ÄúYara, I have to start glowing again. Is that safe in here?‚Äù ‚ÄúYes; all the equipment is turned off. Glimmering, lustrous golden light pours from your Body and competes with the sterile ceiling lamps to illuminate the room. You know he‚Äôs examining the situation from within, searching for a cause or a solution by ‚Äúlooking‚Äù at your Souls directly instead of the physical light they‚Äôre giving off, but it‚Äôs still hard to accept that he‚Äôs not just standing there doing nothing. ... You could try the same. There‚Äôs nothing else for you to do, so you give it a shot, gazing inwards to see if you can discover what happened to your Soul. Confusion. A mess of swirling golden and silver. Instability; you‚Äôre unstable. Something isn‚Äôt in the right state. What? You? It‚Äôs hard to tell anything in the- You jolt, feeling a slight chill. 10:02 PM
‚ÄúWell. That was unexpected.‚Äù [This is a critical point. One character‚Äôs fate will be altered.] - Don‚Äôt tell anyone (like Brother Cobb!) what happened. Mxblah 11/30/2023 9:11 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 27 ... Yara didn‚Äôt want to tell anyone what happened. The experiment might have been approved, he said, but the results certainly weren‚Äôt. Things could get out of hand. Inquisitors were mentioned. But, eventually, you convince him. You‚Äôre worried about what happened to your Souls. Turning them gold? What does that even mean? You could be corrupted or damaged or have some horrible illness that could grow worse over time and end up harming not only yourselves, but anyone nearby. What if it‚Äôs contagious? You could infect the whole Cathedra before anyone catches it! So he agreed to explain what happened, but not to just anyone. Only to his instructor. Unfortunately, his instructor isn‚Äôt an Angel and thus can‚Äôt mend Souls. Someone else had to be called. And that‚Äôs why you‚Äôre now sitting here in a cold, sterile examination room in Illim Hall, all alone and waiting for someone to show up and tell you if you‚Äôll be okay. A knock on the door. You‚Äôre not prepared, but you say ‚Äúcome in‚Äù anyway. You feel like you‚Äôre six years old again, back in that hospital as your breath caught and your lungs ached. What will be wrong with you this time? A female Angel enters, wearing the same white uniform as everyone else. Ghostly pale hair that seems to drift as if it‚Äôs lighter than it should be. A pair of glorious, beautiful white wings folded tightly against her back. An Archangel. ‚ÄúGood afternoon, Jessamine. My name is Aveline; I‚Äôm just here to make sure you aren‚Äôt hurt. How are you feeling?‚Äù ‚Äú...‚Äù You have to say something. ‚ÄúFine.‚Äù She smiles gently, like she understands. ‚ÄúYara is fine, by the way. No sign of any Soul instability. I‚Äôm sure you‚Äôll be no different.‚Äù Well, that‚Äôs good, at least. 9:11 PM
‚Äú... Okay.‚Äù You have no hope of trying to keep your Mind clear just by thinking about it, so you take her advice and start counting up at a steady rate. After a dozen numbers, you realize you‚Äôve unconsciously synchronized each number with a beat of your heart. It‚Äôs a little fast. Aveline takes a deep breath and releases it measuredly. Then, you feel a presence. It‚Äôs somewhat like when Serri touches your Soul during your training together, but the touch is both lighter and more deliberate. You feel a sense of closeness to this Angel you‚Äôve never met before; not necessarily a sense of friendliness or any sort of emotional relationship, but just a sense that you know her. Even though you, well, don‚Äôt. Still, the sensation calms you somewhat even though you know it‚Äôs not real. Someone you know like this couldn‚Äôt possibly do anything bad to you. Sunlight. Warmth from every angle. You could be outside and the fog burnt away for how warm you feel. It‚Äôs - you jolt, shivering with a sudden icy chill. It disturbs you so much that you lose track of your count and physically recoil. ‚ÄúWh-what was that?‚Äù The Archangel steps back as well. ‚ÄúHm. Don‚Äôt be worried; it‚Äôs nothing major.‚Äù You‚Äôre worried. She has to guess. You‚Äôll demand it if she doesn‚Äôt. ‚ÄúIt does seem very recent. You‚Äôve been training very hard lately, haven‚Äôt you?‚Äù ‚ÄúMy... glow. I‚Äôm - I have to suppress it before June...‚Äù ‚Äã
9:11 PM
‚ÄúAhhh.‚Äù She smiles again, seeming to almost cast a physical glow with the emotional warmth. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre very diligent, Jessamine. I believe your Soul may have simply been fatigued enough that, when hit by that energy today, it twisted just a little.‚Äù ‚ÄúBut Y-Yara... he‚Äôs definitely okay? Nothing like this?‚Äù ‚ÄúPromise. He‚Äôs not training as hard as you, it seems.‚Äù ‚Äú... C-can you fix it?‚Äù ‚ÄúOh, of course! It‚Äôs no issue at all. I‚Äôm one of the most proficient Soul channelers alive; I‚Äôve reconstructed Souls burned down to almost nothing. You‚Äôre in good hands, I promise.‚Äù You can only nod. ‚ÄúOkay, let‚Äôs get you all better, shall we? Can you go ahead and lie down for me?
