Just in case, maybe, she‚Äôll tell the truth. ‚ÄúWill, uh, will this hurt?‚Äù Aveline looks you in the eyes. ‚ÄúNo, not at all. You won‚Äôt feel a thing; promise.‚Äù ‚Äú...‚Äù You wake up a minute later, confused but - as promised - not in any pain. ‚ÄúWh-wha...?‚Äù ‚ÄúCalm, calm. Don‚Äôt move for a minute, please. You‚Äôre all done; you did very well.‚Äù ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs... fixed?‚Äù ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre all better. Just please slow down a little on your training. Your dedication is very admirable, but exhausting your Soul every day will take its toll.‚Äù ‚ÄúBut... the deadline...‚Äù ‚ÄúBrother Cobb will understand, I‚Äôm sure. I‚Äôll put in a word with him personally, okay?‚Äù ‚ÄúOkay...‚Äù After a few more minutes of recovery, you‚Äôre feeling good enough to leave. Aveline leads you out to a sitting room where Yara is waiting, then waves farewell and returns into the depths of the hall. ‚ÄúJessamine! Goodness, that took much longer than I expected. You‚Äôre looking... slumpy? Was there - oh dear, was there a problem?‚Äù ‚Äã
9:12 PM
You tell him. He apologizes again and again for getting you involved in this, until you tell him to stop. ‚ÄúYara, it‚Äôs okay. I‚Äôm fine, and you‚Äôre fine, and everyone is fine. And-‚Äù You‚Äôre starting to recover some energy. ‚Äú-you get to turn in a really impressive project report, right?‚Äù He chuckles halfheartedly. ‚ÄúYou could say that.‚Äù That night, you nearly drop your toothbrush when you remember exactly who the Archangel had promised to talk to. You had been disoriented and confused, and agreed out of reflex. Brother Cobb. Oh, no. By the next morning, Yara‚Äôs instructor has been fired, removed from the campus without a trace. Yara‚Äôs lab and equipment has been confiscated. His course unceremoniously terminated. And - he finds you at lunch to catch up - a very stern bishop sat him down and frankly informed him that he was to stop all investigations into Soul transmutation immediately, or else. Not a request. Hardly even a demand. A threat. ‚ÄúUntil you possess the required experience,‚Äù the bishop had said. ‚ÄúWe may revisit this decision in a decade or so.‚Äù ‚ÄúWell,‚Äù he concludes, putting a brave face on it. ‚ÄúAs you said, at least no one got hurt.‚Äù ‚ÄúNot... physically, at least. Your instructor...‚Äù ‚ÄúYes... that does, admittedly, upset me a tad.‚Äù He‚Äôs drumming his fingers on the table, distracted. ‚ÄúSister Bagley apparently ‚Äòdid not have the authority to approve such experiments,‚Äô so said the bishop. @Story Notifications Scene 28 By evening bell, rumors about the incident have become widespread. No one seems sure about the full details, but Sister Bagley‚Äôs firing isn‚Äôt exactly something that can be kept quiet. People are whispering about you behind your back; you just know it. ‚ÄúEr, sure?‚Äù You let Clarity hold your hand for almost ten seconds as she focuses. You know what she‚Äôs doing, roughly; she‚Äôs forming a connection between her Soul manifested in phase with the Body aspect, and your Body. Er, sort of. You‚Äôre pretty sure? Anyway, you know that Angels need to physically touch someone in order to affect their Body with magic, so that‚Äôs what‚Äôs happening right now. ‚ÄúAnd done!‚Äù You feel a brief tingle, then not much else. ‚ÄúHere, take a look!‚Äù Clarity has a mirror, because of course she does. You already have an idea what you‚Äôre going to see, but it‚Äôs still a bit of a shock to see Jessamine the human looking back instead of Jessamine the Angel. You‚Äôre still recognizably yourself, but you look like the ordinary kid you used to be instead of the beautiful Angel you are now. The fact that you did the ribbon wrong is now much more obvious. Darn. ‚Äú...‚Äù ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt worry, the real you is still under there; it‚Äôs just an illusion! It‚Äôll run out on its own after about an hour if I don‚Äôt recharge it, too, so we‚Äôre going to need to be careful to remember that.‚Äù Yara peers at the top of your head. ‚ÄúI think you may have missed... oh, no, nevermind. This is impressive work, Clarity. I didn‚Äôt know you were capable of holding an external transmutation like this.‚Äù She beams at him. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve been practicing just for this! I still think it‚Äôs unfair illusions like this aren‚Äôt projections, but if you want the tactile feeling...‚Äù ‚ÄúOh yes, I can relate! A real hassle. Speaking of, is Denn actually capable of disguising himself like this? He‚Äôs only a second year; I didn‚Äôt know they were teaching it so early.‚Äù ‚ÄúHe is! For reasons! Hehe!‚Äù ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre a real nutcase, you know.‚Äù She winks, but does not elaborate on the ‚Äúreasons.‚Äù ‚Äã
10:00 PM
The three of you hang out for another few minutes, watching various Angels come and go. Some are in uniform, but many others aren‚Äôt; some are even disguised as humans in a similar way to you. It‚Äôs a little hard to tell who‚Äôs actually an Angel like this, but according to Yara, the disguise doesn‚Äôt work on the Soul so it‚Äôs still obvious to him. You‚Äôll have to get better. Denn arrives not long after in a moderately more modest outfit: a tan vest over a cream shirt and standard dark brown trousers, like any ordinary banker would wear in the city. He doesn‚Äôt quite fit in with your group, but a quick addition of a vibrant tie-like thing (you‚Äôre not sure what it‚Äôs called; it‚Äôs not quite a real tie) and another ribbon from Clarity somehow ties (heh) you all together with a splash of bright color. Now he looks more like a banker‚Äôs rich son, which probably works better if you‚Äôre going to all go out together. After that, Clarity leads the way towards one of the Cathedra‚Äôs outer gates and your first visit to the outside world in two whole months. You know she has a whole mysterious ‚Äúsomething special‚Äù planned for the day, but... maybe you‚Äôll have some extra time? ‚Äç‚Äç‚Äç - Plan to visit your family today. Try to make some time. ‚Äç‚Äç - Stay with the group; don‚Äôt worry about it. You haven‚Äôt planned anything and realistically don‚Äôt even know if they‚Äôll be home! @Story Notifications Scene 32 You‚Äôre not sure. It might be a stretch to think you can visit your family today - you had no idea you‚Äôd be leaving the Cathedra and thus haven‚Äôt planned ahead to even know where they‚Äôll be - but it has been two months. You‚Äôd like to. Well, maybe you‚Äôll just see what Clarity has in store first and then see if you can make some time later. Founding Day isn‚Äôt too far away, anyway, so it should only be another month at most even if today doesn‚Äôt work out. A whole month more, huh... ‚ÄúFour Angels heading out for the day,‚Äù Clarity tells the armored guards by the gate. One of them checks each of your disguises, doing a quick once-over to make sure your Angelic appearance isn‚Äôt visible and that your clothes feel real. That‚Äôs why you couldn‚Äôt just change your clothes in an illusion the same way as your Body, Clarity told you earlier. It‚Äôs really hard to change the shape of something to that degree in a way that feels convincing, so you‚Äôd basically just be stuck with an outfit that looks like an Angel uniform but in a different color or material. Not particularly discreet. Very experienced Angels could pull it off regardless, but it‚Äôs so much easier to just wear regular clothes. ‚ÄúLooks good,‚Äù the guard says. ‚ÄúSoul check, please?‚Äù You‚Äôre not sure what he means until the other three begin to softly glow, displaying their Souls through light. Talk about tight timing. ‚ÄúGood, good. 6:35 PM

It‚Äôs a warm spring day by now and the fog is light, but your vision is still limited to just a few blocks. 6:35 PM

@Story Notifications Scene 35 Denn walks ahead of you, alongside Clarity, and directs her to the right streets. At least, that‚Äôs what you assume is happening as he gently guides her towards or away from certain turns. Odd, you thought he didn‚Äôt know where you were going either. Well, whatever, it‚Äôs not like you‚Äôre going to get a straight answer out of them. The area here has seen better days, but it‚Äôs not falling apart just yet. Most of the buildings around are three or four story brick boxes, stained with years of wear and tear but still in generally decent shape. Most seem to be offices or mixed with commercial on the bottom floor, but as you continue along, you start to deviate away from the main streets into narrower alleyways with residential-looking midrises shadowing the foggy sky. Here, Denn starts to pay more attention and often pauses a few beats at each intersection before continuing. Clarity seems content to follow a few paces behind without saying much. There are occasional people around, but not many. Most citizens are out near district centers for the holiday, so those who remain tend to be those too old, young, or infirm to move around easily. The four of you definitely stand out more now, but no one seems to pay much attention regardless. The Inquisitor left, Lemuel helped me gather my things, and off I went. It could have been a complete coincidence that my dad‚Äôs company was hiring clerks this week!‚Äù ‚ÄúBut it wasn‚Äôt,‚Äù Yara asserts. ‚ÄúWell... no...‚Äù ‚ÄúSo you see, I‚Äôm doing alright here, Yara. I‚Äôm truly sorry I put you in danger.‚Äù ‚ÄúOh, no, no; I should be apologizing for getting Jessamine involved-‚Äù You did, you think, but don‚Äôt interrupt him. ‚Äú- but the experiment itself was sound. 4:58 PM

@Story Notifications Scene 36 ... No, you don‚Äôt buy that. Not entirely. God may have a plan, but He wasn‚Äôt the one to fire Sister Bagley. He chooses Angels, but humans confirm them. All three aspects of the self are linked and each can affect the others, though the Soul is the most resistant to change of the three. It‚Äôs not easy to fall into corruption just from a debilitating illness or a heavy depression - if it were, you probably would have during your stay at the hospital - but... it is possible. @Story Notifications Scene 37 Today is Monday, June 3rd, Founding Day, and you aren‚Äôt pleased about it. Well, the day itself is fine - and the fact that you and Serri are about to start your basic magic course is even better - but did Brother Cobb have to start it today? 9:46 PM

@Story Notifications Scene 38 You internally sigh and resolve to give him another chance. This week should be enough, you think. Instead, you will simply get close and, with a physical touch, allow your Soul to touch as well. @Story Notifications Scene 39 Ah, maybe it‚Äôs... ‚ÄúIs it the ability to be corrupted?‚Äù you say uncertainly. ‚ÄúHm? Can you elaborate?‚Äù Oh no. ‚ÄúW-well, people can be corrupted and turn into darkness creatures, and so can animals. They don‚Äôt become darkness creatures because they aren‚Äôt creatures at all, but when you have seen the wastelands and the pitiful plants that reside within them, you will understand the scale of the planetary corruption against us.‚Äù ‚ÄúOh...‚Äù Erich looks kinda smug. Jerk; at least you tried. Wait, you‚Äôre supposed to be being nice. ‚ÄúApologies,‚Äù Brother Cobb continues after a few moments. ‚ÄúBut it was somewhat of a trick question. They‚Äôre made of the same type of matter; we just classify them differently for convenient spell grouping, as the techniques needed to work with (usually) people are significantly different than those needed to work with inanimate objects.‚Äù ‚ÄúWait, there‚Äôs... no difference? But you can‚Äôt... a train isn‚Äôt a Body; you can‚Äôt live as a train!‚Äù Now you just want answers; you‚Äôre not worried about what Erich thinks of you. ‚ÄúWhy not?‚Äù ‚ÄúEr-‚Äù Is this a trick question too? 1:40 PM
‚ÄúTrue. And it‚Äôs true that objects do not have Minds and do not live in the same way as humans do.‚Äù Cobb refocuses, preparing to actually explain what he means. You hope, at least. ‚ÄúThere is no difference at the base level, but objects and Bodies do have a main difference outside of their aspect. Minds, for whatever reason, tend to attach to living Bodies. And Souls, of course, can only attach to human Bodies due to their respective shapes as reflections of God. Inanimate objects do not naturally attract or form Minds or Souls. So, if one were to draw a distinction, the best theoretical one would likely be ‚Äòliving things are Bodies, while inanimate things are objects.‚Äô But, of course, you‚Äôve already noted that plants are considered objects instead of Bodies even though they are alive.‚Äù You nod, about to bring that up as a counterpoint. ‚ÄúThe truth is, we simply don‚Äôt know. It could be that Minds prefer or arise from living Bodies that can move and act independently, and plants are too simple and stationary to need one. It could be that plants do have Minds, but they‚Äôre too small or weak for even the most powerful of Angels to see them. It could be that we‚Äôve misunderstood some fundamental aspect of creation and God has even more discoveries in store for us. That‚Äôs what being on the forefront of magical advancement is about. You three might be the ones to finally figure out the answer to this or any number of other mysteries about the world around us. And any of these mysteries might hold the key to defeating the corruption once and for all.‚Äù Woah. Despite yourself, you feel a little inspired. Maybe you will figure ou - wait a minute. Cobb can talk up searching for truth all he wants, but you know what the Cathedra really thinks about people making new magical discoveries. Yara disciplined and threatened; Sister Bagley fired and left to the streets outside. Make the right discoveries and maybe you‚Äôll be praised like he‚Äôs saying. But make the wrong ones... ‚Äã
1:41 PM
‚ÄúUm, you said... objects don‚Äôt naturally form Minds... Does that mean one could do that... unnaturally?‚Äù You and Erich look at Serri, surprised. You hadn‚Äôt even noticed that bit; you‚Äôd been too busy thinking about the classifications. Even Brother Cobb seems a little startled. ‚ÄúMm. Perhaps. We got the idea from the corruption‚Äôs shades. Creatures with Minds, somehow evading God‚Äôs sacrifice to prevent the darkness from ever thinking again. It‚Äôs very difficult to study them, as you might expect, but it appears that shades are not born naturally and are formed by attaching a Mind to a Mindless darkness creature. At least, most of the time. Well, some of the time. It has happened, at least. So the current idea is that moving a Mind between a Body and an object is theoretically possible, but no one has yet proven it. Magic like this would be Mind transmutation of the highest order, and would face enormous resistance from the Body, Mind, and Soul templates of both the target and recipient. And of course, we have no idea what it would do to a human, so experimenting with anything besides animals is completely forbidden.‚Äù ‚ÄúYou said ‚Äòsome of the time‚Äô - how are shades normally created?‚Äù Brother Cobb sighs, but doesn‚Äôt seem terribly annoyed. ‚ÄúAh, the curiosity of youth. You three have gotten us far off track now and we‚Äôve almost arrived regardless. Fine, one more, but then we must refocus. Most shades are created from corrupted humans whose Minds don‚Äôt break or wither away with the transformation. Instead, it corrupts just like their Body and they become a creature of darkness with a twisted but ultimately still human Mind. It‚Äôs unknown whether these shades and the ones created artificially have the same type of Mind, but either are still incredibly dangerous.‚Äù You‚Äôve got another question, but he did just say- ‚Äã
1:41 PM
‚ÄúAnd to preempt any further questions, yes, a human Soul can also survive its corruption - though this is enormously rarer than the already rare survival of the Mind. Such darkness creatures with all three aspects come only once in a generation, but they are by far the worst among the corruption, comparable to the strongest Angels in power. You will not have to deal with such creatures for a very long time; the one emergency I‚Äôve witnessed like that was the only time I have seen every Archangel band together at once to destroy it.‚Äù Ah, good. It‚Äôs even worse than you imagined. The train is speeding past endless farmland now, but is beginning to slow as it approaches the last station before the city‚Äôs outermost wall. You‚Äôve never been this close before; hopefully Brother Cobb will give you at least a little time to look around. If he does, you‚Äôd like to explore the... [This is a ranked list, not FPTP] ‚Äç - Farms and intriguing machinery dotting the fields. - Wall and the guard posts atop it. Ô∏è - Track that... passes through the wall? They do that? - Bunker-like structures along the wall‚Äôs interior. - Wastelands themselves. Surely just a few steps outside the wall couldn‚Äôt hurt? Just to get a look? Mxblah 12/26/2023 5:49 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 40 Thankfully, that‚Äôs exactly what happens. Brother Cobb needs to check your group in at the bunker buildings near the wall - apparently that‚Äôs your destination today - so he leaves the three of you in the care of a scarred wasteland soldier in drab brown fatigues. Of course, even as trainee Angels, you outrank the soldier (sort of? It‚Äôs tough to know exactly how the hierarchy works when you‚Äôre outside the Cathedra grounds). In any case, he seems amenable enough to your collective requests to go look at various locations nearby as long as you don‚Äôt run off. The train tracks you had noted earlier do indeed travel all the way through the wall and into the wastelands themselves, your guide tells you. They‚Äôre sealed off from the outside world by a pair of thick metal gates, probably even stronger than the stone wall itself and only operable from the inside. When a train needs to pass through, there must be at minimum two Angels on duty to guard the gates through the entire process. And despite there technically being three of you at the moment, he understandably declines to open them for you now. And why are there trains passing through the wall in the first place? Well... The wastelands are vast, travel is slow, and the air itself is poisonous. While Angels are usually strong enough to survive the poison indefinitely - and can heal the ordinary soldiers who aren‚Äôt - no treatment is perfect and it‚Äôs best for everyone involved to spend as little time out there as possible. Add that to the heavy equipment needed for ruin-delving along with recovering artifacts and you have a situation that only a powerful vehicle can solve. ‚Äã
5:49 PM
The tracks are a constant headache, he admits. Mindless creatures tend to ignore them, but shades are well aware of how important the infrastructure is and will often destroy or sabotage further-out rails. To combat this, scouting groups go ahead of the train convoy to check the condition of tracks and run repairs as needed. But of course, the shades know this too and regularly try to ambush the scouts. It‚Äôs a constant back-and-forth with the railways as main points of conflict. The soldier has heard people are trying to develop a fully mechanical vehicle that doesn‚Äôt need to run on tracks - like a horseless carriage - but so far trains remain the only solution for this particular problem. And then he takes you up onto the wall itself. Not out into the wastelands proper - that‚Äôs far too dangerous to risk you without good reason - but from this vantage point, you can at least see the corruption, in person, for the first time in your life. The fog is thinner here, as you‚Äôve been told. Not gone entirely, but you can see a good distance into the dead, barren emptiness beyond the city. Or... what you thought would be dead, barren emptiness. The land closest to the walls, tracks, and other human-made infrastructure is merely cracked, dry dirt, as you expected. Occasional scorched stains and flakes of ash suggest why it‚Äôs so clear, because the rest of it just... isn‚Äôt. Endless plains of colorful vegetation stretch beyond the fog, browns and greens and purples and blues mixing in twisting, unnatural patterns. Tall, shifting grass sways hypnotically in the light breeze, each gust rippling across the field like a wave. Even a few trees - full trees - stand like sentinels: a broken mirror of the wall itself. The wastelands aren‚Äôt dead and empty; they‚Äôre absolutely teeming with life. But the life is... wrong. Alien. Corrupted, you realize. ‚Äã
5:49 PM
Of course the wastelands wouldn‚Äôt be dead. Humans and animals don‚Äôt die when they‚Äôre corrupted; they become darkness creatures. Plants must do the same. And if Brother Cobb was correct about the ground and objects themselves becoming corrupted... You shift your gaze to the railway tracks, tracing a straight line into the fog. But, as they fade into the distance, does their color change? Do they seem a little less straight? Twisted? Alien? Corrupted? You can‚Äôt tell. And this landscape hates you. You can feel it, like that sensation you get when someone is glaring at you from across the room but a hundred times worse. The wastelands despise you, your divine Soul, and everything you stand for. Every tree, every blade of grass; every single speck of dirt out there wants you to die a horrible, painful death and would be more than willing to do the deed personally if only it had the chance. It‚Äôs such a strong sense of malice that you actually start to get a little worried, even up here on the wall with several trained soldiers only steps away. How could you possibly be expected to go out there? Into such an utterly hostile world? ... If this is what just the plants feel like, how bad will the creatures be? ‚Äã
5:49 PM
You glance to either side to see how your fellow trainees are reacting. Serri on your right doesn‚Äôt seem as freaked out as you would expect, given the situation. She just looks a little uncomfortable, but kind of excited too? Maybe she thinks it‚Äôs pretty even though it‚Äôs clearly evil. Erich on your left also doesn‚Äôt seem as affected as you‚Äôd imagine. Given his reaction to the concept of killing a darkness creature, you‚Äôd expect him to be simmering with hatred against the wastelands themselves, but his expression is fairly neutral. Maybe he already knew? But how could you prepare for a sensation like this, even if you did know ahead of time? You feel like you‚Äôre almost ready to cry; it‚Äôs still battering against you even as you try to distract yourself. Surely you‚Äôre not the only one weak enough to feel it so strongly, right? - Ask the others what they feel and admit what you feel. - Ask the others what they feel, but play down the severity of what you feel. - Is that Brother Cobb on the stairs? You can go back down soon; phew. (Winner: ) (edited)

@Story Notifications Scene 41 ‚ÄúHey, Serri,‚Äù you murmur. ‚ÄúDid you know the wastelands were like this?‚Äù ‚ÄúAll full of life? 3:06 PM

Apparently they‚Äôre all built into the wall itself and some even have doors into the wastelands, which is how they get captured darkness creatures and samples of the corruption somewhere safe for study without having to take them into the city proper. You have to go through a security checkpoint where you‚Äôre required to show your Soul again, then a set of thick metal doors. Now, technically, you are outside of the city. Outside of its main security perimeter, at least. Outside with the wastelands that want to kill you. It kind of looks like Illim Hall‚Äôs basement. Long, windowless hallways with metal doors leading to various secure labs and cells and other rooms. There aren‚Äôt many people here, but the ones who are tend to be either wasteland soldiers or monks in robes that mark them as Cathedra researchers. There aren‚Äôt any Angels visible beyond the two with you, which you suppose does make sense. There are only so many of you to protect the entire city. Even in places like this, having more than two would be too many. In fact, listening to the conversations you pass as you wind through the halls, there would normally only be one Angel here; the second is only to protect you three for your visit. You almost shiver. Are you going to have to be the single guardian of a place like this when you graduate? Everyone relying on just you to fend off the corruption; any mistake you make costing the city enormously? Probably best not to think about that. Finally, you arrive at an inconspicuous metal door just like all the others. Brother Cobb gets serious. Well, more serious than he was already. ‚Äã
3:06 PM
‚ÄúHere we are,‚Äù he says flatly. ‚ÄúThere is a piece of the corruption in that room. You should be able to feel it even from here, if you focus. Breathe in, close your eyes, and... shift. As with most times you use your Soul perception, touch is the sense it seems to resonate with the most. You can feel warmth all around you; three weaker Souls and two strong ones. Your companions, of course. But ahead, muffled through the door but still very much tangible, is an amplified version of that icy chill you felt back when the Archangel was treating you after Yara‚Äôs experiment. Frigid cold and... twisty. Like an icicle melted and refrozen until it forms the shape of a sharpened braid, then slid along your skin so you can feel the razor‚Äôs tip, the pressure just barely too weak to cut you open. It‚Äôs uncomfortable, to say the least, but extremely precise. That twisting sharpness is key to whatever the creature is, you‚Äôre sure of it. ‚ÄúReady?‚Äù Brother Cobb asks, pulling you back to the physical world with his distorted voice. You can still see evidence that it was once a regular canine in its structure, but all the details have melted or shifted or rearranged themselves into an alien form. Several mouths, all growling with a sound you can‚Äôt hear. Extra eyes peering from some of the plates. Wavy, dark red tendrils drifting from its back in a nonexistent air current. The thing looks like it would fit neatly in with the strange, corrupted plants in the wastelands. ‚Äã
7:29 PM
Then, without more than an instant‚Äôs warning as it tenses up, the corrupted wolf hurls itself at the glass with all its strength. There‚Äôs a heavy thud and most of you flinch, but the container holds strong. The beast claws and bites at the glass, leaving streaks of smoking saliva on the barrier. It slams itself against the wall several more times, desperate to get out and tear you apart. It hates you, just like the wastelands themselves. You can‚Äôt feel it as agonizingly strongly, but its actions are proof enough. This creature - without even a Mind with which to do so - hates you. ‚ÄúUnpleasant, isn‚Äôt it?‚Äù Brother Cobb notes dryly. ‚ÄúImagine what the retrieval team had to go through to get this charming specimen back here.‚Äù You imagine it. Yikes. ‚ÄúNow, you might be wondering something else that was absent from the pre-reading I assigned. Mindless creatures of darkness, as the name implies, have no Mind. They cannot think or feel or act in the same way we do. And yet, we teach that ordinary animals - such as the wolf that this creature may have once been - do have Minds, and that those Minds are what separates creatures who can move and act from those that cannot, such as plants. So, how can this Mindless creature display traits that seem to require a Mind? Such as movement, sensory processing, or motivation? Any ideas?‚Äù ‚Ü©Ô∏è - It‚Äôs not Mindless? Mxblah 1/1/2024 5:40 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 43 Erich doesn‚Äôt seem to want to answer questions that he isn‚Äôt confident about getting right. And Serri, despite her frustration, is still looking to you to try first. Well, you do have at least a thought. ‚ÄúIs it not completely Mindless?‚Äù you guess. ‚ÄúWhen you were talking about people becoming shades, you mentioned that Minds can corrupt, break, or wither away, so maybe there‚Äôs still something in there that lets it move around?‚Äù ‚ÄúAh ha!‚Äù Brother Cobb seems delighted. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôve hit upon the Mental remnants theory of Mindless darkness. It‚Äôs one of the two main explanations for how these creatures work since, as you might guess, we don‚Äôt fully understand.‚Äù A breath; he refocuses on all three of you. ‚ÄúThe Mental remnants theory puts forth that a Mindless darkness creature‚Äôs Mind is not completely destroyed, but rather leaves some remnants behind when it is corrupted (or spawned). These remnants are sufficient to allow it to act with simplified animalistic instincts, but insufficient to allow it to learn or otherwise implement complex strategies. Even animals will decide to avoid a trap if they‚Äôve seen it triggered before, but Mindless creatures are incapable of even such basic thought.‚Äù There‚Äôs a pause as the three of you work through the idea. Then, Erich speaks up. ‚ÄúAnd the second theory?‚Äù ‚ÄúYes, the Bodily instincts theory of Mindless darkness. That theory states that, much as the Soul can shape the Mind, the Mind can shape the Body. Therefore, the Mindless creatures‚Äô Minds are truly gone, leaving them with only the built-in instincts and desires their Minds imparted onto their Bodies. This also explains why they are capable of movement and normal functions, as the Body would be most apt to imprint those actions, but much less capable of thought and understanding as Mental tasks alone.‚Äù Another pause. ‚ÄúSo, which one is more plausible?‚Äù ‚Äã
5:40 PM
‚ÄúHmmm, which indeed!‚Äù Cobb looks around for effect. ‚ÄúIf either were easily discredited, there wouldn‚Äôt be two theories, now would there? The Mental remnants theory has some flaws, such as the question of how a Mind could remain for a spawned creature which does not have one to begin with, or the contradiction that - were it true - God‚Äôs act to break the darkness‚Äô Minds would not have been fully effective. But the Bodily instincts theory has flaws as well. It shares the same question about spawned creatures, given there was no Mind to imprint on the Body, and the idea that Bodies can act on their own without any Mind at all raises unsettling questions about the nature of objects that scholars have yet to validate.‚Äù Another longish pause; sometimes you forget how often he does that. ‚ÄúPersonally, I find the Bodily instincts theory more compelling, but not by a significant margin. I imagine we‚Äôll need to solve the mystery of the spawning pools to know for sure.‚Äù The spawning pools. You‚Äôve heard of them a few times, mostly from Yara as part of his Soul-related research. Apparently most Mindless darkness creatures aren‚Äôt formed from corrupted animals, but are instead birthed (‚Äúspawned‚Äù) from mysterious pools deep in the wastelands. Due to how far from the city most of them are, and how surrounded by corruption all of them are, the Cathedra still knows almost nothing about how they actually work. Yara seems convinced that figuring it out will mark a major breakthrough in understanding the corruption, and Brother Cobb seems to concur. Apparently all of you have the same semi-understanding, because no one asks for clarification. After a few more minutes of discussing the concept of Mindlessness (with the corrupted creature still slamming at the wall every so often) you get back to practicing. ‚Äã
5:40 PM
You spend the rest of the morning and part of the afternoon working on sensing the corrupted creature. From inside the room, outside the room, down the hall; as far as you can go and still feel anything. Then you‚Äôre asked to pick out which door holds the creature from a selection, to aid in precision. Which direction? How close? Size? Power? Danger? Specifics? It‚Äôs a lot of work; you‚Äôve never spent so long attuned to the Soul aspect before and it gets exhausting quickly. Still, you‚Äôre very good at everything Cobb asks you to do, so you hide that. You try to reduce your performance across every task to around Erich‚Äôs level, which still seems to be moderately above what the instructor had expected. You still don‚Äôt understand why you‚Äôre finding it so easy, and that feeling seems to come across to Serri. She just gets more upset with you as the day goes on, lagging behind the two of you in every activity. Brother Cobb does his best to encourage her, but you can tell that she‚Äôs still a little below where he was expecting for the day. And with the two of you ahead of the curve instead, the gulf is pretty obvious to everyone. Ordinarily that wouldn‚Äôt be a huge problem - Serri‚Äôs used to getting help from you in all things magical - but she seems to really be taking it the wrong way that you accidentally lied and said you studied ahead of time without her. You‚Äôve got to clear that up before the misunderstanding sticks. You just need to figure out how; do you just tell her the truth? Or would that make things worse somehow? You still don‚Äôt even know why you‚Äôre hiding all this and you really need some time to think about it! ‚Äã
5:40 PM
And finally, it‚Äôs time for the event you‚Äôve all been waiting for. Now that the day has passed and you‚Äôre all tuckered out from working on sensing the thing for hours at a time, you get to try to destroy it. As Brother Cobb says, this isn‚Äôt about actually killing the Mindless creature - and he doesn‚Äôt expect any of you to actually do that - rather, it‚Äôs about knowing the sensation of testing your Soul against the corruption and emerging unharmed. You have no idea what that will feel like and admittedly, you are very nervous about finding out. Erich, of course, is still determined to destroy it. Good for him. But as Brother Cobb explains the strategies you should use to project your Soul out towards it, you start to wonder how your unexpected talent at everything you‚Äôve done today will translate to this, too. Will you accidentally destroy the creature without even trying? Would that expose you? What would everyone think? What should you do? [What order should you go in? Most votes = first, least votes = last. Vote for multiple if you want.] Ô∏è - You. - Serri. - Erich. [And how much effort should you put in?] - Do your best. That‚Äôs what this training is about; you‚Äôre not going to get better if you don‚Äôt try your hardest. - Try to reduce your strength by a good amount. Still try, but try less. - Just pretend to try; don‚Äôt actually let your Soul touch. You have a bad feeling about what might happen if it does. (Winners: > > Ô∏è , ) (edited)

Mxblah 1/3/2024 10:58 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 44 Well, despite your misgivings, you‚Äôre going to try your best; that‚Äôs what you should do. You‚Äôve been suppressing yourself all day, but now... trying to do that when you‚Äôre actually touching the corruption... doesn‚Äôt exactly strike you as a good idea. So, if you somehow manage to destroy it, well, you‚Äôll just let Brother Cobb tell you what that means. At least you‚Äôll get to see Erich‚Äôs reacti - no, bad! The darkness creature slams against the barrier, trying to break through and rip off the impudent limb. He takes a breath, steadies himself, and clenches his hand. ‚ÄúYou two; take a moment to observe the Soul aspect. In reality, he simply presses his hand against the glass, teeth clenched as he strains against an invisible force. The fire flares higher and brighter for a few moments until, little by little and then all at once, it wanes. ‚ÄúMs Ambrose, I believe.‚Äù ‚ÄúM-me?‚Äù ‚ÄúYes. Please go ahead. Just project as you‚Äôve done before.‚Äù ‚Äú...‚Äù Oh. Only a few moments pass before Serri spins away from the cage, closing off her Soul again and pressing arms against her head. One of the Angels reaches down to help her away; the other stays behind to ward off the wolf, as before. ‚ÄúVery good, Ms Ambrose,‚Äù Cobb says. ‚ÄúThe creature was certainly less than pleased. And now, Ms Goodall?‚Äù Well, it‚Äôs time. You walk into the room and up to the cage, pressing your hand against the glass just like the others. The glass isn‚Äôt completely immobile; you can feel it vibrating ever so slightly with every impact. Oh yes, it hates you. Focus. Breathe. 10:59 PM
A shock of freezing pain. You‚Äôve just jumped into a frigid, rushing river and you don‚Äôt know which way is up or down. Air escapes you in a gasp as you involuntarily exclaim in shock. You‚Äôre buffeted by the current, tumbling around in a hopeless spiral as the deadly, awful cold saps the life from you at a rapid pace. Ice crystals form on your skin and pierce into your chest, burrowing and seeking and hating and hating and HATING! You rip yourself away from the cage with a garbled exclamation, stumbling until you fall in a spinning heap. The same Angel from before catches you as the other wards off the wolf, except this time the wolf refuses to back off. It howls and snaps and slams against the glass again and again until finally, the second Angel pushes out his hand and the beast crumbles to dust. Silence, aside from your thundering heartbeat and unsteady breathing. Your vision is grey around the edges. You‚Äôre in danger of passing out; you know these symptoms from your illness. 2:08 PM
So that‚Äôs your life for the next month or two, as summer grows hot and time ticks on. A stable, if tenuous, equilibrium between courses, practice, and rest. You don‚Äôt think you‚Äôd be able to manage without your friends‚Äô help, which sometimes leads you to wonder about people like Naoriel. Anyway, your routine gets an interruption one day in late July as - with her six years of training nearly complete - Clarity celebrates her 18th birthday and will soon graduate to become a full Angel. Mxblah 1/9/2024 10:06 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 47 The date is August 1st and you‚Äôre back in the Lordstone Cathedral. It‚Äôs early in the morning - the fog hasn‚Äôt had time to thin yet, so there‚Äôs nothing but soft grey nothingness outside - and you‚Äôre here with all eleven other trainees, as well as several of your instructors. And the Emissary himself, of course. Thankfully, you aren‚Äôt the subject of today‚Äôs ceremony; all you have to do is stand in the right place and not mess anything up. ‚ÄúAngel Clarity Hendersen,‚Äù says the Emissary softly, eyes of gold glinting in the morning‚Äôs mechanical lamps. ‚ÄúRaise your head.‚Äù She does. He regards her for several long seconds, eyes undoubtedly focused on her Mind and Soul as well as her Body. He can do that too, you‚Äôve learned. It‚Äôs so much less intense when you aren‚Äôt the one being scrutinized. ‚ÄúAngel Clarity Hendersen,‚Äù he repeats. ‚ÄúYou have completed your six years of training in good standing. Your instructors have recommended you for promotion to Angel in full. Tell me, are you pure of Body, Mind, and Soul?‚Äù ‚ÄúI am.‚Äù Her voice is strong; it echoes in the cathedral. The motes of light drifting within the Lordstone shift. The rhythm of the ceremony is familiar to you; a mirror of the one you underwent just a few months ago after your Ascension. ‚ÄúDo you reaffirm your immortal, divine loyalty to the Cathedra and God above?‚Äù ‚ÄúI do.‚Äù ‚ÄúAnd do you promise to guide, honor, and protect the citizens of this city and this world, though it may cost you your life?‚Äù ‚ÄúI do.‚Äù The Emissary makes the sign of the matan, descending the steps to stand before her. ‚ÄúI witness and honor these oaths, sworn before our most holy relic. Rise, Angel Clarity Hendersen, and distinguish yourself as one of God‚Äôs most honored servants.‚Äù ‚Äã
10:06 PM
She stands. The Emissary touches her on the right shoulder, then the left, then her forehead. Body, Mind, Soul. The Lordstone flashes once, briefly, sending a short pulse trembling through everyone present. He smiles kindly and says nothing more, returning to his chair. Your group quickly leaves the Cathedral. Clarity herself is enveloped in a mob of other Angels, ministers, and monks all vying to offer words of congratulations or encouragement. Some of the other trainees join the crowd as well, but the ones who know her well sit back on the weathered stone benches just outside the doors. You, Yara, Serri, Etalyn, and - surprisingly - Naoriel, who‚Äôs sitting off to the side on a separate bench and pretending to be busy. ‚ÄúAh, they grow up so fast,‚Äù Yara says, dabbing a fake tear from his eye. ‚ÄúSix years gone in a heartbeat. I wonder what her first mission will be?‚Äù All graduating Angels are given their first real mission, with actual stakes, the same day as their ceremony. As of this very moment, Clarity is now on the rotation and - once the morning bell chimes (it‚Äôs very early right now) - she will be on call. Of course, she‚Äôll have a partner the first few times and the Center staff know which kinds of missions to assign to new Angels to minimize risks, but still. Real stakes. She could be dead before the day is out. ... You‚Äôre kind of a downer sometimes. Of course that‚Äôs not going to happen. ‚ÄúMaybe just patrols or a Blessing? You know, to ease her into it?‚Äù That‚Äôs Serri, ever the optimist. ‚ÄúI bet they‚Äôre gonna have her fight a hive of Mindless darkness. That way, every mission after will seem easy.‚Äù Etalyn often gets annoyed by Clarity. ‚ÄúWhat about gathering intelligence?‚Äù you offer. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs good at disguises and is really personable.‚Äù ‚ÄúFirst day‚Äôs always got combat, Jess,‚Äù Etalyn reminds you. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs gonna fight something.‚Äù ‚ÄúReally? Always? Can Clarity even fight?‚Äù You don‚Äôt remember her doing it much. ‚Äã
10:06 PM
Etalyn shrugs. ‚ÄúWell enough, I guess. Body magic isn‚Äôt easy to use since you gotta be up close, but she‚Äôs mostly quick enough to pull it off. Still, kinda risky.‚Äù ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs why I much prefer my strategy of bombardment at a distance,‚Äù Yara declares. ‚ÄúIn reality, there are no rules requiring your blade-wielding opponent to start so close.‚Äù ‚Äú‚ÄòCept in reality, you‚Äôre gonna be fighting in people‚Äôs homes. Can‚Äôt go blowing stuff up from the next block over.‚Äù ‚ÄúWell-‚Äù He pauses. ‚ÄúIn the wastelands, there are no homes to destroy!‚Äù ‚ÄúYou wanna go out there your first time?‚Äù ‚ÄúPerhaps,‚Äù he muses. ‚ÄúWouldn‚Äôt that be something? A prodigy Angel deployed immediately to the wastes. Ah, such faith; such glory!‚Äù ‚ÄúSuch delusions.‚Äù Etalyn thwacks him on the arm. ... What is Naoriel doing here? Usually, you‚Äôd expect her to be on her way back to, well, wherever it is she spends her time, but for some reason she‚Äôs sticking around today. Does she want to talk to Clarity later? She‚Äôs pretending that she‚Äôs busy writing something in a notebook, but you‚Äôd bet almost anything that whatever she‚Äôs writing down is meaningless. The point has to be elsewhere. The point like... Nope, nothing happened. You were kind of hoping she‚Äôd do something, or at least look up a little, but, nope. Nothing at all for minutes on end. Well, you can‚Äôt just sit here staring at her all day; Clarity‚Äôs almost out of well-wishers and it‚Äôs time for your group to get up. You stand along with your friends and start to head over, only to notice the tall and extremely difficult-to-miss Sims brush past you on a course for Naoriel. He mutters something in a low voice that you can‚Äôt make out through the crowd; she shakes her head and gestures to Clarity. He sighs and says something else; she nods and hurries to catch up with your group. In fact, she notices you glancing in her direction and makes directly for you, falling into step like she hadn‚Äôt just been ignoring you for the past several minutes. ‚Äã
10:06 PM
‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs that all about?‚Äù you murmur, eyeing Sims as he continues to just stand there and stare after her. ‚ÄúOh, nothing much. I was just telling him how much I was looking forward to spending the morning with my good friend Jessamine.~‚Äù You blink several times at her absurdly girly tone; Naoriel‚Äôs voice has been much more reserved when you‚Äôve spoken to her in the past. ‚ÄúEr, but I was-‚Äù ‚Äú- Just as excited? How lovely; I‚Äôm so pleased to be included before morning mass!~~‚Äù At this point she‚Äôs actually clinging onto your arm. You have no idea what‚Äôs going on. - Include Naoriel in your original plans, which were (as usual) more studying with Serri, Yara, and Etalyn. - Change your plans to do something else with just her instead. Mxblah 1/15/2024 2:11 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 50 Naoriel attends mass and has lunch with your group before leaving to do something on her own for the afternoon with a vague promise to stop by again sometime. It‚Äôs kind of awkward - as you‚Äôd expected given that she doesn‚Äôt want to talk much. At least mass isn‚Äôt too bad; you‚Äôre supposed to be quiet for most of it. You‚Äôre still kind of confused about the whole deal, but you do at least learn a little more during lunch. Using the missing Clarity as a focus (she‚Äôs still either at the Center waiting for her mission, or out in the city performing it) you steer the conversation towards parents. Etalyn seems to notice what you‚Äôre doing, but doesn‚Äôt stop you - in fact, she almost seems proud. You feel a little guilty trying to manipulate Naoriel into giving up information like that, but not quite guilty enough to stop. It seems like the table is pretty split on how they feel about their family. You obviously have a good relationship - though you haven‚Äôt seen them in months and those occasional letters just make you lonelier - and Clarity is spoiled by her parents. Yara and Etalyn both don‚Äôt want to give any more details than you already know, but you‚Äôre aware that neither of them had great childhoods. Serri - really? You somehow never asked her before now? - anyway, Serri comes from a very large family near the outskirts, where she‚Äôs the second youngest. Apparently, many of her siblings grew up to work in some sort of farming, often in the underground caverns that wind beneath the city where they harvest plants, fungus, and the small creatures who feed on it. She‚Äôs glad she was spared having to do that. ‚Äã
2:11 PM
You accidentally get derailed by that - it sounds really interesting and you‚Äôre curious how the logistics work - so Serri becomes the center of attention for a while as she recounts her family‚Äôs stories of delving beneath the surface for hours at a time. Harvesting mushrooms from the more cultivated plots near the surface as well as descending to the less mapped caves below, hunting spiny shelled creatures and drawing new maps to be able to explore further next time. It sounds incredibly risky once you stray from the top few layers. Almost seems like something your brother would try. What did he choose for his future career path, actually? You don‚Äôt recall hearing about it in any letters recently. Maybe he‚Äôs saving it as a surprise? That doesn‚Äôt make you feel any better. And by the time you remember that you were supposed to be figuring out something about Naoriel, you‚Äôre all pretty much done eating and you‚Äôve lost your chance. At least, up until good old dependable Yara steps in and asks her directly just before everyone stands up to head out. ‚ÄúSay, Naoriel, you never got a chance to talk about your family after dear Jessamine‚Äôs interest in the caverns. Is there anything you‚Äôd like to share quickly? Everyone else did.‚Äù ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs nothing to tell, really. My father is an assistant deacon and I never knew my mother. I‚Äôve been with the Cathedra for my whole life. Hardly an unusual story for any of the monks here; I was just lucky enough to be chosen to Ascend.‚Äù ‚Äã
2:12 PM
She‚Äôs right; that‚Äôs a very common background for non-Angelic Cathedra staff. Fully ordained ministers - priests and above - are heavily discouraged from having children due to various scriptural taboos that all but forbid the practice, but deacons and below are completely exempt. Therefore, young deacons on the path to becoming a priest often have children early to ensure they won‚Äôt miss out after their ordination. And if you have a kid when you become a priest, you‚Äôre fully allowed to keep them - it would be cruel to force people to choose between family and faith like that. And of course, growing up as a minister‚Äôs child means you‚Äôll be involved in the Cathedra from the time you‚Äôre old enough to walk, which makes it hardly surprising that so many of them become monks. Or, apparently in Naoriel‚Äôs case, Angels. The only unusual part of her explanation is having never known her mother, but it‚Äôs not unusual enough to warrant more than a brief condolence. It‚Äôs weird; you kind of expected her to have a stranger situation. Unless she‚Äôs lying, of course. You glance at her suspiciously, wondering if maybe she was a little too ready to give that explanation? She usually never talks about herself, but here she‚Äôs completely willing? You shake your head. No, you can‚Äôt go around distrusting people like that. You‚Äôll believe her, unless something comes up to change your Mind. Maybe she was just doing her best to actually be friends; you did mention wanting to learn more about her. ‚Äã
2:12 PM
Anyway, you don‚Äôt have anything scheduled for the afternoon, so you go for a walk. Etalyn has another demonstration match and Yara is going along to support her, while Serri has a training session for some sort of volunteer certification? She was a little vague about it and almost seemed embarrassed. And of course, Naoriel ran off somewhere and Clarity is busy, so that just leaves you on your own for the moment. You could probably be doing some more studying or working on that practical demonstration for your Mind course due on Monday, but you‚Äôve got all of tomorrow to get that done. It‚Äôll be fine. You end up wandering into one of the smaller shrines dotted around the campus that symbolize a particular aspect of God. There are the big three, of course - Body, Mind, Soul - but each major aspect has an assortment of minor aspects that can be drawn from it. Traits, emotions, that sort of thing. The shrine you‚Äôre in now is dedicated to vision, according to some metal plaques on the wall. There‚Äôs the standard Bodily vision that you do with your eyes, of course, but the shrine also offers some other interpretations. The Mental vision to see all possibilities and to know which will be effective. And the slightly different Soul‚Äôs vision to know which is the right thing to do. Then there‚Äôs also the more literal Mind and Soul vision that Angels have, but this shrine is aimed at ordinary people as well and doesn‚Äôt mention that. You look up at the matan symbol and make the sign with your hands, matching up your fingers‚Äô triangle to the one on the wall. There‚Äôs no defined way to pray to God outside of the various rites and rituals that produce specific effects. If all you want is for Him to hear you, all you have to do is speak. ‚Äã
2:12 PM
... I‚Äôm worried, you admit, still focusing on the matan and your connection to the divine. Not just for Yara and Clarity and all the others, but just... You hesitate, but God knows what you‚Äôre thinking anyway, and He loves you regardless. The more I learn about the corruption, the more impossible it seems that we can win. Everything‚Äôs been at a stalemate for centuries, but with the darkness growing stronger. Shades never appeared until the last few centuries; did you know that? You shake your head. Of course He knew that. And even beyond just keeping the city safe, we‚Äôd still have to purify the entire planet to really win. I just don‚Äôt see how that could possibly... Great, there‚Äôs that dread again. You try your best to ignore it - and succeed most of the time - but sometimes it just creeps up on you. God, if I am Your Angel, and I am part of Your answer to the corruption, please... tell me if we can win. If there‚Äôs hope. Ô∏è - Somehow, you feel a little better. - There‚Äôs no answer. Of course not; only the Emissary can directly talk with God. Ô∏è - Somehow, you feel a little worse. (Winner: Ô∏è ) (edited)

Mxblah 1/17/2024 9:57 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 51 There‚Äôs no obvious answer. No flash of light or divine voice to allay your concerns and tell you everything will be okay. But you know God won‚Äôt speak to you like that; only the Emissary can hope to do something so divine. You‚Äôll have to look for a smaller sign. Like, perhaps, that feeling of warmth from your Ascension. If that really was God‚Äôs presence, then maybe you‚Äôll be able to feel it again? ... Nope, nothing. You don‚Äôt know what you were thinking. You hastily turn around, breaking the triangle formed by your hands, and hurry outside, suddenly embarrassed to be thinking so brazenly about contacting God. But when you emerge, the fog is a little different. A little clearer; the sun perhaps a little brighter. You can see the belltower you couldn‚Äôt when you went in. And while the change could have happened naturally while you were inside, that doesn‚Äôt mean it did. Perhaps it‚Äôs God‚Äôs will speaking to you softly, telling you that there is still light in the world, no matter how dark things may seem. Somehow, you feel a little better. ... Clarity is back by dinner. She‚Äôs basically fine - just a few strange, pale marks on her arms - but she‚Äôs a little shaken up, despite all her training. Without much prompting, she agrees to tell you what happened. The call came out before midday, about two hours before lunch. Clarity had been sitting in the Center for a while already, listening to the chatter and wondering who she‚Äôd be paired up with, when one of the operators signaled her over. A request from the tenth district, not far from the wall. Reports had come in from fishermen of strange dark shapes in the water, and one man hadn‚Äôt returned from his scheduled shift. The nearest Angels were at the wall instead of the Cathedra, of course, but coincidentally (or not!) the district was also monitoring an unusually close group of Mindless darkness gathering in the wastelands and didn‚Äôt want to leave the wall without its guardians. ‚Äã
9:57 PM
So off she ran to the train station, where her partner was already waiting with a locomotive to carry them northeast as fast as technology would allow. She had been paired up with a fairly experienced Angel for her first mission, a wasteland veteran who had previously spent several years helping workers inspect, install, and maintain the heavy grates in the river that prevent any Mindless darkness from entering the city through the water. This was the fear, that one of the grates had been breached and the shapes were darkness creatures swimming through the Endle River. District constables met up with them at the station and quickly escorted them to the site of the man‚Äôs disappearance on the riverbank. Clarity hadn‚Äôt been fully prepared for just how many people would be involved here; dozens of constables, divers, medics, and workmen all stood back and prepared to assist as soon as the Angels declared the scene safe. Even a number of regular civilians loitered nearby despite constables shouting for them to move along, presumably caught between the situation‚Äôs danger and the chance to see Angels in action. With constables downstream able to confirm intact grates and no corruption just a few blocks south, the Angels decided to just start there - at the maximum possible area the darkness could have infiltrated - and proceed upstream to the wall‚Äôs grate, eliminating any corruption they found along the way. A simple plan, but an effective one - as long as any potential darkness stayed in the water. District constables had the section of river almost fully cordoned off at this point, so nothing else would be getting through without someone knowing about it, but there was always a risk something had escaped beforehand. ‚Äã
9:58 PM
Anyway, between Clarity‚Äôs moderate swimming skill and her Body transmutations to grant some suitable adaptations, she was in relatively good shape to enter the Endle River, attune to the Soul aspect, and strain for any trace of corruption. Her partner followed close by, letting her take the lead as you‚Äôve heard is common in these first missions. The river water was dark, cold, and cloudy near the bottom. Muck of unidentifiable sources swirled in the relatively strong current. All that meant practically was a little bit more Soul energy expended countering it with magic, but it was ‚Äúone of the most disgusting things I‚Äôve ever done,‚Äù Clarity tells you, wiping her arms. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve taken two showers since then and I still don‚Äôt feel clean.‚Äù The water seemed to interfere with her Soul sensing, as her partner had to get her attention and stop her from stumbling into the first creature they found. It resembled a mass of tangled-up plant matter, several gashes breaking the uneven surface and lined with sharpened bits of debris that seemed to answer for teeth. It had been busy tearing bricks out of the wall with long, slimy tendrils made of the same goopy plant matter, but it quickly noticed the two full Angels nearby and attacked. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs what these are from,‚Äù she explains, holding out her wrists for your inspection. The pale marks are about a finger‚Äôs width wide and trail up towards her elbows before fading out. ‚ÄúI was more worried about not getting bitten in two by its mouths, but the tendrils were dangerous too. It‚Äôs totally numb where those marks are and it‚Äôs hard to move my hands properly. See?‚Äù She picks up a glass successfully, but with some effort. ‚ÄúThey told me my Body is already purging the toxins and I‚Äôll be fine in the morning, but it was a little jarring that I couldn‚Äôt just heal it right away. Kinda scary, even though I sort of knew that might happen.‚Äù ‚Äã
9:58 PM
You nod, still staring at the marks. The sickly grey skin is a shocking contrast to Clarity‚Äôs otherwise flawless appearance. If you look at just her hands, it almost looks like she should be in a hospital. ‚ÄúBut we did eventually manage to kill it and burn it away. Then, after a short rest and a report to the constables nearby, we...‚Äù - Found the missing fisherman. - Found a creature crawling out of the river. Ô∏è - Found the broken grate. (Winner: ) (edited)

@Story Notifications Scene 52 ‚Äú... found the missing fisherman.‚Äù She glances away. ‚ÄúWell, part of him. Erm... you know what, I don‚Äôt need to describe it. Just, it was really brutal, Jess. These latter two fights went more smoothly than the first, potentially because the creatures seemed smaller and less aggressive, but potentially because her partner was more active in combat due to Clarity‚Äôs injuries. She‚Äôll gain experience quickly, growing further apart from the rest of the trainees. ‚Äã

@Story Notifications Scene 53 Finding information on Naoriel‚Äôs father doesn‚Äôt take nearly as long as when you dug up the information on Zeke‚Äôs name change, which was the last time you did something similarly stalker-like. You definitely feel a little weird, keeping an eye out in case Naoriel shows up for whatever reason, but there aren‚Äôt all that many assistant deacons (at least compared to all the data you had to sift through last time) and the Cathedra is very meticulous with its record keeping. The problem is then trying to cross-reference the list of potential deacons with birth records from the correct time. You don‚Äôt know Naoriel‚Äôs birthday, but you do know when she Ascended: January of last year, which is a problem. Cevember, the last month of each year, doesn‚Äôt have a Calling day unlike all twelve others. That means the children born in December, Cevember, or the three festival days at the end of the year are all placed into the same ceremony in January. It‚Äôs the biggest of the year for obvious reasons (and some priests are thus campaigning to add a new Calling day in Cevember), but the real issue is that you‚Äôve got slightly more than twice as many possible birthdays to search. 1:27 PM
Her mother is listed as having died in childbirth, an uncommon but not unheard-of occurrence even with modern medicine. Her father‚Äôs name is Columbus Fisher and he‚Äôs listed as an assistant deacon in the eleventh district. The church is fairly small and unimportant, kind of far away from anything of note aside from a small rail station that only sees four trains a day. At that frequency, it‚Äôd usually be faster to just walk to or from one of the nearest hub stations that see dozens or more. Some awards or published sermons. Research or other work. Anything? And, as you had previously noted, he remained an assistant deacon for fourteen years, never moving up in the clergy. Mr Fisher (not Father; only ordained clergy get new titles) is by far the most senior member of the staff there, and you can‚Äôt find a single mention of him outside of the Cathedra‚Äôs records. ‚Äã
1:27 PM

7:04 PM

So, what will you - wait, Yara is literally right in front of you. You quickly summarize most of what you just thought about and are relieved to hear that you‚Äôre pretty much correct: your disguises are meant to avoid having full Angels just wandering around the city, not necessarily to go fully incognito. If someone who knew you before your Ascension recognizes you while disguised, that‚Äôs fine as long as they don‚Äôt cause a scene. ‚Äã
7:04 PM

Mxblah 1/25/2024 9:45 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 55 ‚ÄúWell...‚Äù Nothing else of particular note happens that week. Clarity goes on more missions and shares more harrowing tales of fights against the corruption all across the city, but also tales of the impacts her efforts have on the people you‚Äôre collectively sworn to protect. Not every story ends with a dead fisherman torn apart in the river; many more times, the Angels arrive in time to prevent any serious harm. Naoriel shows up at unpredictable times, continuing in her quest to pretend to be your friend. Still, you keep learning just by hanging around with her, even if you‚Äôre trying your best to avoid actively stalking her. That white beret she wears isn‚Äôt part of the dress code, much like Clarity‚Äôs pin, but since it kinda looks like it could be, no one really bothers her about it. Apparently she had been self-conscious about her hair sticking up before becoming an Angel, and just kept the habit of wearing it even though her appearance is now flawless. You find it a little weird that the Body transformation considered her cowlick to be a ‚Äúflaw‚Äù to correct and spend some time discussing what a ‚Äúperfect Body‚Äù actually means and what determines it. Turns out there‚Äôs actually some literature on the subject, but (as with quite a lot of magic‚Äôs fundamental behaviors) the best explanation anyone can come up with is ‚Äúit‚Äôs God‚Äôs will.‚Äù God, so it seems, prefers smooth hair. Finally, Friday morning arrives. You now have two non-uniform outfits to choose from (courtesy of Clarity, of course), and decide on the less-fancy one to avoid giving too much of a shock. Just a simple full-length cream dress with some darker accents to stop barely short of ‚Äútoo plain.‚Äù This sort of rougher, simpler outfit is what many ordinary people in the city wear, and is familiar to you from your childhood. But somehow, you feel less natural in it than you expected. ‚Äã
9:45 PM
Still with plenty of time, you swap to the other outfit - the one with the blue dress and yellow jacket - and are surprised to find it less familiar, but more comfortable. The you in the mirror just... seems to fit it better than the simple outfit. This discovery does not help with your nervousness. You were already worried you might have changed more than you realized and wouldn‚Äôt fit in with your family again, but now you don‚Äôt even seem natural in the sort of clothes you had worn just a few months back? Maybe you‚Äôre overthinking it; maybe you should swap back anyway. Agh! Why are you so indecisive? You dig through your belongings to find a coin (a leftover from one of your previous outings) and just give it a flip to decide for you. It lands tails, which means... ah! You forgot to assign outcomes to the sides before you flipped it! Okay, okay, do it again... tails, a second time. That means you don‚Äôt change back, staying in the fancier outfit. You suppose your actual Body‚Äôs changes will be far more of a surprise than any clothes you could pick out. Okay, gather a few more things and you‚Äôre ready. Double check the ribbon on the way out to make sure - you did it wrong again! Okay, you‚Äôve got to fix that this time; it‚Äôll be way more obvious when you‚Äôre disguised... Several minutes later, you finally arrive downstairs to meet up with Yara and Etalyn, who have clearly been waiting for some time already. They‚Äôre both in relatively modest outfits - Yara‚Äôs looks like Denn‚Äôs banker-ish outfit, though a little more colorful, while Etalyn has a similarly light shirt but darker blue waist-high overalls. You suppose you didn‚Äôt expect her to wear a dress, really, but it would have been interesting to see. ‚ÄúMinor problem, Jessamine,‚Äù Yara admits once they‚Äôve finished ribbing you for being late. ‚ÄúIt seems I‚Äôm not nearly as good at external transmutations as I thought; my testing with Ets here only lasted twenty minutes, give or take.‚Äù ‚Äã
9:45 PM
You just sort of look at him, emotions on hold as you try to work out if he‚Äôs canceling on you or not. ‚ÄúSo we‚Äôll just have to come with you to your station, instead of splitting up at the departure one here. It‚Äôs less than a twenty minute walk to your home from there, yes?‚Äù Phew. ‚ÄúY-yeah. About fifteen.‚Äù ‚ÄúHmm. Might be a little tight; I‚Äôm not certain if you‚Äôll be as receptive to my magic. We‚Äôll test on the way.‚Äù ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt word it like that,‚Äù Etalyn grumbles. ‚ÄúHow would you have me say it? That I‚Äôm quite capable of enchanting you?‚Äù ‚ÄúWorse. Try again.‚Äù ‚ÄúHmm...‚Äù You pass through the perimeter without issue and walk to the central station, passing by the Cathedra‚Äôs own station just in time to watch a single-car train depart with rapid acceleration. There aren‚Äôt actually many scheduled routes from it; most of its activity comes from the ad-hoc trains transporting Angels to their missions. For useful civilian routes, it‚Äôs usually easier to walk the extra few blocks to downtown proper. On arrival, you all buy your tickets using extra money Clarity had given you previously for exactly this purpose, wait a few minutes by the tracks, and rapidly set off to the sixth district. You can‚Äôt help but compare this ride to the one you took in the opposite direction half a year ago. Then, a private car nonstop to the Cathedra. Now, a full train making every stop along the way. You pass over the Endle River bridge and take a moment to stare into the dull grey water. Even now, in the sunny heat of late summer, the fog prevents any sparkling waves. The water looks as it always does. Although now you know the kind of monsters that could be lurking within it. ‚Äã
9:45 PM
Yara and Etalyn disembark with you; they‚Äôll have to transfer to a different route. ‚ÄúAlright, here we are,‚Äù Yara says, stretching as Etalyn goes to look at a departure board. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm fairly confident your disguise will last twenty minutes based on the degradation rate, so as long as you don‚Äôt dawdle, you‚Äôll get there with time to spare.‚Äù ‚ÄúG-got it.‚Äù Etalyn saunters back over, pointing over her shoulder at a nearby platform. ‚ÄúOur train‚Äôs boarding. Hurry it up.‚Äù ‚ÄúGoodness, already? What fortuitous timing! We‚Äôll return this evening as promised; do enjoy your Endle Day.‚Äù ‚ÄúYeah, have fun, Jess. Lucky to have a family like you do. Appreciate ‚Äòem.‚Äù ‚ÄúI - I will.‚Äù Etalyn smirks and rolls her eyes, heading off to the train she indicated. Yara grabs your arm, recharging your disguise, then waves farewell and hurries off after her. ‚ÄúSee you tonight!‚Äù You don‚Äôt have any time to waste. You wave just once, then spin around and walk out of the station. [It‚Äôs really happening. How are you going to greet your family?] ‚è±Ô∏è - Like nothing‚Äôs changed. - Happily; with excitement. - Politely. Fondly, but properly. - Nervously. It‚Äôs been months! (Winner: ) (edited)

Mxblah 1/27/2024 6:28 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 56 The streets are familiar here. You rarely walked to the station itself from your house, but it‚Äôs surrounded by the neighborhood‚Äôs main commercial zone, not to mention your school. You know the area well. Unfortunately, you don‚Äôt have time to sightsee. You can‚Äôt sense the disguise degrading as anything more than a vague ‚Äúcooling off‚Äù of the warm blanket-like feeling, so you‚Äôre not sure exactly how long you have or at what point it will slip away entirely. Streets pass by in rapid succession as you fall back into your well-memorized route back home. Some of the signs are different; businesses have changed or moved. Homes have new shutters or doors. Life, so it seems, went on. But... somehow, even these little changes make everything seem so different. You‚Äôre used to modern, sleek skyscrapers and traditional, ornate cathedrals now. The shabby wooden townhomes and rough streetsigns belong to a different world. One occupied by ordinary people, not Angels. You‚Äôre discomforted by these thoughts. They don‚Äôt feel like something you‚Äôd think, right? You‚Äôre still human; you‚Äôve only been gone for less than half a year! This neighborhood is just as much your home as the Cathedra; more so, even. Where‚Äôs this vague sense of... separation coming from? There‚Äôs no answer to find as you continue on, winding out of the main streets and into the narrower residential alleys that make up the bulk of the district. The charred-black face of a building catches your eye and you think back to one of the few times you had seen an Angel outside of district assemblies. A townhome down the street had caught fire and, with narrow alleys surrounded by old wood on all sides, it quickly began to outspread any attempts to keep it contained. ‚Äã
6:28 PM
This is one of the main dangers in a city as dense as Nucarreo. There‚Äôs simply no way to move vast quantities of water to a large fire fast enough to douse it, not with so much fuel around. Trains can carry huge pumps and tanks, but the rails don‚Äôt go everywhere and hoses can only stretch so far. If the fire is far from a station (or even a stretch of track where a tanker train can park) carriages, carts, or just plain buckets are the only way to move water. But tanks get stuck in narrow alleys, horses are unwilling to approach the flames, and simple buckets can‚Äôt handle enough volume. Some forward-thinking gearworkers have put forth ideas to tap into the water pipes running beneath the streets, but so far that remains only an idea. So Angels appear instead. Magic. You had stood in the alleyway that night, watching as winged, glowing forms swooped around the inferno and slowly, carefully pressed it back. Not with water or by smothering, but simply by their very presence. Wherever these Angels went, the fire died. Before the hour was out, they had contained it enough that ordinary firefighters could isolate the remaining embers and let it burn itself out. Now, you understand that these Angels must have used some form of external physical projection to absorb or redirect the flames‚Äô energy. Or potentially transmutation to transform the wood into something that couldn‚Äôt burn? No, that wouldn‚Äôt make sense; transmutation is so much more energy-intensive and would have required physical contact. It must have been projection. But though you understand the principles, the concept of you doing something like that just seems so far away. The immense control and focus it would require while flying around to keep yourself and civilians out of harm‚Äôs way as well... You‚Äôre here. ‚Äã
6:28 PM
You recognize the location, the metallic decoration on the door, the little broken-off corner where you and Seth had accidentally thrown a bat into the trim. Smoke is rising from the chimney, which (in the middle of August) probably means someone‚Äôs cooking rather than someone‚Äôs cold. You hesitate a little longer, eyeing the tiny scratches and imperfections on the windows while trying to gather the courage to knock. What are you going to say? How should you act? So much has changed, and it‚Äôs been so long! Briefly, you even consider giving up and fleeing back to the station, but get yourself under control again quickly. Not only would you not make it back before your disguise falls apart, but you‚Äôve been wanting this for months. You have to. Just raise your hand. And. Knock. ‚ÄúJust a moment!‚Äù you hear someone call from inside. It‚Äôs your dad. Of course you still know his voice. You wait on the step, fidgeting with your clothes and hands, for several uneasy seconds. You still don‚Äôt know what you‚Äôre going to say. ‚ÄúHi?‚Äù Sure (maybe?) but what then? Do you talk about the Cathedra? Your future? Seth‚Äôs future? Oh, that might be good; you really want to know what he picked. But how would you even- He opens the door. Even though you‚Äôve been waiting for this for the past few seconds - hours - months - you‚Äôre still caught off guard. Frozen. ‚ÄúJessamine,‚Äù he breathes, kneeling down to embrace you. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre back...‚Äù ‚ÄúH-hi, dad.‚Äù That‚Äôs the best you can do. You hug him back, but something isn‚Äôt right. It‚Äôs exactly what you imagined, except for... Oh no. No, no no. The feeling of alienation from the streets and buildings had been just a worrying prelude. You still feel fond of your dad, but... there‚Äôs no connection. You don‚Äôt... you don‚Äôt love him like you used to. ‚Äã
6:28 PM
And when your mom emerges as well, hurriedly removing her apron to avoid getting flour on your outfit as she hugs you too - even as Seth hurries down the stairs to join in - you... feel separate. You still like and appreciate your family, but... Why? And so you start crying in the middle of the hallway. [When you‚Äôve gotten yourself together, you should...] - Pretend. Mxblah 1/31/2024 8:02 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 57 At first, no one thinks that‚Äôs weird. You‚Äôre still young and just reunited with your family that you haven‚Äôt seen for months; plenty of people would cry in a situation like that. But after you calm down a bit and try to explain what you‚Äôre feeling (doing a very poor job of it, you can tell), mom sits you down on the nice chair and tries to help you figure it out. The adjectives you provide don‚Äôt seem to make them understand. Disconnected, confused, a little empty. It‚Äôs natural to feel a little isolated after being away for so long, you‚Äôre told. You‚Äôve been living in a different world since you left. Of course you‚Äôd feel a little different as well, and that‚Äôs okay. They‚Äôre here for you anyway. You‚Äôre not so sure. It just feels so sudden; surely you haven‚Äôt changed that much. There exists magic that can manipulate your Mind and emotions. Corruption can cause thoughts and feelings to decay. It just... it‚Äôs gotta be something external, right? Something that means it isn‚Äôt your fault for losing how you feel about your family. Something that can be fixed. Otherwise... At some point you realize your disguise fell apart and no one even said anything, even though you can tell the changes are surprising. Surely at least Seth has to be curious about that, but he‚Äôs not saying anything because you‚Äôre still a mess and he has to take care of you again just like he did for years when you were younger and even after your sickness passed he still had to protect you at school and you‚Äôre just the worst and why can‚Äôt you pull yourself together? It‚Äôs so stupid to just be sitting here all sad about nothing! You really should be better at controlling your emotions than this, after these months of Mind training. That thought leaps into your head unbidden, which of course only makes you feel worse. ‚Äã
8:02 PM
What finally calms you down isn‚Äôt any great incident or revelation. You don‚Äôt suddenly find some weird spell squatting on your Mind and toss it aside to reveal those hidden emotions. It‚Äôs just that, after fussing over you for a while, mom has to go deal with the cookies so they won‚Äôt burn. Dad heads over to help with the trays and Seth gets distracted for a moment by something loud happening outside, popping over to look before declaring it just a rattly cart. That, finally, feels normal. You still feel kinda weird, but not enough to ruin anything. It‚Äôs good enough. It‚Äôll have to be good enough, because you don‚Äôt have all day. Yara and Etalyn will be returning ‚Äúthis evening‚Äù at some point, without a concrete time decided because you were just too frantic to think of it, so you‚Äôve only got... you‚Äôre not sure. Until the sun sets, maybe? But you‚Äôve gotta make the most of it! So you have some cookies and explain what you‚Äôve been doing for the past five and a half months. The courses you‚Äôve taken, the friends you‚Äôve made, the magic you can do. You‚Äôre still not very good, but at this point Brother Cobb has had you practice changing your Soul‚Äôs resonance phase and basic projection. It‚Äôs enough to let you create momentary jolts of pressure in the air near you, causing sudden breezes. Certainly not very spectacular compared to what full Angels can do (or even trainees like Yara), but it‚Äôs real magic. Seth is impressed. You keep some stuff to yourself, of course. The incident with Sister Bagley, for one. Details from Clarity‚Äôs missions. That one time you collapsed at the outer wall. The sort of things that would make them worry about you. It‚Äôs better to keep up the facade that Angels are glorious, perfect beings and that you don‚Äôt have anything to fear. There‚Äôs nothing they can do at this point, anyway; worrying would be a waste of effort. ‚Äã
8:02 PM

He can confirm that one, and also reassures you that he‚Äôs not listening to any of those people but that it can be fun to mess with them occasionally. So. You‚Äôre caught up, mostly. Mxblah 2/2/2024 8:56 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 58 Well, you‚Äôve got to know what your brother plans on doing for his future job. While the choices made after one‚Äôs Calling aren‚Äôt completely permanent by design - you are just twelve when it happens, after all - most kids do stick with theirs. The idea is that God inspires you during your ceremony so that, even if you don‚Äôt Ascend to be an Angel, you still get an idea of what His plan for you might be. Seth has kind of been avoiding the topic in your letters and there‚Äôs really no better time to find out. So you ask. ‚Äú...‚Äù You should have guessed. He‚Äôs taking advanced combat, tactics, and survival classes - not to mention extra training on the corruption he‚Äôll start in two years‚Äô time. Your brother is intending to become a wasteland soldier. You think back to the four men in soldiers‚Äô fatigues who saluted you just after your Ascension. The warriors you met guarding the wall and the strange, bunker-like building that (at times) houses captured darkness creatures. They‚Äôre strong, hardy people, a job granted only to the toughest and most pious of men - at least, of those who were not picked to join the Cathedra in a divine capacity. But they‚Äôre only human, after all, and they don‚Äôt have an Angel‚Äôs blessings. Well, they do carry an Angel‚Äôs Blessings, but - nevermind. The point is that they‚Äôre far more mortal than any Angel. You recall Zeke‚Äôs stories of his encounters with shades, and how any encounter without losing a member of the squad is considered a great victory. Descriptions of dangerous, desperate work repairing tracks or equipment as men fight and die to provide the time to do so. Of Angels too busy or too slow to save the men under their command as they succumb to darkness just feet away. ‚Äú...‚Äù Right, of course he‚Äôd notice your expression. What‚Äôs wrong?
