8:56 PM
You try to be a little vague about it, not going into some of the gorier details you‚Äôve heard from Zeke or other senior Angels. Simpler things; even ordinary civilians know that soldiers have it rough. The wastelands take their toll, even with consistent healing from the Angels they accompany. The corruption still degrades your Soul, even if only a little, and the effects are magnified on the Mind and again on the Body. Soldiers rarely have the chance to grow old; even when they survive to retirement, incurable diseases often cut their lives short. The Body turns against itself, you‚Äôve heard. Seth isn‚Äôt dissuaded. It‚Äôs worth it, he declares, to protect you and everyone else in the city. You‚Äôre reminded of your own oath, the one taken with death seeming so distant. To lay down your life for Nucarreo, should you have to. Soldiers make a similar promise. Would trying to stop him be hypocrisy? Your Mind whirls, spinning through the possibilities and snapshots of the future. It‚Äôs hard to focus on what anyone else is saying. Your parents are apprehensive as well. How could they not be, with both of their children pursuing the most dangerous and important jobs in the city? You didn‚Äôt have a choice, and becoming an Angel comes with incredible benefits and powers to defend yourself. But Seth... And yet, neither one of them voices a serious objection. He‚Äôs been thinking about this for months, ever since his Calling. God Himself made His plans known in that chamber; he‚Äôs sure of it. And no matter how worried a parent might be, one can never go against God. If He wills it, then His plan will keep Seth safe. Or, at least, His Angels will. ‚Äã
8:56 PM
You catch the implication. Seth may want to defend you, but you also want to defend him. You‚Äôd never be able to forgive yourself if your brother... Nope, not even going to finish the thought. In case it comes true. ... The sun has dipped beneath the horizon and the fog is tinged with a fading orange as shadows overtake the light. You don‚Äôt know where the last hours have gone; the day is a blur. Even though it should have been a relief or a vacation, you‚Äôve held nothing but a building anxiety since the morning. Even now, you wouldn‚Äôt be able to reproduce a single sentence uttered by anyone since you arrived; only the broad impressions. You jolt, having been unconsciously on edge and listening for it. You told your family that some other Angels would be arriving to pick you up, right? God, you can‚Äôt remember. Mxblah 2/4/2024 2:53 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 59 Well, there‚Äôs nothing wrong with letting your dad answer the door again even if you forgot to mention it. His appearance will be expected for anyone knocking, whereas yours (you belatedly realize) is still Angelic and could cause problems if it‚Äôs actually not who you expect. But it is. You get three more hugs and some quiet goodbyes, then a pulse of magic from Yara and... out you go. Your emotions remain a mystery; there‚Äôs some of the bittersweet sorrow in there that you would expect, but if you‚Äôre being honest with yourself... there‚Äôs some relief in there as well. You hate that; it doesn‚Äôt make sense. You absolutely cannot have changed so drastically in the past few months for that reaction to be natural. There has to be something wrong. You can feel it. 2:53 PM
‚Äú...‚Äù The city looks different at night. Shrouded in fog, the visibility is so low that - from your elevated train - you can‚Äôt see the ground. You‚Äôve still never seen the true night sky, above the fog. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know. Nothing went wrong; it was just like I wanted. But somehow... it just didn‚Äôt feel right. Grown more confident, more skilled, more... opinionated at times. You aren‚Äôt the same person as the one who knelt in the Ascension chamber.‚Äù ‚Äú... You really think that‚Äôs all it is? Just normal growth and change?‚Äù ‚ÄúWhat else could it be?‚Äù ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know,‚Äù you grumble, leaning against the window. ‚ÄúSomething else.‚Äù ‚Äã
2:53 PM
You catch another glance between them in the window‚Äôs reflection. Clearly, they don‚Äôt believe you. Which makes sense, because you don‚Äôt have an alternate explanation. All you have is a feeling that it isn‚Äôt right; that you shouldn‚Äôt have been feeling those emotions. You‚Äôll have to figure it out later. You‚Äôre not giving up just because you don‚Äôt know what‚Äôs going on; just add it to the pile of other things to investigate. ‚ÄúBy the way,‚Äù you eventually continue, changing the subject. ‚ÄúWhat did you two get up to today?‚Äù ‚ÄúAh, just errands. Nothing exciting.‚Äù ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs what you said this morning. Nothing interesting at all happened the whole day?‚Äù They look at each other again. ‚ÄúNope.‚Äù ‚Äú...‚Äù ‚Äú...‚Äù ‚ÄúOkayyyyyy.‚Äù You do the squint again. You don‚Äôt believe them for a second. You dream of distance that night. Endless voids of empty space, fog whispering around you with the voices of your friends and family. You forgot about them. You left them behind. You don‚Äôt need them anymore, is that it? How disgusting. How sickening. To just abandon those who care about you like that. Flat planes of vague white nothing. Grey fog curling around you. Within you. Every breath you take inhales more of that horrible, writhing mist that now echoes with quiet rebukes from inside your Body. You try to stop breathing, but you can‚Äôt. Holding your breath only works for so long, and then you have to gulp in another even larger lungful of the tainted, guilt-laden air. What could you have done differently? It wasn‚Äôt your choice to ignore them; to leave them behind. You didn‚Äôt even do that, right? You came back. You visited. You tried! It doesn‚Äôt have to be something you did for it to be your fault. You are responsible nonetheless. Trying to avoid the duties placed upon you is the way of a coward and a traitor to those who depend on you. Who care about you. Even now, as you push them away, they still care. You‚Äôre hurting them. What are you going to do about it? ‚Äã
2:53 PM
The mist fills you. Your Body fades; your Mind unravels. Your Soul merges with the fog, becoming merely another distant voice in the chorus. You wake up some time before you need to, eyes wet with tears. You know the nightmare isn‚Äôt true. No one hates you. You haven‚Äôt pushed anyone away. It‚Äôs not your fault. But those assurances ring hollow against the fading voices of those crying out from the dream‚Äôs insubstantial abyss. Breathe. Control yourself. It‚Äôs not real. It‚Äôs Sulday; you don‚Äôt have courses. There‚Äôs mass and homework, but that‚Äôs okay. You can recover. You just need something to occupy yourself. [Such as...] - Investigating the paranoia you‚Äôve just experienced. - Continuing your Naoriel investigations. Maybe less-creepily this time, though. - Inquisitors. They‚Äôve been involved in a number of recent events, but you still know very little about them. Ô∏è - Your Soul training. - Your Mind training. - Your Body training. (Winner: ) (edited)

Mxblah 2/6/2024 9:47 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 60 So, of course, you pick one of the least accessible topics in the Cathedra for your next obsession. Inquisitors. You understand generally what they do - hunt down any corruption (or Corruption) in the Cathedra itself and... dispose of it - but you don‚Äôt really know anything beyond that basic overview. There have been Inquisitors involved in a number of recent events and you have a feeling some of them may be getting a little interested in you. Zeke - and Sims; you‚Äôre almost certain he‚Äôs training to become one later - for a few, but sometimes full Angels seem to be watching you when you‚Äôre out and about. Not enough to seem objectively creepy, but just... enough to be disconcerting. You start with the library, but predictably any information on Inquisitors beyond the surface level or passing mentions in other texts has been restricted. You do learn a few interesting things about the Cathedra‚Äôs hierarchy here, though, so it‚Äôs not a total loss. Inquisitors do not report to bishops or archbishops like ordinary Angels. Instead, they are considered to have a rank roughly analogous to Archangels, though somewhat outside of the typical structure. Instead, Inquisitors report directly to the prime council or, in rare cases, the Emissary himself. You‚Äôve heard of the prime council, but (just like Inquisitors) don‚Äôt know much beyond the basics. So you do some studying. ‚Äã
9:47 PM
The prime council is composed of primes, who are the highest ranking ministers in the Cathedra besides the Emissary. The council is handpicked by the Emissary and traditionally consists of nine members (three times three, so twice as holy, you suppose. Thrice?) The primes are collectively responsible for the Cathedra‚Äôs overall direction and governance, with each typically focusing on a specific facet as well as the whole. This is relevant to you for a multitude of reasons (including that they elect the Emissary), but today, primarily because one of the primes is in charge of Inquisition and is thus considered head of the Inquisitors, despite not being an Angel at all. Ranking and official positions get fuzzy near the top, you note, frowning at all the ‚Äútraditionally‚Äù and ‚Äútypically‚Äù and other words that indicate most of this structure is due to centuries of precedent rather than any official rules or scripture. Unfortunately, there‚Äôs not much more to find in the library unless you have a sponsor - which you definitely do not - so you try asking Naoriel next. Discreetly, since you‚Äôve learned by now that she‚Äôs a little nervous about Inquisitors and related topics. You suppose that‚Äôs reasonable, given that Zeke and Sims are still keeping their eyes on her despite nothing of note really happening for months. You have now officially been friends with her for almost a month, during which time you‚Äôve both gotten slightly less awkward around each other, so that surely means she won‚Äôt be too worried about sharing some information, right? No, you know better than that. Naoriel doesn‚Äôt like giving up secrets, so in all likelihood she‚Äôs going to say... ‚ÄúSure. What do you want to know?‚Äù ‚ÄúWhat, really?‚Äù ‚ÄúShould I change my Mind?‚Äù ‚ÄúNo - no, this is fine. Just a little unexpected!‚Äù She shrugs, poking at a loose thread in the jacket she‚Äôs repairing. For once, you‚Äôre ahead on your work and don‚Äôt have anything better to do than hang out and distract her. ‚Äã
9:47 PM
‚ÄúWell... I guess to start with, is there anything different about an Inquisitor? You know, from a regular Angel?‚Äù ‚ÄúNope. They just have a different position and extra responsibilities. Nothing physically different. Like Archangels in that way, except most of those have wings.‚Äù You expected as much, but it always pays to make sure. ‚ÄúOkay, so how are they recruited? You can‚Äôt just apply to be one.‚Äù ‚ÄúUsually they‚Äôre scouted by existing Inquisitors. I‚Äôve heard they tend to look for Angels with a strong sense of ‚Äòjustice,‚Äô good investigation skills, and who aren‚Äôt super obvious.‚Äù ‚ÄúI could literally hear the quote marks around ‚Äòjustice‚Äô there.‚Äù She drives a pin into the cloth with a little more force than strictly necessary. ‚ÄúThey say it‚Äôs ‚Äòjustice,‚Äô but really they‚Äôre just looking for people who like enforcing rules. If it‚Äôs the rules you enforce that decide how just you are, I don‚Äôt think you yourself can possibly be just. You‚Äôre just a middleman, I suppose. Just a just middleman... but just of ‚Äòjustice.‚Äô Hmm.‚Äù ‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù ‚ÄúIgnore me.‚Äù She says that a lot. ‚ÄúOkay...‚Äù You think for a moment, trying to work through her sentences. Except the last one, probably. ‚ÄúSo are their rules just?‚Äù ‚ÄúThey can be.‚Äù A few deft stitches and she starts pulling pins. Naoriel is surprisingly good at sewing, though you‚Äôd be hard pressed to explain exactly why you find that surprising. Maybe just that she‚Äôd bother at all when the normal staff will do it for you. ‚ÄúBut it depends on the primes. I‚Äôm sure you‚Äôve done your background research before asking me, so you know about them. Right?‚Äù ‚ÄúYeah. A little.‚Äù ‚Äã
9:47 PM
‚ÄúSo tell me, if you were the head of Inquisition, how would you decide what offenses or behaviors count as corruption? What about the other kind of corruption? You, as a prime, have almost unlimited authority to do pretty much whatever you want as long as the other primes don‚Äôt object. And they usually don‚Äôt, because even primes aren‚Äôt above Inquisition either. No one can be, or the system doesn‚Äôt work. So, you need to decide how to deal with all the findings your Inquisitors report up to you. Does a priest accepting untracked donations count as corruption? Should he get a rebuke, a demotion, a dismissal? What about a different priest who has a child after his ordainment? It‚Äôs not explicitly forbidden, but it‚Äôs close enough. An Angel who flees a tough situation and leaves a group of soldiers to die. What if they‚Äôre civilians? What if they come back covered in darkness? Under-the-table promises and favor-trading amongst the bishops. Trainees sneaking out of campus. Angels who are just a little too nosy?‚Äù She looks up at you with a very slight smile. ‚ÄúCould you design a system that‚Äôs completely fair?‚Äù ‚Äú... Wh - isn‚Äôt that what judges are for? Or... laws?‚Äù ‚ÄúNo one is above the Inquisition. That‚Äôs how it works. Politicians and judges can set laws, other primes and your predecessors can set standards, sure. But you have to be in charge of reviewing those too! Are the laws corrupt? Was the person who held your title before you corrupt? Having that kind of authority almost makes it harder to know what to do, since nothing can be absolutely certain when there‚Äôs no restrictions, you know?‚Äù You don‚Äôt, not really. You‚Äôve never been in that kind of situation. ‚ÄúSo... the prime just has to do what they think is right?‚Äù ‚ÄúYeah. And they‚Äôre only human. Despite their blessings.‚Äù ‚Äã
9:47 PM
‚Äú... It sounds... like a hard position to be in.‚Äù You try to imagine it; being the one responsible for deciding that Sister Bagley had to be dismissed but not executed. Had the prime even been involved? You never heard from anyone higher than that one bishop. ‚ÄúI‚Äôd be terrified of messing up. Of hurting someone who doesn‚Äôt deserve it.‚Äù ‚ÄúAnd yet, if you‚Äôre too lenient...‚Äù She catches your gaze again; you‚Äôre reminded that her irises are shockingly purple. Such an unnatural color. She must be using transmutation magic like Clarity. ‚ÄúPeople get hurt anyway. It‚Äôs a balancing act, and one that will never, ever be fair.‚Äù ‚ÄúYou‚Äôve... spent a lot of time thinking about this.‚Äù ‚Äú...‚Äù She doesn‚Äôt respond, but quickly goes back to her sewing. Faster than before. Embarrassed? Anxious? You can‚Äôt quite tell. In any case, that‚Äôs the end of the conversation before you can even bring up more questions; she changes the topic shortly after. - Hey, what‚Äôs Serri up to? You haven‚Äôt seen her in a bit. - Didn‚Äôt she say she had something going on? You should probably get back to what you were doing; she‚Äôll show up again soon. (Winner: ) (edited)

Mxblah 2/8/2024 9:23 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 61 Through a series of tangents, you end up talking about non-trivial medical care. How cheery the two of you are. But really, you‚Äôre not entirely sure how you got around to discussing what happens when an Angel is seriously injured out in the field, beyond their own ability to heal themself. 9:23 PM

9:24 PM
Naoriel looks over at you and raises an eyebrow. She‚Äôs being unusually expressive tonight. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre asking me instead of her?‚Äù ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs not here and I‚Äôm curious!‚Äù you defend yourself. Even Erich struggles, but after a few days of work, he retains his position as the preeminent student in the course. And then it‚Äôs suddenly October, and then November, and it‚Äôs winter again. Yara is now a sixth year; Serri is now a second year. You and the others throw parties for both of them. December comes and goes without much fuss either; you quietly bring up the idea of a birthday celebration to Naoriel and end up with a low-key but fun evening. Somehow, she‚Äôs integrated pretty well into your circle. That fake friendship is pretty convincing. It‚Äôs only when Cevember begins and the last Calling day of the year is more than a month ago that you start to wonder where all the new Angels are. Not a single person has Ascended after you, all the way back in March. It‚Äôs not an unheard of gap, but it‚Äôs not particularly common - especially since there are only ten trainees right now and the average is twelve. ‚Äã
9:24 PM
Well, whatever. There‚Äôs literally nothing you can do about it, and there‚Äôs plenty to occupy you right now. Which is going to go well and everyone will agree; you‚Äôre absolutely certain. (Not!) But before that inevitable disaster, there‚Äôs something even more exciting. You‚Äôre getting towards the end of your basic magic course and need to start thinking about specializing. No Angel can be proficient in every variety of magic right away, and even full Angels rarely attain their full strength in any more than two or three of the sixteen combinations. It‚Äôs time to choose the first path you‚Äôll explore, with the understanding that you can always choose more or change your Mind entirely. So. What will it be? [The winner in each category will combine to form your initial specialization. If you pick Soul transmutation of any sort, you‚Äôll reconsider and some second-places will win.] Ô∏è - Internal. Affecting the self, or aspects close to the self. - External. Affecting others, or the outside world. - Physical. - Body. - Mind. Ô∏è - Soul. Ô∏è - Projection. Adding or subtracting matter, energy, or concepts from the target aspect. Producing wind or quelling flames; healing or creating wounds; inducing or calming emotions; bolstering or Blessing Souls. Easier than transmutation. - Transmutation. Manipulating or changing what is already present. Repairing objects; growing wings; manipulating memories; performing delicate Soul mending. Harder than projection. (Winners: Ô∏è , , Ô∏è ) (edited)

@Story Notifications Scene 62 You take some time to think about it, as temperatures drop and snow begins to blanket the city. The fog grows thicker, mixing with the snow to form a deep, muffling quiet. Sounds die away quickly; the crunching of your footsteps hardly echoes, even when you stray off the cleared paths. Somehow, the cold doesn‚Äôt bite as much as you remember, even though your uniform‚Äôs jacket doesn‚Äôt seem as thick as your previous winter coat. 4:58 PM
‚ÄúCorrect! And granting magic to another Angel usually doesn‚Äôt do anything either, as they‚Äôre all able to cast anyway. Mxblah 2/12/2024 8:28 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 63 The talk about specializations - and specifically, Serri‚Äôs interest in healing - reminded you of something Naoriel had mentioned... gosh, it must have been months ago by now. Your memory is improving with both the general changes to your Mind from your Ascension as well as your training, but it‚Äôs still all too easy to slip up and forget things for ages. Anyway, the two of you leave the common room‚Äôs warmth behind head out into the cold to practice tethering. Internal spells, perhaps contrary to their name, don‚Äôt necessarily have to work on something inside you. Most of them do - enhancing your Body, Mind, or Soul - but internal physical spells are actually just effects that stay anchored on you instead of the world around you. There are some external spells that can work like this too, the lines are blurry, and the categories are all made up anyway. It doesn‚Äôt matter. You‚Äôre just out here to create auras of warmth around yourselves and see how long you can focus. It‚Äôs a pretty chilly day and the wind is strong, so you‚Äôve got strong incentive to perform well. Deep breath, sense the world around your Body, form the connection... ‚Äú...‚Äù This part takes a while. It‚Äôs hard to describe what action you‚Äôre actually taking when you change resonance phases, but it‚Äôs not a simple one. In any case, you get it eventually and start warming the air around yourself, neatly compartmentalizing that focus into a section of your Mind so you don‚Äôt have to think about the spell while you‚Äôre walking around. Well, you still do, just not as much. Also, you called that compartmentalization ‚Äúneat‚Äù just a moment ago, but you‚Äôre lying to yourself. You‚Äôre not very good at it yet. Another victory for self-honesty. Serri manages to bring up a similar bubble of warmth a few moments later and off you go. It‚Äôs kind of fun to look back at the melted footstep-shaped holes in the snow as you pass. ‚Äã
8:28 PM
And now, the real reason you needed that Mind trick to free up some concentration. ‚ÄúHey, Serri, you good to talk?‚Äù ‚Äú... I‚Äôm okay.‚Äù She‚Äôs not that bad with the Mind stuff; it‚Äôs just her Soul control that‚Äôs still behind yours. You‚Äôre gonna laugh.‚Äù ‚ÄúC‚Äômon, you know I won‚Äôt.‚Äù ‚Äú...‚Äù ‚ÄúReally!‚Äù ‚Äú... You know, Brother Cobb thinks it‚Äôs a great idea. She gets it back together and off you go. Again. ‚ÄúI know I don‚Äôt seem like someone who would last a minute in the wastelands, fighting against the darkness. @Story Notifications Scene 65 ... The sparring field is surrounded by trees and covered in deep, fluffy snow. The groundskeepers usually keep it clear, but nothing is scheduled today and there‚Äôs still an ongoing dusting of light flakes, so they haven‚Äôt gotten around to it yet. With the shifting layers of partially-frozen sand and powdery snow, it‚Äôs already tough to keep your footing even just walking to the starting locations. Serri definitely could have chosen a better day. Or maybe this is part of her plan? You grip the unfamiliar weight of your sword, sweeping it through the snow to get a sense of the drag. She‚Äôs probably actually certified to sit there, given all her demonstration matches. ‚ÄúStandard practice rules: first to three full hits wins. Magic is allowed, but no direct magical attacks (since I don‚Äôt know that cool warding spell) and for God‚Äôs sake try not to seriously hurt each other. 9:05 PM

It‚Äôs so fluffy that the cloud goes everywhere, blinding you for a moment. Bad position to be in; backpedal. Get out of range. Something heavy and wooden hisses past your Body at around stomach level, the blade just missing you. Hang on; change direction. Brief opening. That sudden shock isn‚Äôt quite enough to break your focus, but it is enough to accidentally release that spell you‚Äôve been preparing. ‚Äã
9:05 PM
Wind blasts out around you and the snowcloud breaks apart, flung away into the air. Serri‚Äôs to your right, not ahead of you, and your clumsy swing thuds into the padding on her side as she shields herself from the wall of snow and air. Trying to anticipate a swing or thrust and react in time, as well as get your own hits in, just takes a lot of quick thinking and agility. And she‚Äôs strong, too. You‚Äôre probably going to lose if this keeps up; you just don‚Äôt have the endurance to keep blocking for much longer. 9:05 PM

You‚Äôre not pleased either. Especially because you‚Äôve been sitting here doing nothing for half an hour without being allowed to leave or being told what‚Äôs going to happen next. Just that ‚Äúsomeone else will be here soon.‚Äù ‚Äú...‚Äù You‚Äôre still intimidated by her, and you‚Äôre starting to get really terrified that no one will be able to fix you. Despite Etalyn‚Äôs strong words, she‚Äôs only a trainee like you. She doesn‚Äôt know everything. And even these powerful, holy adult Angels don‚Äôt know. Who else could they possibly ask? The door clicks quietly open and you have to do a double take, the sight of him here is just so incongruous. Followed by two Angels with starmetal swords at their hips, the Emissary himself walks through the door. ‚ÄúArchangel,‚Äù he says, nodding to Aveline. ‚ÄúAnd Angel Jessamine Goodall. How are you feeling today?‚Äù ‚Äú---!‚Äù He smiles a calm little smile, shuffling into the room and asking one of his guards to bring a chair over. ‚ÄúSurprised, I see. That‚Äôs good; the fewer people who know where I am, the better. But you don‚Äôt have to worry. I am quite different outside of that stuffy old cathedral, you know.‚Äù A glance over to Aveline. ‚ÄúAnd you don‚Äôt have to worry, either. Failure is what makes us human. Even those of us with blessings like yours.‚Äù ‚Äú... Thank you, Emissary.‚Äù ‚Äã
12:26 PM
He chuckles a calm little chuckle. ‚ÄúStill unwilling to use my name, I see. Ah, you‚Äôve always been pious.‚Äù ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs only proper.‚Äù ‚ÄúProper for God, not me. Mxblah 2/20/2024 9:44 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 67 You‚Äôve come a long way from the first time you met him. It also helps that he‚Äôs so much less intimidating without the Lordstone Cathedral as a backdrop. In any case, you‚Äôre able to explain what you know without too much issue, covering the background of your sickness as a child, the recovery after your Ascension, and the recent resurgence. You even bring up what Etalyn said about the Soul smoke, though you were too preoccupied to verify that particular detail. The Emissary nods and listens, only speaking up once you finally finish rambling your way through the information. ‚ÄúI understand. You‚Äôve done quite well to mitigate this sickness‚Äôs power over your life. Let me see if I can help you further.‚Äù His gaze changes. Not the unnaturally golden color of his eyes or anything about the shape or tone. Just... something about how the room‚Äôs ambient light interacts with his Body has changed. Sharp, piercing. He stares into you as his divine insight picks apart your Soul. A brutally uncomfortable minute passes. Far longer than he spent inspecting you during your initiation. You don‚Äôt dare speak or even move. 9:44 PM
‚ÄúVery well.‚Äù The light reflecting in his eyes returns to its normal quality. You‚Äôre still not sure what exactly the difference is. ‚ÄúJessamine, I will be very straightforward with you. 9:45 PM

Mxblah 2/22/2024 8:41 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 68 ‚Äú... one of the most open Souls I‚Äôve seen in years...‚Äù ... Back in the lost, ancient days - before Angels and before the corruption - humanity‚Äôs Souls were open. You learned this months earlier in Brother Trigg‚Äôs course, but the concept returned to Mind as you overheard the Emissary‚Äôs words. Originally, human Souls could easily change phase and form to connect with each other and the world around them. Magic was commonplace; it hardly took more effort to control one‚Äôs Soul as it did to control one‚Äôs hand. Of course, you‚Äôre well aware that this ended tragically, with the corruption arising somehow (leading theories believe it was due to a random mutation that then spread too quickly to contain due to the world‚Äôs interconnectedness) and eventually causing the year-zero cataclysm. As the corruption spread, God took drastic measures to stop it, closing off humanity‚Äôs Souls from the world and each other; preventing further direct infection. This also cut off magic, however, crippling humanity‚Äôs ability to fight back and eventually leading to the Ascension of the first Angels to compensate. These Angelic Souls were bolstered in strength to be able to handle the connection required to use magic without succumbing to the corruption that inevitably came with it. As some scholars argue, Angels are thus more human than humans are. It‚Äôs not just Erich; there are plenty among your cohort and the Cathedra generally who believe that ordinary humans are somehow lesser after God‚Äôs change to their Souls. The loss of that connection - of that reflection of the divine‚Äôs own form - is something that only Angels have regained. Sometimes you wonder what God is like. You‚Äôre getting off track from your original topic, but you don‚Äôt care. It‚Äôs just easier to sit here and drift off in your own thoughts, bouncing from concept to concept whenever something occurs to you. You‚Äôll come back to the important stuff later, probably. ‚Äã
8:42 PM
God has a Body, a Mind, and a Soul. Just like you; just like every human. You, and everyone else, are made in His original, divine image. But... what is He like, really? His Mind is embedded in the planet, at least partially, broken and diffused to keep the darkness uncoordinated. With more reports recently of shades growing stronger and the possibility of Mind-transferring magic seemingly not far away, you wonder how long He will stay there. Objects can have Minds, sort of, according to Brother Cobb, so is God... the planet? If He is, what will happen when He leaves it to return to His original Body? Will He? The only things you know about God‚Äôs Body are that it resides somewhere in the sky far above the planet, and that the Lordstone is a piece of it. So, what does - wait, you know one more thing, actually. You are a reflection of God, so He must look like you. Right? To an extent, at least; the same number of arms and legs and general Body plan. Presumably. But... you don‚Äôt have a crystal like the Lordstone embedded in you somewhere, do you? You haven‚Äôt gone into much depth on anatomy, but even you know that human Bodies are made of flesh and bone, not crystal. A seeming contradiction like that must have been investigated before; surely you‚Äôre not the first person to have the question. You‚Äôll need to look it up later. Maybe the Lordstone is an analogue to your heart or brain or even an eye? Eyes can sort of look crystalline in the right light. Or maybe God is just formed entirely of somehow-mobile crystal, shaped into a human-like form? The idea of a gargantuan, divine, crystalline person floating somewhere far above strikes you as very silly, and you quickly apologize to God for thinking such a thing. And then, after further consideration, you apologize again for thinking your previous thought was silly, just in case it‚Äôs actually true. ‚Äã
8:42 PM
... God‚Äôs Soul. His third aspect isn‚Äôt talked about as much as the other two; your knowledge here is relegated mostly to the fact that He touches the Souls of Ascending Angels to grant them His strength. You‚Äôre not entirely sure what that means; maybe it‚Äôs sort of a stronger version of the Blessings that Angels can do? But that only takes up a tiny fraction of each year; what does He do beyond that? Souls quickly decay without a Body to inhabit and a Mind to tie the two together. You learned that from Brother Cobb again, but also from your history course when going over some of the frankly horrifying experiments done in the fourth century - just after Erejil‚Äôs death - relating to separating individual aspects from their fellows. Using the primitive measuring techniques at the time, Souls were observed disappearing a few hours to a few days after their Body‚Äôs (and Mind‚Äôs) death. Because the Bodies and Minds died simultaneously, it was unknown at the time whether the Soul required the Body, Mind, or both. And although ways now exist to destroy the Mind without killing the Body (thanks to the corruption) no one has repeated the experiment to confirm. For good reason. Would God‚Äôs Soul work the same way? With His Mind away, is His Body still alive? Is His Soul still tied to it, or does it reside with His Mind in the planet below? Both? Or are only humans so weak to require other aspects to maintain their Souls? You‚Äôve reached an end to one train of thought and begin the arduous journey back to the root. Open Souls. Your own. It could explain your sensitivity to Soul... as well as your susceptibility to the corruption. But what caused it? Is the shape of your Soul just an innate trait, or was there something that changed you? Your sickness? Or something else? ‚Äú...‚Äù ‚Äã
8:42 PM
The Emissary leaves and Aveline gives you the outline of a treatment plan, to be expanded upon later. It seems you‚Äôll be doing most of it yourself, over a period of probably years. Don‚Äôt let the sickness have any impact on your life. Grow beyond it. Grow despite it. But also practice the following Body and Mind magic, templated out in texts full of physical tricks and states of Mind penned by the Angel who first cast them. Miracles, they call these prepackaged spells. Robust and powerful; easier to learn than developing one yourself. But inflexible, as you didn‚Äôt make them. Even if you read the whole book cover to cover a hundred times, you‚Äôll never understand them to the degree of a spell you craft on your own. But still. Useful. You‚Äôd never be able to imagine the exacting control over your organs that this author describes, accompanied by painstaking illustrations of the precise effect it‚Äôs supposed to produce on your lungs. Mxblah 2/24/2024 5:37 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 69 It‚Äôs late and you‚Äôre in bed, unable to sleep. Again. You were pretty out of it for the rest of the day after all the stuff that happened. Serri and Etalyn listened to what you relayed about your sickness and possible treatments. They said some things in response, but you don‚Äôt remember. It‚Äôs kind of a blur. You‚Äôll probably have to get back to her about it once you‚Äôve calmed down a bit. The sickness is hiding again. You can‚Äôt feel it anymore, just like pretty much all the time after your Ascension until just today. There‚Äôs no sense of it lurking within you, biding its time and waiting to strike. It‚Äôs just gone. You know better now, of course, but at least it seems you‚Äôll be able to ignore it most of the time. If its behavior is still the same, it‚Äôs only going to be during exertion that you‚Äôll have to be careful. Still, as you get older and stronger, you‚Äôre going to be fighting more. Miracles often come with a specific ritual to perform in order to use them, primarily just to get you in the same Mindset as the creator. Ordinarily, you don‚Äôt need to say or do anything special to cause an effect; you just know what you want and impose your will on the target. 5:37 PM

There aren‚Äôt any humans to clear them, outside of narrow bands around the walls and nearby train tracks. The snow must get unbelievably deep. You‚Äôre going to regret this in the morning if you can‚Äôt get to sleep, but what are you supposed to do if your Body just won‚Äôt cooperate? Honestly, you hadn‚Äôt noticed any issues with the building‚Äôs heating until tonight, but it just seems way too warm now. Even standing in the main room is little better, despite your very light attire and the winter wind just one pane of glass away. And then, all the excess warmth in the room seems to recede in an instant as you glimpse a lone figure through the mist and gently falling snow. Tall, cloaked in some sort of form-hiding clothes, and unlit by anything but the faintest light from nearby mechanical lamps, you can‚Äôt tell much about them. But you know they‚Äôre facing Hearth Hall, because after a few moments of just staring at the building, they begin to walk towards it. ‚Äã
5:37 PM
Simultaneously, you feel a wave of powerful energy washing over you and - you‚Äôre certain - the rest of the building. Magic of some kind; there‚Äôs no way such a strong sensation could be anything else. You don‚Äôt know what it was intended to do or what it did - you don‚Äôt feel any different - but you do know that casting spells, on every Angel in the building, at night, while everyone should be sleeping, without anyone‚Äôs consent, is definitely not allowed. The figure disappears from view in an eddy of misty snow. They‚Äôre heading straight for the front entrance. Something is terribly wrong, you‚Äôre absolutely certain. Even though the winter night looks the same as before, you‚Äôre absolutely wide awake and brimming with fear. Something is telling you to act, and act fast. But what should you do? @Story Notifications Scene 70 ‚Äú...!‚Äù You bolt to the door and sprint into the corridor, not slowing to get properly dressed or even find your shoes. Now! Right now! You hardly have any time to get downstairs to find whoever that is before you won‚Äôt know where to look. Oh, why did this have to happen now? It hardly even occurs to you to worry about disturbing anyone as you knock loudly on her door - if anyone else gets up, that‚Äôs just more people to help you now. ‚ÄúSerri!‚Äù you call, caught somewhere between a desire to be as loud as possible to wake her up and a desire to be as quiet as possible so the mysterious figure can‚Äôt possibly hear you. ‚Äú...‚Äù Nothing. This is the Sulday of Charity and - to the Cathedra - there‚Äôs nothing more charitable than spending a late night in the snow with most available Angels helping as many people as possible. Campus has been empty all day. And, now, so is Hearth Hall. Well, except for your fellow trainees. Maybe someone else is a light enough sleeper to wake up, but at this point you don‚Äôt have time. 8:23 PM
And so you enter the middle stairwell, closest to Serri‚Äôs room, and start to hurry downsta- The door at the bottom of the stairwell clanks open. You freeze. Right. If you had taken the leftmost stairwell, closest to your room, you would have been able to get all the way downstairs without running into the mystery person, who (now that you think about it) would obviously take the middle stairwell, as that‚Äôs where the main entrance is. This is both good (since you found the mystery person) and definitely not good (since you really don‚Äôt want the mystery person to find you). And it‚Äôs not like you can just open a door and leave; the clanking sound would echo up and down the entire space. Footsteps. Heavy and booted, but fast. Your only hope is to just pray that wherever they‚Äôre going, it‚Äôs below the top floor. Quietly, carefully, immensely grateful that your rushed exit left you in a near-silent nightgown and without any loud shoes, you creep up the stairs towards the roof. The mystery person is much faster than you, not having to worry about keeping silent in the stairway, and you start to worry that you won‚Äôt make it to the top floor in time. The idea that maybe this is just some Angel who forgot something in their room and needed to come back for it never crosses your Mind. Not after that wave of energy. Instead, you can‚Äôt help but wonder what they are doing here. Why are they just climbing the stairs? There‚Äôs nothing here but Angels‚Äô living quarters; are they here for theft, or... something worse? No way. Such an act would be a sin so severe it would be akin to spitting in God‚Äôs face. No one would do it. Unless... You focus inward. Your Soul is unusually bright tonight and it‚Äôs correspondingly easy to shift your phase. 8:23 PM

Mxblah 2/28/2024 8:47 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 71 You vault over the railing and land on the sixth floor‚Äôs landing with a quiet thump, guided by your Body training both to avoid hurting yourself and avoid making too much noise. Then, you reach out and snag the door just before it shuts, carefully levering it open just enough so you can peek out into the hallway. The mystery person is close; you‚Äôre only a few paces behind them now. Still - thank God - you‚Äôve managed to avoid them hearing you. They‚Äôve slowed down now, looking up to check one of the signs displaying which rooms are in which direction, then turning around the right corner and leaving the common area. You cautiously slip out of the stairwell and ease the door shut as quietly as you can, trembling at the tiny click as the latch slips in. You creep to the corner, sensing Soul again on the way over to get an approximate position. It‚Äôs hard to sense Souls around corners and through walls, but you‚Äôve been generally able to make out Angelic Souls through (one) normal wall for a few months now. Anyway, the mystery person has made it partway down the corridor and seems to still be moving away, so you figure it‚Äôs safe enough to peek around the corner normally to see what‚Äôs going on. 8:47 PM
Oh no no no; that has to be it. She‚Äôs always been worried about Inquisitors; being tailed by Zeke and Sims for a reason you still have yet to figure out. And an individual with a Soul like the mystery person can‚Äôt be anyone other than a powerful Angel. One with extra duties, perhaps? One who finally gathered some piece of evidence, enough to... do something horrible to her? Surely they wouldn‚Äôt just kill her, right? But... but then why... in the middle of the night?! The person stops. 607. Naoriel‚Äôs room. What... what do you do? What can you do? A key emerges; slots into the lock. A tiny click, audible to you only because you‚Äôre straining all your senses down the hallway. Your heartbeat almost drowns it out. You have to do something. But what? You can‚Äôt think through the panic. The door opens; the person enters. You sprint around the corner, completely unable to explain what your plan might be. Your feet hardly seem to touch the ground. They didn‚Äôt close the door, and somehow didn‚Äôt hear you, again. Are you really that quiet? You peek around the half-open door, able to make out two glimmering Souls in the dim light. She‚Äôs really there too; this isn‚Äôt some awful prank where Naoriel put on platform shoes and a weird cloak and then entered her own room. She wouldn‚Äôt have been able to fake the Soul anyway. You‚Äôre not thinking straight. A sheet of fabric emerges from the cloak. Unfolds. It‚Äôs not a sheet; it‚Äôs a bag. A sack. The near-cliche tool featured in cautionary tales across the city. And as the figure pulls off the covers and starts to slide the still-unconscious Naoriel into the bag, you have to change your assessment. This isn‚Äôt a murder. It‚Äôs a kidnapping. You have to stop it. You have to stop it. Oh, God. ‚Äã
8:47 PM
[Two characters‚Äô fates are temporarily stable. Three characters‚Äô fates will be altered. Specify details in #story_discussion. I have a lot of liberty with writing this next scene.] - Oppose the kidnapper. Put a stop to this. [This includes options such as directly confronting or attacking them, distracting them, forcing them to chase you, and similar plans that require interaction with the kidnapper in some way.] - Run as fast as you possibly can. Get help. [This includes options such as attempting to wake other trainees, getting help from other Angels at the Center, and similar plans that require no interaction with the kidnapper.] (Winner: ) (edited)

Mxblah 3/1/2024 9:14 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 72 You don‚Äôt stop to think. You just do. Somehow flipping your resonance phase in a matter of seconds - despite it taking you half a minute just earlier today - you gather the air and command it to your aid. A pause; a moment of brief low pressure as the breeze bends to your will. The mystery person looks up, finally noticing something is wrong. Not fast enough. You release, feeling the strain on your Soul as you twist it in ways you‚Äôve only just started to practice. Still, you‚Äôre suffused with warmth and the air obeys. A torrent of powerful wind rushes through the room, tossing loose objects around and throwing Naoriel and her assailant in opposite directions. That was the strongest magic you‚Äôve controlled to date. No time to stop and marvel at it; you dash into the confused mess of air, nearly stumbling over several books or paintings you knocked to the floor. Surely that has to have been enough to wake her up, right? No such luck. There‚Äôs powerful magic at work here; no way Naoriel would still be sleeping normally after having just been tossed to the floor like that. You kneel, grab her arms, slump her over your shoulder like you‚Äôve seen some of the full Angels do, then try to stand. Urgh... heavy. You‚Äôve never been particularly strong, even after your Ascension, but you can just about manage to stand up. ... Until the mystery person recovers. Their cloak has been blown away by the force of your blast, revealing them as a somewhat gaunt, unkempt man with patchy stubble on his face. You recoil as he leaps up from the other side of the bed, both due to the immediate threat and because he doesn‚Äôt look anything like an Angel. No Bodily perfection at all. But... the Soul - what?! ‚Äã
9:14 PM
‚ÄúTch. You, I did not expect.‚Äù His voice is scratchy and almost seems layered, like there are several of him speaking just out of sync with each other. ‚ÄúOne of the older ones with more resistance, perhaps, but you? Put her down and no one has to get hurt.‚Äù You take a step back, towards the entrance. He doesn‚Äôt want to hurt you; at least, not enough to make open combat his first option. You have an opening. Memories of your combat courses whirl through your Mind. Older ones. Resistance. You can‚Äôt do this. Not on your own; you need help! You - your breathing... ‚ÄúPut her down. Now.‚Äù An edge of anger; the man places a hand on a short scabbard on his left hip. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt do anything you‚Äôll regret.‚Äù Why won‚Äôt anyone wake up? You‚Äôve made so much noise! Even Naoriel - ! ‚ÄúOkay...‚Äù you murmur, shuffling back another step and raising your arms to lean forward, as if you‚Äôre about to place Naoriel on the floor in front of you. But, at the same time, you switch to Mind. Again, the transition is almost instant; unbelievably quick for someone of your novice skill. But you‚Äôve been practicing this spell ever since you decided to make Mind your specialization. Internally instead of externally, sure, but how different can it be? You bring your Mental connection with Naoriel to the forefront - reliving your shared experiences and thoughts over the last few months - and push as much energy into her head as you can muster. The simplest form of Mental projection magic, and one where the desired outcome is equally simple: to blast away any external influence. Such as, for instance, a sleeping spell. Naoriel gasps and stumbles out of your arms, falling heavily to the floor as you completely fail to catch her. You‚Äôve been using a huge amount of energy; your Soul is already almost spent. And although casting magic doesn‚Äôt cause physical strain, your sickness is building as you exert yourself further. ‚ÄúRun! Go!‚Äù you scream, reaching down to pull her upright. ‚Äã
9:15 PM
She‚Äôs remarkably quick on the uptake, taking only a few seconds to go from completely unconscious to on her feet and running alongside you for the hallway. But, just as you‚Äôre about to reach it, there‚Äôs a rush of wind and the door slams shut. Then, another burst of energized air rustles your hair and clothes, though you can‚Äôt tell what this one was designed to do. The door is well and truly stuck; you can‚Äôt get it open even though the handle turns freely. ‚ÄúCalm down. Look at me.‚Äù You turn, shaking and almost out of tricks. Naoriel found a regular butter knife somewhere and is gripping it like a weapon. Neither of you can say anything, but that‚Äôs not because you aren‚Äôt trying. In fact, the air around you seems to have almost hardened, deadening any sound you might try to make. ‚ÄúYou win. I‚Äôll admit that,‚Äù the man says, hands casually in pockets as he kicks aside something on the floor. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt do anything now without making a fuss or killing you both. And that‚Äôs just not something I‚Äôm willing to do.‚Äù W-what? ‚ÄúEven if I wiped your memory of this event, you‚Äôd naturally be questioned as one of her-‚Äù a nod to Naoriel; the man seems to be addressing you. ‚Äú-friends. They‚Äôd find something. Erasure isn‚Äôt clean enough. So, I‚Äôll leave. And I won‚Äôt be back. Not like this, at least. You have my word.‚Äù ‚Äú...?!‚Äù ‚ÄúBut. If either of you breathe a word of what happened here, to anyone else.‚Äù The sword emerges from its sheath. Starmetal glimmers in the low light. That blade is sharp enough to shear completely through your torso in a single swing. ‚ÄúNot only will I return, but someone may just receive an anonymous tip.‚Äù Finally, his eyes slide over to Naoriel. ‚ÄúBastard child. I know all about you, and if you let a single peep slip out, your precious Emissary and all his primes will know it too.‚Äù Naoriel drops the knife. She‚Äôs shaking worse than you now. ‚Äã
9:15 PM
‚ÄúThat‚Äôs what I thought.‚Äù He glances briefly behind him and the window springs open, releasing frigid winter air into the room. ‚ÄúSee you later, girls. Just not like this.‚Äù And out he goes, plummeting six stories. Except with control over the air like he‚Äôs just demonstrated, you doubt he‚Äôs even going to reach the ground. The silencing barrier falls apart a moment later. ‚Äú...‚Äù Neither of you know what to say. @Story Notifications Scene 74 ‚Äú...‚Äù It‚Äôs... not your place to ask. The two of you decide to go to evening mass instead of rushing for the morning one, then spend some time cleaning up Naoriel‚Äôs room while everyone else is out. 9:47 PM

Though given that you now have less than a full week left before the festival, that does make sense. 9:47 PM

The caving slip means you‚Äôll be sent down into the vast network of caverns beneath the city, harvesting edible mushrooms from the top levels or descending deeper to hunt for spiny shelled creatures and map out more of the network for future expeditions. It‚Äôs what most of Serri‚Äôs family does, so she pops over to give you a few bits of advice beforehand. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a lot wetter down there than you‚Äôd expect,‚Äù she informs you. ‚ÄúSo make sure you really pay attention when they teach you how to seal your boots and gloves and stuff. Also, don‚Äôt touch your face after touching any plants down there except for ones you definitely know what they are. My sister did that once and her cheeks swelled up for days afterwards. It was really funny, except it was also really painful. So not really that funny, actually.‚Äù ‚Äã
9:47 PM

Mxblah 3/7/2024 9:58 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 75 Gate, station, train, station, gate. It doesn‚Äôt take all that long to make your way out to the cavern entrance where you‚Äôll be working for the next two days. You and Erich don‚Äôt really talk much on the way there, though at least there is a monk accompanying you so it‚Äôs not terribly awkward. Just moderately so. Nor does it take very long to meet your hosts - you try but fail to catch anyone‚Äôs name as the train starts pulling away at exactly the wrong time with a chorus of hissing steam - or get suited up in the drab brown outfits designed for work in the caves. It‚Äôs a weird kind of dissonance to see Erich in such plain, untidy (though clearly recently washed) attire - he‚Äôs usually so fastidious about his appearance. You‚Äôre sure your own appearance is strange as well, but there aren‚Äôt any mirrors here so you can‚Äôt tell for sure. The fabric is rough and not very breathable; of course not, as it‚Äôs supposed to be mostly waterproof. It‚Äôs not very comfortable. You‚Äôre used to finer clothes now. But it does do the job. The supervisor has you both wade through a deep puddle to test the seals, and thankfully you‚Äôve both done them well enough to emerge dry. Then that‚Äôs it; it‚Äôs time to go underground. You take one more look around the area - just a small cleared section along the rails between the still-dense buildings of the city - and descend into the earth. ‚Äã
9:58 PM
You‚Äôve never been belowground before. Well, basements and such, but not really belowground. Daylight from above gets lost in merely a few turns, leaving you with only the supervisor‚Äôs helmet-mounted light that seems to operate similar to a mechanical lamp. You wonder how it can still produce light without an obvious source of steam, but he doesn‚Äôt know how it works either. He just has to connect it to a pipe aboveground to recharge, then it‚Äôs good for a few hours at least. Of course, neither you nor Erich need any lights, as you can simply release your glows and illuminate the caverns with your Souls. The supervisor comments how useful that would be for the ordinary folks who work here normally, then continues on. A dirty wooden elevator shaft looms open to your left, connecting to one of the buildings upstairs, but you aren‚Äôt using it today. That one descends to the deeper areas, where unexplored passages still teem with unknown creatures. No, today you‚Äôll be staying up here in the mushroom fields. Much safer. The Cathedra certainly wouldn‚Äôt appreciate it if any of their trainees never returned. The mood is all wrong for that joke. Some of the others you pass eye you with a glare somewhere between suspicion and resentment. That‚Äôs new. You don‚Äôt feel very divine down here, singled out by your glow and your appearance. ‚Äã
9:59 PM
The most abundant type of cultivated fungus down here is called slab mushrooms. They‚Äôre about a foot and a half in diameter, maybe a quarter of that thick, and resemble semi-melted pats of cracked, grey skin. The supervisor demonstrates how to tell if they‚Äôre ready for harvest (by the texture and firmness, primarily), how to pull one out of the ground (use a gentle twisting motion, pulling just around the hidden stalk beneath the bulbous cap), how to remove and discard the lower portion (with a knife), and how to pack them efficiently for transport (there‚Äôs a specialized wire basket with some built-in racks to stack them like extremely unappetizing pancakes). He also breaks one open so you can see the thick, off-white interior. Apparently they‚Äôre surprisingly nutritious and taste almost like flour-based products when prepared properly. You wonder if you were actually quite privileged, even before you became an Angel. You‚Äôve never had to understand any of this; your parents always bought normal food, not these weird mushrooms. Well, normal to you. To some people, given how cheap they are for how many people they can feed, these mushrooms would be the norm, not ordinary bread. ‚ÄúOrdinary.‚Äù You‚Äôre doing it again. Anyway, after some time working on the nearby patch with the supervisor correcting you occasionally, he seems satisfied, asks you to finish harvesting this patch and the one next to it, then come back up for a break. And then he leaves. You‚Äôre not alone down here; there are plenty of other people around harvesting, carrying, or tending to the fungi. But most of them tend to avoid you. No one‚Äôs sure how to act around an Angel just... farming, like a normal person. And there are still those occasional people with the glares that make you very uncomfortable. Hyper-aware of your glow. Why are they so upset? You‚Äôre just here to help them, and even in your normal duties that doesn‚Äôt change. You protect them. That‚Äôs your job. That‚Äôs your purpose. ‚Äã
9:59 PM
‚ÄúE-Erich,‚Äù you finally murmur, voice masked under the flow of trickling water from a nearby stream. Serri wasn‚Äôt kidding about it being wet down here. ‚ÄúH-‚Äù ‚ÄúYes? Did you need something? Are you having fun, Jessamine, and wanted to ask if I were enjoying this enthralling experience as much as you?‚Äù ‚ÄúWh - no? Why would - nevermind. I just wanted to ask if you noticed those people staring at us.‚Äù ‚ÄúWhich people?‚Äù He stands up and looks around the cavern until he spots the men you were talking about, making obvious eye contact until they look away, grumbling darkly. ‚ÄúThem?‚Äù ‚ÄúY-yes. But you didn‚Äôt have to do that.‚Äù ‚ÄúDo what? Confront them about it, even weakly? Pah, they have no right to even look at us like that.‚Äù ‚ÄúPlease, um, keep your voice down...‚Äù Unlike you, he‚Äôs not making much of an effort to stay quiet and some of his remarks are definitely audible to nearby workers. More people are stealing glances at you now. Your skin crawls, and not because a bug got into your outfit. A heavy sigh, but he does as you request. ‚ÄúSo. I noticed them. What about it?‚Äù Ô∏è - Mention the resentment you felt. What does he think? - Nevermind. He‚Äôll probably just make things worse if you continue with this topic. ... No, you‚Äôre not confident enough to try to talk to the other workers. You doubt it would be a good idea anyway. (Winner: ) (edited)

Mxblah 3/9/2024 6:06 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 76 ‚Äú...‚Äù The stares. No, this isn‚Äôt worth it. You doubt he‚Äôd have anything to say you‚Äôd want to hear, anyway. ‚ÄúN-nevermind.‚Äù ‚ÄúReally? You just wanted to know that?‚Äù A pause; you shrug nervously. ‚ÄúFine, whatever. Get back to work, then.‚Äù Whew. Normal workers lose interest and turn away after a few more moments, leaving you to just your thoughts and the mushrooms. Still, you‚Äôre now hyper-aware of not just your glow, but its effect on everyone nearby. People still glance at you, even without pointedly staring, far more than you‚Äôre used to. Like when you came back to school after your sickness receded. You haven‚Äôt had to deal with that since you Ascended; Angels are common in the Cathedra and you‚Äôve always been disguised outside of it. Those glares persist. Not as unbroken as when you had mentioned it to Erich, but there are still glimpses out of the corner of your eye. When they think you aren‚Äôt looking, unaware of the heightened senses that came with your changed Body and Mind. Most people just seem curious - being able to watch an Angel for such an extended period of time is highly unusual - but those glares... What are they thinking? Almost without realizing it, you begin to attune your Soul to the Mind aspect. It takes you the normal half a minute again; you‚Äôve never been able to reproduce the near-instant switches from that night with Naoriel and the intruder. She didn‚Äôt have any real ideas either when you mentioned it, and it‚Äôs not like you can ask anyone. You did have the thought that maybe it was just her, acting as some sort of magic-enhancer, but a few different experiments trying to reproduce the scenario didn‚Äôt seem to work at all. Maybe you need to be in actual peril for it to work. You‚Äôre not sure; it remains yet another mystery on the pile. ‚Äã
6:07 PM
Anyway, although you did choose internal Mind projection as your first area of focus, your Mind instructor has been making you practice with external projection too, as she claims it‚Äôs far more useful to learn both together than just one. Of course, that means you‚Äôre making slower progress in both, but you do at least get where she‚Äôs coming from. Internal Mind projection involves bolstering your own Mind against intrusion, primarily, which is why you picked it. You wanted to be sure your thoughts are your own. But there‚Äôs limited impact you can have on the world or your opponents like that. The corruption will attack your Mind, but you won‚Äôt be facing it for real for years to come. It‚Äôs a good idea to also build a skill you can use in more flexible ways. Denn agreed with her assessment as well; you had almost forgotten when you were choosing your focus with Yara, Serri, and Etalyn, but Denn is focusing on much the same path as you‚Äôve chosen. You don‚Äôt meet up with him all that often (for some reason, he hangs out with Erich a lot!) but he‚Äôs still given you some tips about the techniques he‚Äôs found most useful to practice. So the point is that you‚Äôve started working on being able to sense thoughts and emotions in those around you, while avoiding getting overwhelmed yourself. It‚Äôs not exactly a combination of external and internal magic (you can only focus on one target at a time, and this one‚Äôs external) but a lot of the internal principles do apply to keep from getting lost in others‚Äô feelings. Okay. Deep breath, form the connection. Mind magic requires a Mental connection, but that‚Äôs simple enough here. You can use the work; the feelings of plucking mushrooms from the mucky dirt. Your thoughts about the job almost certainly aren‚Äôt the same as the others‚Äô, but there‚Äôs enough commonality to make the bond. Now... release. Open your senses. Listen. ‚Äú...‚Äù ‚Äã
6:07 PM
You don‚Äôt get any explicit words or obvious surges of emotion. You‚Äôre not good enough for that; not yet. But you do feel something. Several things. A dull chill, like sitting submerged in one of the many puddles or streams down here. Lanterns in the distance, distractingly bright and flickery. Glitzy; glamorous. These caverns are deep. So deep that the bottom has never been found, nor even fathomed. Just tunnels after tunnels, winding their twisting way down into the corruption-festering bedrock below. ... Some of those may have been your thoughts. You pull back, letting the lingering magic disperse into the air. One of the grumbly guys looks up briefly, as if confused. Maybe he felt your touch? Even though it was so light? You hope not; he doesn‚Äôt need any more reasons to dislike you. That... wasn‚Äôt really helpful at all. The only thing you learned wasn‚Äôt really new; just remembering that the earth itself is corrupted. How far down would you have to go before the ground starts to hate you? Is the entire city sitting atop a mire of darkness? What‚Äôs stopping it from flooding up from tunnels unknown and rising to walk the city streets? ... You, presumably. Well, not only did you fail to learn anything, now you‚Äôre nervous about that open elevator shaft just a few tunnels over. Imagining some nebulous miasma of darkness rising from the depths to strike you down... Oh, you‚Äôre done with the mushrooms. Time to head back up. ‚ú® - Things get a little better. - Things get a little worse. (Winner: ‚ú® ) (edited)

Mxblah 3/11/2024 10:17 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 77 The rest of the day isn‚Äôt as bad once you‚Äôve gotten used to it. The promised break that you don‚Äôt physically need grants you an opportunity to wander the small area above and watch as workers load stacks of mushrooms onto a cargo train. Discreetly. You don‚Äôt know how they‚Äôd react to being observed, and you don‚Äôt mean anything by it. You‚Äôre just curious. This sort of thing is new to you. No one really approaches you, including Erich. He seems content to just sit in a corner and grumble to himself while you poke around. It‚Äôs interesting how even the wispy, woody vines growing along the fence still produce little bluish berries. Every plant in the city needs to grow something edible, you know, but you sorta figured that rule only applied to things people planted purposefully. Although you suppose it‚Äôs possible that the vines are here on purpose. The afternoon goes more smoothly than the morning. The work isn‚Äôt any different - there‚Äôs a lot of mushrooms to harvest - with the exception that you also have to tend to the ones that are still growing. It‚Äôs not hard; you‚Äôre well aware that fungi can grow anywhere, especially a place as dark and damp as this cave. No, all you have to do is sprinkle some fertilizer around, check to make sure the soil is nice and moist, and add a touch of water if it isn‚Äôt. Oh, and make sure there aren‚Äôt any pests or weeds getting too close. You sorta get into it after a while, tending to the little ones that aren‚Äôt yet ready and extracting the bigger ones that are. It‚Äôs kinda soothing. But you can definitely understand how this job would get monotonous after doing it for weeks, or months, or years. For you, it‚Äôs a nice break from your daily routine. For the workers who do this for a living, it is their daily routine. ‚Äã
10:17 PM
At the end of the day, you‚Äôre thanked by the supervisor for gracing his humble worksite with your presence (you try to turn it around to thank him for the opportunity, but don‚Äôt quite manage it; Erich doesn‚Äôt say anything), then you get back on the train and return to the Cathedra. A few other workers who are waiting for a different train have to stand there and watch as your train blocks theirs (idling just down the tracks), since there‚Äôs only one platform at this station. You try to hurry up to minimize the disruption. The trainees catch up at dinner and trade stories about everyone‚Äôs jobs. Yara and Etalyn, working in sanitation, were spared from the dirtiest work by their supervisor, who seemed about ready to faint at the thought of sending Angels to go clean anything worse than a fresh water pipe. Naoriel had ended up with Emmett as attendants at one of the main train stations downtown. They spent some time sorting letters and cargo and such, and some time in a ticket office. Every customer got a surprise at the window that day. Serri and Rhysa, meanwhile, worked in delivery at the same station as Naoriel and Emmett, helping to move supplies from bulk trains to local carriages and vice versa. Rhysa is apparently pretty adept at levitating objects, so she was extremely popular with the workers there. And finally, there hadn‚Äôt been enough unique jobs for everyone, so Denn and Sims spent the day similarly to Naoriel, Emmett, Serri, and Rhysa, but at a different station. ‚Äã
10:17 PM
Everyone else experienced some degree of being set apart from the regular population and other workers, but no one reported any glares or senses of vague resentment. Although, when you bring that up, Yara‚Äôs quick to point out that everyone else had been in public or at least close to it. Sanitation work takes place in the city streets, and the various station people were either working directly with the public or within plain view on cargo platforms just across from the passenger ones. You and Erich were just down in the caverns all day with no one but the other workers around. ‚ÄúBut why would they dislike us?‚Äù you say, though you already have an idea. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre just there to help, and that doesn‚Äôt change even once we go back to our normal jobs. I‚Äôve never met anyone who isn‚Äôt grateful that Angels are here to protect the city.‚Äù Glances here and there. Some of the trainees seem to be considering it, like they aren‚Äôt quite sure either. Some, however, are just deciding how best to phrase the answer. - ‚ÄúThey hate us because we‚Äôre better than them.‚Äù - ‚ÄúThey hate us because we‚Äôre better off than them.‚Äù - ‚ÄúThey hate us because we represent the corruption, through its inverse.‚Äù - ‚ÄúThey hate us because they are corrupted.‚Äù (Winner: ) (edited)

Mxblah 3/13/2024 9:46 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 78 ‚ÄúThey hate us because we‚Äôre better off than them.‚Äù Emmett, surprisingly. You haven‚Äôt really talked to him much (at all). Predictably, most of the group turns to him for some sort of elaboration. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs obvious, isn‚Äôt it? We didn‚Äôt ‚Äòdo‚Äô anything to earn our spots here at the Cathedra; we were simply chosen by God in our Callings. And just look at all the fabulous benefits we get for that ‚Äònothing.‚Äô Immortality. Magic. Enhanced Bodies and Minds. To say nothing of the actual living arrangements. From the outside, the training and work we do is hidden. As is the danger we put ourselves in every day to defend the city and its population. But even with that, wouldn‚Äôt you say the rewards are worth it?‚Äù You think about that. And you keep thinking about it through the rest of the night. Most of the Angels had agreed. Serri hadn‚Äôt said anything, but she didn‚Äôt disagree. A few others stayed quiet as well, and the conversation quickly pivoted so not everyone got to weigh in, but the general mood was ‚Äúyes.‚Äù Being an Angel is worth it. Right? ... What happens when you die? It‚Äôs a question that the church answers, by default, in a perfectly ordinary way. Your Soul is the core of ‚Äúyou,‚Äù not your Body or Mind. So when your Body dies and your Mind goes with it, your Soul lingers and is eventually incorporated back into another human being. The circle of life. You don‚Äôt remember the previous lives you‚Äôve lived, since memories are stored in your Mind. But sometimes, particularly vivid or important details get seared into your Soul and you might find yourself having moments of strange familiarity. It makes sense. It‚Äôs a clean, happy cycle. But the Cathedra doesn‚Äôt always tell the full truth during normal mass. ‚Äã
9:46 PM
Souls can be corrupted. That‚Äôs what the corruption is. And you know that, if a human is corrupted too much, things start to unravel. The Soul can fracture; decay; crumble. It‚Äôs possible to destroy a Soul. And if that‚Äôs the case, that cycle of reincarnation starts to break down. If you die in a normal manner, uncorrupted, it still works. Your Soul drifts off and returns later. But Angels don‚Äôt die normally. You never age. You never get sick. You can‚Äôt be killed by ordinary means unless you make a serious mistake. And that means that - when your death inevitably arrives - it will be at the hands of the corruption. Soul worn away at the edge of death, despite your resistance. Splintered, broken. Is there any coming back from that? Do you, in exchange for your Angelic immortality, sacrifice your even more permanent immortality of reincarnation? Or is all of this a lie? Experiments done in the fourth century, you recall, showed that the Soul decays within hours to days after its Body‚Äôs death. Later scientists determined that the Soul actually moved on - it wasn‚Äôt destroyed - but... moves on to where? You can observe Souls. They‚Äôre not some nebulous, invisible presence that you just have to believe exists (at least, not for you; ordinary people do have to do that). So if a Soul vanishes from your sight... where does it go? Surely the simplest explanation is that it no longer exists. That it‚Äôs destroyed. That there is no rebirth, and this one life is all you get. Which makes your immortality even more valuable. And the danger you will be subjected to even more perilous. As with so many things, there‚Äôs no way to be sure. ... The next day isn‚Äôt anything special. You don‚Äôt go down into the depths where the corruption may lurk; you just tend to more fungus in the shallow caves. More grumbles from Erich and some, but not many, of the other workers. ‚Äã
9:46 PM
You do spot a group of people emerging from the elevator around midday, though. Grimy, exhausted, hauling a large wheeled crate presumably containing the spoils from their trip. One of the men walks with a limp, a dirty bandage on his thigh suggesting that something down there did not like him very much. You would never have to deal with a wound like that; at least, not for long. Emmett‚Äôs words echo. The injured man grins as one of the others points you out, giving a little wave. You‚Äôre surprised enough that you waste several seconds trying to figure out if you know him (you don‚Äôt) and by the time you gather yourself enough to wave back, he‚Äôs already turned away. ... Everything seems more abstract in the snow. The mist is heavy. You‚Äôve been feeling a little disconnected lately, thinking thoughts as heavy as the mist while lying in bed and not really fully being in the waking world. You don‚Äôt know if you‚Äôve really learned anything from your work these last two days. Maybe you just need something exciting to do. A distraction; something you‚Äôve been looking forward to. The festival starts tomorrow, of course. Day of Body, Day of Mind, Day of Soul. And then it‚Äôs the end of the year and the start of a new one with the Calling ceremony on the very first day. You‚Äôve made plans, haven‚Äôt you? What were they again? - Go home again. Your Mind is stronger now. You can face it... right? - Explore the city events with some of your friends. You‚Äôll need to be disguised again, but you didn‚Äôt really want to go alone anyway. - Explore the Cathedra‚Äôs events. You don‚Äôt need to go with anyone, and the magic involved makes them astonishing. Or so you‚Äôve heard. ‚≠ê - Or maybe there‚Äôs someone in particular you‚Äôd like to hang out with? ‚ÄúEr...‚Äù Right. After you stopped just short of making her admit that she knows her mom‚Äôs identity, Naoriel went right back to pretending she has no idea. Sorry.‚Äù At this point, the crowd is getting thick enough that you shouldn‚Äôt be talking about this stuff anyway. The Day of Body is, as one might expect, a festival day focused on the aspect of Body. Specifically, that means a variety of physical performances and contests (from dance to swordfighting and everything between) as well as various souvenirs designed to act upon the Body. Chefs trial strange new dishes and bring out old favorites, gearworkers produce prototype machines for soothing, physical protection, or enhancement, and Angels (though not as many as on the Sulday of Charity a few weeks back) provide healing and, occasionally, cosmetic services. You know none of the changes away from a person‚Äôs template will be permanent, but it can still be fun for a kid to wander around with bright green hair for a day, for instance. Not that you‚Äôve done that. Seth did. And then of course some parents complained to a priest about using God‚Äôs divine powers for something so trivial. The Angel who did it must have been reprimanded, since that was the last year he cast anything like that. ‚Äã
7:09 PM
The main square is, as you expected, absolutely packed with people and stalls providing the aforementioned souvenirs. The mist seems to be thin today; you can see all the way across to the buildings on the other side. Train bells ring nonstop from the station - service frequency is way up for the festival days as everyone is traveling around the city - and strings of festive lights decorate the administrative offices. You have no idea how they get the lights to work like that; there‚Äôs no way it can be traditional fire, and if it‚Äôs mechanical, where are the pipes? Or maybe they‚Äôre just reflective and not actual lights. It is pretty bright out right now. ‚ÄúWhat do you want to do first?‚Äù you half-shout to Naoriel. It‚Äôs so loud that you‚Äôre having to apply some techniques from your Mind course to filter out the background as best you can. ‚ÄúI haven‚Äôt been to this main one before, so is there anything really good?‚Äù ‚ÄúI haven‚Äôt been either! I thought you were leading!‚Äù Ah. Whoops. ‚ÄúMaybe that thing?‚Äù There‚Äôs a large stage set up near the center of the square. Though you can‚Äôt make out what‚Äôs going on from here, even just getting that far will give you plenty of opportunities to get distracted with stuff along your path. ‚ÄúAnd see what‚Äôs interesting on the way?‚Äù You get an agreement, so off you go. Pushing into the crowd, weaving between all sorts of people. Using your smaller stature and Angelic strength to your advantage to slip into gaps and avoid being pushed back. It only takes you a minute to work out the tricks; you‚Äôre somewhat familiar with large crowds from occasional trips to the station. ‚Äã
7:09 PM
The first distraction is a booth not far into the trek that‚Äôs both producing and selling a sort of hot spiced blue cider in the square itself; a hybrid between performance and souvenir. It stood out to you because they‚Äôre using the same little blue berries you spotted on the vine near that fungus farm, squashing them in a human-powered press and then mixing and adding a blend of spices before heating over a fire and serving. It‚Äôs a complicated operation to pull off in the small space afforded, especially with the open flame. Is that safe, really? Either way, apparently you look young enough to count for the kids‚Äô free samples and walk away with a little covered mug each. By this point, Yara‚Äôs magic has worn off and your nervousness spikes. No one‚Äôs paying much attention, but... how are you supposed to drink this without pulling down your scarf to expose your face? You clearly can‚Äôt do that, so how...? Maybe if you sorta loosen it a little, you can slip in under it? Naoriel helps develop a technique, making sure you‚Äôre still covered up as you manage to take a sip and nearly burn your tongue. Then you help her with the same task, thankfully allowing the drinks to cool while you work out the details. The end result only looks a little silly, though it is definitely quite warm. Your scarf is now suffused with the scent of whatever the blue berry drink is actually called (the berry has to have an actual name besides just ‚Äúblue berry‚Äù - that‚Äôd be way too lazy). It‚Äôs pretty good. A little tangy. Very warm. You‚Äôd already be sweating if you weren‚Äôt also resistant to heat. How do normal people deal with stuff like this? You‚Äôre already beginning to forget. ‚Äã
7:09 PM
Sudden cheers and applause rise from the stage, but you‚Äôre too short to see over everyone to know what‚Äôs going on. There‚Äôs some raised seating over there that would let you see, but you‚Äôre still pretty far away. It sure sounds exciting, though. Maybe you should rush? - You are speed.
