Mxblah 3/19/2024 9:03 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 81 No, probably not. There‚Äôll be more stuff later, and you‚Äôre already getting distracted by a demonstration area along the way. There‚Äôs a small fenced-off zone in the square containing two men in stout coats, a strange-looking backpack that one of them is putting on with the help of the other, and a few large rocks. A third man outside the zone is explaining what‚Äôs about to happen to a number of spectators. You sneak a little bit closer on your way past to hear. The men are gearworkers (which makes sense; those coats look similar to your dad‚Äôs) and they‚Äôre demonstrating a new prototype device that‚Äôs designed to augment a worker‚Äôs own strength with that of steam-fueled pistons. The power source lies within a heavily insulated backpack and connects to a pair of arm braces made of gleaming polished brass. They seem to be tailoring the speech towards business owners or supervisors - a lot of the details involve how cost-effective it can be or how much time it can save workers. A number of the spectators seem to be well-dressed middle-aged men. You almost decide to just leave, but you are kinda curious how it works. The gearworker wearing the backpack clicks it on and flexes his arms in a few different angles, showing that the skeleton-like frame moves easily with him. He picks up some small tools and writes a few sentences, to show that it doesn‚Äôt impact manual dexterity. Then, he reaches down around the rock and, with a little hiss from the backpack, manages to pick it up with some effort. The man outside the fence clarifies that he already tried this earlier without the device - before you showed up, it seems - and was unable to lift it. Then, he sets it down again, adjusts a dial on the backpack to change the machine‚Äôs mode, pulls back, and slams his fist into the rock. ‚Äã
9:03 PM
There‚Äôs a loud crack and chips of broken stone fall from the boulder. The man pulls back, showing his unharmed hand. The machine somehow absorbed the force of the blow on his arm, and heightened it on the rock. That‚Äôs pretty cool, and you‚Äôd like to know how it works, but unfortunately you‚Äôre just not as good at this stuff as your dad. For obvious reasons, since he‚Äôs a professional and you haven‚Äôt even studied gearworking to any significant degree. Just in case you were wondering, you‚Äôre not allowed to try the thing on. Although you sure are curious how it‚Äôd work with your enhanced strength. ... It probably wouldn‚Äôt be all that impressive, honestly. You may be strong for your frame, but you‚Äôre still not as strong as, for instance, just a regular adult man like the guy who had just used it. Maybe if you had Body enhancement magic it would be a different story. There‚Äôs a seemingly-endless parade of additional distractions on your way to the main stage. Naoriel notices a strange selection of hats and clothes based on mushroom-like designs; a little odd in winter, and it‚Äôs not like you can try much on properly, but you still have fun giggling at each other in the floppy hats that droop almost enough to cover your faces even without the scarves. You‚Äôre caught up in a free sample event for some sort of steamed meat bun thing, and between the two of you have to figure out how to try and eat them without giving anything away or getting too messy. That‚Äôs a real struggle, but the floppy hats come in handy to shield you from prying eyes. (Naoriel bought one. What is she going to do with a hat that large? Also, where did she get the money?) Astonishingly, the mushroom hat is actually collapsible to some degree, folding up so she doesn‚Äôt have to look like a maniac for the rest of the day. You ask if she noticed that before buying it, and... yeah, she did. Would have been funny if she had simply been willing to put up with the thing at full size just for fun, though. ‚Äã
9:04 PM
More distractions. A slapstick theater performance that you‚Äôre very impressed can still be both comprehensible and funny in just the minute or two you spend watching. A group of acrobats careening around a series of metal poles on glistening ribbons as if they were flying. Two young dancers, so in sync they can move nearly within the same space without hitting each other. And more and more beyond that too; you hardly make it a few steps past the last distraction before coming across something new. It seems like it takes you hours to finally make it to the main stage, and you actually can‚Äôt disprove that. You didn‚Äôt check to see when you started. But at last, you climb up a few rows of elevated seats to see what everyone was so excited about. Or, potentially, something entirely different after that first thing was over. It took you quite a while to get here, after all. It‚Äôs a swordfight. You‚Äôre just barely in time to catch the end of it, where one of the combatants skewers strikes the other in the stomach with their definitely-not-real practice sword, and that‚Äôs the end of it. Some of the crowd cheer; some groan; the referee calls the match. And you and Naoriel look at each other with an almost identical expression. ‚ÄúSo that‚Äôs where all those demonstration matches are,‚Äù she comments first. Some of them, at least. @Story Notifications Scene 82 ‚ÄúI‚Äôll ask later,‚Äù you decide. ‚ÄúI kinda doubt she‚Äôd be out here fighting, er, people, but it‚Äôll make me feel better to know that for sure.‚Äù ‚ÄúMm h - hey, isn‚Äôt that Yara?‚Äù ‚ÄúWhere? Which, you find out quickly, is a play. Specifically, it‚Äôs a somewhat abridged version of False Angel Erejil, the definitive work on the tragedies and unrest surrounding the titular (false) Angel‚Äôs life and death. You‚Äôve never seen it (only read excerpts from it for Brother Trigg‚Äôs history course) so you‚Äôre on board with staying to watch it. Naoriel seems a little uncomfortable with the subject matter (it is a little gory, that‚Äôs for sure), but you convince her after a minute and settle down to watch. ‚Äã
8:24 PM
To summarize the already-abridged version of the original play (which runs for about four hours - understandable why the festival would choose to shorten it), the story follows Erejil himself from the week before his Ascension through the week after his death. In the abridged version, much of the details from his childhood or training are removed, save for the beginnings of an unhealthy obsession with understanding the corruption. Young Erejil clashed with his mentors several times before eventually learning to better hide his views - not abandoning them. Later, as a full Angel deployed to the wastelands, Erejil came into contact with a shade. A shade who, somehow, seemed to know of him and his dangerous ways of thinking. A shade who, instead of fighting, made a deal. Erejil would help it defeat Angels who ventured into the wastelands. In exchange, he would learn of the corruption. As much as he desired. An incredibly lopsided deal, but at this point Erejil‚Äôs brow was already cast in shadow and his wings darkened to a pale, sickly grey. You doubt he actually had wings at all - he was only supposed to be in his late twenties here and most Angels take decades to manifest them - but you suppose there‚Äôs some artistic liberty that can be taken without affecting the plot too much. He accepted. Angels died. Some received worse fates. The gore has been turned down for this rendition, but some of it is still enough to make you want to look away. You‚Äôre surprised they can get away with this - there are kids in the audience! - but... it‚Äôs important to be uncomfortable about this. Maybe. You certainly don‚Äôt want to repeat his mistakes. Is that it? ... Man, viewing the full version would be a painful experience. Maybe that was the playwright‚Äôs point? ... Naoriel‚Äôs sure turned her opinion around by now. You glance over a few times and she‚Äôs always paying close attention. ‚Äã
8:24 PM
There‚Äôs not long to go. The stage lighting grows darker as Erejil descends into madness. Even with his Angelic resistance, constant exposure has worn his Mind down to the point where he agrees to sabotage the wall. A single quick, bloody execution of a fellow Angel. Another escapes just in time, dying once in midair from a burst of corrupt magic, but recovering enough to fly to the Cathedra to raise help. The shade from before leads an army of Mindless darkness, but is met by a vanguard of Archangels. By the end of that night, portions of the city fall in shambles and dozens of Angels lie dead in the streets they sacrificed themselves to defend. Erejil himself is captured, brought before the Emissary, and stripped of his powers. At that point, the corruption festering within him takes over and, in a matter of hours, he is executed before he can fully descend. Descend(?) The actor playing the then-Emissary then emerges onto stage in a single spotlight (when did it get so dark?) and narrates the epilogue. Erejil changed the rules. Shades had never appeared before that day, and from then on, they continue to plague the city with scheming darkness. Future Emissaries pay careful attention to any new Angels to ensure no one can repeat the same story. To this day, they have succeeded. There has never been another breach of the same magnitude. And, God willing, there never will be. The corruption‚Äôs sole purpose is to destroy us utterly. It will lie and scheme and say whatever you want to hear in order to further that goal. Never, ever, listen. A bow. Applause. The performance was very well done, you have to admit. Some details don‚Äôt seem to match up with other tellings of the Erejil story you‚Äôve heard - sometimes the Emissary detects his corruption, sometimes it‚Äôs the escaped Angel; stuff like that - and you‚Äôre not entirely sure what it has to do with Body, but it‚Äôs still gripping regardless. ‚Äã
8:24 PM
The sun is gone. It‚Äôs well into evening by now; the mist is thickening and mechanical lamps spring into life around the square. You hardly see any true flames around anymore. @Story Notifications Scene 83 The walk back is longer than you remember. It‚Äôs dark and cold and (though you won‚Äôt admit it to Naoriel) more than a little scary with your current state of Mind. 12:52 PM

Mxblah 3/25/2024 9:49 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 84 The Day of Mind, similarly to the Day of Body, is centered around the aspect from which it takes its name. Whereas yesterday you had athletes, chefs, and playwrights, today you have artists, authors, and... still playwrights. It seems theater is a mix of Mind and Body - although the same could be said of pretty much everything from both days. As you‚Äôve learned, there‚Äôs rarely such a thing as a strict categorical division when it comes to aspects (and most things, really). The lines blur. The Day of Soul will likely feature plays for a third time. People like theater. Anyway, you‚Äôre still bundled up today, but not hiding your face now that Yara‚Äôs with you and capable of maintaining proper transmutation disguises. You did tease him a little about not having faith in his no-magic disguise plan, but really you prefer it this way too. It‚Äôs way more convenient and also much less nerve-wracking. You similarly teased him a little about being out with Etalyn yesterday, but not much. You get it. Now... how are you going to talk with Serri? She seems to be in a good mood today, poking around at the various booths and demonstrations around the square; you can‚Äôt just go up and ask if she‚Äôs figured out a solution to her... decision? Sort of? From what you‚Äôve heard, she‚Äôs committed to learning external Body projection as her first specialization, but whether to heal or harm (or both) is still a mystery. You haven‚Äôt really had many chats with her since the day of the duel. But, as you noted yesterday, the festival isn‚Äôt really a good place for in-depth or secret conversations. Maybe you should just give up and hang out with her normally. Plus, Yara‚Äôs here too and you don‚Äôt know how much he knows about all that. ‚Äã
9:49 PM
In fact, his presence just makes it harder to try and do anything serious. Both because Serri‚Äôs good friends with him and because of his general personality. How can you avoid getting sucked into the antics of a guy who goes around comparing the baking abilities of every depiction of the original twelve Angels he can find (and there are a lot of them), based on little differences in their likenesses? You can‚Äôt. And so you don‚Äôt. You make your way across a large portion of the square, crossing between artists‚Äô booths and stopping at whatever seems interesting on the way. There‚Äôs plenty beyond just traditional paintings around; it seems a major interpretation of ‚ÄúMind‚Äù is ‚Äúcreative,‚Äù so pretty much anything cool and handmade is fair game. Sculptures with seemingly impossible contours or of unusual materials, like chain links. That one captures your attention for a while, just wondering how it can stand up like that with no obvious means of support. It seems like the links themselves are somehow providing their own tension to avoid a collapse, but it‚Äôs beyond you to find where exactly the support is located. You can see right through it; there‚Äôs no pole or anything! Woven rugs or tapestries are also fairly traditional, but ones that can fold out into large structures are definitely not. This is where Yara gets another one of his Angel depictions, noting that ‚Äúthese ones won‚Äôt be quite so effective due to excessive flammability.‚Äù Being made of yarn does seem like a significant disadvantage in baking, you have to admit. ‚Äã
9:50 PM
There‚Äôs also a surprising number of books around. Yara dings these again for flammability, as well as lacking arms, but you and Serri try to convince him to relax the requirements and go on the description in the text instead of the physical books. He eventually agrees and also accepts one of the cover illustrations for consideration too. You‚Äôre pretty sure that one didn‚Äôt actually happen in reality, given that it depicts one of the twelve in a sword-lock against a shade, when shades didn‚Äôt exist until Erejil‚Äôs era hundreds of years later. Also, you don‚Äôt think shades have quite such well-defined physiques. Also also, you‚Äôre pretty sure most Angels didn‚Äôt fight nude with just conveniently positioned limbs and swords to cover anything up. What kind of a book is this, actually? Oh, you‚Äôre moving on. Yara notes impractical attire for baking purposes. You note impractical attire for all purposes. Serri doesn‚Äôt note anything, since you‚Äôve already covered it. Science is not absent today either. The gearworkers have returned to show off new inventions and concepts that aren‚Äôt necessarily Body-related, but are still important or interesting. But beyond them, other scientists haven‚Äôt been idle either. A lot of this new stuff about medicine or physics or even magic (yes, people outside of the Cathedra study it as well, though they typically end up being recruited before long if they get too in-depth) is well over your head. Plus, the stuff you do understand is mostly magic-related, and it probably would be a little suspicious to know too much about that. No new depictions of the twelve original Angels except in name alone. Yara doesn‚Äôt score any of these. ‚Äã
9:50 PM
Like yesterday, you end up making your way to the main stage just before a play starts (easier today, since there are plenty of plays around). But just as you‚Äôre making your way up the seats to your mystery performance, one final distraction sneaks in. Ô∏è - ‚ÄúPortrait of God.‚Äù That‚Äôs... not forbidden, exactly, but it‚Äôs certainly frowned upon. And of course, no one knows what He looks like... right? - ‚ÄúFortune Teller.‚Äù That‚Äôs also not quite forbidden, but it‚Äôs even closer than the portrait. But... this guy doesn‚Äôt look like a fortune teller, either. Weird? (Winner: a tie between Ô∏è and . chosen by author discretion.) (edited)

Mxblah 3/27/2024 9:36 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 85 A fortune teller? There‚Äôs a quaint little booth packed in just beside the stands, but it doesn‚Äôt look how you‚Äôd expect. Divining the future is impossible, and so its practice is forbidden. However, there are plenty of useful and quite possible methods of predicting future events, like weather patterns or elections - or even just games of chance - to the point where an outright ban on anything to do with probability would be impractically cumbersome. So predicting the future based on mathematics or concrete events is allowed, but doing so with false magic or no evidence is not. Fortune telling, as you‚Äôd expect, originally fell into the latter category when this rule was implemented. But its practitioners (surprisingly industrious!) spent time to devise and prove out a variety of mathematical methods related to drawing cards, marbles, or other objects. Several people did studies and found various levels of correlation between predicted and actual outcomes. Hardly any of the studies agreed, which meant (depending on who you asked) that some of the studies were correct and a correlation existed - thus validating these methods as accurate - or that more studies were needed to confirm - thus allowing fortune tellers to practice normally as long as they called their trade ‚Äúresearch.‚Äù Some in the city legislature have caught on, but some haven‚Äôt and most have better things to do. For now, the practice remains legal, but only just. All you need to do is have a little disclaimer on your stand - ah, like over there - and it counts as ‚Äúresearch.‚Äù Perfect. Of course, you don‚Äôt know any of these details since you‚Äôre not very interested in niche legislative loopholes. Rather, you‚Äôre just vaguely aware that fortune telling is more allowed than not and that most oracles tend to look all mystical, covered in silks and ribbons and weird dark candles. Not, you know, like a banker. ‚Äã
9:37 PM
Yeah, this particular oracle caught your eye mostly because he looks so normal, contrasting with his booth. Average height, maybe a little pudgy, sandy hair and a tan vest over a collared shirt and dark brown trousers. Like a financial worker might wear. ‚ÄúHey, I‚Äôll meet you up there,‚Äù you call to Serri (Yara‚Äôs already made his way up). ‚ÄúGonna check something out first.‚Äù You can barely hear the ‚Äúokay!‚Äù shouted back. People are very excited for whatever this next play is. The line isn‚Äôt too bad (again, people are excited for the play) and you can see that the oracle is using cards here. He shuffles the deck and holds them out, then you pick three (Body, Mind, Soul) to reveal your fate. Simple, normal. You‚Äôre not familiar with the pictures on the cards, but that‚Äôs fine. It‚Äôs only his clothes that are weird. Are you reading too much into this just to be scammed? Too late. You‚Äôre up next. The noise of the festival seems to fade away a little as you sit down on the little chair in front of the booth. It‚Äôs too short for you. The oracle turns his head slightly. Quizzically? You suppose you‚Äôre not a normal customer. ‚ÄúGood day, miss. A reading for you?‚Äù ‚ÄúEr, yes please.‚Äù ‚ÄúVery good. Of course, no charge for someone like you.‚Äù ‚Äú... Huh? Like, only adults have to pay?‚Äù ‚ÄúSomething like that.‚Äù He shuffles the cards, hands bare despite the cold. His left pinky bears a golden ring adorned with a light blue gem. You resist the urge to ask about it. Not a normal ring, nor a normal finger to wear it on. The cards are presented. ‚ÄúPlease draw just one to start with. This represents your Body.‚Äù You hesitate. What should you pick? The middle? A side? Eventually, you decide on one slightly to the left of center. ‚Äã
9:37 PM
‚ÄúAh, the broken gear.‚Äù Indeed, the card shows an image of a stylized clockwork gear with several of the tiny teeth broken off. Shards of metal lie scattered in the picture‚Äôs background. ‚ÄúMy condolences. Your Body bears a permanent flaw which you will never be able to repair. But, as you drew the gear right-side-up, that flaw should remain the only one. You will otherwise be blessed with good health for the rest of your days.‚Äù ‚Äú...‚Äù Eerily accurate. Could that apply to a lot of people? You know that‚Äôs how a lot of fortune telling sounds good; the advice is so vague it‚Äôs correct for the vast majority of people. Maybe? ‚ÄúPlease pick the second, for your Mind.‚Äù You veer right for this one, almost but not quite near the end. ‚ÄúThe sun.‚Äù The card bears an image of a burning, fiery orb that you‚Äôve only ever seen through a curtain of mist. Inky purple-blackness fills the background behind it. ‚ÄúYou are the heart of an important group; the linchpin that holds it together. That may be a family, a group of friends, a workplace, or something else, but you are a beacon of light that maintains these bonds. Again, you drew it right side up, so your efforts will not be in vain. You will be able to overcome your flaws with the help of those around you.‚Äù ‚Äú...?‚Äù The Cathedra, obviously not. But your group of friends? Your family? Surely, this card can apply to almost anyone who has a family. Well, if they still get along. But nearly everyone has some group they belong to, right? ‚ÄúPlease pick the last card, for your Soul.‚Äù The center. No, no. That one‚Äôs sticking out a little, like he wants you to pick it. Instead, you select one midway to the right that‚Äôs almost hiding under a different card. The oracle lets out a breath as you turn it over. ‚ÄúThe fallen Angel...‚Äù ‚Äã
9:37 PM
The card depicts a tortured-looking Angel, bloodied hands over their face as if sobbing. Their wings are dark grey and bear several bleeding cuts. The background is darkness. You swallow, nervous despite your skepticism. You‚Äôve drawn this one upside-down. ‚ÄúBetrayal. Someone close to you will turn against you. A friend, a family member, a mentor; someone like that. You will be badly hurt by this, though with the sun as it was drawn, you may still recover if you dare continue to trust those you still hold dear.‚Äù That... that one can‚Äôt possibly apply to a large number of people. Surely not. The oracle smiles sadly. ‚ÄúI cannot avert this fate, but I may be able to do just one more thing to help. Choose a question, then pick one more card.‚Äù - ‚Äú... Who?‚Äù - ‚Äú... 2:33 PM

@Story Notifications Scene 87 ‚ÄúThe one presiding at a feast, of course. 3:01 PM
Minutes more pass as you walk back from the festival and continue to discuss baking merits. Eventually, a technical agreement is made to pare down the scope of the question. Carrying baked goods is not baking, nor is slicing baked goods. Were those the categories, different depictions would have claimed victory. 3:01 PM
You dream of betrayals. Walking down long, dark corridors with one of your friends, then a sudden twist of expression. A glinting smile. A starmetal blade. You run, fleeing towards a sparkle of distant light that promises an exit, but never gets any closer. The hallway is endless. Every time you look back, you‚Äôve never gotten further away. A beckoning sign. Building pressure in your lungs as you exert yourself more and more, trying to escape. A cold, metallic shock as the blade eventually sinks into your back. Over. And over. And over again. At some point, you wake up. It‚Äôs still dark; you scramble out of bed halfway inside a dream and run into the wall. Fumble for a switch and turn on a lamp. You‚Äôre shaking. There‚Äôs a pain in your back, right where you‚Äôve just been stabbed dozens of times over. In reality? No, surely not. The dream lingers. You lock yourself in the bathroom and use a combination of two mirrors to inspect your back. Nothing but smooth, perfect skin. Rub your hand on the spot that hurts. Nothing but a phantom pain. It fades with the new sensation. More minutes pass before you manage to untangle the last threads of the dream and emerge fully into the waking world. You‚Äôre still shivering, a little. Peek back into your bedroom with its lonely active lamp, scanning the shadows for a boogeyman. Nothing. You creep out and turn on the rest of the lights, using the extra illumination to clear the rest of your apartment as well. Sit wrapped in blankets and wait for the sunrise. ... You‚Äôre starting to wonder if there‚Äôs something wrong with you. ‚Äã
3:01 PM
These fears aren‚Äôt completely unfounded, is the problem. Naoriel was almost kidnapped from her bed in the middle of the night, in this very building, only two weeks ago. You know there‚Äôs a traitor hiding somewhere in the Cathedra. These dreams might not be real, but the worries definitely are. How can you possibly feel safe unless you somehow figure out who they are and reveal them to someone who can actually do something about it? It‚Äôs just a lot to deal with. The sun finally peeks over the horizon, turning the mist orange as it always does, and you get ready for the Day of Soul. The main festival is again available for ordinary people, but Angels have a different way to celebrate. Today, you will attend a special mass given by one of the bishops instead of a normal priest, then reflect on the year. A lot happened, so you‚Äôll certainly have a lot to reflect on. And once you‚Äôre done with that, you‚Äôre supposed to offer your feelings about it to God (positive, negative, anything) so He can help you do your best in the year to come. As with a lot of these reflection things, there‚Äôs not much in the way of guidelines. Some people seclude themselves for the day; others spend the time with their friends or even random strangers for that unbiased outside opinion. As for you... - On your own today. Mxblah 4/2/2024 9:27 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 88 Somehow, you‚Äôre a little disappointed in the Day of Soul mass. It‚Äôs longer than normal and it‚Äôs presented by a bishop instead of a priest, but otherwise it‚Äôs much the same as regular mass. You‚Äôve heard most of this before. Be good. Devote yourself to serving God and the people who rely on you. Live as a beacon. As a heart. As a... sun, perhaps. Ugh. You‚Äôre still thinking about that reading from yesterday, plus you‚Äôre glancing around the cathedral and wondering who the traitor could be. Most of the Angels are here now - not those on the walls or missions, but most others - so the odds are good the traitor is here too. Probably not one of the trainees or young Angels, given their powers, but who among the senior Angels could possibly be so twisted? Or maybe even someone above them, an Archangel? You scan the smaller group sitting near the bishop with their brilliant glows and beautiful wings. You don‚Äôt recognize most of them; you‚Äôve really only interacted with Aveline before. And beside the dozen or so Archangels are the two current Seraphim, the most powerful and most senior Angels in the city. They resemble golden statues, with metallic skin, glowing eyes, and permanently manifested wings shimmering with a reflective texture. It‚Äôs almost hard to believe they were once human - and still are, actually. Beneath the almost alien exterior, the Souls inside are still as human as yours. Stronger, of course, but fundamentally the same as everyone else‚Äôs. ‚Äã
9:27 PM
At least, that‚Äôs what they tell you. The Mind does funny things after growing powerful enough to transform like that. You‚Äôve never interacted with one of them before, but you‚Äôve heard Seraphim can seem irrational to ordinary Angels. Making decisions that seem insane, until a carefully calculated series of events pays off in a masterful blow to the corruption. They work alongside the primes, serving the Emissary directly on only the most critical tasks. Someone like that would be above scrutiny from all but the head of Inquisition or the Emissary himself. You stare at the flawless, golden-skinned men for perhaps longer than you should, feeling irrational paranoia against these paragons of divinity. From the outside, trying to kidnap Naoriel would seem insane. But to a Seraph, with a stronger (and stranger) Mind than anyone currently alive...? Anyway, when one of them seems to notice something and glances in your direction, you quickly look away. It‚Äôs entirely possible their senses are so keen as to actually notice you. ... You‚Äôre doing a real bad job of paying attention and reflecting on the year. After mass, you try to rectify that. You spend some time with anyone you know that you run into. Sometimes talking, sometimes not. Thinking. Remembering. Yara, the first Angel to properly welcome you to the Cathedra, emerging from his blanket pile and offering encouragement during your first weeks and onwards. Showing you magic, helping you learn about this strange new world of divinity and scheming. The experiment; the firing. You still haven‚Äôt figured out why your Souls glowed there. You might never. ‚Äã
9:28 PM
Serri, a kindred spirit during your hesitant first weeks, but now grown colder and more distant. Are you still friends? Probably. But as close as you once were? Not really, and you don‚Äôt know why. You almost ask her straight-out as you sit together and contemplate the year, but can‚Äôt quite find the courage. She might not even know either. Still, she clearly cares for you and vice versa. Is that enough? Etalyn, blunt and abrasive at worst, but protecting and steadfast at best. You‚Äôre pretty sure she and Yara are dating at this point, though no one‚Äôs ever actually confirmed it. She‚Äôs always available to back you up if you need it, even if you‚Äôre not that close. Naoriel, the mystery girl whose secrets you‚Äôve managed to uncover, somewhat by accident. At least, some of them. Reclusive to most, but surprisingly forthcoming and friendly when you get to know her. Strong. Able to support herself under the terrible pressure of her lineage, and against that traitor hunting her for it. You doubt she‚Äôs been having nightmares like you. Denn, jovial and calm no matter the situation. He‚Äôs capable of making Erich cool off as well, which you think is a neat super power. Dependable. Clarity‚Äôs still around too, even though she‚Äôs graduated. Still as cheerful and energetic as always, despite her new responsibilities. Always willing to listen, even if you don‚Äôt want advice. And on and on it goes. You‚Äôve met so many people and made so many friends over the past year-ish. It‚Äôs gone so much better than you could have thought. Sure, you‚Äôve had some problems. You feel alienated from your family. You have to deal with the traitor or you‚Äôll never stop having nightmares. You‚Äôre still sick, despite your ostensibly perfect Body. But overall, you‚Äôre a better you. And that‚Äôs all you can really hope for, isn‚Äôt it? ... ‚Äã
9:28 PM
The end of the year isn‚Äôt anything special. There are a few fireworks and the bells all toll in unison, and that‚Äôs it. The end of one year and the beginning of the next. Tomorrow (today) is now January 1st again, and in a scant few hours, another group of children will have their Calling ceremonies. One or two might Ascend. But to you, by now, that possibility isn‚Äôt anything new. This is the tenth Calling day since your own and no new Angels have been chosen. Even though you know there‚Äôs a chance, and it would start to get really quite worrying if there remained none, you still sort of don‚Äôt believe it‚Äôll happen. Until church bells ring across the city, signaling a child has been found worthy. As of today, you are no longer the Cathedra‚Äôs newest Angel. - Pull a Yara and meet them today. - Just try to catch a glimpse today, but don‚Äôt approach. - Leave them alone and meet them tomorrow. Mxblah 4/4/2024 7:57 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 89 Well, you‚Äôve got to meet them, don‚Äôt you? To start with, you check with Yara to get some advice, as you‚Äôre not sure you want to copy his strategy exactly. Plus, it might have been a coincidence anyway. ‚ÄúOh, yes, I‚Äôve been known to do that every so often. It can be quite entertaining to meet new Angels before Cobb‚Äôs gotten to them, as you know so well. Sometimes I get distracted or they change where the tour goes, but I‚Äôve made it most of the time. I‚Äôm curious.‚Äù ‚ÄúHmm! Well, I feel I can leave this one to you, then. Do you remember that I‚Äôm graduating in...‚Äù He pauses, counting up the time. ‚ÄúTen months? That kinda makes it sound like you‚Äôre going away when you graduate. You‚Äôre still going to be right here; you could keep doing it.‚Äù A pause; he doesn‚Äôt say anything immediately. ‚ÄúRight? You‚Äôre not actually going anywhere?‚Äù ‚ÄúOh, no no. But the older I get, the stranger it seems, yes? I have less in common with new trainees now, and that‚Äôs only going to get worse. I figure it‚Äôs better to pick a sensible cutoff and leave it to the younger generation than to drag it on forever. Plus, I‚Äôll get to meet them in a few days anyway.‚Äù ‚Äú... Okay. @Story Notifications Scene 91 Somewhat surprisingly, you do actually have an answer in Mind. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve been thinking about Erejil recently,‚Äù you admit. ‚ÄúEver since I saw the play during the festival. God, it‚Äôs embarrassing that you have to clarify. Still, no corruption. Just the sickness. Of course, you aren‚Äôt an expert in Soul-sensing, but you are hypersensitive. It‚Äôs not like you can spot flaws with the Emissary‚Äôs precision, but you‚Äôre certainly better than the average trainee. It makes you feel a little better, but not much. Especially... Huh? Naoriel... what...? You turn your head a little, trying to understand what you‚Äôre sensing. Her Soul glows the same as everyone else‚Äôs. It doesn‚Äôt seem damaged, corrupted, or otherwise different from how you‚Äôd expect. You can‚Äôt explain why you‚Äôre confused or what you‚Äôre seeing. But something just doesn‚Äôt seem quite right. Well, great. Now you‚Äôre worried and confused. And you missed whatever they were saying about plants, because now the topic has moved on to magic generally. And Yara‚Äôs got the cards out; today is just a strange mirror of your own first day. You join the game, still uneasy. Cards. The fallen Angel. The Spy. Argh; you have got to stop thinking about Phil‚Äôs reading! It‚Äôs just going to make you more paranoid! [Results will be ranked by votes. This week, you will focus on...] - The tests for Trigg. - The project for Cobb. - Getting to know Jun. - Should you be worried about Serri? - What the heck is up with Naoriel now? ‚ùì - Or a different priority? Mxblah 4/12/2024 8:50 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 93 You spend the rest of the week stalking your friends and learning about the Cathedra‚Äôs ultimate betrayer. The ‚Äúlearning‚Äù part at least makes sense. You‚Äôre investigating what Brother Trigg told you about Erejil‚Äôs resistance before delving into the topic for real. After a day or two, you figured out that the reason is probably in the restricted section; there are plenty of texts that discuss Erejil overall, but stop curiously short (sometimes in the middle of a sentence!) of describing exactly what the deal is, so to speak. So you told Brother Trigg. He seemed pleased with your initiative and said he would put in an exception for you, to be activated later in the week. You had no idea it was that easy. Then of course there are the tests as well. After the first day of detection, Cobb had you demonstrate basic channeling on the second day, followed by projection in various aspects for the remaining three. He wasn‚Äôt wrong when he said you didn‚Äôt need to study; you‚Äôre doing fine just from regularly practicing over the last few months. It‚Äôs a real relief to know that something about your Mental transformation is working, as you‚Äôre much more capable than you feel you should be in memorizing these complicated patterns and non-physical motions. ‚Äã
8:50 PM

You decided to ‚Äúcoincidentally‚Äù linger nearby and ‚Äúcoincidentally‚Äù practice some of the Mental magic you‚Äôve been learning that helps enhance your senses. It turns out that it‚Äôs not all Body, actually, and you can cast spells to help filter, detect, and even enhance nearby sounds using your Mind alone. From what your instructor says, combining this technique with Body magic is even more effective (to physically improve your ears, for instance) but at least one of them would need to be transmutation or the other would interfere. So, just the Mind for now. She‚Äôs harder to stalk, given that she‚Äôs had to deal with probable Inquisitors watching her for a while now, so you‚Äôre caught pretty quickly and have to explain what you were doing. You fumble your way through a poor explanation of what you thought might have been going on with her Soul, but are emphatically assured that there‚Äôs absolutely nothing wrong with her and you shouldn‚Äôt be concerned. ‚Äã
8:51 PM
So naturally, you figured there was something wrong with her and you should be concerned. You still catch yourself staring every so often, still puzzled over what it is you‚Äôre sensing. It‚Äôs something really subtle, whatever it is, or you‚Äôd be able to describe it in more detail. Or you could just be deluding yourself and there‚Äôs nothing out of the ordinary to see. That‚Äôs what Naoriel thinks. Two things happen Friday afternoon. First, Brother Cobb declares that all three of you have passed the basic magic course and are permitted to advance to the higher courses. That‚Äôs pretty much it; he doesn‚Äôt give a speech or hand you a badge or certificate or anything. It just goes in your paperwork somewhere and that‚Äôs the last day of that course. Underwhelming and sorta bureaucratic; that‚Äôs Cobb‚Äôs style, you suppose. At least you get to be relieved about Serri. The second thing is that your exception is processed. Brother Trigg lets you know and, when you next enter the library, you‚Äôre allowed to request a catalog and individual works restricted under the categories of Erejil and corruption resistance. It‚Äôs a surprisingly vast trove you suddenly have access to, and you kind of wonder just how many books are actually locked away like this, only available for certain people. You still don‚Äôt get to go into the basement, though, so you still don‚Äôt get to find out. And it doesn‚Äôt take you long at all to learn that Trigg was right. The reason for Ereijl‚Äôs low resistance is, in fact, very simple. It just also raises a whole lot of new questions that you hadn‚Äôt anticipated needing to cover in your report. False Angel Erejil wasn‚Äôt actually a full Angel. He was a half Angel. What?! ‚Äã
8:51 PM
Okay, I should probably be used to being surprised like this by now, you think, covering the book and glancing behind you to make sure no one else is sneaking up to steal the restricted knowledge. The Cathedra conceals a lot of stuff. A LOT. But... Angels can‚Äôt have children. Or, they can, but...? Hang on, you don‚Äôt actually know. You‚Äôre not really familiar with human or Angelic reproduction beyond the vague basics and a very strong notion that the topic is extremely improper for a young lady like yourself to be thinking about in any depth. But... one thing you do know is that Angels and humans can‚Äôt have children together. But, well, that‚Äôs clearly wrong. According to this text, Erejil‚Äôs father was an Angel and his mother was a human worker in the Cathedra. They met, they fell in love, they had a child. That child nearly destroyed Nucarreo. ... You‚Äôre going to need to get some more information on this. You haven‚Äôt gone through all the texts you‚Äôre allowed access to with this exception, but the titles indicate that they‚Äôre primarily about Erejil himself, not his heritage or the mechanics of half-Angels generally. Mxblah 4/16/2024 9:39 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 95 You‚Äôve got some free time over the weekend, given that the basic magic course is over and you only get to even register for your next one next week (probably a continuation of your current focus area, you think; you don‚Äôt want to split your attention too much). So, because it seems you‚Äôre a hopeless academic, you decide to spend the time continuing on your research for the project that Trigg hasn‚Äôt even properly assigned yet. Well, it‚Äôll be good to get the jump on it when he actually does. You learn some more stuff, to put it succinctly. Erejil was the first known half-Angel. You‚Äôre pretty sure of that after delving through much of the catalog you‚Äôre allowed from the exceptions you‚Äôve been granted. But there have been others after him. Of course, none have been publicized because of the potential damage to the Cathedra‚Äôs reputation: a true, holy Angel falling from grace by conceiving a child with an ordinary human?! That sort of thing. But they‚Äôve been recorded somewhere and, even though you don‚Äôt have any of the primary sources, there are some passing references in your various Erejil books. You wonder if Brother Trigg might be willing to grant you another exception about half-Angels specifically; that sure would make this a lot easier. Anyway, you‚Äôre able to figure out a good amount by putting together various footnotes and asides in a large number of texts. To start with, it seems that Yara is right that half-Angels, though somewhat more perfect in the three aspects than their peers, can typically pass for regular humans until their Calling. At that point, they all Ascend. At least, all the ones you know about, which isn‚Äôt many. Maybe a few per century or so, but that still adds up to more than twenty between Erejil‚Äôs time and now. ‚Äã
9:39 PM
You‚Äôre missing details on what happened after that for over half of them, but you have managed to track down solid information on seven half-Angels spanning the centuries; the latest was ‚Äúonly‚Äù six decades ago in the year 1163. That‚Äôs within the lifespan of some of the older monks, and certainly many still-living Angels. You might be able to get a firsthand account of something, if you can find the right person. However, you‚Äôre not too pleased with the information you find, couched in bland, emotionless sentences or rows in a table. Every one of these known half-Angels, all half-divine children 12 to 18 years of age, were executed. You had to do a double take the first time you saw that in a footnote at the end of a chapter. It‚Äôs rare the Cathedra will admit to executing anyone except the highest traitors to the church, the city, or the scriptures. For instance, despite Naoriel‚Äôs understandable caution about her own heritage, the last time a minister was executed for having a child was almost a century ago; most modern cases are simply expelled from their positions. And executions of Angels are even rarer, with the last one (you finally looked it up) being exactly at the turn of the millennium, year 1000. That‚Äôs so long ago you can hardly imagine what life would have been like! Almost all executions nowadays are of heinous (but ordinary) criminals, not those associated with the Cathedra. But apparently, half-Angels are so bad that the Cathedra is willing to kill newly-Ascended Angels, even as recently as 60-odd years ago. This bothers you, a lot. These kids didn‚Äôt choose their parents; that could have been you if you weren‚Äôt lucky enough to be born to your mom and dad. ‚Äã
9:39 PM
Wait... was that what the bishop meant when he said ‚Äúan Archangel would have been sent in my stead?‚Äù You... kinda thought he was joking. Just... really badly. But was he maybe telling the truth? Had he been checking to see if you were truly a full Angel and not a half? If you had been, would you have died then and there? ‚Äú...‚Äù You suppose preventing another Erejil is important. Very much so. And if this is what‚Äôs needed to do that... Is it? ... Later, you lie awake in bed for what seems like the hundredth time since your Ascension. Thinking, as usual. You‚Äôre trying to think about Souls. If an Angel and a human can have a half-Angel child, then what does that mean? Is the strength of your Soul determined by your parents? What is Ascension, then? If all half-Angels Ascend, then doesn‚Äôt that mean they‚Äôre blessed by God? Why would the Cathedra defy Him by killing them? That sort of thing. Productive, healthy worries. Well, productive worries. Well, worries. But instead you‚Äôre just thinking about the executions. Nothing about the logistics or the reasoning or anything academic. Just the clattering of metal as the blade is lifted, the horrible pause of anticipation, and then the wet thunk as it falls. Over and over and over again. You don‚Äôt even know if you‚Äôre awake at this point; it‚Äôs not like you can open your eyes and see the room. It‚Äôs all just dark. Why? Why are these people so dangerous to warrant such measures? Sure, Erejil fell to the corruption, but you could just keep them safe! Check up on them! Make sure they‚Äôre healthy and don‚Äôt send them outside the walls! Just be nice! It would be so easy! Thunk. You jolt, thoughts falling from your Mind like scattered papers in a breeze. That wasn‚Äôt just in your head... was it? Pause, still your breathing. Ignore your beating heart. Listen. Clattering metal. A horrible pause. Thunk. ‚Äã
9:39 PM
You squeeze your eyes shut even tighter, trembling under the blankets. No, no, no no no no... It‚Äôs not real. It can‚Äôt be real. You‚Äôre dreaming or hallucinating or something. Why?! You‚Äôre supposed to be getting better at this! Why is your Mind so weak?! Thunk. Louder. More well-defined. Closer. You can hear a squelching drip as liquid oozes onto the carpet. ‚ÄúNo nonono nonononono-‚Äù you whisper aloud, clutching your head. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not real. It‚Äôs not real. It‚Äôs not-‚Äù THUNK. Silence. You hold your breath. Ô∏è - Look. - Don‚Äôt. (Winner: Ô∏è ) (edited)

Mxblah 4/18/2024 9:46 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 96 Clattering metal. It‚Äôs so close you can almost feel the blade scraping against your Body. Loud, immediate. Horrible. You can‚Äôt help it; you have to know. You look. A shadow stands beside your bed. It‚Äôs tall, humanoid, fuzzy around the edges, and made of utterly pitch-black darkness. Two burning-silver eyes are the only features on its entire Body, and they‚Äôre looking at you with an unreadable expression. A guillotine blade hovers abstractly behind it, dripping dark liquid onto the carpet. The creature‚Äôs arms have stopped inches from the covers, reaching out for you. You can‚Äôt move. You don‚Äôt know if you‚Äôre frozen from fear, some sort of dream-based sleep paralysis, or the shadow‚Äôs awful magic. The creature steps back, folding its arms in a shockingly human gesture. It considers you. Silently. The only sounds are your shaky, shallow breathing and the guillotine‚Äôs macabre dripping. Why haven‚Äôt you woken up yet?! Whatever this is, you know it can‚Äôt possibly be real. Under any circumstances. Because that thing is a shade. At least, it looks like how they‚Äôve been described. Human, but made of shadow. Are you hallucinating your stresses into one of your greatest (though most abstract) fears? There‚Äôs no way a shade could possibly actually be in your bedroom right now. How would it have gotten into the city? Into the Cathedra? Why would it be carrying a floating guillotine around?! ... It‚Äôs still just looking at you. The air is freezing cold; you‚Äôre shivering even though you still can‚Äôt move. You‚Äôre transfixed just staring back at it. Training; remember your training! Cleanse outside influences! Wrestle back control of yourself! C‚Äômon... you just have to- ‚Äã
9:46 PM
The phase of your Soul shifts in order to accommodate the Mind magic you‚Äôre about to cast. And at that moment, the shade leaps forwards. You scream, throwing yourself back off the bed and breaking whatever force kept you anchored to the spot with some panic-fueled surge of strength. But then... That‚Äôs it. Everything‚Äôs quiet again. You‚Äôre disoriented and a little sore from falling off the bed; you‚Äôre tangled in the blankets and wiggle around to get free. There‚Äôs nothing else in your room and, when you turn on the lights, there‚Äôs no evidence a shade had ever been here. No droplets from the guillotine, no footsteps, no icy chill; nothing. Maybe I just had another nightmare and fell off the bed? you rationalize. It‚Äôs happened before, though not quite as real as this one had felt. To be safe, you check the rest of your apartment, just like the last few times you dreamt of terrible monsters hunting you down. Nothing there, as usual. Darkness outside; it‚Äôs still the middle of the night. But... Did you leave your bedroom door open? You usually did, until Naoriel was attacked and your dreams got worse. Then, out of some misplaced sense that the door might actually help, you started closing it at night. Now, it‚Äôs open. You could have just forgotten or gone back to your old habit for a night, but... did you? Or did a shade mysteriously make its way into your room, without leaving any traces on the main door or windows, and then open just your bedroom door in order to stand creepily over you with a floating blade? ‚Äú...‚Äù It must have been a nightmare. A terrifyingly realistic one, but just a nightmare. Logically, there‚Äôs simply no way any of that could have been real. You wait out the rest of the night locked in the bathroom with the lights on, eventually passing out on the floor to wake up late and confused until you remember why you‚Äôre not in bed. Another double check; still no signs of anything. No liquid, no footsteps besides your own, nothing. No shade. ‚Äã
9:47 PM
You have to get your dreams under control. ... Brother Trigg properly assigns the project. You‚Äôre studying corruption resistance through the lens of Erejil and half-Angels, which means even more grisly texts about deaths, mutilation, and the effects of exposure on Angels who venture into the wastelands. Reading about how your Body distorts, your Mind cracks, and your Soul frays. Not a light topic. Are you just addicted to misery? Your next magic course will be intermediate Mind. Internal projection, mostly, but the description includes a short introduction to transmutation and some external application as well. Interestingly enough, the instructor‚Äôs name is familiar too. Sister Veriline Noll, the monk who gave you the tour on your first day here. She did say she‚Äôs a Mind instructor, so you suppose you shouldn‚Äôt be surprised. The course doesn‚Äôt start for a bit, which gives you time to work on your project. Terrible dreams continue to assault you. Nothing as intense as the shade, but it‚Äôs rare that you can get a good night‚Äôs sleep anymore. You just have so many worries. Serri, Naoriel, your sickness, the kidnapper, Inquisitors, the corruption, betrayal, your fortune, and on and on. It‚Äôs a small mercy that your Angelic Body is capable of functioning despite your poor rest, though you seem to be coughing a little more often with your physical energy focused more on keeping you upright than healthy. It‚Äôs probably fine. Something will change soon. You‚Äôll fix something; you can feel it. Winter fades. Spring approaches. The fog thins; the air warms. It‚Äôs still cold, but snow is starting to melt. You‚Äôve made good progress with your project. Now it‚Äôs time for the practical experimentation portion. ‚Äã
9:47 PM
[This is a critical point. One character‚Äôs fate will be altered.] [What did you decide to do?] ‚Äç - Gather a large, consistent dataset of standardized resistances, including non-Angels. None of this slapdash science from previous studies. [Large group, small testing] - Attempt to correlate a number of factors to various aspects of resistance, among a moderately sized group. [Medium group, medium testing] ‚Äç - Test a number of varied sources on only one or a few individuals, for comparison of the sources themselves. [Small group, large testing] ‚ùì - Or something else...? [Specify in #story_discussion.] [And who‚Äôs helping you with it?] - Just you. ‚Äç‚Äç - Some of your fellow trainees. - Some adult Angels. (Winners: , ‚Äç‚Äç ) (edited)

Mxblah 4/20/2024 5:06 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 97 Brother Trigg taps the sheaf of papers on the table to straighten it, then hands it back to you. ‚ÄúYour plan has been approved, though with the specified caveats listed on the front here. Namely, you‚Äôll need to have two purification-certified Angels on site whenever you‚Äôre working with the corruption, and you‚Äôll need to do all the experimentation in one of the wall sites. We can‚Äôt risk anything getting into the city by mistake.‚Äù You nod, accepting the papers. The plan is startlingly thick; it‚Äôs hard to believe you wrote it. You were worried about that too, since your experiment is dealing with an even more dangerous substance: the corruption itself. So to protect yourself and Trigg, you made sure to clear the whole plan with one of the bishops. At least that way, if anyone gets in trouble, it won‚Äôt be someone you personally care about. You skim the pages he‚Äôs referring to; everything seems to make sense. ‚ÄúOkay. I think I‚Äôm ready, then.‚Äù ‚ÄúGood, good! Now, just one more check beforehand. I‚Äôve seen your drafts and everything looks sensible so far, but is there anything about your topic that you have questions on? Anything whatsoever; I want you to be as prepared as you possibly can be before going into this.‚Äù ‚Äú... Well, there is one thing...‚Äù ‚ÄúI‚Äôm all ears. How can I help?‚Äù ‚Äã
5:06 PM
‚Äú...‚Äù You weren‚Äôt sure if you wanted to ask him about this. But, given that you‚Äôve already halfway done so... ‚ÄúHalf-Angels. @Story Notifications Scene 99 ‚Äú...‚Äù ‚ÄúJessamine?‚Äù ‚ÄúWe need to talk after this.‚Äù She looks at you, expression somewhere between quizzical and concerned. ‚ÄúAbout what?‚Äù ‚ÄúLater. Mxblah 4/26/2024 10:09 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 100 You‚Äôre stronger than you were just a few months ago. Even though you haven‚Äôt been specifically practicing physical magic, you still learned the basics. And you know you can do this one, since you did before. The air pulls in, drawing from all around you in a brief, powerful vortex. Then, in an instant of painful tension on your Soul as you strain it to your limit, release. A blast of wind rushes out, racing against the falling stone. Impact. You‚Äôre almost knocked off your feet by the heavy shock as the ground trembles. Too much dust in the air. Is anyone okay? You hurry forward, hearing alarmed shouts from somewhere behind; still too far. The first purifier Angel looms out of the dust cloud like a phantom, expression twisted into a snarl. He grabs your wrist before you have time to react, yanking you away from the shattered rock and ominous quiet. ‚ÄúYou again. 10:09 PM

Etalyn, Yara, and Clarity are joined by two more adult Angels - including the purifier whose appearance the kidnapper had stolen - and manage to heft the bulk of the rock up and away to thud into the ground nearby. Immediately afterwards, Clarity and the purifier kneel and start to close the wounds. Well, sort of. There‚Äôs not much that can be done for anything caught under the boulder‚Äôs main mass. You have to look away, feeling sick, as both of her legs come away much shorter than they used to be. They can fix that. Surely. ... Trains come and go. He presses, but you just... ‚ÄúAlright, that‚Äôs enough. Move on. I‚Äôll speak with her.‚Äù ‚Äã
10:09 PM
The serious Angel moves on. A distinguished man with a mustache and deep blue badge on his vest sits down in the other chair. You‚Äôve been moved inside at some point. There‚Äôs no one else here. Those eyes aren‚Äôt gold like the Emissary‚Äôs, but they‚Äôre just as discerning. ‚ÄúI need to know. What happened today? And was it truly just an accident?‚Äù ‚Äú... This is the man who‚Äôs been stalking her for years! How much does he know? Is this just a test? ‚ÄúCan‚Äôt decide whether to tell the truth?‚Äù You flinch, despite desperately trying not to. ‚ÄúI understand. Maybe I can ease your fears.‚Äù He taps on the wall, looking away from you for a brief moment. ‚ÄúSeal this room. Don‚Äôt allow anyone to listen in. And that includes yourselves.‚Äù A brief pause. You feel a pulse of magic wash over you from several directions. ‚ÄúThe Inquisitors are very loyal, and very good at their jobs. No one will hear anything you have to say except me. And, similarly, no one will hear anything I have to say, either.‚Äù ‚Äú...‚Äù ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve been watching Naoriel since she Ascended. Why? Don‚Äôt you know?‚Äù ‚ÄúI... don‚Äôt-‚Äù ‚ÄúDo not lie to me. 10:09 PM
... What are you supposed to do? Does he really know, or is he trying to get information out of you? You... you can‚Äôt say. No matter what. ‚ÄúI promised not to talk about it.‚Äù The prime nods, seemingly surprised. ‚ÄúDetermined, are you? Very well, I‚Äôll respect that.‚Äù A deep inhale. ‚ÄúWe are watching Naoriel because she has suspect parentage and shows physical signs of potential corruption.‚Äù You do your best not to react when he continues with the very thing you had intended to clear up with her just earlier today. ‚ÄúIn brief, certain members of the Cathedra are suspicious that Naoriel is a half-Angel.‚Äù ‚Äú...‚Äù ‚ÄúThey are correct.‚Äù You feel like you‚Äôve been punched in the gut. @Story Notifications Scene 101 ‚Äú... It wasn‚Äôt an accident. And this isn‚Äôt the first time, either.‚Äù The prime stays quiet, inviting you to continue. With some difficulty, you do. @Story Notifications Scene 102 Despite the recent revelations, nothing in particular happens - and in fact matters improve somewhat - over the next few months. The betrayer does not appear again, no one calls out or executes Naoriel, and you start your new magic course in mid March. Sister Noll doesn‚Äôt go easy on you just because you‚Äôd met before. ‚ÄúInternal Mind magic is about perception and defense,‚Äù she tells you on the first day, as you stand awkwardly in the sparring grounds holding a seemingly non-Mind-related wooden sword. ‚ÄúYour first course taught you the basics of perception and focus, but nothing of defense.‚Äù ‚ÄúEr, Mental defense, right? Not...‚Äù You gesture with the sword, hoping she gets the idea. ‚ÄúBoth! A competent Angel uses their Mind as much as their Body in physical combat. With practice, you can block out the corruption and still accelerate your own thinking to guide your Body with minute precision. But that will come later. To start with, let‚Äôs work on your more basic Mental defenses.‚Äù ‚ÄúOkay.‚Äù A pause. You still haven‚Äôt had your implied question answered. ‚ÄúSo, the sword...?‚Äù ‚ÄúFor realism. You don‚Äôt think you‚Äôre going to be just sitting in a perfectly quiet environment while having to defend yourself, do you? Come on; show me the skills you‚Äôve built up during your first year. Focus!‚Äù ... Yeah. Things went on like that for a while. You often came back from your Mind course more beat up than from your Body one. But you have to admit it has been effective, both in Mental technique and in swordplay. Your focus is improving and you‚Äôre becoming more adept at purging external presences from your Mind. And also getting clobbered by Noll‚Äôs blade less often - though you‚Äôve still got a long way to go on that front. It‚Äôs probably a good thing she works with Angels; it feels like you would have gotten seriously hurt if you were still a normal human. As-is, you‚Äôre usually feeling better within a few hours. ‚Äã
9:08 PM
Anyway, this new defensive training is probably why your nightmares seem to be getting less intense. Or at least, that‚Äôs what you‚Äôre going to believe. You haven‚Äôt seen that terrifyingly realistic shade again, and it‚Äôs now much more rare to get the kind of dream where you‚Äôre betrayed or murdered or hunted endlessly. A full night‚Äôs sleep returns to a more ordinary occurrence, and your health improves correspondingly. Fewer coughs; it feels like you‚Äôre finally making some progress with the miracle for your lungs. You finally managed to make it stop hurting, and the Soul motion to cast it is starting to become second nature. Things, in brief, are looking up. You even have some time with all the self-improvement to get together with Yara, Clarity, Denn, Erich (ugh), and Serri to learn disguise magic, because you‚Äôre allowed to now and you‚Äôre totally not spreading yourself too thin. Actually, you‚Äôre kind of surprised Erich hadn‚Äôt already learned it; he‚Äôs been a second year for a while. It‚Äôs even more surprising that he‚Äôs willing to join up with you and everyone to learn together; maybe Denn asked him? He‚Äôs about the only one of the group friendly enough with Erich for that to make sense. Naoriel, to avoid any awkward questions, skips out on the main group; you insinuate to the others that she just doesn‚Äôt want to be around Erich. Which, luckily, is plausible because he really does not like her at all. Instead, she practices with you and Yara later, since he‚Äôs trustworthy enough to not say anything if you ask him not to. You do contemplate trying to bring him in on the secret entirely, but Naoriel‚Äôs understandably reluctant to tell anyone else without an extremely good reason. You figure he might find out on his own eventually anyway. He‚Äôs sharp like that. ‚Äã
9:09 PM
Disguise magic is Body projection (at least the basic form is; Clarity can do transmutation as well), which means you‚Äôre having to learn a new focus area whether you want to or not. It feels very different from Mental projection in ways you have trouble putting into words. At least you‚Äôre not trying the transmutation variant where you‚Äôd be manipulating your actual Body; thinking about that sort of thing gives you the creeps. What if you accidentally lost concentration for a moment and moved your arm where your leg should go? At least with projections, it‚Äôs all illusory. You‚Äôre not changing your Body in any ‚Äúreal‚Äù sense - you‚Äôre just adding a different appearance on top of it. You‚Äôre not entirely sure how that makes sense - projections can only add or subtract the target aspect, and you‚Äôre not adding or removing flesh and bone - but Clarity explains that you‚Äôre ‚Äúadding Body in the sense of appearance, not in the physical sense.‚Äù Sure. Whatever that means. Erich is annoyingly good at this too, able to change his hair color on the very first day and quickly progressing to more complicated illusions faster than anyone else. However, with Serri focusing on Body projection in her courses, she‚Äôs actually got an advantage on you and manages to turn around her performance in the basic magic course. Good for her! Not good for you, though; it‚Äôs kind of embarrassing having everyone else give you tips as you struggle to grasp your Soul properly. For some reason, it‚Äôs hard for you to visualize your appearance, which makes it a lot more difficult to direct how you want your Soul to move. Erich suggests a mirror. You roll your eyes, until he emphasizes he‚Äôs being serious. With that tone, you figured he was just making fun of you. Maybe that‚Äôs just his default voice. ... It does help to look at yourself as you practice, reminding you what you actually look like and what you want to change. Darn Erich having a good idea for once. ‚Äã
9:09 PM
Anyway, you‚Äôre so busy with your training that the spring and summer fly by in no time at all. Before you know it, August is already here. Two new Angels have already Ascended after Jun in January, but you‚Äôve been so distracted you‚Äôve hardly learned anything about them. All your investigations have been on hold as well; you‚Äôve just been so focused. But. Here you are. August 14th - Endle Day - is almost here. It‚Äôs been nearly one whole year since the last time you went home. You‚Äôre stronger now, but are you really ready to try that again? Seth and your parents have been understanding in their letters, but somehow you feel like they‚Äôre just saying that. Like you‚Äôre betraying them by not coming home. But returning just because of that feeling wouldn‚Äôt be fair either, would it? - Go home. - Don‚Äôt. (Winner: ) (edited)

Mxblah 5/2/2024 8:33 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 103 ‚Äú...‚Äù The train feels different today. Maybe it‚Äôs because this is your first time traveling on your own, without anyone else to sit with or talk to. That makes sense. You‚Äôre only barely adept enough at disguise magic to get out of the Cathedra under your own power, a mirror of the first time you left after just learning to suppress your glow the day before. The gate guards had to consider your appearance for longer than usual, checking to make sure you didn‚Äôt miss anything with your magic. You didn‚Äôt, but the disguise is fragile and weaker than Clarity‚Äôs or Yara‚Äôs. You have to keep your focus in order to keep it up, and you still look perhaps more pretty or graceful than an ordinary girl your age should. Still, it‚Äôs within the bounds of humanly possible. You‚Äôre fine. The weather is hot and sunny, much like last year. You‚Äôre continuously grateful for your Angelic Body that resists the heat without even needing to sweat (at least, not much). The people around you seem almost gross by comparison, even though you know that‚Äôs just what normal people look like. It‚Äôs not like you‚Äôve been completely isolated and forgotten what non-Angels are (your instructors and other Cathedra staff, for one) but you‚Äôve... kind of been having similar thoughts about them sometimes. Only occasionally, though! You don‚Äôt look down on anyone, not like Erich! So you do your best to be as polite as you can, pressed against the window due to the unfortunate girth of the sweaty gentleman in the seat next to you. It‚Äôs not his fault and he is trying to be polite by shuffling a little into the aisle; this is just the reality of too many people and not enough seats on the train. At least the windows are partially open today, letting out the heat and letting in the breeze. It‚Äôs a real relief when the train makes it out of downtown and more people start leaving at each stop than boarding. You miss the private trains that are your privilege with the Cathedra. ‚Äã
8:33 PM
Anyway, here you are at your stop. You squeeze past your seatmate and the other people in the aisle, emerging into the station‚Äôs somewhat-fresher air. Then, without much of a reason to stick around, into the same city streets you last walked almost exactly one year ago. Just about down to the minute, actually; the train schedule hasn‚Äôt changed much and you‚Äôre pretty sure you took the same one. The neighborhood hasn‚Äôt changed much either... Hum. No, maybe it has. Something seems off as you walk down the not-quite-familiar-anymore streets, and it‚Äôs not the same thing that felt off last time. You‚Äôre still nervous about meeting your family again, sure, but you don‚Äôt quite feel the same sense of alienation. This time, the streets just feel... wary? On edge. There‚Äôs anticipation leaking from the cobbles and buildings here, and it seems to be following you. The area is aware of you, and it intends to do something about your presence. Does that even make sense? Objects don‚Äôt have Minds; they can‚Äôt think like that. And yet... corrupted objects can. You know they can, because those flowers hated you. The wastelands hate you. This sensation is sort of like that, but not quite so violent. The streets don‚Äôt hate you. They‚Äôre just watching. Carefully. A slight shiver; you glance back uneasily. You can‚Äôt see any more details than that, since you‚Äôd have to shift your Soul‚Äôs phase to something other than Body to read Mind or Soul clues. But, obviously, you can‚Äôt do that without dropping your disguise. That‚Äôs the main disadvantage of projection over transmutation - you can only do one thing at a time - and it‚Äôs already annoying you enough to consider learning transmutation. Everyone says it‚Äôs really hard, though, so maybe slow down a little with that ambition. ‚Äã
8:33 PM
The area‚Äôs also kinda empty. There are some people around, and you suppose you wouldn‚Äôt expect too many here on Endle Day, but you can often go a whole block without anyone in sight. Is there something else going on? It is a holiday; maybe everyone‚Äôs just out at one festival or another? You resolve to ask the next person you see, and that next person happens to be a girl probably a few years older than you. She steps out of a house midway down the block, failing to turn and close the door, then wanders off in the same direction you‚Äôre going. You figure that shouting to get the attention of a perfect stranger is probably a little much, so you quicken your step a bit to close the distance. The hourly bell starts to chime; you‚Äôre now officially late. That‚Äôs not entirely your fault - the train was delayed due to hectic holiday crowds - but you should hurry up. Maybe you can just ask your family, actually, and then you won‚Äôt need to interact with anyone else. But why is she walking so weird? You have a fair amount of time to stare (not creepily!) as you catch up, and her steps are oddly monotone. Your current attunement to Body makes it more obvious that this isn‚Äôt her natural gait, though you really wish you could dip into Mind for a moment to figure out what she might be thinking. There‚Äôs no one immediately visible in the house she just left either; no parents or siblings to get annoyed about her leaving the door open. You almost close the door, but maybe there‚Äôs a reason; you probably shouldn‚Äôt interfere, just to be safe. Maybe this is some kind of weird game, like hide and seek but you have to step in a certain way to count down? The girl turns left at the next intersection; you need to go straight. So, you... - Go straight. - Turn left and talk to the girl. Ô∏è - Turn left and follow the girl. (Winner: ) (edited)

Mxblah 5/4/2024 4:21 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 104 Go straight. It‚Äôs not that you don‚Äôt have any suspicion about the situation, but really, the odds that you‚Äôre just misreading something and will be butting into someone else‚Äôs business are much higher than there being an actual problem you could possibly do anything about. Plus, you‚Äôre already late and you can get information on the district from your family anyway. You leave the girl to her wandering and continue on your way. But, even though you should be hurrying due to the time, you start to slow down a little as you get close. Anxiety. Nervousness. A bit of dissociation - that‚Äôs the same as last time - slips back into your Mind. No; you‚Äôre stronger than this now. You. Can. Do. This. So you stop, just for a minute. Place your hands on a cool metal streetlamp. Close your eyes. You still can‚Äôt shift over to Mind because someone could show up at any moment, but you can calm yourself using nonmagical means. Focus on the texture of the stem you‚Äôre gripping. None of those abstract worries are necessary right now. Back to their compartments. All you need is yourself, right now. ... Maybe that helped a little? You can‚Äôt really tell; you‚Äôre still nervous. Okay, you‚Äôll just cheat when you get inside; you can drop your disguise there and use Mind magic. Despite Noll‚Äôs insistence that you should only rely on the technique against the corruption or in other extreme situations, she still taught you how to directly bolster your own emotions. You‚Äôre not very good at it yet, as she‚Äôs been focusing mainly on more broad applications, but you can do it. Projection: adding or removing the aspect. You will be able to simply remove your own fear once you get out of the street. ‚Äã
4:21 PM
Well... it doesn‚Äôt quite work like that - it‚Äôs less precisely targeted than you‚Äôd like to think - and you can‚Äôt do it forever, but even just the idea that you have a backup plan in case you get overwhelmed again helps. Ha, nonmagical means to calm down by thinking about magic. Does that count? Noll probably wouldn‚Äôt be impressed. You manage a little grin and let go of the lamp, opening your eyes and continuing to your destination. Okay, go. Do it. Raise your hand. And. ‚Äú...‚Äù Second try. Go on; raise your hand. And. Knock. You hear some thumping from inside, followed by the door being very quickly thrown open. ‚ÄúJess‚Äôs here!‚Äù Seth shouts back into the house, before ushering you in. ‚ÄúAnd she‚Äôs late!‚Äù ‚ÄúH-hey,‚Äù you protest. ‚ÄúThe train was late. I can‚Äôt do anything about that!‚Äù ‚ÄúAw, you still can‚Äôt fly yet? They‚Äôre keeping all the cool spells from you.‚Äù ‚ÄúWell-‚Äù It feels surprisingly natural this time. Much of your anxiety drops away as you and Seth bicker like you always do. As dad comes in from the back where he‚Äôd been tinkering with the pipes. As mom hurries down from upstairs, also running late. As everyone gives you a hug. This is more like it. More normal; more real. The echoes of last time already feel almost like a bad dream. It‚Äôs been so long, but everything‚Äôs okay now. You‚Äôre fine. That‚Äôs such a relief. ‚ÄúSo, er, where is everybody?‚Äù you ask a while later, sitting at the table with Seth while your parents finish cleaning nearby. Normally one or both of you would be helping them, but you‚Äôve both been told to stay put this time. Seth seems to know something you don‚Äôt. Surprises make you nervous. ‚ÄúI only saw a few people once I left the station.‚Äù ‚ÄúHm? Probably just out enjoying the festivals. We don‚Äôt have one here and most people don‚Äôt stay home today.‚Äù ‚Äú... Okay, I guess that makes sense.‚Äù It does, but you‚Äôre still a little uneasy. Was it this empty last year? You can‚Äôt quite remember. ‚ÄúIt just feels a little weird today.‚Äù ‚Äã
4:22 PM
‚ÄúWell, you‚Äôve been gone forever,‚Äù Seth complains. ‚Äú‚ÄòCourse it‚Äôd seem different.‚Äù ‚ÄúI was just, er, busy...‚Äù ‚ÄúLearning more cool magic? What can you do now?‚Äù ‚ÄúUh...‚Äù You hesitate, thinking through all the magic you know. I can do my disguise spell on my own now.‚Äù ‚ÄúEh? Does that mean you can make yourself look different, too? Can you look like me?‚Äù ‚ÄúW-well...‚Äù No, not really. Disguise-by-projection is a tricky subject and you‚Äôve been pestering your Body instructor about the theory behind it, since you still don‚Äôt get why it isn‚Äôt transmutation. One thing that‚Äôs sort of critical to the spell is that you can only change your appearance by projection to things you can visualize as ‚Äúyou.‚Äù So, you can make yourself look like a normal version of you instead of an Angelic version, but you can‚Äôt make yourself look like your brother. That‚Äôs because you can‚Äôt see yourself as being him, so your Body aspect doesn‚Äôt contain anything you can add or remove to get to that endpoint. Does that make sense? So you can ‚Äúremove‚Äù the divinity from your Body using projection in order to do your disguise spell, but you can‚Äôt ‚Äúadd‚Äù your brother to your own appearance. Even though it sort of seems like you should be able to, you just can‚Äôt. You can ‚Äúadd‚Äù age to see what you might look like in the future, but it‚Äôs just a guess based on your own conception. 4:22 PM
In order to make yourself look like Seth, you‚Äôd have to ‚Äúchange‚Äù your appearance, which would be transmutation. Which actually makes what Erich did on his first day even more puzzling, since he changed his hair color. Assuming he doesn‚Äôt dye his hair regularly enough to see black hair as part of ‚Äúhimself,‚Äù that means he must have been using transmutation. It just doesn‚Äôt make sense and you haven‚Äôt decided if you want to ask him yet. ‚ÄúJess?‚Äù Oh, shoot. How long have you been spacing out? ‚ÄúN-no, I can‚Äôt. 4:22 PM
You‚Äôve heard of such weapons and have seen a few around, but also haven‚Äôt used one yourself. Angels typically don‚Äôt - they tend to use physical magic for ranged combat - but soldiers need ways of dealing with corrupted beasts at a safe distance. @Story Notifications Scene 107 Okay, stay calm and think about this rationally. Whatever was influencing you could do it again as soon as you let go of the magic. You need to leave. But what should you tell your family? ... So either it‚Äôs just after you specifically (most likely, you think) or it‚Äôs after everyone and you won‚Äôt be able to make a difference even if you stay to try to protect them. With a breath out, you release the suppression spell and switch back to the one that guards your Mind against interference. Your emotions return in an instant, causing your breath to hitch as you remember you‚Äôre already scared of the dark from all your nightmares and now the knowledge that there definitely is something out there makes it all the worse. ‚Äã
9:43 PM
Another big problem is your appearance. You‚Äôd have to switch back to Body in order to recover your disguise, but that would leave your Mind vulnerable. After thinking about it for a few minutes inside, you eventually decided to risk being seen as an Angel (it‚Äôs dark and there aren‚Äôt many people around) rather than risk losing control of your decisions. One could lead to a minor scandal and a firm talking-to; the other could lead to death. Yeah, you know which risk sounds more appealing. So off you go through the darkened streets, balancing a desire to stay in the light of the few streetlamps around with a desire to hide away from them. You‚Äôre already jogging, uneasily passing through empty intersections as quickly as you dare. What are you going to say if you run into someone? Will you pretend to be on a mission? Surely they wouldn‚Äôt believe it; no one would send a trainee like yourself out at night with no backup. Just... do your best to avoid getting into a situation like that. The station‚Äôs not far off, really, and it should be faster at your current pace. As long as you don‚Äôt miss a turn. It‚Äôs hard to read the signs in the dark. You‚Äôre still going the right way. Probably. Someone peeks at you from a lit window as you hurry past. Surely they didn‚Äôt get a good enough glimpse to tell anything. You speed up, back itching as if something‚Äôs about to stab you in it. A glance behind you; still nothing there. You‚Äôre not reassured. Warm lights up ahead; a train‚Äôs bell clangs. The station is close and that light is the square in front of it. Even at this hour, it‚Äôll still be busy with people. You‚Äôve got to change back to your disguise now; there‚Äôs just no way you can ride a regular train all the way back as an Angel. It‚Äôll be far too obvious. ‚Äã
9:43 PM

You‚Äôre on your own this time, and you have to just stand there for many excruciating seconds as you try to wrangle your Soul into the right phase. It‚Äôs made harder by your fear, which you know you could fix if you returned to Mind, but that‚Äôd just put you right back where you were! You have to just power through and make it work! You make the switch, finally, your Soul slotting into place with almost a jolt. Now you just have to cast the spell - not a quick or easy feat on its own - and you‚Äôll at last be able to emerge into safety. There‚Äôs a man walking quickly down the street in your direction. He‚Äôs heading for the station... or you. Head up, but eyes in shadow from the darkness and a large cap, like some factory workers tend to wear. Your attunement to Body tells you his movements are somewhat unnatural, like that girl from earlier. The night is cold, yet he‚Äôs only wearing thin clothes appropriate for an evening at home.
