Mxblah 5/12/2024 1:40 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 108 No. Stay calm. You‚Äôre probably just being influenced by Mind magic to find this man more threatening than he actually is. Just step off to the side here where you‚Äôll be in deeper shadow, then finish the spell. Easy. The man glances at you on his way past. ‚ÄúHuh?‚Äù He looks back, but you‚Äôve finished your disguise in the second between glances. ‚ÄúMust‚Äôve been imagining it,‚Äù he mutters. Then, in a louder voice intended for you to hear, ‚ÄúEvenin‚Äô, lil‚Äô miss.‚Äù He shakes his head as he wanders off, obviously confused. Too close. You pass the man again on your way into the station, though neither of you say anything that time. Get your tickets from the counter and make your way to the proper platform to await the train. Even later at night, service is still frequent today due to the holiday; you won‚Äôt have long to wait. ... There sure are a lot of people around like that man. Weird gait, though probably undetectable to someone not attuned to Body. Weirdly underdressed for the weather, though with thick work gloves. Do they all work at the same factory and are just getting done at the same time? Was there a convention for glove appreciators? You wander down to the other end of the platform, trying to look casual doing it. Some of the glove people follow you, though it‚Äôs hard to tell why and you wouldn‚Äôt have noticed if you weren‚Äôt actively monitoring them. Maybe they just think you know where the train will show up. Well, none of them approach, harass, or attack you, so you suppose it‚Äôs fine. Just a little weird. At last, the train arrives three minutes late and you board to return downtown. Some of the glove people get on, but some of them just wander off. The doors close and you let out a relieved breath, starting to believe you‚Äôve gotten away from whatever might have been chasing you. Or, really, it might not have been and you were just psyching yourself out for no reason at all. ‚Äã
1:40 PM
The only glove person in your car gets off a few stops down, muttering confusedly to himself, and you finally relax. Everyone else on board seems normal. Plus, you‚Äôve got a seat to yourself this time so you don‚Äôt have to deal with anyone making the day‚Äôs heat even worse. ... Why did you think it was cold earlier? The day was blazingly hot and the night is still warmer than normal. Maybe it was just panic. You‚Äôre not entirely convinced, but don‚Äôt have a better explanation. Now, with the immediate situation under control, your thoughts (almost certainly your own again, given how far you‚Äôve traveled) turn to what you should do after returning to the Cathedra. Admittedly, you don‚Äôt have any real evidence that anything dangerous was going on. Nothing actively attacked you and there was nothing weird going on - at least, nothing that you couldn‚Äôt explain in some other way. Like a glove-wearer‚Äôs convention. Well, the factory explanation is probably more sensible, but you get the idea. If you tell someone and they send a real Angel to investigate, what are they going to find? Probably nothing, if you‚Äôre being honest. You‚Äôd just be wasting important peoples‚Äô time and making yourself look more paranoid to the dispatchers who you really don‚Äôt want to stop believing your reports. But of course, if you don‚Äôt tell anyone and there is an actual thing there, you could be making the situation worse by letting whatever it is get away with whatever it‚Äôs doing. ‚Äã
1:40 PM

Was... was that even magic at all or was it just a different part of your own Mind and you‚Äôre going nuts? Were you just misleading yourself unconsciously, wanting to stay behind now that home felt so much more comfortable? Can that even happen? It seems ridiculous, but you know that magic is imposing your will on the world through your Soul. There‚Äôs enough wiggle room there for the idea of unconscious self-delusion through magic to seem possible, if not plausible. Here you are. Push your way onto the platform, through the still-busy downtown core, and onto the somewhat quieter streets back to the Cathedra. Everything here is wider and more well-lit, in contrast to the dim, narrow alleys near your parents‚Äô house. The gate guards don‚Äôt say anything unusual about your late return - it‚Äôs still within the same day, so you‚Äôre fine - and you release your disguise with a grateful sigh as you pass into the grounds proper. It‚Äôs surprising just how much better it feels to look like an Angel. You‚Äôd swear there was a physical difference, even though you know there isn‚Äôt really; it‚Äôs all just an illusion. But the Center is the other way, and if you want to report what happened to someone, sooner is probably better than later... - Tell a dispatcher what happened. Mxblah 5/20/2024 9:10 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 112 You switch to Mind and everything moves very quickly for a moment. A burst of energy in your head; a flurry of movement from the shade. You run forward as it leaps at you, the same as before, except this time you throw yourself to the ground to avoid its lunge on purpose instead of because you fell off the bed. After scrambling to your feet again, already shifting to Body as you go, a quick glance behind confirms the thing is gone. Where? It did this last time too, but then you woke up right away. Is it actually gone or just hiding somewh - stop that; you have to hurry! The Angel‚Äôs glow vanishes beneath the tar and you spend a moment to release your own so you can see. With Body as your aspect, you need a physical connection to work magic. Therefore, though you‚Äôre both grossed out and very concerned about what the thing will do to you if you touch it, you have no choice. Hands in the gloop. Connected. It‚Äôs disgustingly warm and so viscous you can barely make a dent in it with your fingers. The muck‚Äôs overpowering scent burns your nose, but you can‚Äôt quite describe what it smells like. Like burning-freezing cold, maybe. Even though it feels warm. And it hurts. A dull ache in the skin of your palms that you‚Äôre certain will quickly grow worse if you stay like this. Your plan is very simple. Angels possess the power to burn away and purify corruption with a touch, and this tar can be nothing else but corruption. You hold no illusions that you‚Äôll be able to destroy this entire mass on your own, but you don‚Äôt need to. You‚Äôre going to burn your way through to the trapped Angel, pull them out, and then improvise from there. ‚Äã
9:10 PM
Thankfully, burning away corruption is one of the simplest magics you can learn. There‚Äôs no fancy twist of weird state of Mind; it‚Äôs just a straightforward contest of its power against yours. The most you have to do here is just contain your Soul as it rushes through your hands to burn away the tar so that you don‚Äôt get carried away and kill yourself by exhausting all your energy trying to destroy the entire monster. Which, admittedly, is a little tough. Your power wants to destroy the corruption. That‚Äôs what your Soul is made for. But you hold it back, mostly, channeling your energy just into the small area around your hands. Goop melts away and steams into the air. The smell grows unbearable; you almost gag at the indescribably vile stench. Heating this thing up only made it worse. But you can see something white and glowing just beneath your hands; only a little bit more and... something hard. You grab on, brace yourself against the fountain - ack; little tendrils of tar were trying to wrap around your feet! - and pull! Enhance your Body as you do, pulling your Soul back in to empower yourself instead of destroying the goop. There‚Äôs a sickening squelch, another burst of horrid scent, and you fall back against the fountain holding a dripping, tar-covered skull. ‚Äú--!!!‚Äù The skull bounces merrily across the cobbles as you instinctively throw it away. The skin on your hands is burning and the tar has re-absorbed the rest of the Angel‚Äôs now headless Body. Your back itches; there‚Äôs tar on it and your legs now, too. You tear yourself away from the fountain and run halfway across the square before collapsing to your hands and knees, gasping for air and desperately trying not to look at the skull. It‚Äôs not a clean, white abstraction like you‚Äôve seen in anatomy courses. It‚Äôs... you gag again, about ready to throw up. ‚Äã
9:10 PM
Your hands hurt so badly! The pain forces your attention away from the tar and - and your skin is melting off! Focus! Concentrate; purify! You can stop this! You can - your legs hurt too and your back and ------ you can‚Äôt focus it just hurts everywhere you can‚Äôt a a a aA A A ... You wake up with a choking gasp. Tar lies around you, scorched and burned by incredible heat. Your Body is healed, completely, without a single scratch or burn anywhere. It takes you a moment to figure out what happened. You died. This is your second chance. The first time in your life that you would die, God will save you. You revise the tense from future to past. God saved you. But, if that‚Äôs true for you, then the skull- ‚ÄúNo...‚Äù Still dead; just more horribly melted now. You quickly look away. Maybe they already used it, or the goop triggered it earlier, or it doesn‚Äôt work on just a skull, or... you don‚Äôt know. You failed. There‚Äôs nothing more you can do here; you just have to- The clatter of a loose stone just behind. You turn. The shade stabs you in the chest, right below the heart. No. Nononono not like this. The magic that would save you hovers tauntingly just out of your grasp. You‚Äôve never trained extensively with healing spells, nor can you focus through the agonizing, leaking emptiness as blood pours out of the ragged wound even if you had. There‚Äôs nothing you can do but take a few stumbling steps, trip, and collapse to the ground again. Angels may be God‚Äôs perfect soldiers, but you‚Äôre certainly just as fragile as any mortal human. You know that now. ... Bright sunlight. You open your eyes and slowly sit up. You‚Äôre in your bedroom at the Cathedra. It‚Äôs morning. You aren‚Äôt dead. ‚Äú...‚Äù Well. You knew your nightmares were going to be bad. But that was beyond even your expectations. ‚Äã
9:10 PM
You‚Äôre still shaking when you eventually get up, and you have to check your Body and clothes to make sure there‚Äôs no evidence of anything that happened. No wounds, no burns, no tar. You‚Äôre unharmed. Was everything that just happened simply a dream? No shade, no tar, no second chance; nothing? Just a figment of your stressed imagination? ... Clarity! Is she okay? Right? ‚Äú...‚Äù - Go find her right now and make sure! - Calm down and find her once you‚Äôve gotten ahold of yourself. If she had anything urgent to share, she would have woken you up already. Mxblah 5/22/2024 8:35 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 113 Well... better to be sure. You hurry downstairs, about ready to start checking with everyone you run into (at least, everyone you know). But that seems to be unnecessary, since you can already hear her explaining something with great enthusiasm. But of course, the last time you heard her... You find Clarity in the little cafe area on the first floor, cheerfully chatting with Yara. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre okay!‚Äù you exclaim, accidentally interrupting her. ‚ÄúOh, morning, Jess! No, erm, shades or... t-tar monsters?‚Äù ‚ÄúTar monsters?‚Äù ‚Äú...‚Äù With a careful effort, you manage to avoid breaking down at the table. The skull didn‚Äôt look that much like her, anyway. 8:35 PM

Usually, a Soul will dissipate shortly after the Body or Mind it‚Äôs tied to dies, presumably dying as well. (Although no one really knows where Souls go after that, if they go anywhere at all. The church‚Äôs public stance is that God reclaims the energy of dissipated Souls and may eventually return them to new lives with faint memories of the people they had been - though as an Angel, you know that‚Äôs never actually been proven. You hope it‚Äôs true.) But some Souls just... don‚Äôt. Most lost Souls are formed by lingering on after a particularly miserable or violent death, and they sometimes seem able to bind themselves to other objects or Bodies different from their original one. They‚Äôre one of the many facets of corruption that Angels must destroy within the city, since there‚Äôs no way to put them back together after their original Body‚Äôs death. It‚Äôs one of the few exceptions to the ‚Äúhuman Souls are sacred‚Äù clause, since they‚Äôre corrupted beyond any chance of repair - you‚Äôre told it‚Äôs kinder to end their suffering. 9:23 PM
‚ÄúLike so many things around here, ‚Äòit‚Äôs God‚Äôs will‚Äô is the best answer anyone has managed to come up with so far,‚Äù Erich declares. ‚ÄúBut the trend is real enough. We have a reasonable chance of making something work today that would have been mythical a few centuries ago.‚Äù You think about that for a while afterwards, long after Yara heads off to the Center and the rest of your group disperses to various destinations. If Angels get their power from God, and Angels are getting stronger over time... then wouldn‚Äôt that mean that God is getting weaker? It‚Äôs a simple equation and you‚Äôre able to come up with a few reasons why it wouldn‚Äôt be true. Maybe God is also getting stronger, drawing power from some outside source - maybe wherever He came from, if He came from anywhere at all. Maybe it is just improved training or humanity‚Äôs Bodies and Souls in general becoming more used to Angelic powers over generations of Ascensions. Maybe you‚Äôre draining power from the corruption, shifting the balance in your favor over years and years. But what can you say? You‚Äôre a pessimist. The simplest explanation is usually the right one. And the idea that God might be growing steadily weaker is a simple (and very frightening) one indeed. - So, of course, the concept colors your dreams for the night. - But compared to your usual fare, this threat is so distant that it doesn‚Äôt bother you as much. (Winner: ) (edited)

Mxblah 5/30/2024 8:17 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 117 It‚Äôs very dark and everything is quiet. You shuffle around in bed, trying to ignore whatever vaguely threatening premonition woke you up this time, but it‚Äôs no use. You‚Äôre wondering about it now, and that anxious curiosity is just waking you up further. With a sigh, you sit up and turn on the - no, better not; you really want to go back to sleep after this. Instead, you just drowsily pad over to the bedroom door (left open again; you‚Äôve mostly gone back to your old habit by now) and head to the window. Nothing seems amiss as you peer outside, scanning the silhouettes of various Cathedra structures and the ground far below for anything dangerous or unusual. Mechanical streetlamps shine into the night, illuminating empty pathways and locked-up buildings. Your anxiety starts to settle and you move to close the curtains, already imagining sinking back into bed. ‚Äú...‚Äù You sure could see pretty far out there. The mist is gone. You press up against the window, reluctantly admitting that you‚Äôre probably not going to be getting any more sleep tonight. It‚Äôs not just the mist; the stars and galaxies that everyone always says are above it - those are gone too. Or maybe they never existed; you‚Äôve certainly never seen more than a dim glow to suggest their presence. And... now that you‚Äôre looking closer, you can‚Äôt see any lights outside of the Cathedra itself. Nucarreo is massive and - even at whatever hour of the night this is - there should be streetlamps or train lights or something visible without all the mist that usually obscures your view. Instead, there‚Äôs nothing but empty blackness. ‚Äú...‚Äù ‚Äã
8:17 PM
You put on some clothes and slip out of your room, quietly heading upstairs to Naoriel‚Äôs room first. With the betrayer‚Äôs repeated appearances, the two of you had promised to wake each other up in case anything weird happened overnight. In fact, you even have a spare key for exactly that purpose in case of another silencing or sleeping spell or whatever. So after a few knocks fail to produce any response, you carefully insert the key and step inside, holding your breath against the possibility that... Gone. An empty bed, neat and tidy. You search the rest of the room quickly, but there‚Äôs no sign of a struggle or... or even a sign that anyone ever lived here. No books, clothes, or other personal artifacts. Would a kidnapper have been so thorough? No; surely not. Something else is going on. Your key somehow works on more doors, even though it shouldn‚Äôt. Yara is missing too, as are Serri, Etalyn, and whoever else you happen to check. After a while, you give up on opening random doors and rush out - no, no; calm down. Be careful. You carefully peek out the front doors and listen, attuning yourself to Soul and searching for any danger before you risk going out to look for anyone else. You should have tried that first. There‚Äôs no one here. There‚Äôs nothing here. Your usually oversensitive Soul picks up absolutely nothing at all. No Angels, no humans, not even any hint of the corruption that you had sort of been worried about. Not a single thing anywhere. It... it should be safe to go out. But to be doubly safe, you repeat the experiment with Mind and Body (i.e. your normal eyes) to confirm nothing in any of the three aspects. Just the empty Cathedra grounds, naked without their coating of mist and devoid of any signs of life. ‚Äú...‚Äù ‚Äã
8:17 PM
The night is cool and dry on your skin, without the normal touch of moisture the fog would ordinarily bring. You feel terribly exposed beneath the empty sky, scurrying along like a hunted animal and constantly glancing around to make sure nothing is anywhere near. With such a long line of sight, you should feel reasonably safe, but you just don‚Äôt. The world shouldn‚Äôt look like this. The Center is empty as well, its chairs and equipment neatly tidied up as if every dispatcher had just gone on break at once. You shouldn‚Äôt be surprised by now, but it‚Äôs still somewhat of a shock to see the normally-bustling office utterly silent. If anyone is left in the city - if there even still is a city - Angels will not be able to hear their pleas. ‚Äú...‚Äù At this point, you‚Äôre almost certain that you‚Äôre the only person left in the world, but there are still some very big questions to answer. You eye the nearby fence; the city isn‚Äôt any less dark from here. You can‚Äôt tell if the buildings are still present, just hidden, or if they‚Äôre gone entirely. Another check of Soul and... oh no. There‚Äôs still nothing at all on this side of the fence, but Nucarreo simmers with icy cold darkness. You‚Äôve never felt so much corruption before; it‚Äôs enough to almost knock you over with the force of its hatred. You know now, without even approaching the fence, that the city is gone. To go out there would be nothing but suicide; you can‚Äôt possibly stand up to such poison on your own. You flee inwards instead, eventually finding yourself near the Cathedra‚Äôs center: the Lordstone Cathedral. Surely, if anything has survived this utter apocalypse, it would be the fragment of God that lies in this very building. ‚Äã
8:17 PM
The doors open at your touch and you step into the antechamber, nervous. Maybe if anyone else survived, they would have had the same idea? Should you call out? M-maybe not yet. Instead, you approach the second set of doors and swallow, steeling yourself to enter the main room. - The Lordstone is gone and, like everyone else, there‚Äôs no sign that it had ever even been there. - The Lordstone is there, but it‚Äôs a husk of its former self. Dull grey patterns drift slowly across its surface. ‚ÄçÔ∏è - The Lordstone is there, and there‚Äôs a man standing before it. He sort of looks like the Emissary, but taller and more regal and... and...?! (Winner: ‚ÄçÔ∏è ) (edited)

Mxblah 6/1/2024 3:50 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 118 The Lordstone is still there, but you can‚Äôt see much of it because there‚Äôs someone standing in front of it. He‚Äôs facing away at the moment, but you can tell he sort of looks like the Emissary. Just taller and more regal and with a faint glow like an Angelic Soul and... and...?!? ‚ÄúEr-‚Äù You struggle to decide what to say to this mysterious figure who is seemingly the only other person left in the world. But... here, and looking like that...? ‚ÄúIs... are you... G-God?‚Äù The man slowly turns to face you. And has the gall to laugh out loud. ‚ÄúI said you‚Äôd call me God next time we met! Mxblah 6/3/2024 9:01 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 119 You spend a lot of time with Yara and Erich over the next few months, helping them work on and test out their new detection spell. It‚Äôs the first time you‚Äôve collaborated with other Angels to make your very own spell - well, it‚Äôs your first time doing that even without the collaboration aspect - so there‚Äôs lots to learn. For instance, how do you share progress or an idea with your partners? It‚Äôs not like you can just explain the specific movements you‚Äôre making with your Soul to them - language just isn‚Äôt precise enough and you don‚Äôt have any tools to measure anything specific. Even if you could say ‚Äúmove X inches to Y angle at Z seconds‚Äù or something, trying to actually follow those instructions would be far too difficult. That‚Äôs one of the reasons that miracle books are so lengthy and so complicated; they have to explain the exact effects you‚Äôre supposed to be producing in such a way that you can produce them yourself. And your aspects will be very different from the author‚Äôs, so they often ask you to go by feeling or to work backwards from an effect or combination of effects you already know how to produce. But here, when you‚Äôre trying to develop something initially, writing out that level of detail would be entirely impractical. So, you get to put into practice some of your new, more advanced Mind abilities. Mind reading, the common people sometimes call it. The ability for an Angel to peer into someone‚Äôs head and understand them better than they could explain it in words. Sometimes people are uncomfortable with the intrusion, but in most cases it‚Äôs understood to be a useful tool to quickly gather specifics that a person just can‚Äôt articulate in any other way. As you‚Äôve been working with Sister Noll for a while now on defenses, she‚Äôs willing to add some extra lessons on this topic - though of course she has to work swordsmanship into it somehow, too. ‚Äã
9:02 PM
‚ÄúRead my intentions. Connect to my Mind and anticipate where I will strike. Ignore my Body; I‚Äôm very skilled at misdirection. Mind only. Ready?‚Äù ‚Äú... Ready.‚Äù You can feel a dim, churning sense of thoughts and directions. Is she going to try and trick you Mentally too? Of course she will; that‚Äôs what she does! ‚ÄúFocus...‚Äù Noll stalks forwards, raising her blade carefully. Still the training one, though that doesn‚Äôt make it much less intimidating. There‚Äôs a sudden surge; you can almost see your own shin. Which one? You have no idea, so instead you leap straight up... a second too early. Noll clobbers you in the side on your way back down, sending you tumbling across the sand. ‚ÄúThat was almost very good,‚Äù she laughs, helping you up as you wipe sand off your back and prod at the new bruise. ‚ÄúBut I think you know the timing was a little off.‚Äù ‚ÄúYeah...‚Äù Those sessions with Noll continued for a while until you mostly got the hang of sending and receiving sensations, emotions, directions, and the like. It‚Äôs very difficult to do with anyone you don‚Äôt have a strong Mental connection with - such as Noll as your instructor or Yara and Erich as your partners in this experiment - and the range is very limited. Touch works best, even though that shouldn‚Äôt matter since physical contact is only required for Body spells. The reason for that, you figured out on your own, though! Physical contact is an inherently Mental action, alongside its more dominant Body trait. You have to think about why you‚Äôre doing it, what you‚Äôre doing, and what you think of the person you‚Äôre touching. Similarly, they‚Äôll have thoughts about what you‚Äôre doing as well. Are you good enough friends to hold hands, or are you just acquaintances and you‚Äôll make do with a brief tap? Do they think of you differently than you think of them? And that‚Äôs not to even mention all the... additional kinds of touches that people in... romantic relationships can think about. It‚Äôs a lot of information to process! ‚Äã
9:02 PM
Of course, you don‚Äôt have to physically touch someone to have all those thoughts. You can think about your relationship or actions you‚Äôre making or whatever whenever you want. Instead, the touch is more of just a focus; a way to tell yourself that this is what you‚Äôre thinking about right now, and that this is the most important thing to focus on at the moment. A way to trick yourself into paying more attention, you suppose. And for someone with as little practice as you (and, if you have to admit it, as prone to distraction as you) that sort of trick is very useful. So anyway, back to the spell. With all the above in Mind, the most effective way to share your ideas is to link your Mind to one of your partners... and then just demonstrate them. If you‚Äôre connected well enough, whoever is ‚Äúriding along‚Äù in your Mind will experience the exact same motions and feelings that you used to produce your version of the spell. Although it can get a little embarrassing if your Mind wanders during the process or if you get distracted by something and suddenly Erich is listening to you think about whatever random thing about clocks (or whatever) suddenly occurred to you. You also have to be terribly careful not to think about Naoriel or anything she‚Äôs told you during these sessions. And of course, trying your best not to think about something is a surefire way to think about it. You‚Äôve had your share of close calls, to the point where you‚Äôve been pursuing another branch of internal Mental magic that would let you modify or suppress your own memories. Unfortunately, that‚Äôs transmutation and it‚Äôs far too difficult to master in any reasonable amount of time. Plus, you‚Äôd get really scared of doing something wrong and basically destroying your own Mind by forgetting which memories you even suppressed and being unable to get them back later. ‚Äã
9:02 PM
So you do your best. You have to break off the connection more than once when a dangerous thought worms its way into your Mind, which can get pretty uncomfortable for whoever was in your head as they get unceremoniously ejected. But of course, you suffer your own fair share of ejections as Yara or Erich think about something they don‚Äôt want you to see, so the three of you mostly just forgive each other and admit you all have things to hide. And after all that work (and literal Mind reading), you‚Äôre really starting to get a better idea of how Erich thinks. You already know Yara pretty well, but this is the first time you feel like you‚Äôve really started to understand Erich. He‚Äôs... actually a very hard worker, and he respects people who put in as much effort as he does. Maybe that‚Äôs why he‚Äôs been working with Yara so well; if there‚Äôs anyone to put in way more work than you‚Äôd expect on something Soul-related, it‚Äôs him. - You and Erich have started to get along better. Maybe working towards friends? - Even with all this time spent, you still just don‚Äôt really like him. (Winner: ) (edited)

You have no idea what you‚Äôre doing. - Say yes. - Say no. (Winner: ) (edited)

Mxblah 6/13/2024 7:58 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 124 Not too long after that conversation, your train pulls into the district seven central station and you disembark. It‚Äôs a little colder here, right on the riverbank, and the station has a kind of interesting design to account for that. The platform is actually curved to match the shape of the river and you have to be extra-careful to step over the larger than normal gap. It‚Äôs odd, since there are plenty of elevated stations around the city; this one could have just gone over the river. Maybe they wanted the central station to be on ground level, or didn‚Äôt want to risk a train falling in the water. Erich takes the lead (which is good, since you don‚Äôt know where you‚Äôre going) and shows you a neat little switchback-staircase carved into the riverbank and paved with stones. It‚Äôs just outside the station, but there‚Äôs no signage and it‚Äôs not very visible from any of the main roads. But it‚Äôs convenient, since it gets you all the way down to the water (well, mostly ice at the moment) much faster than the main path a few streets away. There‚Äôs a gate, but someone left it open and there‚Äôs no sign telling you not to, so you don‚Äôt feel too worried about tentatively stepping out onto the Endle River itself. A lot of it is fully covered in snow, but there are some sections where that‚Äôs been cleared away to reveal ice beneath. There are plenty of people on the river today: enterprising fishermen drilling into the water beneath to catch what chilled fish still pass through, large groups of kids and their parents playing in the massive amounts of unspoiled snow, and a number of other people just walking around like you. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôll be coming back here in the afternoon,‚Äù Erich informs you as he heads further upstream. ‚ÄúBut for now, the caves are just a ten-minute walk this way.‚Äù ‚Äã
7:58 PM
‚ÄúThe caves?‚Äù you narrowly stop yourself from saying. You‚Äôre supposed to remember what‚Äôs going on and that would probably be a little too direct. Still, the caves? Like the ones that you worked at briefly last year... and Erich was there too, now that you think about it. Probably not quite the same, since you‚Äôre on the river this time. You‚Äôre not very knowledgeable about fungi, but something tells you they don‚Äôt grow in water. Maybe near it, you suppose. But why would he be taking you to a grimy, dark farm, essentially? He hated it in those caves. You don‚Äôt have to wait long to find out, as the two of you are both more fit than whoever made the ten minute estimate and make it there ahead of schedule. These caverns are far from the dimly-lit grotto you farmed fungi in; instead, they‚Äôre massive tunnels bored into the riverbank by some incredible force of the distant past. Ice coats the floor - presumably these caves are flooded in the summer - as well as forms into sparkling stalactites on the walls and ceiling. The still-rising sun is angled just right to pass its diffuse yellow-orange glare along the semitranslucent ice, lining the entire cavern with fangs of fiery gold. ‚Äú... Wow,‚Äù you admit. ‚ÄúAnd that is why I said we had to come here first,‚Äù Erich says proudly. ‚ÄúThe sun only lines up like this for a few minutes.‚Äù You do vaguely remember him saying something about that, now that the swirling worries in your Mind have been forcefully ejected by the spectacle. ‚ÄúImagine what it‚Äôd be like if there weren‚Äôt all this mist here.‚Äù ‚ÄúEven more brilliant, I imagine.‚Äù ‚Äã
7:58 PM
You‚Äôre content to stand here and watch for a while, taking in the subtle changes in color and gleam as the sun continues its rise. Clearly, Erich isn‚Äôt the only person to know about this place, as there are plenty of other people gathered around getting in your way and talking about whatever strikes their fancy. For a moment, jostled by a woman who wasn‚Äôt looking where she was going, you feel a surge of annoyance, but it‚Äôs replaced by curiosity as you spot several people disappearing into the cavern‚Äôs mouth. With the overhanging roof starting to obscure the sun, the light show is nearing an end; the crowd starts to dissipate. ‚ÄúErich, where are those two going?‚Äù you ask, pointing into the cave. ‚ÄúWhere do you think?‚Äù he asks in return, angrily dodging around a man backing up to get a better view. ‚ÄúThe caves in this city run deep, and these flooded ones are connected to the main network. Some people like to explore a few rooms in and see what interesting ice formations have popped up this year.‚Äù He stops just short of inviting you to go in, but he doesn‚Äôt have to. Of course you want to; look at this place! ‚ÄúHow far can we go?‚Äù You take a few steps forward, straining to see past the entryway. No good; too much glare from the ice even for your eyes. ‚ÄúProbably farther than they can. But not too deep; we don‚Äôt want to spend hours in there.‚Äù You‚Äôre already moving forward; Erich picks up the pace to catch up. ‚ÄúBack here? Ooh, the light reflects way further than I thought! It‚Äôs like the whole tunnel is glowing!‚Äù ‚è™ - See a few rooms and head back out. Don‚Äôt get carried away. - Okay, maybe get a little carried away. (Winner: ) (edited)

Mxblah 6/15/2024 3:12 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 125 Erich is right; these caves are massive. Even though you don‚Äôt have any equipment, your light Body combined with your Angelic strength lets you clamber up and down and all around the tunnels without too much difficulty. The only parts you have trouble with are vertical shafts where the walls are covered in ice - you can‚Äôt get any good handholds as the whole thing is just too slippery. Thankfully, there aren‚Äôt many of those and you‚Äôre able to just avoid them. In fact, staring up at one such narrow passage in the ceiling, you kind of wonder how and why it would have been formed at all. Were all these caves formed just by the passage of water from the river? Why are they so twisty-turny if that‚Äôs the case? The river itself just keeps going over that way; how much water does it lose down these holes? And where does it all go? ‚ÄúWhat do you think‚Äôs down there?‚Äù you ask at one point, standing on a solid plug of ice that extends down further than you can see, even with your glow at maximum strength (you don‚Äôt have any lights, so this is the best you can do). ‚ÄúIt just keeps going down. This can‚Äôt possibly melt every year, right?‚Äù Erich pokes around the edges of the room, his glow similarly reflecting off the walls. ‚ÄúI doubt it. The river doesn‚Äôt lose that much water and we‚Äôve been going up for a while... I think. This is probably permanent.‚Äù ‚ÄúI wonder if there‚Äôs a way to get below it.‚Äù You hesitate, thinking back to your time underground at the mushroom farm. That time when you stared at the elevator, wondering how deep into the poisoned earth you could go before the very dirt and rocks started to hate you. Before the wastelands stretched beneath your feet as well as past the walls around the city. ‚ÄúHey, er-‚Äù ‚ÄúAh, found something!‚Äù He beckons you over. ‚ÄúSee, there‚Äôs a small fissure here that seems to lead further down.‚Äù ‚Äã
3:12 PM
You quickly walk over. There‚Äôs a small crack in the cavern wall here, forming a narrow, ice-covered passageway down into some unknown chamber below. You try to trace it through the semitransparent main plug, though the ice isn‚Äôt clear enough to get more than a vague outline. ‚ÄúIt almost seems like it goes into this ice here,‚Äù you note, tapping your foot on the floor for emphasis. ‚ÄúHow does that make sense?‚Äù ‚ÄúIt doesn‚Äôt. This passage goes through the rock and would have been carved well before the ice plug froze here. You‚Äôre probably seeing it winding along the edge of the plug.‚Äù ‚ÄúHmm...‚Äù You lean a little closer, trying to see better inside. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs just this first bend; if I could see past that, I could...‚Äù You grab onto a wedge of ice from the fissure‚Äôs edge, holding onto it as you lean further into the fissure. Still just a little out of sight. ‚ÄúCareful,‚Äù Erich warns. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs not stable-‚Äù With a sudden snap, the ice you‚Äôre holding gives way. You scream for an instant as - unable to get any grip on the icy walls that almost resemble a slide from this angle - you topple into the passage. But then you‚Äôre falling backwards and hit the ground on top of something softer and warmer than ice. It only takes you a moment to work out what happened, heart pounding from the near miss. ‚ÄúAre you okay?‚Äù Erich asks, muffled from somewhere beneath you. He managed to pull you back just in time, causing you both to fall over on the slick ice. Or, well, him onto the ice and you onto him. He‚Äôs still gripping you tightly for a moment before relaxing as you respond. ‚ÄúF-fine,‚Äù you manage, disentangling yourself into a sitting position. ‚Äú... And you?‚Äù ‚ÄúNo issues,‚Äù he grunts, sitting up and rubbing the back of his head. ‚ÄúJust glad I was fast enough.‚Äù A few more seconds to catch your breath. ‚Äú... Thanks. 3:12 PM
‚Äú... Yeah.‚Äù You feel up to the task of standing again and help Erich up as well. ‚ÄúMaybe we should go back.‚Äù ‚ÄúThat sounds smart.‚Äù A pause. ‚ÄúIt... it was this way, right?‚Äù ‚Äú... This way almost certainly leads into the main cavern network, and though you could maybe stumble upon a farm or elevator down there, it would be treacherous and you‚Äôre in no mood to risk any more injury than you already have. So instead, you go the other way and are able to find your way back out with only a few backtracks and turnarounds. The light helps, once you get close enough for it to reflect again, as does the sound echoing from the outside. But mostly, it‚Äôs just the elevation. You were going up to get there, so you‚Äôre going down to get out. But not too far down. ... It‚Äôs harder than you‚Äôd prefer, but at least you don‚Äôt get lost in the caves for too long. When you finally do emerge back onto the Endle River, the sun is already high overhead and the morning‚Äôs snow has stopped. It‚Äôs bright, even though the mist. And not understanding that we put in a lot of work for their benefit, even though it might look like all we do is lounge around until it‚Äôs time to fight the darkness? Those workers?‚Äù ‚Äú... 8:27 PM
‚Äú... No.‚Äù He‚Äôs right; they were being rude first. You start to doubt yourself; were you really just letting a poor first impression color your thoughts of Erich for years? Is he actually just completely reasonable, if a little driven and occasionally grumpy? Were you even misreading his ‚Äúobvious‚Äù disdain for Serri? ‚ÄúJessamine, it‚Äôs getting somewhat late,‚Äù Erich says, changing the subject. You have been quiet for a while, just thinking. How long? ‚ÄúWhy don‚Äôt we dry off, get some food, and then go searching for anything out of place in the sixth district?‚Äù ‚ÄúEr, y-yeah.‚Äù That‚Äôs right; you were going corruption-hunting later. ‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù you repeat, more sure of yourself. You can handle this sort of investigation much more readily than nebulous questions about social hierarchy. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know if I want to find something or not, though.‚Äù ‚ÄúHmm... Mxblah 6/28/2024 8:38 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 129 ... ‚ÄúIn this neighborhood? Really?‚Äù You glare at him briefly. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs wrong with this neighborhood?‚Äù ‚ÄúNothing! It‚Äôs quite peaceful, in fact!‚Äù ‚ÄúMmmm... You‚Äôre careful to stay away from your actual house (how would you explain this to your parents, for one?), but since both prior incidents happened at home or nearby, you‚Äôre searching in the same general area. Hence his comments about where you used to live. It‚Äôs dark already and getting colder by the minute; you‚Äôll be fine for heat a while longer, but you still really hate the dark. The fog is much worse tonight than on Endle Day, making it near-impossible to see even to the end of the block. And you‚Äôre not sure if the occasional shivers are from anxiety, the temperature, or... something else. ‚ÄúI need to switch to Soul,‚Äù you decide, stepping backwards into the pool of light cast by a lonely streetlamp. Its glow forms a halo in the mist. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt see anything focused on Body like this.‚Äù ‚ÄúGo ahead, but make sure you cover up in case we come across anyone.‚Äù ‚ÄúMm hmm.‚Äù You pull up your scarf, get confirmation from Erich, and let your disguise drop with some measure of relief. 8:39 PM

Eventually, you decide to return to the station. But very suddenly, only a block further than you‚Äôd been searching previously, you feel something. A chill on your Soul instead of your Body. No. I, er, don‚Äôt think so, at least.‚Äù He stands up. ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs go take a closer look.‚Äù You stand there in surprise for a few seconds as Erich confidently walks into the mist, then rush after him, afraid to be left alone in the darkness. ‚ÄúThis is not a good idea,‚Äù you whisper, using your Soul sense to guide the two of you towards whatever it is anyway. ‚ÄúThis is a bad idea, in fact.‚Äù ‚ÄúTell me if it notices us or gets stronger. I can‚Äôt even feel it yet, so I‚Äôm not concerned.‚Äù ‚ÄúY-you can‚Äôt?‚Äù ‚ÄúYour Soul must be more sensitive than you thought. But that means whatever we‚Äôre approaching is weak. 8:39 PM

He looks to be much younger than you - maybe around seven? - and seems nervous, glancing over to the kitchen every few seconds. Assorted minor burns and cuts are visible on her arms above a pair of thick work gloves. You can hear the occasional thock of a knife striking a cutting board; the kid flinches every so often. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs... that‚Äôs what the gloved people on Endle Day looked like!‚Äù you hiss, somehow deciding to focus on that instead of anything else going on. ‚ÄúSame sort of outfit!‚Äù Erich mostly ignores you, scanning the room with his Soul sight. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs definitely corrupted, but I think he‚Äôs okay for now.‚Äù A pause; he considers the darkened rooms. ‚Äú... 2:20 PM

Mxblah 7/2/2024 8:17 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 131 You run forward. She‚Äôs not even looking. You‚Äôre fast. It‚Äôll be fine; you‚Äôll be okay. Erich sidesteps on the counter, feinting with the baking sheet to keep her attention. You focus through the fear, bringing your Mental connection with the woman to the front of your Mind. Wrap your hands around one arm, using your Angelic strength to hold her back as she starts to turn to face you. Focus; connect. Purge. At last, you feel something. And the very instant that connection forms, you dump an enormous amount of your Soul energy into the spell. There‚Äôs a sudden flare of light, a blast of heat like you just opened an oven, and a raw-throated scream that cuts off as quickly as it begins. The woman collapses, skin steaming from your power. Did you overdo it? ‚ÄúIs-is she-‚Äù Something oily-dark emerges from the woman‚Äôs chest as if clambering out of a deep pit. You take several steps back, wide-eyed, as the thing unfurls to its full height. Its head brushes the ceiling. The lost Soul is humanoid, but absolutely not human. Its mostly-opaque form is distended, with its torso and limbs shrunken to put more focus on its swollen, bruised head. Bulging like an overripe fruit. Its neck twists a dozen times like a screw, folds of ghostly flesh twitching as it moves. Its eyes are glassy white and leaking a dull silvery liquid that evaporates as soon as it touches the floor. The monster reaches towards you and lets out a rattling exhale, dribbling dots of the same liquid onto the floor. Then, as its non-eyes swivel to track you, the exhale transitions to a moan, then a ghastly howl. It takes a step towards you, then speeds up. You scream. ‚ÄúERICH!‚Äù ‚Äã
8:17 PM
You can‚Äôt see him behind the monster. It‚Äôs slightly translucent, but in the moment all you can make out is his glow somewhere behind. There‚Äôs a crash as a baking sheet flies harmlessly through the thing‚Äôs head, briefly distorting its shape, then a crackling ZAP as Erich shoves his hands into its back. The Soul stumbles forward several steps, screeching, but it isn‚Äôt dead (re-dead?). And now it‚Äôs upon you. Utter, bone-numbing cold engulfs you as the thing latches onto your shoulders, burning away from its back but salivating and gnashing its horrid, wilted teeth in your face. Its hands steam as your aura burns them, but it‚Äôs devouring your energy so... quickly... Erich yells something from behind the creature, but you‚Äôre too dizzy to understand him. It feels like you‚Äôre underwater, watching the surface slowly recede into a long, dark tunnel. Weakly, you raise your hands and try to pry the thing off. Its wrists burn at your touch, but it just digs into your shoulders more painfully, pressing clawlike digits in like numbing icicles. You... just don‚Äôt have the energy left. Another flare of light pulses behind the thing; its head swells and strains, about to burst, but... not... quite. Instead, part of the flare burns along the Soul‚Äôs arms and hands, pushing into your Body and adding a contradictory fiery pain to the horrible cold already present. Its claws pierce deeper, moving towards your neck... But that light brings you to your senses, dispelling some of the numbing cold. You realize you‚Äôre lying on the floor, half-restrained by the ghostly figure. Erich is behind it, by your legs, pushing even more energy into its shoulder blades. The Soul is half burned away by now, with its legs completely gone and torso nearly so; all that remains is the bulging head and the arms pinning you down. You raise your hands, trembling with exertion. Grab hold of the thing‚Äôs rotten nose and face. And release what remains of your Soul energy into its head. ‚Äã
8:18 PM
The thing explodes. A moment later, it‚Äôs over. You‚Äôre covered in dots of black, tar-like goop. The lost Soul is gone, dispersed into fragments by your power and returned to wherever it is that Souls go when they disappear. With your permission, he pulls your sweater aside a little to reveal streaks of dull, cold grey on your shoulder. Little pinpricks of blood are welling out of the grey skin, staining your sleeve. Neither of you know enough about the injury to tell if that‚Äôs seriously bad or just regular bad. You start to get dizzy again, so you reluctantly lie down as Erich checks on the woman and the kid emerges from his blanket again. Focus on your breathing. Don‚Äôt pass out. Don‚Äôt throw up. You are an Angel. You heal really quickly. Just a few minutes and you‚Äôll be okay. You hear the woman wake up and Erich explaining what happened. The kid‚Äôs relieved sobbing that his mom is okay again. God, you wish you could participate in the conversation. Erich looks in the bedroom. You open your eyes and, with a massive effort, manage to sit up under your own power. Your shoulders ache with dull, frigid pain and your arms and hands tingle, but you can move and the dizziness has gone away again. Mostly. ‚Äã
8:18 PM
Erich notices you sitting up. ‚ÄúExcuse me,‚Äù he tells the woman, hurrying over to make sure you don‚Äôt fall back down. ‚ÄúJessamine, please be careful. 12:20 PM
‚ÄúWell, Yara told me a while ago that shades can have gold or silver eyes, and those shades are the ones that are the oldest and strongest. But I don‚Äôt know if lost Souls work the same way, since... I don‚Äôt think we could have beat a really strong one.‚Äù ‚ÄúThis may be a little too pedantic, but I believe the Soul‚Äôs eyes were white. It was crying silver, but its eyes were not silver.‚Äù ‚ÄúAh! I think...‚Äù You try to remember, but the main feature seared into your Mind is its teeth. ‚ÄúI think you‚Äôre right. I wonder how it‚Äôs - Erich, the liquid!‚Äù It‚Äôs gone, and with it, so too is the corruption. Some lingers in the air like a bad smell, but the overwhelming hatred has disappeared. You can breathe more easily again, and the twist in your stomach you hadn‚Äôt even realized was there is now actually gone. Now you can really focus on how much your arms hurt! ‚ÄúFaded away. What was it?‚Äù You hurry over to the bed, despite his protests, and take a look. ‚ÄúNothing here. It doesn‚Äôt even look wet, see?‚Äù You brush your hand across the blankets right where it had been. ‚ÄúNothi... oh... oh no-‚Äù ‚ÄúJessamine?‚Äù ‚ÄúOh that was so stupid. Hold on.‚Äù You stumble away from the bed and sit down against the wall, churning with acute nausea. Your hand feels like it‚Äôs immersed in boiling water. Or freezing? ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs happened? I told you to stay away from it!‚Äù He kneels beside you, but there‚Äôs not much he can do. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs-‚Äù You hold a shallow breath, desperately not wanting to throw up on Erich. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs some - something left.‚Äù A pause. Your hand is turning grey and little pinpricks of blood are welling out, just like your shoulders. At least the nausea is receding. ‚ÄúOhhh, why did I do thaaat?‚Äù Erich doesn‚Äôt have any answers for you. ‚ÄúJessamine, please be more careful. That‚Äôs twice in one day.‚Äù ‚Äã
12:20 PM
‚ÄúTw-twice? Oh, the cave.‚Äù You close your eyes and lean back against the wall. Blood is dripping onto the floor. You don‚Äôt need all of it, right? ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know what‚Äôs wrong with me today. I‚Äôm never like this.‚Äù He doesn‚Äôt have any answers to that either. It only takes another minute or so before you feel strong enough to stand up and leave the bedroom. You tell the woman that whatever was in there isn‚Äôt anymore, but she definitely shouldn‚Äôt go in until a full Angel has cleared it. She seems to think you‚Äôve destroyed it, given the new injury on your hand, and you don‚Äôt explain how you really got hurt. It‚Äôs probably better that way. Certainly less embarrassing. Finally, the requested full Angel shows up. Neither of you know him, but from your brief interactions he seems pretty laid-back. He clears out the bedroom, informing the woman that he‚Äôs going to have to destroy the bedding but the rest is now clean, tends to everyone‚Äôs wounds, and even stops the bleeding from your grey skin. Apparently the grey itself will go away on its own overnight as your Body recovers its connection to your Mind. Yes, it seems that‚Äôs what happened: portions of your Body were forcibly ripped away from your Mind, leaving them confused, directionless, and dying. That‚Äôs probably fine. ‚Äã
12:20 PM
And at last, well into the night, you make it onto a train (private, now that you‚Äôre on official Angel business) back to the Cathedra. The full Angel stayed behind to destroy the bedding as promised, do a last sweep, and work with the constables, so it‚Äôs just you and Erich alone in the fancy train car. Well, you, Erich, and your thoughts. - You feel generally positive about the day. - You feel generally negative about the day. - Erich is a pretty good guy. - Erich is not a pretty good guy. - Explain your idea about the liquid to an authority, like Cobb or a bishop. - Tell your friends, but that‚Äôs it. Mxblah 7/6/2024 7:21 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 133 You don‚Äôt talk much on the way back; both of you are exhausted and have plenty to think about on your own. But towards the end of the journey, when the train starts slowing down to navigate the tighter turns near downtown, Erich eventually speaks. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm glad we actually found something, despite... everything that happened.‚Äù It almost seems like he‚Äôs about to continue, but he doesn‚Äôt. ‚Äú... Even though it was maybe a little harder than expected.‚Äù ‚ÄúConcerns for the future, I suppose.‚Äù ‚Äú...‚Äù A longer pause. ‚ÄúI think I know what the liquid is.‚Äù ‚ÄúReally?‚Äù ‚ÄúWell, it‚Äôs a guess. How do they keep showing up? Maybe because they were being spawned from little pools like that one in the bedroom?‚Äù Erich considers this idea. ‚ÄúLost Souls aren‚Äôt spawned from pools. 7:21 PM

Right now, Angels can prevent all but the craftiest shades from getting into Nucarreo, but if new corruption can simply appear inside the walls... it would very quickly become impossible to manage. Angels usually aren‚Äôt capable of detecting corruption from very far away - Erich had to be on the same block to sense the Soul tonight, for example - so entire districts could become infested without anyone even noticing. Such as, for an anxiety-inducing example, the sixth. But what can you do about it? You can‚Äôt even touch the stuff without your hand just about falling off (it‚Äôs still achey and tingly, but at least that‚Äôs it) - let alone figure out how to destroy it or prevent it from entering at all! You just don‚Äôt know enough. No one does. Your dreams tonight are certainly going to be intense. ... There‚Äôs a silent, intimidating man in a bishop‚Äôs coat standing in the corner; you start to wonder if you‚Äôre in trouble. ‚Äã
7:22 PM
As it turns out, you kind of are, but it‚Äôs not that bad. You‚Äôre both chastised for risking your lives by hunting down corruption you aren‚Äôt ready for, but after a little bit of not-quite-lying about how much was your idea to go hunting and how much was just spotting someone in danger and trying to help them, there‚Äôs not much they can actually berate you about. You manage to get out of the room with only a warning to be more careful next time and to call for backup if at all possible. But you aren‚Äôt about to leave without telling someone more important than you about your spawning pool idea. Cobb and the bishop listen without interruption as you detail the evidence - Erich backs you up as well, even though he was just doubting you half an hour ago. Fortunately (or unfortunately?) Cobb and the bishop seem to take your report seriously. That‚Äôs good, since someone will probably do something about it, but very bad because that means there‚Äôs a chance you might actually be right. After all that, you part ways with Erich for the first time since the morning, clean up as best you can (your outfit is totally covered in that tarry goop from the Soul; you don‚Äôt have much hope for it, but maybe the laundry service can work a miracle) and finally crawl into bed... to lie there staring at the ceiling instead of sleeping. You‚Äôve gotten pretty familiar with the ceiling by now, after all these sleepless nights. It‚Äôs not as pure white as you might think; there‚Äôs texture to see if you know where to look. Hm, that almost sounds like you‚Äôre making some metaphorical statement about Angels or the Cathedra, but really you were just remarking on the ceiling. Promise. ‚Äã
7:22 PM
The obvious topic to think about is what it will mean for the city if spawning pools can in fact form within Nucarreo, but you really don‚Äôt want to ponder that right now. Instead, you distract yourself by wondering about your own behavior. You were, to be honest, a little airheaded today. Falling down that icy passage and touching the corrupted blankets were just the standout examples; you also had trouble holding back improper questions, you were weird on the train, and you had some unusual thoughts about Angels and humanity. It‚Äôs like you were distracted the whole day. And, well, you were. You were nervous about the whole ‚Äúis this a date?‚Äù thing before the lost Soul appeared, and obviously you were distracted by it after it did. In fact, that date question never got an answer. You didn‚Äôt ask him and it‚Äôs not like there was actual evidence one way or the other. Him acting weird on the train doesn‚Äôt really count; after all, you did that too! ... He‚Äôs not nearly as annoying as you had thought and you did have fun today (at least until the lost Soul incident, which kind of overshadowed everything before). But... like like...? Back under the blankets; you flip over and squeeze the pillow as you consider the idea. But... no; you‚Äôre smarter than this. You‚Äôre way too confused, exhausted, and emotionally drained right now to come to any reasonable conclusion. You emphatically decide to think no more of this tonight. Instead, you will go to sleep. ‚Äú...‚Äù Yeah, it‚Äôs great to say that (think that), but... It sure would be great if there were a spell that could just knock you out. Maybe there is. 7:22 PM

@Story Notifications Scene 136 ‚Äú...‚Äù You take a few moments to think about it, but really the answer seems obvious. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôd reveal... why they‚Äôre targeting Naoriel.‚Äù ‚ÄúGood. I know it‚Äôs a little ruthless, but... c-could you just...‚Äù Trying to get the words ‚Äúkill them?‚Äù out is difficult; even for someone like that, to purposefully kill anyone, let alone an Angel... Luckily, Mr Fisher seems to understand. ‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre referring to killing the betrayer, that‚Äôs unlikely to work either. My Inquisitors could likely do so, but only if pushed into a battle. If the betrayer simply surrenders, we wouldn‚Äôt be able to attack. And even if a fight does break out and they are killed, they‚Äôre an Angel. They have a Second Chance. Only if they then attempt to fight again could we potentially finish the job, as it were. Too unlikely to work, even if everything goes well.‚Äù ‚Äú...‚Äù Secretly, you‚Äôre a little relieved. Angels fighting Angels shouldn‚Äôt happen (at least, not outside of training). Not since Erejil. ‚ÄúSo... if that won‚Äôt work, and arresting them won‚Äôt either, and we can‚Äôt just leave them like this...?‚Äù ‚ÄúYou see the problem. There are of course other ways, such as poisoning, ambushes, traps, or sabotage in the wastes, but we aren‚Äôt assassins. There are limits to how far our methods can - or should - go. At the end of the day, it seems likely that the betrayer will have time to say what they intend to say after their arrest. I can‚Äôt see another plausible path.‚Äù ‚Äú... So it‚Äôs hopeless?‚Äù ‚Äã
8:55 PM
You must look really sad, because the prime continues quickly. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not simply sitting here. It may be possible to convince the betrayer to stay quiet once captured, or even to arrange a deal to cease her attacks. Trying to make contact is a delicate matter, of course, but certainly possible for us. So just give us a little more time to work; you might be surprised at how things turn out.‚Äù ‚Äú...Her?‚Äù ‚Äú...‚Äù Mr Fisher winces. ‚ÄúHell. Ah, Naoriel will be pleased with you. I assume you already have a list of some sort, and I‚Äôve just cut it in half?‚Äù ‚ÄúM-more than half,‚Äù you admit. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre... er, down to... two, now.‚Äù Three of the remaining five Archangels had been male. The only two left now are Aveline and an Archangel you don‚Äôt know named Kamiya. ‚ÄúTwo?‚Äù the prime exclaims, standing up with a start. You jolt in your chair. ‚ÄúOut of the entire Cathedra?‚Äù You nod nervously. ‚ÄúHow did you-‚Äù A pause. ‚ÄúWho are the two?‚Äù You show him the list. ‚ÄúNow, you know I can‚Äôt confirm or deny your selection. But how did you narrow this down?‚Äù ‚ÄúW-well, they needed to be an Archangel or Seraph because of the powerful magic from the last attack... and some of them had alibis... and then we tried to find out who could or couldn‚Äôt have cast the spells we saw... and... er, that‚Äôs... about it. U-until you, er, said... ‚Äòher.‚Äô‚Äù ‚Äú...‚Äù You stay quiet too. You don‚Äôt know what to say. ‚ÄúYou two must have been busy. Perhaps too busy for your own good. Magical proficiency is not directly tied to rank, even though Archangels tend to be more experienced.‚Äù ‚Äã
8:55 PM
‚ÄúErm... It, er, we... did a lot of reading. A-about tournaments and that sort of thing, and... I figured that, to handle all the spells at once during the last attack would have needed-‚Äù You quickly count them up again. ‚Äú-er, four different spells at the same time. For the disguise, the illusion of the other Angel, causing the rock to fall, and f-flying away. And the number of transmutation d-domains they must know to do all that and the other attacks...‚Äù You‚Äôre getting really nervous with how intense his gaze is getting; it‚Äôs getting hard not to just trail off. ‚Äú... there‚Äôs... never been any non-Archangel who‚Äôs been recorded d-doing all that.‚Äù ‚ÄúYou may have missed your Calling,‚Äù Mr Fisher says flatly. ‚ÄúYou could have been a detective. Mxblah 7/14/2024 2:10 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 137 Unfortunately, you don‚Äôt have much of a plan to share. The original idea had always been to just find the betrayer and then everything would be fine. After all, what they‚Äôre doing is terrible and illegal; they would be arrested and that would be that. But, when you really think about it, this problem had been there from the start. If the betrayer is targeting Naoriel because they know her secret, then if anything happens, they can always just reveal it. In fact, the only reason she‚Äôs still here right now is that the betrayer simply hasn‚Äôt done so yet. You feel so helpless. ‚ÄúI... don‚Äôt know. There‚Äôs no good option.‚Äù ‚ÄúI see.‚Äù You think he sounds disappointed, though his expression hasn‚Äôt changed. ‚ÄúThen please, just stay out of this. Let me handle it.‚Äù ‚Äú...‚Äù He doesn‚Äôt have much of a plan either; he admitted that just a minute ago. But, if you don‚Äôt have any better ideas... ‚ÄúOkay...‚Äù ‚ÄúGood. Then, is there anything else?‚Äù There isn‚Äôt. You‚Äôre ushered out of his office; one of the Inquisitors standing outside enters as you leave. Presumably to hear the prime‚Äôs account of what you discussed, though obviously he‚Äôll be redacting some details. You assume. So, back to Naoriel. But as you walk, you start to wonder. Mr Fisher is the head of Inquisition. He‚Äôs experienced with interrogations and he leads probably the most powerful group within the Cathedra. Would a man like that really have accidentally let slip the betrayer‚Äôs gender? Or did he do it on purpose? Was it a lie, just to mislead you? Is the betrayer actually a man, like their disguises have been? Or was it the truth, and he was giving you real information for some reason? Why? ‚Äã
2:10 PM
Well, there‚Äôs really only two cases: truth or lie (discounting the possibilities that he actually just slipped up or doesn‚Äôt know, for now). If you assume he was telling the truth, then he must have wanted you to have that information. And that means he must want you to find the betrayer. And... do what? You don‚Äôt have a plan either! No one was listening, so if he wanted you to do something, he could have just told you directly! Maybe it‚Äôs a plausible deniability kind of thing, where if you get arrested, at least he didn‚Äôt directly tell you? But if Naoriel is revealed as a half-Angel, Mr Fisher is definitely going to be arrested too, no matter what you say. So that doesn‚Äôt make sense either! But if he was lying... you can think of at least one reason to do that: to stop you from finding the betrayer and putting yourself or Naoriel in even more danger. You can see the rationale from his point of view, but you‚Äôre already in danger just from the betrayer being around. How much worse would it be if you knew who they were? If you did something about it? But what could you even do? That doesn‚Äôt really make sense... does it? Ugh; all these motivations and possibilities whirl around in your Mind. None of them seem to make sense, though some are more nonsensical than others. Maybe Naoriel has some ideas. ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs change her memories.‚Äù Well, that‚Äôs not what you were expecting. ‚ÄúChange... memories?‚Äù ‚ÄúThe problem is that, if we arrest her, she‚Äôs going to tell them everything. But let‚Äôs go step by step. One: Mind magic can change someone‚Äôs memories. Yes or no?‚Äù ‚Äú... Yes. But only through-‚Äù ‚ÄúHold on; just yes or no for now! Two: you know how to do that. Yes or no?‚Äù ‚ÄúNo!‚Äù ‚ÄúRight. So three: memory erasure is easier to do.‚Äù ‚Äú... Yes.‚Äù ‚Äã
2:10 PM
‚ÄúBut, four: it‚Äôs more obvious and would be a lot more suspicious.‚Äù ‚ÄúYeah.‚Äù ‚ÄúFive: we definitely wouldn‚Äôt be able to do that by attacking directly.‚Äù ‚ÄúYes! Er, no? That - that‚Äôs right.‚Äù ‚ÄúSo, six: if we know who the betrayer is and can recruit someone with good Mind magic, we can change her memories sneakily, and then it‚Äôd be fine to arrest her!‚Äù ‚Äú... That‚Äôs a lot of ‚Äòifs.‚Äô Plus, it sounds kind of... unethical?‚Äù ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs trying to kill me! And my dad!‚Äù ‚ÄúY-yeah, that‚Äôs right. And it‚Äôs transmutation, so there‚Äôs no way I could do it anytime soon. Even erasure - which is projection, so I could maybe learn it in a year or two - is really hard and has the same problems.‚Äù ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs why we figure out who she is and, I don‚Äôt know, sneak in while she‚Äôs sleeping.‚Äù ‚Äú... You were uncomfortable enough with just Mind reading, and that- Oh. 2:10 PM

Mxblah 7/22/2024 6:59 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 138 Well, every plan always has at least one alternative, and that‚Äôs procrastination. As days and then weeks go by, you get less confident and more worried as additional details come up. You continue to work with Noll on how to detect meddlers in your Mind - both for actual reasons and to find out how to hide if you yourself are the meddler - and are concerned that it really does seem easy unless you‚Äôre up against a true master of subtlety. When you‚Äôre reading someone else‚Äôs Mind, your Soul (attuned to Mind) is touching it. That‚Äôs how magic works, of course. That‚Äôs fine if you‚Äôre trying to hide from ordinary humans, because they usually can‚Äôt sense Souls at all, but for an Angel to miss such a direct touch would be implausible. This concept is one of the main reasons why everyone‚Äôs so sure you weren‚Äôt possessed by a lost Soul that one time, and why you think the Mind manipulation then was due to corruption exposure instead. If the Angel isn‚Äôt attuned to Soul or Mind, it‚Äôs harder for them to notice - especially with your Soul in the Mind aspect instead of its native one - but it‚Äôs still pretty obvious as your thoughts inevitably mix to some small degree with the ones you‚Äôre trying to read. This isn‚Äôt usually an issue if you‚Äôre doing this consensually, as you can filter out your own thoughts near-unconsciously after some practice, but it‚Äôs a big problem for being sneaky. ‚Äã
6:59 PM
The best literature on this practice still isn‚Äôt very good, as the need for Angels to hide from Angels is usually nonexistent, but there have been some studies for various purposes - usually relating to detecting shades that can use magic. And those studies tend to say that you should try to attune your thoughts to the target as best you can, so they feel more similar and are easier to pass as the target‚Äôs own. Which kind of leads back to the first problem you ran into way back at the start: it‚Äôs much easier to use Mind magic on someone if you know them well. And although you interact with Aveline on a somewhat frequent basis, you wouldn‚Äôt say you know her well. Not to mention you‚Äôve never even seen Kamiya. Anyway, the point is that you probably won‚Äôt be able to pull off even the Mind reading, let alone the Mind manipulation that‚Äôs your current best (still very bad) plan to deal with this whole situation. So, uneasily, you just kind of don‚Äôt do anything. It‚Äôs not giving up; you‚Äôre just waiting for a better chance. When? ...Sometime. Probably. You feel bad not being able to help, but at least Naoriel agrees that it would be a really bad idea to go for it without being extremely, fully confident in success. If you choose the wrong person and get detected, you‚Äôll get in big trouble. But if you choose the right person and get detected... So, yeah. Instead, you start to focus on preparing for your third year practical. Not that there‚Äôs all that much to prepare, really. You don‚Äôt have to demonstrate anything or take a test or whatever; you‚Äôre simply assumed to be ready for this by now. And you sort of feel like you are? After destroying that lost Soul with Erich, you‚Äôve felt more confident in yourself (at least in some ways). Despite the horror, you did it. And you‚Äôll always be better prepared now (and in the future) than you were then. ‚Äã
6:59 PM
No, the main things are just the paperwork (mostly not your problem), packing (basically just a few copies of your uniform), and getting ready for appearing in public without a disguise. Yes, you‚Äôll be working in your official capacity for the practical, so you get to keep your true Angelic appearance. It‚Äôs not the first time you‚Äôve been outside the Cathedra like that, but it‚Äôll certainly be the longest and most public. You‚Äôre told that the hosting constabulary gets to choose what you‚Äôll be working on, though you (as an Angel) have as much authority as you want to veto whatever they want you to do. The administrative person working with you on this cautions you against using that veto too often - the constables don‚Äôt really like being ordered around by a 14 year old girl - but if you feel uncomfortable or anything, to just say no. You ask what sort of things they might have you do, and receive a fairly generic answer. ‚ÄúBasically whatever isn‚Äôt likely to get you hurt‚Äù seems to be the gist of it, varying from normal patrols or handling lesser offenses to helping track corruption or investigate the aftermath of such an attack. It does seem more likely that you‚Äôll be dealing with corruption and adjacent activities, for hopefully obvious reasons, but it seems very possible you‚Äôll be issuing someone a citation for parking a carriage in the wrong spot. The image of that strikes you as incredibly funny, but probably not for the person receiving the ticket. One other change from prior outings is that you‚Äôll be on your own this time. Not completely - you‚Äôll be surrounded by constables during the day - but there won‚Äôt be any other Angels around unless they‚Äôre called out to deal with corruption in your constabulary‚Äôs district. Well, you‚Äôve been alone before. You‚Äôll be fine. ‚Äã
6:59 PM
But what you haven‚Äôt done before is live on your own. It‚Äôll only be for a few weeks, but you won‚Äôt be living at the Cathedra, your parents‚Äô house, or in the constabulary (there‚Äôs nowhere to sleep there, unless you want to live in a jail cell). Instead, you‚Äôll get a nearby apartment and be expected to basically just take care of yourself before reporting to work in the morning and after leaving at night. Which apparently means there‚Äôs absolutely nothing to stop you from going out into the city during the evenings aside from being told not to unless you‚Äôre disguised. Which is fine; you can do that. What you‚Äôd do in the city at night is another matter; maybe you should just stay in the apartment. You‚Äôre certainly fairly capable and far stronger than you look, but the idea of getting into trouble and having to fight someone or reveal your Angelic appearance sounds like a very bad one. It would probably be fine. The streets are pretty safe. Mostly, likely. There‚Äôs always the risk. Still, it‚Äôs something you‚Äôve never had the chance to do before, and probably won‚Äôt have the chance again until you graduate. How daring are you feeling? - Yes, very. Go out at night; see some things! - Nope, not very much at all. Stay in at night; be safe. (Winner: ) (edited)

Mxblah 7/24/2024 9:57 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 139 Pretty daring, as it turns out. You‚Äôve grown a lot over the past two-and-a-bit years. Time moves quickly and before long it‚Äôs the first day of the practical. You‚Äôre taken directly to the constabulary while some porter or monk or whatever takes your stuff to the apartment. And then, you spend the day learning about the wonders of paperwork. It seems the constables are almost married to the stuff; everything needs a report or a form or at least a memo. Your first task is correlation. You‚Äôre given a stack of incident reports and a mentor constable experienced in this sort of thing, then asked to find patterns. Are these incidents actually related? If so, how? The same perpetrator? Locations? Victims? Is the corruption involved? How much effort should we put into investigating? What additional data would be helpful, if you can‚Äôt decide based on what you currently have? That sort of thing. It‚Äôs not boring work - at least, not in your opinion - you find yourself getting pretty absorbed in maps and charts and lists upon lists upon lists. In the latter half of the day, you draw a few conclusions and point out a few estimates for where might be good locations to survey for more information, and that‚Äôs that. Someone, presumably, will be dispatched to investigate your hunches. Maybe even you! But not today. You didn‚Äôt really talk to many constables outside of the captain and the mentor he assigned you, but your location near the middle of the open office led to you overhearing a lot of conversations. There‚Äôs a lot more going on every day than you thought, and so many more incidents than Angels hear about. Most of it is mundane, everyday stuff like parking violations, event planning, disorder complaints, and the like, but not all. Constables are really busy. It‚Äôs no wonder the precinct offices are so huge; with all the stuff that happens in the district every day, it‚Äôs more of a wonder why they aren‚Äôt huge-r! ‚Äã
9:57 PM
After your shift is over, you‚Äôre allowed to leave the building with your true appearance. It‚Äôd be tough to hide given that you‚Äôre wearing an Angel uniform anyway. But you‚Äôre not alone yet, and probably for good reason. A small group of constables shields you from prying eyes as you quickly head to the apartment building while people on the street watch. Or, in some cases, beg. ‚Äú-Miss Angel, Bless my husband! PLEASE! PLEASE-‚Äù ‚Äú-just a moment of youR TIME WAIT-‚Äù ‚Äú-are we going to do, Miss Angel, about the-‚Äù ‚Äú-need your help to-‚Äù ‚Äú...‚Äù That last man just stares at you pitifully, unable to speak. He has no lips or teeth. You... try not to think about how that could have happened. You can‚Äôt help him anyway. And then you‚Äôre delivered safely into the building, the gate and door shut firmly behind you, and the group of constables return to the precinct office. You can still hear the clamor from outside, but not for long. People give up and leave. Those incident reports don‚Äôt seem quite so fun anymore. You try to shake it off by exploring your apartment. It‚Äôs a complex of several rooms on the seventh floor of a newly constructed brick building near the district 14 central station. The height would be impressive if you weren‚Äôt used to the Cathedra; it‚Äôs certainly one of the very tallest buildings around. The fourteenth district is situated near the southwest of the city, where the Endle River flows out into the wastes, and is thus a prime spot for industry: waste can just be dumped into the river and it flows right out, never to be seen again! Anyway, the point is that, with all the factories and such, the district is typically dirty, sprawling, and not all that wealthy. So having a skyscraper here is a little weird; you suppose maybe it‚Äôs mostly for visitors from other districts. Maybe that‚Äôs why it‚Äôs so close to the station. ‚Äã
9:58 PM
The apartment itself certainly impresses you more than the building‚Äôs height. Your room at the Cathedra is well-built and clean, but simple. Humble, almost. This room is definitely not that. Glass and polished stone and beautiful wooden accents against the brick make it feel more like you‚Äôre a visiting factory owner than your actual self... though, if you think about it, you‚Äôre probably more important than any such owner. Why shouldn‚Äôt you get to try some luxury every so often? It‚Äôs just a break from your normal room anyway; it‚Äôs not like you‚Äôre going to live here permanently. ... The bathtub is a hot tub. ... You spend a little more time than strictly necessary utilizing that particular discovery, then change into a more normal outfit for your excursion into the city. You still need to find some food tonight or you‚Äôre going to be very hungry tomorrow, and you still intend to go out and experience the city in ways you‚Äôve never been able to before. You‚Äôre just a little nervous about going out after sunset (still hate the dark; that hasn‚Äôt changed in the past few months). But you‚Äôll manage. Okay, disguise on. Check your appearance and your clothes. You‚Äôve learned from your trips with Erich to be more careful matching your outfit to the location, so you aren‚Äôt wearing anything ostentatious today. Just a standard cream dress with some accents, just like any ‚Äúnormal‚Äù young lady might wear. And you mean it this time; it‚Äôs not secretly fancy. You‚Äôve also tried to make yourself look a little older with your disguise, but it doesn‚Äôt seem to have worked very well. You figured maybe that would help you be taken more seriously, but it just looks weird. So you revert it to normal and resolve to put in more practice later; you‚Äôre still bad at visualizing your own appearance well enough to change it like that. ‚Äã
9:58 PM
Okay, ready to - wait. Your hair is too smooth and, well, too pretty to match the plain dress. You ruffle it up a bit, noting as you do so that it‚Äôs gotten pretty long. You used to keep it trimmed a little past your shoulder blades, but since becoming an Angel you just haven‚Äôt cut it; it‚Äôs down to the small of your back by now. Your perfect Body means it simply hasn‚Äôt tangled, or split, or generally been a nuisance, which would be your usual cue to get the scissors out. Hmmm, it‚Äôs going to be tough to mess it up enough to look right. Maybe you should just get a hat? Can you even fit all of it under one? You‚Äôre probably overthinking this. You could just be a normal girl with a really good hair care routine. Perfect; okay, ready to go! But... go where? - Somewhere big! - Somewhere small! ‚ùî - Somewhere random! - Somewhere in another district! (Winner: ) (edited)
