Mxblah 7/26/2024 6:08 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 140 Well, you‚Äôll find out after looking around a bit. You leave through a different entrance, wrap around the building since you‚Äôre kind of curious if any of the crowd from earlier is still there (the toothless guy is, but no one else), and then stride confidently off under the railroad tracks. You figure there‚Äôs probably more shops near stations, and though you could ride the train to the next one, you figure you‚Äôll take the opportunity to look for smaller places along the way. Plus, the tracks have plentiful streetlights on their undersides, so it‚Äôs not really very dark at all down here. It would probably feel pretty dim during the day, but at night it‚Äôs certainly brighter than on many nearby roads. The area is pretty lively at this point in the evening, busy with workers just finishing their shift or just arriving to take over for someone in the former category. You seem to blend in well. Though there aren‚Äôt many girls your age around, there are a number of older teenagers and up - presumably employed somewhere around here, since you haven‚Äôt seen a school nearby. If you act just a little older and a little tireder than you actually are (really would be nice if that disguise alteration had worked), you fit right in. You don‚Äôt really know where to go, so you cheat a little. Using your heightened hearing, you listen in on groups of workers discussing dinner plans until you overhear somewhere that sounds good, then casually change your path to follow them. There‚Äôs still enough people around that you can get away with this without looking weird, and before too long your unwitting guides lead you into a small restaurant built between two of the heavy pillars holding up the railway. You wonder how loud it is when a train goes by. After a moment‚Äôs consideration, you figure you‚Äôre going to find out pretty soon. ... ‚Äã
6:08 PM
Wow, it‚Äôs not as loud as you thought. You can certainly feel it - the building vibrates under heavy wheels - but there must be something incredible in place to reduce the noise to roughly the same level as the general din. Hardly anyone seems to pay it any Mind. In other news, the food is good. Greasy, spicy, a little messy. Not the Cathedra‚Äôs clean, straightforward meals. The conversation is loud. Honestly, the same adjectives could apply to it as well. Certainly not like the Cathedra. And a number of the patrons here seem to be growing only louder as the night progresses. You know of alcohol, of course, and you know that you‚Äôre both too young and too holy to partake. Drunkenness is a sin, though a minor one, and you must maintain your purity. But that doesn‚Äôt mean you can‚Äôt just sit here, watching and listening to the people who aren‚Äôt young or holy. Although, as you scan through the general crowd, you aren‚Äôt the only youngish person around and the staff don‚Äôt seem to pay much attention to who exactly at a table consumes the drinks that are ordered. Perhaps it‚Äôs just your holiness stopping you, not your age. Well, it‚Äôs enough either way. You‚Äôll just observe. There‚Äôs a group of grumbly-sounding gloved men at the bar. You had to do a double take when you saw them come in, since the mystery glove people from the sixth district immediately popped into your Mind, but these men took off their gloves like normal people when they ordered food. Now, they‚Äôre seemingly complaining about something related to the constables. ‚Äã
6:08 PM
A few tables back, nearly at the limit of your hearing in such a crowded environment, there‚Äôs a pair of quiet teen girls, probably only a few years older than you. It‚Äôs tough to catch much of their conversation, since they‚Äôre not yelling and the loud men are, but you think it‚Äôs about working at a mill. And they seem... worried? You briefly wonder what they‚Äôre doing here all on their own, but figure that would make you a hypocrite for doing the same thing. A man smelling faintly of coal smoke and wearing clothes stained with the stuff sits with three fellows, muttering darkly about an incident on the river today. His friends seem sympathetic, but you can tell from your Body attunement that he‚Äôs not just distressed. He was injured today - badly, you think - though his heavy coat hides it. You‚Äôre curious and still have plenty of your (non-alcoholic) drink left as an excuse to linger, but you can only listen to one conversation in detail at a time. Whose? - The men complaining about the constables. ‚Äç - The girls worrying about work. - The man muttering about the river. (Winner: ‚Äç ) (edited)

@Story Notifications Scene 141 Maybe it‚Äôs just their age or that they remind you a little bit of yourself, but you find yourself most curious about the girls‚Äô conversation. Still, it‚Äôs tricky to hear much from all the way over here and it‚Äôs not like you can just move to a different seat; it‚Äôs far too busy for that. So you just do your best to make out their quiet voices through the general din and piece together what they‚Äôre saying. The one on the left - with the straight but choppy black hair and very pale skin - is Mila; you learn that as the other one says her name to get her attention. Unfortunately, this doesn‚Äôt happen the other way around, so you have to keep calling the other one ‚Äúthe other one‚Äù or something like that. 2:21 PM

Mxblah 7/30/2024 9:02 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 142 Well, not much for tonight. But you‚Äôll keep an eye out. It‚Äôs unclear if there is actually anything in this situation you can do anything about - from a constable or Angel‚Äôs perspective - but you‚Äôve been kind of on high alert for weird things after catching those lost Souls in the sixth district. Transferring people to a mystery warehousing job, never to be heard from again, definitely seems like it qualifies as ‚Äúweird.‚Äù But it might just be a normal kind of weird, not corruption or illegal. You‚Äôll have to find out. Later. So you head back to the apartment without incident, take another bath because what else are you going to do with a hot tub in your room, and eventually go to bed. You‚Äôre feeling pretty calm today, so it catches you completely off-guard when you wake up sprawled across the floor of some dark, wooden room, utterly certain that you‚Äôre dreaming. Uneasy, but not as panicked as if you thought this was real, you slowly stand up and look around. The floor is some sort of oddly smooth, oddly uniform stone covered in grit and dust, while the walls are ragged, splintery planks of deep, dark wood. There‚Äôs a door and a window, so you look out the window first. Barren, snowy wastes as far as the eye can see. It‚Äôs clearly night, but there‚Äôs no mist. Stars shine brilliantly overhead, reflecting off a thick carpet of snow that drowns any details of the landscape. Shadows of taller spire-like structures indicate that the building you‚Äôre in is more than just this room and that there‚Äôs a brighter light source behind or above you (the moon?). ‚Äã
9:02 PM
The door collapses at your touch, falling off its hinges and causing a rattling slam to echo through a much larger space. You duck back behind the wall, peering into the darkness to see if anything heard that, but the gloom is near-impenetrable. There aren‚Äôt enough windows; they‚Äôre all placed up high in a slanted roof and only illuminate a tangled mess of girders, cranes, and other industrial detritus suspended far above floor level. Down on the ground, there‚Äôs nothing but blackness. But thankfully, you always have a light. You begin to glow, revealing tangled conveyor lines, ruined machinery, and piles of broken components. A few are recognizable as you inch further into the room. Gears, hinges, fittings. Tiny pipes; wires to conduct heat. But others are less understandable. Strange, green plates with a texture you‚Äôve never before felt. Miniscule barrel-like things with tiny metal legs. Flexible wires, like the pipes from before, but braided together with odd assemblies on each end. You‚Äôre walking through a destroyed factory, but what it once made is beyond you. ‚ÄúWhy am I seeing this?‚Äù you whisper aloud, not really expecting an answer. You certainly don‚Äôt have one. If this dream is from your own Mind, you‚Äôd love to know where you got the ideas for all these weird mechanical components. Maybe you saw them once in your dad‚Äôs work and forgot? But if it‚Äôs not from you- The silver-eyed shade. It‚Äôs here, standing atop a pile of broken metal that may have once been a machine. You‚Äôve just blundered right up to it, unable to see its shadowy form in the total darkness. It looks at you. You‚Äôre not frozen, not like the last two times. Turns its head slightly, just as before. Arms folded. Looking. ‚Äã
9:02 PM
Even though you can, you‚Äôre afraid to move. Like if you do, the thing is going to pounce. Despite your newfound confidence, you‚Äôre still trembling. Somehow, it just seems right that the shade would appear here. Why wouldn‚Äôt it? It haunts your dreams somewhat regularly, especially when they don‚Äôt make sense. Why wouldn‚Äôt it show up here, just to surely do something horrible like try (or succeed!) to kill you again! Why not?! ‚Äú...‚Äù What... is it going to do, actually? It‚Äôs just standing there. Its form slowly shifts, though the contours themselves never change. Menacing, despite its stillness. Or perhaps because of its stillness. Slowly, the shade unfolds one arm. You take a half-step back, ready to react if it does anything aggressive, and it notes that movement with a fleeting glance. But all it does. Is take the arm. And very slowly. Mxblah 8/1/2024 7:24 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 143 Hesitantly, you look behind you. What else is there to do? There‚Äôs nothing there. Well, there‚Äôs plenty there, but nothing has changed. Still just a tangled mess of mechanical debris and ruined machines. Suddenly concerned that you‚Äôve fallen for the oldest trick in the book, you quickly turn back to the shade, but it hasn‚Äôt moved either. ‚Äú...‚Äù What does it...? You pause. Shades can speak, if they want to. Maybe you can simply ask instead of wondering silently in your head. ‚ÄúW-What do you want to show me?‚Äù The shade does not speak, but it does respond. Its silver eyes shift down slightly, and it takes a step on the pile. You match it, retreating another step, but it doesn‚Äôt come after you. Instead, it very conspicuously picks up a damaged mechanical lamp from the mess, holds it up for you to see, and then crushes the bulb in one shadowy hand. Glass shards and powder scatter to the floor. And then it points again; not behind you, but at you. Is that a threat? Is it saying that I‚Äôm like the bulb? Does it want to crush me? But... but it could have just attacked if it wanted to do that, not... whatever this is. The shade points behind you again. Something occurs to you. ‚ÄúDo... do you want me to turn off my light?‚Äù The shade lowers its arm. It‚Äôs still looking at you. ‚Äú...‚Äù You swallow nervously. You can only interpret that as a ‚Äúyes,‚Äù but to disable your glow and leave yourself completely blind in total darkness, with this creature standing right there... You shiver, imagining your brutal death at its hands. But this is a dream. It‚Äôs not real. Even if it feels real... You suppress your glow before you can change your Mind. The light vanishes quickly, as if grateful to return to the total darkness that is natural to this place. And then, because you don‚Äôt know what else to do, you look behind you again. ‚Äã
7:25 PM
It‚Äôs not totally dark. A thick, flexible, transparent tube about the width of your arm hangs behind you. It glows with an extremely faint light, only visible in near-total darkness, that barely reveals the smooth, glassy surface of its shape. The tube disappears up into the jumble of debris above... and below, it sinks into the small of your back. You reach back and touch it, shivering at the eerie warmth. The tube pierces your clothing and skin, embedding itself inside of you. Your Body is hot, almost feverish at the point of contact, but otherwise you don‚Äôt feel it at all. Even the warmth is only noticeable now that you‚Äôre touching it with your hands. How long has this been here? Why is it here? Why did the shade want you to see it? You‚Äôre doing it again. The shade hasn‚Äôt killed you, and by its still-visible silver eyes, you can tell it hasn‚Äôt even moved since you turned off your glow. You don‚Äôt have to wonder; you can just... ‚ÄúWhat is this?‚Äù There‚Äôs so much more you want to ask, now that it seemingly isn‚Äôt going to be attacking, but you figure you‚Äôll start with the obvious question. The shade slowly shakes its head, only visible as its eyes move in the darkness. ‚Äú... Do you not know? Or do-‚Äù Another rejection, before you can even get to the second part of your question. You hesitate for a moment, struggling to figure it out. ‚ÄúYou can understand me.‚Äù A statement, but you want to know how it agrees with you. If it does. The eyes shift up and down, as if nodding. ‚ÄúBut you can‚Äôt speak?‚Äù Another nod. ‚ÄúBut...‚Äù Now you arrive at the problem. ‚ÄúShades can speak. Your kind can negotiate with us. At least, the ones with Minds. And, er, it seems... like... you, er, do.‚Äù Nod. ‚Äú...‚Äù It can speak, but it can‚Äôt? Ah! ‚ÄúThe tube. Is this... interfering in some way?‚Äù Nod. ‚ÄúCan I take it out?‚Äù Nod. ‚Äú... What happens if I do?‚Äù No answer. It just looks at you. ‚Äã
7:25 PM
Great. Despite your apparent truce, you haven‚Äôt forgotten that this creature is a being of corruption. You‚Äôve certainly improved since your first time on the wall, but all three of your aspects protest its presence, even in a dream. It has tried to kill you twice before, and succeeded once. And this isn‚Äôt even just a creature of darkness: this is a shade. One of the rare few with a Mind, cunning and willing to bargain with humans and Angels alike to advance its goals. Your mortal enemy. And you‚Äôre seriously considering following its advice. Just to be able to hear it speak? Do you really want that? Surely if it‚Äôs asking you to do something - even indirectly, since you came up with the idea - that‚Äôs a bad thing to do. Right? But this tube doesn‚Äôt feel right either. You turn halfway, holding onto it with one hand so you can look at it without bending around too much. It hardly illuminates your skin, even when directly touching, but it still glows with heat. There doesn‚Äôt appear to be anything in the tube - no substances being extracted from you and no strange material being inserted. Just the heat and the strange, uneasy knowledge that there could be. Experimentally, almost without meaning to, you give the tube a little tug. It shifts in your back and you flinch, feeling a quick stab of pain where it connects to you. A diminishing echo of the jolt fades over the next few seconds. Your heart rate rises. If that was just a tug, what will it feel like when you tear it out? ‚Äú...‚Äù Aggghhhh! You just don‚Äôt know enough! This is a dream, sure, but if you‚Äôre willing to accept the shade is real, then certainly there can be consequences for things that happen here. Removing a strange, glowing tube from yourself that has been there for who knows how long is not a simple decision to make. What if you hurt yourself in reality? Sure, that‚Äôs never happened before, even when you died twice in a row, but... it could! ... Probably. ‚Äã
7:25 PM
The tube itself does not assist in your decision. It makes no sound, movement, or anything else. You almost complain at it; willing it to protest its innocence or prove its villainy. The shade shifts on its pile of rubble, descending a step or two towards you. It doesn‚Äôt seem to be willing to wait forever. W-what if... ‚ÄúH-hold on,‚Äù you stammer, backing away as if to ward it off. Almost surprisingly, the shade stops. ‚ÄúI... I haven‚Äôt decided yet. A tiny - miniscule, even - thread of silver liquid winds its way out of your Body and up into the ceiling. A larger streak of deep red blood accompanies it. You shudder, almost lightheaded even though you didn‚Äôt feel a thing. Silver. The color of magic. Of your Soul‚Äôs light. Of this shade‚Äôs eyes. What is it doing to you? [This is a critical point. One character‚Äôs fate will be altered.] - Pull out the tube. You have to know. - Leave the tube in. It‚Äôs too risky. (Winner: ) (edited)

Mxblah 8/3/2024 4:08 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 144 Moments slip by as you hesitate. Neither option seems appealing. But somehow, this external threat - the one you know, at least to some degree - almost seems preferable to the internal threat. The one you don‚Äôt. The tube is taking something from you. Something silver. Something precious? Important? You find yourself breathing quickly as you grasp the tube with both hands. Shaking, just a little. It‚Äôs flexible enough that you can compress it slightly with your grip. The shade only watches, nothing but a pair of silver eyes in the dark. Your heartbeat is loud in your ears. This - what if you‚Äôre wrong? What if you‚Äôre about to do something irreversible? What if- You‚Äôve always hated hospitals. Ever since your sickness. Doctors, needles, implements. And tubes much like this one. You‚Äôre breathing too fast. Your heart is beating too fast. You‚Äôre thinking too fast. You tear out the tube. There‚Äôs a ghastly sound as the thing separates from your flesh. Wet, slimy splatterings as the clear fluid it had contained splashes onto the floor. You collapse to the ground, overwhelmed with pain. Movement is impossible; it feels like the sun is embedded in your back. You would scream, if you could. The shade approaches. Kneels beside your head. Slips a fuzzy, shadowy hand under your chin and lifts it so you have no choice but to look into its eyes. Its form is blurry through the tears. ‚ÄúWell done,‚Äù it rasps. It has no mouth, but the outline of its head vibrates with its voice: that of a scratchy, whispering elder. ‚ÄúYour strings are cut. You are His puppet no longer.‚Äù It feels like you‚Äôre falling. Its words bounce around in your head, unable to find purchase through the haze of agony. But something sticks. The way it pronounced ‚ÄúHis.‚Äù Emphasized. Capitalized. Divine. You feel like you‚Äôve made a horrible mistake. ‚Äã
4:08 PM
The shade releases your chin; your head falls painfully back to the floor. It stands; moves out of your view. A sound you don‚Äôt know how to describe. And then silence. Minutes pass. Slowly, slowly, the torture fades. You can breathe again. Move your trembling hands; wipe the tears from your eyes. Your fingers are slick with blood. Carefully, you reach back to feel for the gaping hole it must have left in your torso. Nothing. The pain is receding quickly now and you fumble your way into a kneeling position, twisting around to see behind you. The shade is nowhere to be seen. Your back is whole, though there is a neat circle cut out of your clothing that marks where the tube had connected. But beneath it, instead of a raw wound gushing with blood, there‚Äôs a strange, triangular design formed out of scars or raised skin. It almost looks like the matan, but... different. The triangle‚Äôs bottom side is missing, and the circle is inside of it instead. You run your hand over the pattern, wincing at the heat and brief jolts of pain. It‚Äôs still very tender and even that momentary touch has prompted a few dots of blood to well out. The tube hangs just behind you, dangling empty and deflated. A puddle of clear, jelly-like substance mixes with blood and occasional tiny filaments of silver or gold liquid. There‚Äôs a terrifying assemblage of hooks and barbs on the lower end where it had connected to you; scraps of flesh still - you look away, feeling sick. Where is the shade? No - there‚Äôs something more important. ‚ÄúYou are His puppet no longer,‚Äù it said. His puppet. You - was that - did you just... You turn your glow back on, momentarily relieved that it still works. Still marks you as an Angel. Your worst fears fail to materialize. And, as you attune to Body and cause gusts of wind to dance around you as well, the relief becomes even greater. You haven‚Äôt cut yourself off from magic. From Soul. From God. So what was that tube? ‚Äã
4:08 PM
‚Äú... H-hello?‚Äù you call into the darkness, not nearly as scared now that you‚Äôve met surely the most dangerous thing that could dwell in it. ‚ÄúAre you still there?‚Äù Eerie silence, and then a brief rustle from above. You look up, then jump aside in surprise as the rest of the tube crashes down beside you, flopping into a tangled, disordered pile. Like discarded snakeskin. Empty; dead. The shade drops next to it, landing gracefully and returning to its upright posture. Its left hand is a blade, but it quickly returns to normal. You think you know what it was doing up there. ‚ÄúYes,‚Äù it says simply. ‚Äú... W-what did I just do?‚Äù ‚ÄúYou cut your strings.‚Äù ‚ÄúWhat does that mean?‚Äù ‚ÄúYou are now free.‚Äù ‚Äú...‚Äù You decide to change tactics. ‚ÄúWho are you?‚Äù ‚ÄúOne who never had strings.‚Äù A nervous swallow. If this shade never had strings, and now you don‚Äôt... ‚ÄúD-do you have a name?‚Äù ‚ÄúThose without strings bear no names.‚Äù ‚Äú...‚Äù A pause; you take a moment to make sure you remember your own name. Jessamine Laura Goodall. It‚Äôs okay. You‚Äôre okay. Breathe. ‚ÄúWhat do you want with me? Why do you keep following me in dreams?‚Äù ‚ÄúIt offers alternatives. For the one who cut her strings, and the one with broken strings.‚Äù ‚ÄúAl...ternatives?‚Äù You try to work through the obtuse titles the shade seems to use in place of names. ‚ÄúI - I‚Äôm the one who cut her - my - strings, right? Then... the one with broken strings...‚Äù A floating guillotine blade forms behind the shade and clangs into the floor, severing a segment of the deflated tube as it does so. ‚ÄúH-half-Angel?‚Äù ‚ÄúA puppet with half its strings is a broken puppet. But it can be mended.‚Äù ‚ÄúHow?!‚Äù ‚ÄúHe will not allow it. Broken puppets serve not His purpose. But it provides for all.‚Äù ‚ÄúTh-that‚Äôs not an answer! How do I save her?‚Äù ‚ÄúIt can fix the one with broken strings. You must simply arrange a meeting.‚Äù ‚ÄúW-who is ‚Äòit?‚Äô Is that just... you?‚Äù ‚ÄúIt has no strings.‚Äù ‚Äú... Y-So, yes? I... I need to think. How can I, er, arrange a meeting?‚Äù ‚Äã
4:08 PM
‚ÄúIt will return.‚Äù You wake up instantly, transitioning in an eyeblink from the dark, broken-down factory to the light, opulent apartment. There‚Äôs too much to think about. Too much you have to consider and remember and maybe even tell, but you just need to understand it first. And there‚Äôs no time to do that now; you‚Äôve only got a few minutes to get ready before you have to meet your escort to the constabulary. But before any of that... You run to the bathroom and turn around so your back is facing the mirror. Grip the hem of your nightclothes anxiously. And quickly get it over with, pulling it up so you can inspect the- Not there. You breathe out in relief, running your fingers over smooth skin just to be sure. Of course it‚Äôs not there. Nothing in a dream has ever affected your physical Body. Just... this one felt... different, somehow. Whatever; you have to get ready! You cheat a little with magic, both to speed things up and to make sure you still have the ability in the waking world too. Everything‚Äôs fine. You feel perfectly healthy and normal. No aches in your lower back, no strange chills, and certainly no mysterious symbols traced into your skin. In fact, you kind of feel a little better than normal. You can‚Äôt quite pinpoint it, but there‚Äôs just something a little stronger about you today. A little calmer. A little more in control, perhaps? You hurry downstairs to meet the constables. ‚Äç - You‚Äôre very distracted today, thinking about everything. - You‚Äôre on the ball today. Everything just clicks into place. (Winner: ) (edited)

Mxblah 8/5/2024 6:47 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 145 That sensation of control persists throughout the work day. You spend some time on more paperwork, some time learning about the constables‚Äô new rifles (so you can better coordinate with them and soldiers in dangerous situations, not so you can use one yourself), and some time following up on various leads from yesterday. Some of your inferences have borne fruit and you have more data to sift through, but that‚Äôs not what you‚Äôre most interested in. You‚Äôre looking for details on what those girls were worried about. And, delightfully, you find something. Honestly, given how little information you have, you didn‚Äôt really expect any results. But it turns out one of the few female constables at the station happens to have a friend who works at the same mill and knows Mila. It‚Äôs a real coincidence and she‚Äôs just as surprised as you are when the two of you connect the dots. But that helps get you names, locations, details, and even the other girl‚Äôs name so you can stop calling her ‚Äúthe other one.‚Äù It‚Äôs Kate, by the way. Anyway, it‚Äôs not like the constables track every person all the time, so you don‚Äôt know if any of the people transferred to the warehouse job are actually missing or if they just didn‚Äôt keep in touch. In fact, you won‚Äôt even get a list of who was transferred unless you can convince one of the mill‚Äôs managers to give you one. But that should be no problem for a constable. Or at least, no problem for a constable who is also an Angel. You run out of time in the day before you‚Äôre able to dig up anything else. Still, it‚Äôs a lot of progress. You‚Äôll follow up later. At the end of your shift, you change into the normal clothes you intelligently brought to the station today and can skip the escort back to your apartment. Then it‚Äôs off to find somewhere else to eat, some more rumors to listen to (though they don‚Äôt lead anywhere today), and finally back to bed to think about everything the shade said. ‚Äã
6:47 PM
It really seemed to like the puppet metaphor. You can see why; it makes sense from its point of view. God doesn‚Äôt directly control the Angels, but He does choose who Ascends and there‚Äôs the whole Cathedra in place to ensure they live up to their responsibilities. As soon as God chose you in the Calling chamber, your life - to some degree - became predetermined. You will train for six years, graduate, and defend the city and its population. Eventually, you will fall in battle (twice, probably) and die. If you ignore the specifics, you do sort of seem like a puppet. Plucked from your ordinary life to be thrown against the corruption and eventually discarded. Your Angelic energy released and reused to cause some other kid to Ascend and start the cycle anew. At least, you figure that might be how that part works. And its description of Naoriel as a broken puppet makes sense too. You already know she‚Äôs dangerous: her unstable Soul could lead to another Erejil situation. From the Cathedra‚Äôs perspective, it‚Äôs not worth it to try to fix the puppet. Throw it away and Ascend a new one. You can understand the shade‚Äôs perspective. It makes sense; it seems reasonable. And that worries you. This thing is one of the most dangerous, most deceptive creatures of the corruption, and it‚Äôs offering to help. It‚Äôs offering to save someone the Cathedra would kill. So, what‚Äôs the catch? Well, the most obvious one would be that the shade‚Äôs ‚Äúhelp‚Äù is just turning Naoriel to the corruption. Making her into a fallen Angel; using her to change the rules, just like Erejil did. And then, once she‚Äôs killed or captured and her connection to the Lordstone is broken, the corruption will abandon her just as readily as the Cathedra. A puppet whose purpose has been served; a puppet whose strings have been cut. After all, the corruption‚Äôs sole purpose is to destroy us utterly. It will lie and scheme and say whatever you want to hear in order to further that goal. Never, ever, listen. ‚Äã
6:47 PM
At least, that‚Äôs the line from the play False Angel Erejil. It just makes sense. You shouldn‚Äôt trust it. But somehow, you can‚Äôt get that little ember of hope out of your Mind. You know the corruption has ways of manipulating Minds and Souls that the Cathedra doesn‚Äôt. It has to, for shades to exist. Creatures that should be impossible after God‚Äôs sacrifice, yet here they are. But why would it help you? Even assuming the shade somehow holds the power to help Naoriel, why would it use it? You‚Äôre the enemy. Your purpose is to destroy it utterly. You will lie and scheme and say whatever it wants to hear in order to further that goal. Why should it help you gain another Angel that will help destroy it? You don‚Äôt believe it‚Äôs just being nice; that simply doesn‚Äôt happen. Which leads you back to the first idea again. But if it‚Äôs so obvious, then surely the shade would know that too. They‚Äôre supposed to be smart enough to tempt and trick Angels. Just offering something that‚Äôs an obvious lie isn‚Äôt very convincing. Maybe it could want peace? Wars have been settled before, in the time before year zero, without the utter destruction of one faction. Maybe the corruption intends to negotiate, now that it has enough Minds to do so? ... You can‚Äôt take that idea seriously. But what is the alternative? There has to be one! It‚Äôs driving you nuts! ‚Äú...‚Äù Maybe... maybe becoming a fallen Angel isn‚Äôt a death sentence. That‚Äôs a dangerous thought. Angelic Souls are powerful enough to survive immense levels of corruption, usually. Half-Angels might work differently, but the point is that most fallen Angels retain their Minds and Souls (and magic, through their divine connection) after their fall. Even Erejil did, which is of course why he was so dangerous. Every fallen Angel died soon after their fall... but not to the corruption. They were killed by their fellow Angels, or executed after being stripped of their powers by the Emissary. ‚Äã
6:47 PM
What if a fallen Angel could simply live... normally? Sure, they would be corrupted, but what is the corruption associated with such a fall, actually? If it doesn‚Äôt destroy your Body, Mind, or Soul - like it would an ordinary human - what does it do? Are you turned into a monstrous version of yourself? Clearly not, as fallen Angels often go undetected for a while. Are you made subservient to the corruption? Maybe, but you‚Äôre not convinced. The stories always make it seem like the fallen Angel chooses to commit horrible acts, not that they‚Äôre being forced into it by some sort of Mind control. Would a fallen Angel Naoriel be - somehow - healthier than a half-Angel Naoriel? You don‚Äôt know. And you would bet anything that you won‚Äôt get a straight answer from the shade if you ask it. God, and you haven‚Äôt even thought about yourself yet. The tube; your mysterious sense of confidence that still hasn‚Äôt quite faded. You‚Äôve just been too distracted wondering about Naoriel to wonder if you‚Äôre going to be immediately arrested and executed after returning to campus. Are you corrupted? It doesn‚Äôt feel like it, but would you even be able to tell? Is your connection to God still okay? You can still glow and cast magic and such, but again: are you able to tell for sure? The Emissary can see all kinds of things in Souls that even top Angels can‚Äôt, but you‚Äôd be kind of super mega nervous to tell him about any of this. ‚ÄúOh, yeah, I talked to a shade‚Äù all casual-like. And then you get turned to ash by his Lordstone powers. You‚Äôre rambling now and you know it. There won‚Äôt be any true answers found just by thinking very hard. You‚Äôll have to figure out what to do without knowing all the facts. But that‚Äôs nothing new. - Go get the warehouse list as an Angel. - Go get the warehouse list as a constable. - Go get the warehouse list with a group of constables. (Winner: ) (edited)

Mxblah 8/7/2024 7:44 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 146 You don‚Äôt dream that night, or the next, or the two after that. Another day of preparation passes, then two more. You need a lot of paperwork to actually go out and do anything, so you‚Äôre stuck in limbo and other work as approvals work their way through various levels of bureaucracy. But finally, enough people with enough authority have agreed to let you go to the mill and do some proper investigating. Remila, the constable from earlier who has a friend there, accompanies you as your partner, and you manage to decline the offer of a larger group. You want to do this as normally as you can, and a squad of twenty constables coming along to look after you would be... not that. Plus, it‚Äôd be kind of embarrassing. You can look after yourself. So off you go in your official constable uniform, not dressed as an Angel today. It‚Äôs a little big for you (they don‚Äôt tend to have many constables your size) but with a bit of disguise magic you can make the outfit seem more presentable. It‚Äôs a little unclear how exactly this doesn‚Äôt count as transmutation either (disguise magic is just weird, okay?) but apparently you‚Äôre ‚Äúadding‚Äù tidiness or ‚Äúremoving‚Äù wrinkles? At least it works as long as you think about it that way. Close enough. After a brief train journey (during which you get several strange looks, hopefully just due to your apparent age), you arrive near the mill in question. As with many factories in this part of the city, it‚Äôs a large brick building with a few large chimneys for the on-site steam plant that powers the machinery. Narrow, grimy windows don‚Äôt really afford any view of the interior, even as you get up close. It feels like a place of... not despair, exactly, but certainly not happiness. You consider switching to Soul to get a better sense of any corruption nearby, but decide the hassle of redoing your disguise would be too much. You would have noticed anything egregious as-is anyway. You‚Äôll take a Soul-look later. ‚Äã
7:44 PM
You meet with one of the managers near the door and explain what you need. Request the list and a few other details that might be helpful; present your authorization paperwork in case he had any doubts. The man takes his time looking it over, then requests even more time to find the records. In the meantime, a different manager escorts you around the floor to inspect whatever you‚Äôd like. No one here seems pleased to see you. There‚Äôs no outright hostility - certainly, the managers are treating you with careful (if confused) politeness - but there is a sense of wariness and... perhaps distrust. No one you talk to offers much of use. Workers have seen their friends transferred, but haven‚Äôt spoken to anyone afterwards. Managers speak at length about the advantages of the move and the specifics the new job entails. Sorting, stacking, carrying, loading, unloading; it‚Äôs exactly what you‚Äôd expect, basically. All the minute details that mean absolutely nothing. It sort of feels like you‚Äôre just wasting time. How long does it take to get a stack of papers ready that they should already have available? You don‚Äôt see Mila or Kate anywhere, though you haven‚Äôt toured the whole factory yet. Eventually, the first manager comes back. ‚ÄúFound the paperwork, madames. Hiding down in the back offices. If you‚Äôd like to inspect them, please follow me.‚Äù You very much would like to inspect them (and hopefully get some copies), so off you go back to the lobby, then down a narrow staircase just beside it. This leads into the mill‚Äôs basement, where the steam plant and back offices are located. It‚Äôs incredibly loud down here, as well as hot and humid; your guide almost has to shout to be heard over the mechanical din. But finally, he shows you a slim wooden door tucked beside a tangle of pipes. Inside is a long, narrow room crammed with filing cabinets and a few desks. A third manager sits near the back of the room, arranging a stack of papers. He looks up as you enter and beckons you over. ‚Äã
7:45 PM
There‚Äôs a loud crack from behind, audible even over the general din. You start to recoil in surprise, but strong arms wrap around and drag you back. A rag doused in horrible-smelling liquid is pressed to your face; out of the corner of your eye, you see Remila falling to the ground, another man standing over her holding a smoking gun. Wh-wh- I - DO SOMETHING! You shock yourself into action, struggling against the man‚Äôs grip. You‚Äôre so much stronger than you look that you catch him off guard and actually manage to break an arm free, elbowing him in the gut and eliciting a grunt as his other hand loosens... but then another man joins in (perhaps the shooter) and you don‚Äôt have a chance. Still, you strain against them both, instinctively holding your breath to thwart whatever they‚Äôre trying to force you to inhale, but you have to breathe and it‚Äôs just... not... enough. ‚ÄúHow the hell‚Äôs she still awake?!‚Äù one of them exclaims as your vision starts to tunnel towards blackness. ‚ÄúDid you fuck up the dose?‚Äù ‚Äú----------‚Äù You can‚Äôt catch whatever the other man says in response. Instead, you pass out. ... You drift into consciousness some time later. Rough cloth covers your eyes and mouth; there are heavy metal chains on your wrists and ankles. The floor and wall are wood, and the entire room rattles. You‚Äôre clearly in a carriage or wagon, being transported somewhere. Terror sets in quickly. This isn‚Äôt a dream. You‚Äôve actually been kidnapped. Your breathing quickens as you try to figure out what to do. Should you try to make noise? Wiggle around? Stay still? The constables will notice you‚Äôre missing soon, if they haven‚Äôt already, and they‚Äôll surely inform the Cathedra. Angels will be out looking for you before nightfall. But... will that be fast enough? Where are you being taken; will anyone even be able to find you? ‚Äã
7:45 PM
‚ÄúHey, I think she‚Äôs waking up.‚Äù A gruff voice speaks very close nearby, making you jump. He responds to the movement immediately. ‚ÄúShit! Definitely awake! What do I do?‚Äù ‚ÄúCalm down and keep your damn eyes open like you‚Äôre supposed to. If she makes trouble, knock her out again. Not hard, is it?‚Äù That‚Äôs a different voice, from the direction of travel. The driver, maybe? ‚ÄúB-but... s-she; I mean, have you looked at her? Someone must‚Äôve fucked up bad to send us off with a - an - A-Angel!‚Äù A brief moment of shock, but it makes sense that they would know. Your disguise requires concentration to maintain; it would have dropped as soon as you passed out. But... for these men to dare kidnap an Angel... The terror surges higher. You never really considered that anything truly bad could happen to you in the city, except by corruption. Even if criminals targeted you for some reason, they would stop if you revealed your true form. No one would dare harm an Angel. Or so you thought. ‚ÄúSo what? Angel or not; can‚Äôt do anything all tied up like that. If you‚Äôre really scared, knock her out again. I won‚Äôt tell.‚Äù The driver chuckles gratingly. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs not the problem! She‚Äôs holy! Chosen by God! W-we need to set her free! Beg for forgiveness! Y-you can‚Äôt just do this to the divine!‚Äù ‚ÄúNever knew you were religious,‚Äù the driver responds. ‚ÄúBut shut up and do what you‚Äôre told or you won‚Äôt live long enough to be cursed, or whatever. You think her Angel buddies would just let you go if we set her free? The conners? Hmm?‚Äù ‚Äú... No.‚Äù ‚ÄúSo keep watchin‚Äô her till we get there. Then you can spend the night in penance or something.‚Äù ‚Äú... Alright.‚Äù A brief pause, then you feel him shifting closer to you (though not close enough you could reach him). A quieter voice. ‚ÄúEr, s-sorry ‚Äòbout this. If that means anything.‚Äù ‚ÄúHey! What part of ‚Äòshut up‚Äô don‚Äôt you understand? Don‚Äôt talk to her!‚Äù ‚Äã
7:45 PM
The nervous thug shifts away again. ‚ÄúSorry.‚Äù You feel horrible. Not physically - you‚Äôre just a little dizzy and sore; otherwise fine. But the anticipatory fear of wherever these men are taking you mixes with a paradoxical guilt that you should have seen this coming and stopped it. The carriage stinks of corruption, even without being attuned to Soul. If you had just taken the time to look earlier instead of worrying about your disguise...! Mxblah 8/9/2024 5:58 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 147 Your immediate thought is to try to escape. You can use magic; you‚Äôre super strong; surely you have some way to get out of here. But as you think about it, holding as still as you can and trying to slow your breathing, there‚Äôs actually not a lot you can do physically with the chains on your limbs. Sure, if they weren‚Äôt there you could take off the blindfold and break out of whatever vehicle this is, then run away before they could catch up. Easy. But... you don‚Äôt know any spells that can help you with solid metal. You‚Äôve been focusing on Mind, not Body. But... you‚Äôve been focusing on Mind. Still trying to stay quiet so the nervous thug won‚Äôt do anything stupid, like knock you out again, you try to calm yourself down enough to focus on Mind. It‚Äôs very hard work in this situation and you still don‚Äôt seem to have the ability to instantly switch. Is it because Naoriel isn‚Äôt here? Are you still not in enough danger? Or... have you lost it somehow? You try and fail to distract yourself with those thoughts; every shuffle or cough from the thug nearby feels like the approach of another horrible-smelling cloth. But eventually, after minutes of trying to stay calm, you finally switch aspects and hold a tenuous grip on Mind. It‚Äôll have to do. ‚Äã
5:59 PM
To start with, your senses are enhanced. The sound of horse hooves ahead mingles with a background thrum of machinery and distant voices, but there are no people nearby. You‚Äôre probably still in the fourteenth district somewhere, but definitely not in a central location. The stench of corruption is heavy, but stale. The carriage has been exposed to enough of it to absorb some darkness - as Brother Cobb explained, even objects can be corrupted - but the people inside aren‚Äôt corrupted. At least, not enough to explain their behavior. You had sort of been giving them the benefit of the doubt, thinking maybe they were possessed or something, but... they seem to be doing this of their own free will. Perhaps influenced by corruption, but not controlled by it. But what you really want to know isn‚Äôt something you can tell from your senses alone. With a shaky inhale, you shift slightly and focus on the nervous thug. He shuffles in response, but doesn‚Äôt quite say anything. Good. You were really worried he‚Äôd freak out. Connection. You need a connection. But you don‚Äôt know anything about this man! You know he‚Äôs nervous, which you could maybe use as common ground, but his anxiety and yours aren‚Äôt really the same. Different sources, different intensities, and... it just feels different. You can‚Äôt use anything basic like ‚Äúhuman‚Äù either, not in your current state of Mind. You‚Äôve never felt more distant from the regular human race. But there has to be something you can use! ‚Äú...‚Äù Guilt? Specifically, his guilt due to... well, you. And since you‚Äôre the target of that particular feeling, you don‚Äôt need to share it. Which is good, because although you‚Äôre certainly feeling extremely guilty right now, it‚Äôs for different reasons. You try not to think about the gunshot. So sudden. Your grip on the aspect wavers, but you have to hold on. Just... think about something else. Like your magic. ‚Äã
5:59 PM
With that connection, weak though it is, you can peer into the man‚Äôs Mind. It‚Äôs not nearly as clear as with a two-way connection between Angels, but you‚Äôve practiced this with Noll. You know how to pick out the details you want, even when they‚Äôre blurry. And you know how to be sneaky about it. In fact, you‚Äôre so absorbed in your task that you almost forget how much danger you‚Äôre in, which only helps your concentration. It‚Äôs like a puzzle! Briefly. You‚Äôre not going to a warehouse. You‚Äôve already been to the warehouse, and now you‚Äôre being moved again. The man whose Mind you‚Äôre reading doesn‚Äôt even know about the mill; all he knows is that sometimes he‚Äôs called upon to move people from a certain locked room to a certain... you struggle to make out the destination. Is it... water? A pond, or the river? You strain your ears, trying to make out the sound of waves or boats that could tell you, and... yes! Distant, but just barely audible: the tell-tale splashing of the Endle River breaking against docks and posts. You must be near the northern side of the district, between the outer wall and the border with the thirteenth. But your sense of accomplishment fades quickly as the river sounds grow louder and more obvious. You‚Äôre clearly heading straight for it and would have picked that up soon even without the Mind magic. The thug‚Äôs current thoughts seem to center around locations and his worries about you; you can‚Äôt get anything about who he might work for or why he‚Äôs doing this at all. Have you even gotten anything useful out of this? So far, it‚Äôs just been something you could have figured out anyway and that this guy doesn‚Äôt know anything! ‚Äã
5:59 PM
As the sound of splashing grows louder, something else occurs to you. A spell you haven‚Äôt practiced much, but one that could be extremely useful if you can pull it off. You have no idea how long you have until you get wherever you‚Äôre going, so you do your best to pull in as much information about the man as you‚Äôve gleaned over this brief time, then release your magic. A gentle stretching sensation pulls behind your eyes, then... You‚Äôre looking at yourself. The man whose senses you‚Äôre borrowing brings his hands up to his face, muttering worriedly about his eyes; the driver grouchily asks what he‚Äôs muttering about and he says nothing important. Your Body is so tiny from the thug‚Äôs perspective; it feels like he could snap you like a twig. But you‚Äôre not here just to watch the inside of the carriage; you‚Äôre here to figure out what‚Äôs going on. You do your best to memorize the driver‚Äôs appearance as best you can from this angle in a few seconds, then scan the edges of the man‚Äôs vision for anything identifying. The carriage is windowless in the back, so you won‚Äôt be able to see anything from there. But up front, as the driver mutters something like ‚ÄúAlmost there,‚Äù the thug watching you lets his gaze wander. And... there! A small, high-up angle lets in a glimpse of sky... and Nucarreo‚Äôs outer wall. You‚Äôre right on the edge of the city and right next to the river, in the fourteenth district. There‚Äôs only one place this could possibly be: the industrial waste disposal plant. Or at least very close to it. But that realization just brings another with it. If you could tell anyone where to look, you‚Äôd be found right away now that you have a location. But if anyone were here to tell, they would have already found you! Briefly, you consider trying telepathy again, but you‚Äôre well aware it‚Äôs completely beyond your abilities; you‚Äôve only got a maximum range of a few hundred feet, and that‚Äôs with a pre-existing connection. ‚Äã
5:59 PM
Still, what have you got to lose? You switch targets as quickly as you can, feeling the carriage slow as you approach a nondescript wooden garage, then scream out your location as best you can. Not verbally, of course, but Mentally. If any Angels happen to be... basically within the block, they‚Äôll be able to hear. The nervous thug flinches. ‚ÄúH-hey, did you just suddenly think about the-‚Äù ‚Äú-the disposal plant?‚Äù the driver finishes. ‚ÄúYes...‚Äù Humans can hear it too! Even if you‚Äôre not targeting them directly! Good to know! Very good to know! Silence for a few seconds. You try to get your sense-sharing spell back, but the thug‚Äôs state of Mind has changed. And as you‚Äôre trying to deal with that... ‚ÄúKnock her out again,‚Äù the driver says coldly. ‚ÄúE-eh?‚Äù ‚ÄúBetter to be safe if that was her doing. Who knows what else she can do?‚Äù ‚ÄúI-if you‚Äôre sure...‚Äù No! Nononono you‚Äôll lose any further opportunities if they do that! You panic for a moment, trying to come up with a solution, then quickly latch onto the first thought that comes to Mind. No time to reconsider; just do it NOW! The thug douses a rag with the same horrible fluid from earlier - you can‚Äôt see it at the moment, as you‚Äôre working on a different spell, but you can smell it already - then moves up close. ‚ÄúS-sorry,‚Äù he mutters, then- A few moments‚Äô hesitation. You let your Body slide down the side of the carriage as if you‚Äôre asleep. The man never even held the cloth up to your face. Your heart thumps so loudly you swear he should be able to hear it. ‚ÄúO-okay, she‚Äôs out,‚Äù the thug announces. ‚ÄúHate this stuff.‚Äù ‚Äã
6:00 PM
You... you did it. You planted the idea in his head that he had already drugged you, before he actually did it. He honestly thinks he just knocked you out, even though you‚Äôre only pretending! You - you desperately try to steady your breathing, as if you‚Äôre really sleeping. Thankfully, it takes him long enough to get rid of the rag that you can mostly calm down before he returns, and you even have enough time to bring the sense-sharing spell back up, this time being careful to activate it when the driver says something so the thug won‚Äôt feel tempted to mention the twinge behind his eyes. They‚Äôve brought the carriage into the nondescript garage you noticed earlier and the driver has gotten out to close the door. ‚ÄúOkay, unhook the chains and get ready to carry her. Mxblah 8/11/2024 2:31 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 148 Switching aspects to Body is tempting, as that would make you stronger and faster, but you‚Äôre already on Mind and need to maintain the spell so you can see what‚Äôs going on. So... a slightly different plan. You don‚Äôt need Body magic to temporarily disable two ordinary humans. At least, as long as you can time and target everything properly. Right away, your plan hits a snag. The thug starts working on your chains, but the driver leaves his field of view. You hear a door opening and some conversation. There are more people here beyond just these two! O-obviously, now that you think about it. They have to be delivering you to someone. But that makes your plan even more precarious; how many people can you safely disable at once? You‚Äôve done up to two in practice, but even that is somewhat straining and it‚Äôs not something you get much training in. As, of course, most darkness creatures don‚Äôt have Minds and it‚Äôs rare that an Angel needs to subdue humans. The spell does work on shades (at least theoretically) but you‚Äôre not anywhere near experienced enough to be working on that sort of magic. Your arms are now free, but the thug pauses to tie your wrists together with a length of rope before moving on to your legs. Another problem; your confidence (never high to begin with) lowers again. You could maybe break it with Body magic, but - you stealthily pull against it when the thug isn‚Äôt looking - it‚Äôs certainly too strong for you to break with just your normal strength. You don‚Äôt need your arms to run away, but they would certainly help! ‚Äã
2:31 PM
Voices get louder. There are two more men nearby talking to the driver; the thug glances up briefly so you can get a look at them. Dark masks and hoods obscure most of their features, leaving only their eyes visible. Eyes which, you‚Äôre alarmed to note, aren‚Äôt a natural color. The hue has been drained from their irises, leaving them sickly, pale grey. These men are humans, but they‚Äôve clearly been touched by some sort of power. ‚Äú... impressed that you managed to bring her here safely,‚Äù one of them says. ‚ÄúHas she been unconscious the whole way?‚Äù ‚ÄúYes,‚Äù the driver lies smoothly; the thug glances up momentarily, but doesn‚Äôt say anything. ‚ÄúThe dosage had to be adjusted higher, but it still works.‚Äù ‚ÄúInteresting. This is the first Angel we‚Äôve captured; I‚Äôm certain we‚Äôll get enormous value out of her. Your payment for this delivery will be tripled, as long as you breathe not a word of this to anyone.‚Äù ‚ÄúVery generous of you. Our lips are sealed.‚Äù The driver eyes the thug, who nods vigorously. He also finishes unbinding your legs, but everyone‚Äôs looking at you and you‚Äôre still lying down and it would be really hard to stand up without your arms and - ack, you need to start preparing the other spell - God you hope this works - so you reluctantly break your connection with the thug‚Äôs senses and change your target to every Mind you can sense in the room. Four people at once. You hope you can do it. You need to be able to do it. There‚Äôs some rustling and clinking as money is exchanged. Then the thug picks you up, drooping you over his shoulder like a sack of potatoes. ‚ÄúWhere d‚Äôya w-want her?‚Äù he asks. ‚ÄúJust down the-‚Äù You release your magic. ‚Äã
2:31 PM
To you, it‚Äôs only a distant Mental echo as you receive feedback from the other nearby Minds. But to them, it would be an amped-up version of the telepathy from earlier. A Mental scream loud enough to overwhelm senses and scramble thoughts. The effect will only last a few seconds since you‚Äôre targeting so many people, but it will be enough. It has to be. The thug drops you immediately, moving his hands to clutch his head. You - blessedly - manage to land on your feet and stay standing. You are now free to run... but run where? You‚Äôre still blindfolded and can‚Äôt use your arms, and all the doors are closed! There is literally no time to hesitate; you pick a direction that seems to match up with what you remember of the room‚Äôs arrangement and sprint blindly. You slam into a wall within moments, but hardly register the pain. Door; door; where is the door?! A handle pokes you in the side; you maneuver so you can just barely grasp it with your hands tied behind your back. Fumble with the smooth metal as you anxiously listen for anyone to get up after the spell. It‚Äôs so slippery and hard to turn from this angle and you just can‚Äôt be defeated by a doorknob of all things but you hear angry shouting and footsteps and you finally get the thing to turn and-!!! A hand closes around one arm. You yank against it, shoving the door open into warm sunlight and screaming against the gag hoping that anyone at all can hear you. But it‚Äôs not enough. More hands join the first and haul you back inside, roughly restraining you against one of the hooded men as everyone shouts about something. Still, even then you‚Äôre stronger than he expects and your struggles are almost making headway until- Someone punches you squarely in the side of the head. Shocked and reeling in pain, you‚Äôre too surprised to do anything for a moment. And then there‚Äôs another blow. And another. And then the second hooded man is taking out all his aggression on you in a flurry of physical violence. ‚Äã
2:32 PM
You‚Äôre strong. You‚Äôre tough. But you aren‚Äôt invincible. By the end of it, you can hardly move but to sob into the gag. Everything hurts. And finally, someone brings over a different horrible-smelling rag and everything goes black. ... You wake up some time later. Your head spins and your Body aches. Dried blood flakes from your nose and mouth. You are utterly miserable. The blindfold, gag, and rope have all been removed; you‚Äôre free to move around normally. But you won‚Äôt be able to get far. You‚Äôre locked in a small room mostly made of damp, dull, weathered stone bricks. One wall seems more recent than the rest; the bricks are cleaner and have less lichen growing. And the wall opposite that is made of stout metal bars, like a jail cell. You can look through the bars into a massive, dark chamber. Flowing water splashes down from many openings in the walls into a central pool only a few feet beneath your level. Other cells line the walls of the chamber, and some of them even have people inside. Though with all the noise from the water, you won‚Äôt be able to talk to anyone. Despondent, you tug at one of the bars, but it predictably fails to budge. Push on some of the walls; no movement there either. You‚Äôre stuck. Alongside who knows how many others. The entire place just shivers with corruption, too. What a failure of an Angel you are. - Continue being Jessamine. - Be Yara. Briefly. [Requires unanimous agreement. May not happen even if selected, or may take the form of a story or flashback later. This is more to gauge if there is any interest in a non-Jessamine perspective in this story than a binding choice.] (Winner: ) (edited)

@Story Notifications Scene 149 Elsewhere... ‚ÄúYara. Over here.‚Äù Your name is Yara Conner, aspiring Soul channeler and full Angel of the Cathedra, and you stride quickly across the bustling room. Clerks and dispatchers cross your path, but everyone is attentive enough to avoid a collision. The air strains under heavy tension; something serious has gone wrong this time. ‚ÄúAfternoon, captain.‚Äù You greet Stella casually, despite the situation. That‚Äôs just how you are, and she knows that well. You‚Äôve been working together since you graduated. ‚ÄúWhat horrible monster do you have for me today? And is it going to apologize for causing trouble while I‚Äôm supposed to be off duty?‚Äù ‚ÄúNot sure and not a chance,‚Äù she responds. ‚ÄúI called you because if I didn‚Äôt, you‚Äôd rush after us the minute someone told you what was going on. This way; hurry.‚Äù ‚ÄúOh dear. What could that mean?‚Äù You arrange your gear as you hustle after Stella, following her towards the trains. The Center is crowded with an unusual number of other Angels and their attendants doing the same thing. ‚ÄúHum. Don‚Äôt you dare tell me something went wrong with Jessamine‚Äôs practical.‚Äù ‚ÄúSorry. She‚Äôs gone missing.‚Äù ‚ÄúWhat?! How?‚Äù ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt know yet. This just happened and the constables are confused too. They aren‚Äôt saying much.‚Äù ‚ÄúOh, excellent; they were only responsible for her safety. Why would they know what happened?‚Äù The gate guards hurriedly step aside for you and the train pulls away seconds after you board. Two more idle at the station, presumably waiting for more Angels yet to arrive. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve got the same questions. Someone‚Äôs gonna have to answer for this, but not till we find her and bring her back safe. Think you can help with that, even on your day off?‚Äù No humor or sarcasm this time. You can only say ‚ÄúYes.‚Äù ... ‚Äã
8:13 PM
Several hours later, you stand perturbed near the center of a wide-open warehouse somewhere in the fourteenth district. Stella, Clarity, and Zeke (now officially an Inquisitor, you‚Äôve learned) are all somewhere nearby, linked to you via telepathy in case whatever took Jessamine manages to get one of you as well. Constables surround the building and question nearby residents. The entire district is currently locked down, with constables from neighboring districts cooperating to search anything leaving the area through any means. You open your senses again, trying to do it the way Jessamine showed you. Despite her inexperience, she‚Äôs better than you at sensing corruption. Better than anyone, except perhaps Archangels. But only the same low, constant thrum of darkness comes back as the last few times; nothing more actionable. You‚Äôre certain there was something here, but where it went remains a mystery. ‚Äú...‚Äù The mill was empty when you arrived. Fires smoldered within; someone had clearly tried to set the place ablaze to destroy as much evidence as possible, but the flames failed to catch and your group was able to quickly extinguish those that remained. Still, most documents had already been burned. Though the workers and managers had gone, you managed to get some useful information out of nearby locals, and even the constables themselves (after some prodding). Ongoing transfers to a warehouse job. Changing behaviors. Worsening conditions. People that never returned. Jessamine‚Äôs notes were predictably thorough - at least after you managed to retrieve them from the bureaucratic mass that had somehow already misplaced them. Madness. It had only been a few days. It didn‚Äôt take long to find the warehouse, though it too was empty when you arrived. No fires smoldered, but no documents remained anyway. The whole place seemed more of a shell than anything else. There was little evidence anyone had worked here - at least, not for long. ‚Äã
8:13 PM
So now here you are, searching through the maze of shelves and back rooms in the hope of finding anything at all that could lead you towards Jessamine. But there just isn‚Äôt anything. Some reports of a carriage driving around, but no one remembers where it went. Odd sounds in the building at night, but no one can describe them. Workers who arrive one day and are gone by the next week. No one has seen an Angel. Well, aside from the half-dozen currently searching the place. It‚Äôs a rare display of force from the Cathedra; Angels usually travel alone or in pairs. But today you have the four of you, plus Archangel Kamiya and one of the purifiers whose name you‚Äôve somehow managed to avoid learning. ‚Äú...‚Äù A sigh, physical this time. You turn slightly to spot Clarity approaching from a few rows over. ‚ÄúFind anything?‚Äù you ask, though of course she would have told you Mentally if she had. ‚ÄúNo, but Jez‚Äôs group has.‚Äù You can hear her words echo in your Mind, sharing the information with Stella and Zeke. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs a good tracker, you know. That‚Äôs why he‚Äôs here.‚Äù Jez. That‚Äôs the purifier‚Äôs name. You‚Äôll remember it this time, probably. ‚ÄúPlease don‚Äôt bury the lede; I‚Äôve had a very stressful day. What have they found?‚Äù ‚ÄúRight.‚Äù You‚Äôve rarely seen Clarity so down. It almost makes you want to cheer her up, but you‚Äôre also in rare form today. Not going to happen. ‚ÄúTraces of the same drug we found at the mill, plus some lingering echoes of corruption in - get this - wheel ruts in the loading dock.‚Äù ‚ÄúWheel ruts?‚Äù ‚ÄúI thought he was joking; I couldn‚Äôt sense a thing. But apparently not.‚Äù A pause; she glances back as someone shouts a name, but neither of you are needed. ‚ÄúHe can‚Äôt track it through the streets, but there‚Äôs at least enough consistency to get a direction. North.‚Äù ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs... potentially good. There‚Äôs less ground to cover that way.‚Äù ‚Äã
8:13 PM
‚ÄúUnless they crossed the river. Or went into the river.‚Äù Clarity hesitates, allowing a hint of anxiety to show on her face. ‚ÄúYara, what if they took her into the wastelands? Every section of the wall is constantly watched, and we even posted extra guards by the river exit after the last time something broke in. None of the watchmen have seen anything unusual today. @Story Notifications Scene 150 But despite your optimistic words, an entire day passes without finding Jessamine. There are signs. People come forward with reports that match up with the carriage you‚Äôre tracking. The search is narrowed. You find a discarded rag with the same drug again. It seems increasingly clear that she was taken to the river, so you search there. And you discover something strange. A number of people either living or working on the riverbank tell investigators about an odd feeling that came over them yesterday around midday. A sudden thought of the waste disposal plant. At least a dozen people mention the same thing; you and Stella swear it must have been some of Jessamine‚Äôs magic. So you go look there. And find nothing. The disposal plant staff cooperate as best they can, but there‚Äôs no hint of anything nefarious in the building or around the docks below. Jez (who has apologized more than once that his nickname sounds so close to ‚ÄúJess‚Äù) even makes a sacrifice and goes diving to see if there‚Äôs anything in the river itself. Nothing but wastewater being flushed out through the grates and into the wastes. But on the morning of the third day, as you and Clarity are sweeping nearby buildings for anything that could possibly be useful, you find something. An unremarkable wooden garage whose owners could not be contacted for permission to search it. But unfortunately for them, you two (as Angels) don‚Äôt need permission. And there‚Äôs something about this garage that... ‚ÄúYara, do you feel that too? Mind,‚Äù she clarifies, letting you switch aspect. ‚ÄúHummm...‚Äù you murmur, sensing. ‚ÄúVery faint, but I swear that‚Äôs remnants of magic. Some sort of undirected blast that sank into the building too?‚Äù ‚ÄúAnd who do we know with a penchant for Mind?‚Äù ‚ÄúI‚Äôm going in,‚Äù you decide immediately. ‚ÄúBack me up.‚Äù ‚Äã
8:17 PM
‚ÄúNo you aren‚Äôt. Switch with me.‚Äù Clarity nudges you out of the way, her skin taking on a silvery sheen as she focuses on a Body transmutation. It does make sense for her to go first; her magic is much closer-range than the blasts you specialize in, and her transmutation lets her protect herself much better than you can. ‚ÄúVery well. Side door?‚Äù ‚ÄúToo obvious. Ready?‚Äù She positions herself by the main garage door, muscles in her arms noticeably expanding. You get the idea. ‚ÄúOh yes.‚Äù Clarity bursts through the garage door like a wrecking ball. You follow quickly, delicate frost forming on your arms as you prepare to freeze anything aggressive inside. ‚ÄúCarriage,‚Äù she notes, approaching it. ‚ÄúCorrupted.‚Äù You clear the rest of the room as Clarity rummages through the vehicle. ‚ÄúChains. Rags. More of that drug. Ah, a broken wheel; must be why it‚Äôs still here. Yara, you wanna call backup?‚Äù ‚ÄúJust a moment.‚Äù You‚Äôve spotted a locked door in the corner, crumbling apart the flash-frozen lock after a touch from your hand. The door creaks open to reveal a narrow staircase leading into a dark tunnel. Warm, humid air drifts from below, laden with an undercurrent of corruption. ‚ÄúYes. If this isn‚Äôt it, we need to deal with it anyway. But this is it. Has to be.‚Äù ‚ÄúI‚Äôm faster,‚Äù Clarity notes. ‚ÄúYou stay here and guard the place while I go get the others. Okay?‚Äù ‚ÄúSure. Be quick.‚Äù She eyes you suspiciously. ‚ÄúPromise you won‚Äôt go down there alone?‚Äù ‚ÄúDo I look like the kind of person who would partake in such ill-advised activities? Get going!‚Äù A brief smile. ‚ÄúI won‚Äôt answer that.‚Äù She gets going. ‚Äã
8:17 PM
Of course, you are exactly the kind of person to partake in such ill-advised activities. Or at least, you used to be. After graduating and working in the field for a while, you‚Äôve learned to take things a little more cautiously. Angels are very powerful, but the opponents you face are strong as well. Despite how much you want to rush in and incinerate whoever kidnapped Jessamine, it would do absolutely no good to bungle it and turn one rescue mission into two. So you restrain yourself to merely investigating the immediate area while you wait. There‚Äôs not much left here: the carriage, a spare coin that rolled under it, and some empty storage containers. The door has seen better days - almost looks like someone slammed against it - and... is that blood? You crouch to get a closer look. Dried, but you‚Äôve become uncomfortably familiar with the sight of the stuff by now. And you‚Äôve also learned a little trick you can do with Soul to see if the blood in question belonged to a human or... A faint resonance. This blood was spilled from an Angel. You scramble around, trying to work out if there‚Äôs enough on the floor to be deeply concerning, but there isn‚Äôt. She must have been injured, but not killed. As long as they didn‚Äôt clean up the rest of it... The doorway beckons. She could be just downstairs. Where are the others? No; you‚Äôre smarter than that. Stick to the plan. Backup is literally minutes away; you can wait that long. Clarity will return any moment. ... Zeke leads the charge, his massive starmetal blade glinting softly in the light emitted by your collective Souls. Clarity next, followed by you, Kamiya, Jez, and Stella to watch the rear. The close-combat specialists sandwiched around those with longer-range spells. Apparently Kamiya specializes in Body and physical transmutation, like Clarity, but wields it in a different way. One more suited to distance, you assume, but she‚Äôs been fairly tight-lipped about her abilities. ‚Äã
8:17 PM
You find your Mind treacherously wandering as endless stairs pass by. It‚Äôs odd, actually: the Archangel doesn‚Äôt keep her wings manifested. Permanent wings are the physical symbol of her divinity and rank, but even outside of such a cramped space, she usually keeps them hidden under an illusion similar to disguise magic. Is she not proud of them? Or perhaps it‚Äôs a humility thing, or a desire to stand out less. But if so, why grow the wings at all? The progression isn‚Äôt a required step for Angels - most never gain them. And it takes years of dedication to truly, physically create brand new Body parts capable of bearing your weight in flight. Even longer to imprint the wings into your Soul so they don‚Äôt decay over time. Why do all that just to keep them invisible? ... What if it‚Äôs the other way around? You don‚Äôt actually need wings to become an Archangel, so perhaps she‚Äôs just projecting them occasionally for effect and- You run out of stairs. Zeke extends a hand, cautiously holding the rest of you back as he eases open the lower door and peeks into a long hallway. You don‚Äôt see exactly what happens next, but there‚Äôs a loud shout. Zeke leaps into the hall, dashing to the right and cleaving something with his sword - you can hear the ringing chime as it rends through material. Clarity emerges behind him, shouting back something about battle, then it‚Äôs your turn. The staircase emerges haphazardly into an ancient brick tunnel, fully round and with a trickle of water down its center. Offshoots on either side have been sealed with grates or barred doors, and even from here you can spot a fuzzy, human-shaped mass of darkness lying on a table within the first one. A brief shiver; it resembles a shade, but more solid. What are they doing here? ‚Äã
8:17 PM
Zeke is chasing after two cloaked men to the right, one holding the broken halves of a spear - indicating what he cut. Clarity, meanwhile, is facing off against a trio of gnashing, howling wolf-like darkness creatures that have crashed out of another nearby offshoot. You step into the tunnel, igniting an ember of flame in one hand and aiming a blast to help Clarity. Kamiya was quite clear in her orders before descending - outranking Stella, who would otherwise make this call. You are to rescue any Angel or human victims down here, if possible. Everything else - and everyone else - burns. One of the men dies by Zeke‚Äôs starmetal sword, torso cleanly bisected by the peerlessly sharp blade. You are Angels. You swore an oath to protect the citizens of Nucarreo. Humans should never have to fear you. For Zeke, today seems to be an exception. And if you don‚Äôt find Jessamine safe and sound, today just might be an exception for you as well. ‚è™ - Be Jessamine, roughly a day and a half ago. ‚ñ∂Ô∏è - Be Jessamine, now. Mxblah 8/17/2024 2:26 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 151 Earlier... ‚ÄúJessamine...‚Äù ‚ÄúWha-?‚Äù A pause. You could have sworn someone just whispered your name, but no one‚Äôs here. ‚Äú...‚Äù You must be going crazy. You‚Äôve been trapped in this cell for hours now; on the surface, it‚Äôs probably well into evening or night. In that time, you‚Äôve experimented further with attempting to break out, casting various forms of Body magic and trying to break the bars, lock, or one of the walls. No success with the bars or lock (the metal is beyond your strength), but you have managed to chip away portions of mortar from the rear wall. Flowing water is audible behind it as well as in front, so you‚Äôre fairly confident you aren‚Äôt just drilling into solid earth. Where it goes exactly, you of course have no idea, but with enough time, you might be able to make a large enough hole to find out. Assuming you aren‚Äôt detected and stopped before then. But for some reason, no one has even come close to your cell. Maybe they‚Äôre scared of your Mind magic... or maybe they just haven‚Äôt decided what horrible torture to subject you to yet. Other cells have had visitors. More of the cloaked men from before have approached, unlocked, and dragged the prisoner inside away to some unknown fate through a passage above you. You‚Äôve tried to share senses or even just create a telepathic connection with anyone else in the room, but everyone is so far away and the heavy corruption makes it even harder. That‚Äôs another problem. For some reason, you don‚Äôt seem quite as sensitive to this corruption as normal, even though you can tell that objectively, it‚Äôs quite strong. But it is still affecting you, adding even more stress on top of the already very stressful situation. The whole room watches hatefully. ‚Äã
2:26 PM
Or perhaps more than just the room. Soft footsteps approach from the side, indicating that you‚Äôre finally about to get a visitor. You tense up, focusing on Mind as best you can. If you can manage it, your plan is to manipulate one of the cloaked men (who probably have the key) into just opening your cell. And from there... well, you‚Äôll figure it ou - oh God. A humanoid figure made of fuzzy black darkness steps around the corner, deep orange eyes burning like hot coals in the dim light. A shade. You instinctively scramble back against the rear wall before pulling yourself together and trying to at least look less scared and pathetic. M-maybe it will be as polite as the silver-eyed shade from your dreams...? Ergh... the corruption emanating from its Body is much harder to manage than just the ambient stuff; you feel lightly sick. You hope it didn‚Äôt come here just to stare. ‚ÄúSo it is true,‚Äù the shade hums. Its voice is noticeably smoother - more melodic - than its silver-eyed counterpart. ‚ÄúYou have cut your strings.‚Äù ‚Äú...‚Äù It seems to be waiting for a response. ‚Äú... Yes.‚Äù An inscrutable pause. The shade brushes its formless hand against the lock on your cell and it springs open. You hesitate, confused and wary. ‚ÄúIt will slay you where you stand should the need arise,‚Äù it warns. ‚ÄúAccompany.‚Äù Cautiously, you stand up. Even more cautiously, you take a few steps forward until you‚Äôre standing next to the creature. It feels like you‚Äôre standing right in front of a roaring fire - except cold instead of hot. Bearable, but only just. If this goes on too long... ‚Äã
2:27 PM
The shade leads you along a narrow path that winds its way up the side of the room, which - from your new vantage point - you can tell must be some sort of ancient cistern. Pipes (now transformed into cells) lead in and out from all angles, and the stone walls are stained with years upon years of water. Clearly, this place has been repurposed as a jail... though you don‚Äôt think Nucarreo‚Äôs water management system ever makes use of such massive structures. Is it older than the city itself? A relic from civilization before year zero? ‚ÄúIt hopes you have not been waiting unpleasantly. It was occupied determining the consequences of your arrival.‚Äù ‚Äú!‚Äù Does the shade know if your friends are searching for you? ... Is it capable of stopping them? ‚ÄúI-it wasn‚Äôt too bad...‚Äù you murmur unconvincingly. ‚ÄúEr... what - what are these c-consequences?‚Äù The shade looks at you briefly, expressionless. ‚ÄúHis puppets approach. It must move what it can. What it cannot must be removed.‚Äù You try to contain the brief surge of hope. ‚Äú...‚Äù ‚ÄúBut before that, it will make as much use of you as it can.‚Äù Ah. You‚Äôre now entering a smaller tunnel, round and with a trickle of water like an old sewer pipe. Offshoot pipes form branching rooms or occasionally entire tunnels, threatening a maze if you leave the main path. ‚ÄúAnd, er, what... is that use?‚Äù The shade‚Äôs corruption is really starting to hurt by now; you briefly wonder what it would do if you started crying right in front of it. ‚ÄúIt hears that the cut-string puppet‚Äôs senses are unusually keen. It will borrow them to carve new puppets from uncut blocks.‚Äù ‚ÄúEr-‚Äù That‚Äôs something you weren‚Äôt expecting, and you‚Äôre not sure what it means either. Especially... ‚ÄúMy s-senses?‚Äù ‚ÄúSoulcraft. It will be aided by the one who cut her strings.‚Äù A pause. ‚ÄúDoes the cut-string puppet not desire to aid? Only say the word and it will make use of her in another way.‚Äù ‚Äã
2:27 PM
‚Äú...‚Äù It‚Äôs asking for your... help? Or was that just a veiled threat? And why is it acting like its minions didn‚Äôt just kidnap you?! ‚ÄúW-What is this other way...?‚Äù ‚ÄúThe cut-string puppet will be reborn into a new form; one which never had strings. It believes your Mind is sufficient to survive the process.‚Äù It - that‚Äôs - it‚Äôs going to turn you into a shade! Can it even do that?! The... the ones without strings are shades, you know. So... you can‚Äôt let it even try. You just can‚Äôt! And if it seems to want your help as you are, then it must stand to gain more than if it... did that. So... m-maybe you can learn more about what these things are doing. What they want. ... Whether becoming a fallen Angel is even a bad thing. ‚ÄúTh-there‚Äôs no need for that...‚Äù you stammer, trying not to think about what being ‚Äúreborn‚Äù would entail. ‚ÄúGood. Such rebirth would waste your current state. Enter, then, and aid.‚Äù The shade leads you into a smallish offshoot from the main pipe, closing and locking the barred door behind you. The ‚Äúroom‚Äù is merely a blocky chamber of decrepit stone brick, stains on the walls showing that it had once been flooded to near the roof. There is a simple table standing incongruously in the center, upon which lies an unconscious human. The outfit and age seem to mark her as a former worker at the mill, probably transferred to the warehouse only to end up down here. An assortment of glyph-marked tools lurk menacingly on a smaller table to the side. The overall picture reminds you of an operating room; something you still find just a little terrifying, even after all these years. ‚ÄúStand,‚Äù the shade instructs you, gesturing to the opposite side of the table. There are a pair of thin metal rods lying on the table, connected by wires to somewhere beneath the ‚Äúpatient‚Äôs‚Äù Body. ‚ÄúGrasp,‚Äù it continues, indicating the rods. ‚ÄúH-hang on; what are you - what am I doing to her?‚Äù ‚Äã
2:27 PM
‚ÄúCarving a block into a beautiful puppet.‚Äù You blink; the shade is capable of considering something beautiful? ‚ÄúIt will only make improvements. Now, grasp.‚Äù ‚Äú...‚Äù You... doubt you have a choice, if you don‚Äôt want to get turned into a shade or just plain killed. But... maybe you have a choice about how you provide the ‚Äúaid‚Äù requested of you. - Do everything wrong. Get in the shade‚Äôs way as much as you can, without being obvious. - Don‚Äôt fight it, but don‚Äôt help it. Stay as neutral as possible; learn as much as you can about what it‚Äôs doing. - Assist as best you can. If nothing else, a flawless procedure will probably hurt the patient less than a botched one.
