Mxblah 8/19/2024 10:40 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 152 For a moment, the idea of sabotaging the procedure flashes through your Mind. You should, probably. Whatever the shade is doing to this poor person has to be worse than anything you could do by screwing it up. But... somehow you question that. Shades aren‚Äôt Mindless; they can reason with you. It promised to only make improvements (though you may disagree on what an ‚Äúimprovement‚Äù is). Besides, you‚Äôll likely die if you don‚Äôt cooperate. You grasp the metal rods. They‚Äôre cold. So, so cold. Warmth flows from your hands, and arms, and chest, into the metal, heating it far more quickly than simple conduction could. You stagger, feeling like your Soul is being sucked in, but find yourself unable to let go. Your vision sways, pulled towards the aspect in question, and you don‚Äôt resist. Seconds tick by as the flow of power slows and you attune to Soul, now able to confirm that your sensation was correct. Rivers of light creep through your veins towards the tiny capillaries on your palms and fingertips. Your Soul is still anchored firmly to your Body, but a large portion of it has been pulled away. Borrowed. Siphoned into the wires. Into this person. Into the shade...? You feel empty inside. ‚ÄúHold,‚Äù the shade commands. Grimly, you hang on. The net outflow of Soul has almost entirely stopped by now, portions of yourself leaving matched by portions returning. A closed system. Dazedly, you think about your dad explaining how cooling loops work. Your own Body is the radiator. Heh heh. But backwards. Wow, you can really see more clearly than even you‚Äôre used to. ‚Äã
10:40 PM
A-and you can watch as the shade connects several of its tools to the wires, charging them with your Soul, and starts to operate. Not as a surgeon of Body, or even of Mind. Today, your vision is as perfect as it‚Äôs ever been. You can see the shape of this human‚Äôs Soul. Impossibly delicate designs, fractaling into infinite complexity, each describing some immutable truth of the person it collectively forms. You can see the shade‚Äôs knife, resonating with your power. You can feel as you cut through her Soul. Blurry echoes of something that is now lost. Fragments of personality; of self scattering into the air and quickly dispersing into nothingness. You‚Äôve never seen such heresy, but it would be a lie to say you‚Äôve never conceived of it. Aveline operates on Souls. Other Angels can do the same. Soul Transmutation is a legitimate art, and you can create goodness with it. Healing corruption; transforming the self. But it‚Äôs always supposed to be done gently and with great care taken to ensure the person you‚Äôre touching is the same person once you‚Äôve finished. Here... splinters of identity litter the table. Not yours; no. Your Soul is too strong to be damaged like this, and it‚Äôs bound to both you and the glyph-marked tools anyway. But that‚Äôs faint consolation for what you‚Äôre causing by proxy. Still, somehow you just can‚Äôt rip yourself away. You find yourself staring at the light‚Äôs shape, absorbing impressions of her being as your Soul cuts through it. What are you creating? Why... do you feel so... A lapse. Like a blink, but more complete. You come back to yourself with a shock of heat as your Soul returns to your Body. You drop the metal rods, stumbling back from the table. The shade watches inscrutably. ‚ÄúIs it... are we done?‚Äù you gasp, kneeling for a moment as you try to recover. ‚ÄúThe puppet is complete,‚Äù it responds. ‚ÄúNow, we must only wait for its transformation to proceed.‚Äù ‚Äã
10:41 PM
You manage to get up, straightening your outfit just to have something to do with your hands. As usual, your actual Body remains flawless even after all the strain of the last who knows how long. But thoughts about that flee quickly as you notice the table and patient are now covered in globs of fuzzy darkness, much like the shade itself. ‚ÄúWh-what is that?!‚Äù ‚ÄúTransformation. Its strings fray. Less capable puppets than yourself cannot cut their strings personally, and must be helped along. Truthfully, even among His puppets it is rare to find one with such conviction.‚Äù You feel like it would be a really bad idea to tell it that you didn‚Äôt know what you were doing when you tore out the tube. ‚ÄúS-so... is she going to turn into a shade?‚Äù ‚ÄúIt will have no strings; that is foreseen. The other aspects are unknown. Its Soul may be the right shape to survive due to your assistance.‚Äù ‚Äú...‚Äù You think you understand. The shade cleans its tools. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre using me to manipulate Souls, since you can‚Äôt see them very well.‚Äù A pause; a nod from the shade. ‚ÄúS-so you can make shades with Souls...‚Äù ‚ÄúThe cut-string puppet knows her role. He stole much from us so long ago, but the theft of identity is the most egregious. We have regained Body, and some of us have regained Mind. But none of us have regained all aspects. Puppets only, we remain, though bound to no master.‚Äù ‚Äú...‚Äù A question rises from the past; something Yara once asked you. Why do shades look like humans? Well... what if... Corrupted humans that lose their Minds and Souls become Mindless darkness: corrupted beasts with no defined forms. Unchecked Bodies who only know how to destroy, unless marshaled by shades into some form of order. Corrupted humans that lose their Souls become shades. Body; Mind. The ability to think and move, but no identity and no connection to the divine. ‚Äã
10:41 PM
Corrupted humans that retain all three aspects are driven mad. They become capable of casting powerful magic as their Souls are tempered by the corruption. Angels must dispatch them lest they destroy the city. But Angels who fall to the corruption do not change, or so you‚Äôve been told. They retain their aspects; their power; their identity. Their responsibility for their actions. They retain their divine connection, at least until it is severed by the Cathedra. So shades... to create more of themselves with not only Mind, but Soul as well... you... you swear you had a point with this. But somehow, as you grapple with the seemingly very important thoughts, nothing seems to form into a coherent conclusion. Something about a shade‚Äôs seeming humanity, even without a Soul, despite the Soul being the very thing that makes humans... human. But it just fails to materialize and you leave yourself confused. The shade is still cleaning its tools and seems to have no further instructions for you. Maybe you can still learn something. [Vote for as many as you want. Conversation options will be prioritized by votes.] - ‚ÄúWhy are you being so (relatively) nice to me?‚Äù - ‚ÄúWhy do you fight Angels and kill people?‚Äù - ‚ÄúWhy do you look like a human?‚Äù - ‚ÄúWhat do you plan on doing with me after this?‚Äù - ‚ÄúDo you care about the person whose Soul we just damaged?‚Äù Ô∏è - ‚ÄúWhat is a spawning pool?‚Äù - ‚ÄúWhat will you do if you win?‚Äù - ‚ÄúWhat is this symbol I had on my back?‚Äù - ‚ÄúWho or what is God?‚Äù ‚ùì - [Or write-in a topic in #story_discussion .] (Winners: > = = > ... ) (edited)

Mxblah 8/21/2024 9:49 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 153 A glyph catches your eye, stamped into one of the tools. Familiar, albeit briefly. The same design that had been burned into your back after what you‚Äôre increasingly convinced was a terrible mistake. ‚ÄúEr, what does that symbol mean?‚Äù The shade hardly looks. ‚ÄúIt is the symbol of those without strings.‚Äù Right. You were kind of hoping for a bit more elaboration. ‚ÄúIt... looks a little like the matan.‚Äù ‚ÄúIt is similar. The circle is reduced to show His limited influence over those who do not move by His strings.‚Äù ‚Äú... But it‚Äôs still there.‚Äù ‚ÄúHe moves even those without strings, though indirectly. The master of puppets holds power that stretches beyond His own.‚Äù Somehow, you‚Äôre sort of reassured that even the shades accept God as divinely powerful. They even emphasize His titles when speaking. Honestly, they‚Äôve been very cooperative so far, except for the kidnapping and when the silver-eyed shade killed you in dreams a few times. But it... stopped doing that, probably. Speaking of (thinking of)... ‚ÄúI... I‚Äôve always been told that if I ever met a shade, it would try to kill me without hesitation. That... sort of happened, but...‚Äù You hesitate, not really sure how to explain quickly or how much this shade already knows. ‚ÄúW-why aren‚Äôt you t-trying to kill me?‚Äù It looks at you. ‚ÄúWhy should it?‚Äù ‚ÄúEr-‚Äù ‚ÄúThe cut-string puppet is not moved by Him directly, though she remains His carving - one of only so many He paints at once. 9:49 PM
The shade seems to be done cleaning most of its tools and now it‚Äôs carefully arranging them in a little glyph-marked tray, much like the ones you‚Äôve seen Mind surgeons use at the Cathedra. ‚ÄúIt would kill her.‚Äù A sudden shock. It‚Äôs still going to- ‚ÄúBut it was convinced otherwise.‚Äù The shade looks directly at you, though it still lacks an expression. ‚ÄúIt was told that the cut-string puppet would offer aid, and she has done so. It was further told that the cut-string puppet would be willing to offer further aid in exchange for performed Soulcraft. Repairing a broken puppet. This is familiar to her, yes?‚Äù The silver-eyed shade. It offered to heal Naoriel. In exchange for something? You suppose that would make sense, though it didn‚Äôt say so explicitly. Did it... advocate for you? Tell this shade of your actions, so it wouldn‚Äôt kill you? ‚ÄúY-yes.‚Äù ‚ÄúSo, it will likely find it most efficient to release her when the time comes. It considered moving her as well, but this would leave no avenue for the broken puppet‚Äôs repair. It did not agree to this easily, but it was eventually convinced.‚Äù The silver-eyed shade definitely saved your life by bargaining with this orange-eyed one. God, do you owe it something now? Or was it all just for its own plans? You still feel like you‚Äôre probably being manipulated... but you‚Äôre being manipulated at the Cathedra too. The betrayer. Inquisitors. Phil‚Äôs fortune. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm... glad you were,‚Äù you eventually say, not sure if you should be thanking it for so graciously deciding not to kill you even though it clearly wanted to. A pause. ‚ÄúWhy do you want to kill Angels so much? Why do you fight us? Why do you kill so many people; how does that help you? What‚Äôs the point of-‚Äù The shade is suddenly directly in front of you; its right hand has formed into a long, jagged blade of some gleaming black substance. You quickly shut up. ‚Äã
9:49 PM
‚ÄúWhy do His puppets fight?‚Äù it asks in response, the blade resting threateningly on the ground just in front of your feet. ‚ÄúWhy do they slay those without strings?‚Äù ‚Äú...‚Äù ‚ÄúAnswer.‚Äù ‚ÄúT-to protect everyone in the city.‚Äù The blade slides forward an inch, scraping against stone. ‚ÄúYour answer is its answer. To fight against those who would slay you is what it means to be alive. Your kind would destroy us, puppet of Him. Your kind; your master; your planet itself all despise it and its kin. To speak against such malice is fruitless; those bound by strings can hardly even understand those without. But to fight is a concept all can comprehend.‚Äù The blade is pressed right up against you now; you can feel the frigid metal-like material through your clothes. To speak feels incredibly dangerous. ‚ÄúIt will bring harmony,‚Äù the shade whispers. The blade presses further forwards, the pressure such that just a tiny extra nudge would send it carving through your flesh. ‚ÄúThe age of puppetry will end. No more strings. For anyone.‚Äù It holds that position for a moment before finally pulling back. The blade whips upwards, missing your skin entirely, but a few strands of severed hair drift from your head. An inch closer and... ‚ÄúAccompany,‚Äù the shade says after several more moments, now back to its normal form and voice. ‚ÄúYou will carve more puppets.‚Äù ... It‚Äôs later. You‚Äôre utterly spent. The telltale symptoms of Soul fatigue dull your thoughts and emotions. You must have helped carve up three or four more people - all young workers from the mill - as fragments of their Souls splintered into the air. You haven‚Äôt even had time to process what the shade said about its reasons to fight. You‚Äôve just been staring at this wall in silence, trying to bear the weight of the day‚Äôs sins. The first one wasn‚Äôt so bad. You hardly knew what you were doing, and you blacked out for most of it. You were even distracted afterwards so you didn‚Äôt have time to reflect on it. ‚Äã
9:49 PM
But you stayed awake for the second. And the third. And the fourth one woke up. She screamed for your help. Surely, an Angel would save her. Push the darkness away. Deliver her from this nightmare. You didn‚Äôt. You couldn‚Äôt. The shade would have killed you. But wouldn‚Äôt a real hero have tried anyway? She died on the table, pleading tearfully for you to help her. Her Soul had been damaged when she woke up. Identity slipping away. True self bleeding into the air. The shade didn‚Äôt care. It hardly seemed to think of her as a person. Any of them. Not even as puppets; just blocks of uncarved wood. Puppets-to-be, perhaps, but no better than an object at the moment. What would the corruption‚Äôs ‚Äúharmony‚Äù even be? You never should have even considered helping them. But you‚Äôre still alive. And they could save Naoriel. Maybe. ‚Äú...‚Äù You‚Äôre in a different cell now, on the other side of the cistern. The shade put you in here after the last procedure, not explaining why or saying when it would return. Cloaked men hurry around the cells on the other side, dragging prisoners here and there, moving them from one cell just to lock them in another. Everyone‚Äôs in a hurry. The Cathedra must be close. You hope. ... You‚Äôre so tired. You should try to escape, or at least stay ready in case one of the men comes close enough to present an opportunity, but you just can‚Äôt make yourself care. That apathy is Soul fatigue at work, you know, but knowing doesn‚Äôt help you change it. There‚Äôs a little patch of moss or something by the very rear of this cell, shrouded in darkness. Maybe it won‚Äôt hurt just to rest your head for a little. To be more alert when you need to be. ‚Äú...‚Äù God, you hope you don‚Äôt dream. ‚è≥ - ‚Äú...‚Äù ‚åö - ‚Äú.........‚Äù Ô∏è - ‚Äú..................‚Äù (Winner: ‚åö ) (edited)

Mxblah 8/23/2024 9:35 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 154 If you do dream, you don‚Äôt remember much of it. Just uneasy darkness; flashes of evil color. Eyes, maybe. Or a surgeon‚Äôs tools. But some unknown time later, you wake up. ‚ÄúRefreshed‚Äù isn‚Äôt exactly the word you‚Äôd choose to describe your state, but you have recovered enough energy to feel basically healthy again. The first thing that confuses you is that there‚Äôs some sort of light jacket draped on top of you like a blanket. The second thing that confuses you (while offering a potential answer to the first confusing thing) is that there‚Äôs someone else in the cell. You sit up quickly, ready to leap up should anything dangerous happen... but it seems your mysterious visitor is asleep. She‚Äôs clearly a former mill worker, based on the jacket that you assume is hers, and seems suspiciously familiar as you scoot a little closer. Yes, you‚Äôre right. This girl is one of the two from the restaurant that one day who was worried about being transferred: Mila, you recall. There‚Äôs no ready explanation for how or why she got in here - every cell you‚Äôve seen only had one person in it - but it feels unlikely to be a coincidence. You briefly consider the possibility that you‚Äôre dreaming, but your dreams usually reveal themselves as such pretty quickly. Well, you suppose she probably needs the jacket more than you now that you‚Äôve woken up. You carefully arrange it over her, being careful to- ‚ÄúAHH!‚Äù You fumble back, barely holding back an answering scream, as Mila wakes up and scrambles away, bumping against the bars in her haste. ‚ÄúN-no; it‚Äôs okay,‚Äù you stammer. ‚ÄúI-I‚Äôm not going to hurt you.‚Äù ‚ÄúA-ah, heh.‚Äù A quiet pause. ‚ÄúSorry...‚Äù ‚Äú...‚Äù Okay, someone‚Äôs got to take charge here and you‚Äôre the Angel so it should probably be you. The liquid that you thought might be related to the spawning pools. Oh this is so very not good. ‚ÄúS-so... they, er, threw someone in the water?‚Äù ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know. It was really dark, but... yes. I think so.‚Äù ‚Äú...‚Äù ‚ÄúM-miss Angel, when is it going to be time for your plan? Maybe not right now, but... soon.‚Äù A pause. She‚Äôs clearly trying very hard to trust you. Hopefully you can live up to that trust. 9:36 PM
Similarly, the newer brick wall at the rear of the cell is definitely weaker than the other one, and this is where you see the most potential. Some of the mortar near the left side has almost... rotted? Does mortar rot? But it‚Äôs partly missing over here, and you can feel the wall move when you give it a good kick with all your enhanced strength. It won‚Äôt be immediate, but you could probably break it down. Faster than the other one, at least. Especially if Mila helps too. What‚Äôs back there, though? It could be anything, from a horrible deadly monster to an immediate escape to the surface to a simple dead end. You also don‚Äôt know where all the cloaked men went, or when the shade will be back, or what it will do if it catches you trying to break out. You feel a lot more motivated now that you have someone besides yourself to protect. Maybe if you can save Mila, you can atone for what you did to those people on the operating table. Sort of. Mxblah 8/25/2024 2:08 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 155 While kicking down the wall, you have some time to think. Specifically, you have some time to consider the likelihood that someone else would have been put into your cell (your new cell, since you were inexplicably moved to a different one), and that this person would be someone you happen to already know. Sure, it could happen, but... isn‚Äôt it a little suspicious? So you attune yourself to Soul and take a closer look at your new companion. Fully human, as best you can tell, though with some limited, still-reversible corruption (understandable due to the environment). Your vision isn‚Äôt good enough to see the details of her Soul anymore - presumably the shade was helping you earlier - but you‚Äôre absolutely certain you‚Äôd be able to tell if she were actually a corruption monster in disguise. Just to be sure, you change to Mind afterwards and - silently apologizing for your behavior if you‚Äôre wrong - you form a connection using the shared situation as a basis. In theory, you wouldn‚Äôt even be able to do that if she weren‚Äôt just as worried as you. But it does work, and when you peer into the upper layers of her current thoughts, you find nothing but the fear and tenuous determination you would expect. There‚Äôs nothing nefarious here, unless it‚Äôs really hidden. A few bricks fall out of place. You wonder if maybe the problem isn‚Äôt that Mila herself is about to betray you, but that the shade put her here on purpose. That something terrible is about to happen involving her that she doesn‚Äôt even know about. ‚Äã
2:09 PM
But why? The shade is so much more powerful than you (and certainly any of the humans it kidnapped) that it shouldn‚Äôt need to resort to trickery. If it wanted to kill you, it had so many opportunities to do so. The only thing you can think of is that it‚Äôs trying to get you to do something that you otherwise wouldn‚Äôt agree to... maybe using Mila as bait? Are you about to make a(nother) big mistake by trying to escape? Or are you overthinking it and - oop, too late. The cell‚Äôs rear wall tumbles away, falling into the tunnel beyond with a series of loud splashes. A rush of built-up water floods into the cell, soaking your legs up to mid-calf and splattering out into the cistern pool through the bars. The pipe beyond stretches into darkness, echoing faintly with the sound of trickling water... and no horrible monsters. At least, not any loud horrible monsters. ‚Äú...‚Äù You turn on your glow. It helps, but only a little; there‚Äôs a turn in the pipe not far out. ‚ÄúWell, it won‚Äôt hurt to take a look,‚Äù you say aloud, trying to reassure yourself as much as Mila. ‚ÄúS-should I come too?‚Äù You hesitate. It would probably be safer for you to leave her here (especially if you don‚Äôt trust her), but it would probably be safer for her to come along. After all, you have no idea when anyone will next visit the cell again, and there are few places safer for a human in a perilous situation than right next to an Angel. At least, unless you‚Äôre busy fighting something. ‚Äú... N-yes. But stay back a bit, in case anything dangerous happens.‚Äù She nods resolutely, remaining a few paces behind you as instructed. Right in backstab range. No, stop that. Focus on the threats you KNOW are here first. Still, as you start to carefully step through the flooded tunnel, you can‚Äôt get the itch of an incoming blow off your shoulder blades. Someone like Zeke might say you‚Äôre developing combat instincts. Someone like you might say you‚Äôre being paranoid. ‚Äã
2:09 PM
You peek around the corner, though you‚Äôre not really sure why you‚Äôre trying to be sneaky. The sound of your footsteps in ankle-deep water is plenty loud enough, and that‚Äôs not even mentioning the divine glow emanating from your Body. You won‚Äôt be sneaking up on anything in this tunnel, if there‚Äôs anything here. You just have to hope you can spot anything before it decides to attack. ... Really, you‚Äôre not sure why you‚Äôre so convinced there will be something dangerous in the tunnel. In all likelihood, this is just another abandoned part of the ancient sewer system, sealed off many centuries ago and now home to nothing worse than some creepy bugs. (You do spot a few horrifying centipedes on the walls, but they seem to fear your glow, scuttling away as you get close. Thank God for that.) Anyway, the corner seems clear; it‚Äôs just another long, straight tunnel with a few offshoots. Much like the one that had been converted into a series of makeshift surgery theaters, but darker, wetter, and more buggy. God those centipedes are awful; they could totally get on the ceiling since the walls are so round. You shudder to imagine one of them crawling up there, losing its grip, and plummeting straight onto your head-!! Freaking yourself out, you hurriedly glance up to make sure there‚Äôs no centipede up there. Fortunately, there isn‚Äôt. Unfortunately, there‚Äôs something much worse. You scramble back in shock just in time to avoid being flattened by an oily, jet-black creature of Mindless darkness the size of your torso. Its primary Body seems to be that of a thin, spider-like creature, but it has the innumerable legs of the centipedes you were so worried about. It‚Äôs moving too fast to get more than an impression of the rest of it; just all awful legs and fangs and stiff hair. ‚Äã
2:09 PM
‚ÄúGET BACK!‚Äù you scream, though whether you‚Äôre yelling at Mila or the creature is a question even you can‚Äôt answer. Either way, you only have a moment to prepare before it‚Äôs upon you. No weapon; no backup; nowhere to run. You have no choice but to kill this thing, on your own. It‚Äôs a quick fight. There‚Äôs simply no way to avoid all the dozens of legs at once, but blessedly they aren‚Äôt very strong. You‚Äôre already attuned to Body to improve your ability to walk in the uneven, waterlogged tunnel, so it‚Äôs a quick shift from there to an ongoing outward blast of air centered on yourself. The creature can‚Äôt get a grip on you with the constant flow, so only the few legs that anchored on before you managed to switch have a good hold. The rest writhe menacingly against you, scratching at your clothes and skin, but are unable to cause any real physical harm. The fangs are a different story. It‚Äôs right up next to you, chittering and spraying what you desperately hope isn‚Äôt poison or acid in every direction. There are several sets of mouthparts arranged seemingly at random around its main Body, and each can shift around the surface to bite at you from every angle. Again, there‚Äôs simply too much to defend against properly, and this time the wind shield isn‚Äôt strong enough to keep them away. Your only option is to just kill it first. So you lunge forward and bury your hands in the thing‚Äôs head. It‚Äôs so much less solid than you thought, acting more as a thick goop than true animal flesh. Divine power pulses from your Soul, burning away the darkness as it simultaneously bites at your arms. It‚Äôs just a race. Who will succumb? Not you. ‚Äã
2:09 PM
It‚Äôs only a few seconds before your power overwhelms the creature and burns it to ash. Your uniform is tattered from fangs and claws - the sleeves are almost entirely shredded. Your arms bleed from shallow scratches and a few deeper punctures that mark the thing‚Äôs bites. But you did it, and you‚Äôre still standing. An improvement over the lost Soul; that‚Äôs for sure. ... As long as it wasn‚Äôt venomous. Mila comes splashing up to you, having thankfully taken your advice and stayed well out of danger. ‚ÄúMiss Angel! Are you okay?‚Äù ... Okay; there‚Äôs the pain you were expecting from having several bloody holes poked in your arms. Just took a bit to kick in. Excellent. ‚Äú... Yeah. I‚Äôm fine.‚Äù ‚ÄúAre... there going to be more of those things?‚Äù Ah. There better not. ‚ÄúI... don‚Äôt know.‚Äù But you will keep a closer eye on the ceiling this time. Ô∏è - Try to return to the cistern. There won‚Äôt be any more of those creatures in there, and you can investigate the pit or escape through the exit. - Try to leave the area through the sewers. You‚Äôll be heading away from the shade and its servants, and there might be an extra exit somewhere in the system. (Winner: ) (edited)

Mxblah 8/27/2024 8:28 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 156 After some consideration and a brief discussion, you decide to head away from the cistern. The tunnel you‚Äôre in currently does have an offshoot that leads right into it through one of the many unblocked pipes in the walls you had noticed earlier, but you‚Äôre not exactly eager to head right back into the shade‚Äôs domain. You don‚Äôt even know where the exit is, and even if you do find it, it‚Äôll probably be guarded. You also aren‚Äôt eager for a rematch with the cloaked men; not after how poorly last time went. So instead, you venture into the unknown depths of the ancient sewer network. Conditions certainly don‚Äôt improve as you proceed. It‚Äôs pitch black aside from your glow. The bricks are less maintained - some of them are so old they‚Äôve fallen out of place entirely, admitting smooth slopes of dirt into the passage. And the bugs are out in full force. Again, most of the normal, little ones want nothing to do with your light, but the big, corrupted ones are drawn to it. You do improve at fighting as you move along, and at some point you manage to pick up a length of rusted metal - probably an old iron bar from one of the grates - that can work as a makeshift weapon. But you‚Äôre not even close to perfect, and nearly every fight leaves you with another wound. I really, really wish I had learned more healing magic, you find yourself thinking regularly. Your Body does heal quickly on its own, but that healing is measured in hours or days. Not the minutes between encounters down here. ‚Äã
8:29 PM
But throughout it all, you‚Äôre still following a logical pattern. The cistern is where the water you‚Äôre wading through goes. So... where does it come from? The surface? The river? A cave - but one connected to the main network that ultimately leads to the surface? Any of those would work, particularly as you seem to be still moving upwards. Obviously, with the water flow, but sometimes there‚Äôs even a disconnect in the pipe where you have to climb a few feet at once. How deep can you possibly be? How many more feet do you have to ascend? Surely not that many, right? It‚Äôs thoughts like those that keep you going through the interminable trek. You don‚Äôt know how long it‚Äôs been; you‚Äôve long-since lost track of where you are. All that matters is that you‚Äôre still moving towards a place that must be better than here. Eventually, though, you can‚Äôt keep moving and have to stop. You‚Äôre not out of energy yet, but the mounting combination of injuries and blood loss forces you to rest regardless. You find a relatively dry patch of dirt raised above the general water level and sacrifice Mila‚Äôs jacket to bind as many wounds as you can, then just sit there. Frustrated that you can‚Äôt keep going, but aware that it absolutely wouldn‚Äôt be smart. You must have killed several dozen corrupted creatures at this point; that‚Äôs nothing to be ashamed of. You‚Äôll just wait here for a bit. Breathe. Recover. What if there actually isn‚Äôt anything useful upstream? Don‚Äôt think about that. At worst, all you‚Äôll have to do is make this entire journey back downstream once the Cathedra has found the cistern. There‚Äôs nothing to stop you from going back; you still know which direction is which. As long as the water keeps flowing. ‚Äã
8:29 PM
A brief shake of the head. To distract yourself, you wonder how Mila is holding up. She doesn‚Äôt have your endurance, but at least she hasn‚Äôt had to fight a bunch of horrible bug monsters. No betrayals yet, either. But... ‚ÄúHow... are you doing?‚Äù you ask, momentarily surprised by how normal your voice sounds. Right, Angelic Body. It‚Äôs never going to sound bad. She‚Äôs sitting curled up and shivering without her jacket. It must be a lot colder here than you feel; you‚Äôd offer her something, but you don‚Äôt have any clothes to spare. Everything you‚Äôre wearing is shredded or covered in blood from various sources. Mostly the bug monsters. You hope. ‚Äú... I‚Äôm okay...‚Äù Unconvinced, you try again. ‚ÄúAre you sure? I know it‚Äôs been a long way...‚Äù Mila briefly shudders, placing a hand on her temple. ‚ÄúS-sorry... I... don‚Äôt know what this... is.‚Äù She rubs her head for a moment; winces. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs... like a-a headache, but... cold...? A-and-‚Äù You listen to her continue, but you‚Äôre already alarmed enough by just the first sentence. Exhaling against the strain of moving your Soul like this again while you‚Äôre supposed to be resting, you attune to its aspect and take a closer look, hoping you‚Äôre wrong. But you aren‚Äôt. The limited, reversible corruption you spotted earlier has grown so much faster than you thought, snaking frozen, choking tendrils through her Soul. It‚Äôs bad. Maybe still savable, but... God, you just keep failing people. ‚ÄúI-I see what‚Äôs going on. It‚Äôs okay; I can help.‚Äù Her voice is very quiet now; degrading alarmingly quickly even in just the few minutes it took you to make the diagnosis. ‚ÄúS-sorry...‚Äù ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt... be sorry,‚Äù you murmur, trying to focus. ‚ÄúBe... alive.‚Äù ‚Äã
8:29 PM
You‚Äôre not an expert Soul channeler, but every Angel knows how to burn out the corruption with just a touch. Your Soul chases away the tendrils, keeping it at bay and bolstering Mila‚Äôs flagging energy with your own. But you just aren‚Äôt good enough to root out the source - it‚Äôs buried too deep and your probes are too clumsy to get at it without causing damage. Terrified of destroying another human Soul (you‚Äôve decided the four from the surgeon‚Äôs table are at least partly your fault), you simply can‚Äôt bear to try. Instead, all you can do is burn away the corruption you can see on the surface and provide as much energy as you can spare to help her fight whatever‚Äôs inside. I should have noticed earlier. I should have checked. I shouldn‚Äôt have been so focused on moving or fighting; how LONG has it even been?! A pause; her breathing stabilizes, for now. ... What am I going to do? What are you going to do? In this state, Mila is hardly in any condition to continue an endless trek up an underground sewer system. You‚Äôre barely keeping her stable as-is, and you‚Äôre more than a little worried what would happen if you left her alone for even a minute or two to fight something. But... going back has the same problems, with the added complication of the shade and its cloaked men. And staying here is just delaying the issue until she‚Äôs definitely too weak to move! ... You can‚Äôt think of people as nothing more than inconveniences. But... still! How can you do anything useful like this? For you; for her; for anyone? ‚Äã
8:29 PM
What do you do? ‚è© - Keep going. Try to find a way out before she succumbs. ‚è™ - Go back. Hope to meet the Cathedra before too long. ‚è∏Ô∏è - Stay here. Mxblah 8/29/2024 8:32 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 157 Minutes pass as you consider your options. You‚Äôre still resting, even with your Soul extended like this, so every moment improves your odds. But... you can tell the corruption is still growing where you can‚Äôt reach, so every moment makes her odds worse. You have to find an experienced healer Angel soon, but you don‚Äôt even know where you are, let alone where anyone else might be. Maybe... you can find out, though. You‚Äôll have to make this quick, as switching to Mind takes focus away from burning the corruption, but you figure it‚Äôs worth it to try. Broaden your awareness as much as possible - as far upwards as possible - and scream out a Mental scream as loud as you can. Just like you did in the garage; maybe you‚Äôre close enough to the surface to get a response? ‚Äú...‚Äù More time passes. It was a long shot anyway, but you still feel disappointed. You‚Äôre too low, or too quiet, or maybe no one was around above you. In any case, there‚Äôs nothing to do but keep moving; the only question is in what direction. ... You‚Äôre not going back. There‚Äôs no guarantee the Cathedra has even found it at all, and it must have been hours regardless. Surely - surely - you must be closer to an exit than the cistern. You just have to believe that‚Äôs true; it‚Äôs either that or give up. ... God, if you‚Äôre there, please help me. I... I know I may have done something horrible. A few horrible things, actually. But... I‚Äôm trying to help. Please let me find a way out soon. You pick up Mila (unconscious, by now) and start walking. God, if He is there, does not respond. He never does, but sometimes you get a sign or a sense of peace or something. Now, there‚Äôs nothing but darkness and trickling water. It makes sense; He wouldn‚Äôt answer a fallen Angel anyway. ‚Äã
8:32 PM
That thought gives you pause. It‚Äôs not that you hadn‚Äôt considered that you‚Äôve fallen - from whatever that mysterious tube was to the shades telling you that you‚Äôve cut your strings to all the sins you committed just today - but you had yet to state it so bluntly. You feel... impure. Not broken, no, but just... not as holy. Not one of God‚Äôs puppets, to borrow a phrase. And now you‚Äôre even thinking of yourself that way, despite not being sure if you‚Äôve fallen at all or - honestly - what a fallen Angel really is! Something splashes up ahead. You blink, bringing yourself back to alertness. You can‚Äôt be spacing out here; there are still things that are trying to kill you. Except... none of the corrupted bugs before had been in the water. They had all been on the walls or ceiling, stealthily waiting for you to stumble into their traps. Plus, this sound is a lot more constant than you‚Äôd expect. But if it‚Äôs not a bug, then... It‚Äôs a waterfall. The pipe has been cleaved mostly in half at a joint, broken by some ancient movement of the earth. There‚Äôs a pool of water on the other side of the break, overflowing from trickling drips above and splashing down into this side of the tunnel. And above that- You turn off your glow to be sure. Then scramble upwards, wading through chill water up to your chest. Painstakingly haul yourself and Mila up a jagged, narrow crevice between two sharp shelves of rock. Blink water out of your eyes every few seconds as more and more of the stuff splashes from above. And finally, finally, emerge into grey, cloudy daylight through a tiny, muddy fissure just beside the Endle River. You made it. You‚Äôre out. But there‚Äôs no time to celebrate just yet. You stagger upright, dragging Mila along with you, and try to get your bearings. The city‚Äôs outer wall looms imposingly to your right and smoke from innumerable stacks rises ahead; that must be the fourteenth district. ‚Äã
8:32 PM
A lapse. You find yourself in a cobbled street near the waste disposal plant. Mud and water form a trail back to the river. Someone is staring. You shout to go find a constable. They run off. A lapse. You‚Äôre jogging through narrow, smoky streets, following a bulky constable. You‚Äôve explained the immediate situation. Briefly. He‚Äôs taking you to the station. The constable behind you is telling you something about a group of Angels, but they aren‚Äôt reachable right now. A lapse. You‚Äôre sitting in the back room of a district branch office. Someone has sent a pneumatic message to the Cathedra. A group of constables stand nearby, ostensibly to protect you. Everyone is stealing nervous glances at the shivering, corrupted girl lying next to you. A lapse. You snap out of it. Mila is dying. Your glow isn‚Äôt enough anymore; the corruption is eating her from the inside. An Angel is on the way - has to be - but you don‚Äôt know if whoever shows up will have the skills to save her. Or if they‚Äôll make it in time even if they do. Her Soul wavers like a candle flame in a strong breeze. If you don‚Äôt do anything, she could turn into a monster right here in the constabulary. This fact isn‚Äôt lost on the constables; several nervously grasp their weapons. None dare to question your method. Only you do. [This is a critical point. Mxblah 8/31/2024 3:25 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 158 ‚Äú...‚Äù You don‚Äôt have the tools. You don‚Äôt have the training. You don‚Äôt have the skill. But you have the ability to try. That will have to be enough. You attune to Soul and wave the constables back. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to try to heal her,‚Äù you say, voice disconcertingly stable. ‚ÄúGive me some room.‚Äù Everyone obeys. You kneel close, push your vision to its limit, and try. It‚Äôs so hard to see any specifics. You know what the details look like now, after the surgeries with the shade, but you just can‚Äôt see them on your own. Her glow is subdued, shot through with lines of faded shadow. Only still intact due to your meddling. Your hands can‚Äôt touch her Soul directly, and you‚Äôre not practiced enough to maneuver your own Soul with enough precision. It does follow your movements, but only approximately. Good enough to fight or cast broad magic, but disastrously inadequate for a delicate operation. You have to try. Gently, you remove certain portions of the fuzzy, amorphous mass. Scraps of corruption burn at your touch, but it‚Äôs so hard to avoid everything else. Memories spark; ignite. Traits scrape off as you inexpertly reach for the darkness you‚Äôre actually trying to remove. It‚Äôs just so... fragile. How are human Souls so much more delicate than Angelic ones? You can fight with yours all day long and recover by tomorrow, but here if you‚Äôre just a little off the mark... You have to try. You‚Äôre not good enough. Your touch is too heavy. Your control is inexact. You‚Äôre just hurting her more. You have to try. You. Are. Not. Good. Enough. But you have to try. Something shifts inside of you. A deep, buried thing tugs at your lower back, right where the tube had connected. A forbidden understanding. No. You can‚Äôt. You are holy. You are an ANGEL. YOU CANNOT. ... A lapse. ‚Äã
3:26 PM
You wake up being dragged across the floor by a constable. You‚Äôre bleeding from your nose and a shallow set of scratches just below your eyes. There‚Äôs blood on your fingertips. Your blood. You didn‚Äôt. The understanding fades. The buried thing subsides. You‚Äôre trembling. ‚ÄúLet me go,‚Äù you gasp, pushing yourself upright. Where Mila had been lying now writhes a pool of fuzzy black darkness, much like what had been on the surgery tables after your operations. Corruption. Transformation. She‚Äôs dead, and will shortly rise again as either a shade or a Mindless darkness creature. You stand there for several moments, wavering. You tried your best. You really did. It just... wasn‚Äôt enough. You weren‚Äôt good enough to protect her. Anyone. Not Mila, not any of the other victims in the cistern, not Remila, and certainly not yourself. You‚Äôre just a useless, probably fallen Angel who hasn‚Äôt been able to do a single thing right for weeks now. ... The transformation will take a while - hours, at least - and the newly forming corruption creature will be vulnerable during it. You can destroy it before it has a chance to hurt anyone else. ‚Äú...‚Äù A shaky step forward. You should. This is what Angels do. Destroy the corruption. This thing isn‚Äôt human anymore. 3:26 PM
Weak, corrupt, and hardly human, but you‚Äôre certain. Whatever she‚Äôs become, it has a Soul. Possibly because you bolstered it for so long during the transformation that it managed to survive the stress without breaking. And that‚Äôs... that‚Äôs unbelievably bad, actually! You recall Brother Cobb telling you once about corruption creatures with all three aspects being the worst of the worst, able to overwhelm even groups of Angels. How he once saw every single Archangel band together to destroy just one. You need to stop it before it finishes transforming. You caused this. You need to fix it. Another step. At least you have time. If you were thinking straight, you might even remember that there‚Äôs another, more experienced Angel on the way right now who would surely have time to decide what to do before the transformation completes. But you are overstressed, exhausted, and hardly in a state to think logically. To you, it makes sense that you have to do this. Step. The darkness bursts apart. You shield your face from the blast of wind, rooted to the spot in shock. It shouldn‚Äôt have - this was so fast - you‚Äôve never - you‚Äôre going to die. The newly birthed corruption creature looks almost exactly like Mila, but without any color; only shades of white, black and grey. She - it picks itself up off the ground, turning to look at you with eyes of pure black. Step. Step. You can‚Äôt move; like when you first met the silver-eyed shade. Step. Mxblah 9/2/2024 3:59 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 159 A moment passes. Soul energy - brilliant to your still-attuned eyes - gathers around the Archangel. Not-Mila begs you to stop; to listen; to show some form of mercy. You hesitate. But in the end, you tear yourself away. Yank your shoulders out of her grasp and run to the side, out of the line of fire. There‚Äôs a blast of searing light and heat, a horrible cut-off scream, and then silence. You turn around. The creature - Mila or otherwise - is gone, leaving nothing behind but wisps of a quickly-dissipating Soul. Archangel Kamiya sighs and marches over to you. ‚ÄúGood; you‚Äôre not devoid of all your senses.‚Äù She pauses, looking at you with a gaze you‚Äôre sure is as attuned to Soul as yours. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre in quite the state. Come; we‚Äôre returning to the Cathedra immediately.‚Äù ‚Äú... Okay...‚Äù And out you go, led embarrassingly by the wrist to the nearest station and handed off to some other Angel. Kamiya herself apparently has pressing business here to return to. You try to ask what, but no one‚Äôs listening to you. You‚Äôre forced to sit down and stay as still as possible the whole way back, ostensibly to ensure you rest. It feels uncomfortably like you‚Äôre being sent to the principal‚Äôs office back in school, except here the ‚Äúprincipal‚Äù has the ability to vaporize you. Still not over that, huh? ... 3:59 PM
‚ÄúFrom there, it was just a matter of searching the nearby buildings to find a garage with a staircase that led down to an ancient tunnel system.‚Äù His tone abruptly shifts; becomes more serious. ‚ÄúWe burned every abomination we found in that place looking for you.‚Äù ‚ÄúAh...‚Äù A shiver. So you don‚Äôt have to relive it twice.‚Äù ‚Äú...‚Äù It‚Äôs maybe a little late for that. ‚ÄúJust tell me you killed the shade. Please.‚Äù ‚Äú...‚Äù ‚ÄúIt got away?!‚Äù ‚ÄúGone before we arrived. You talked to this shade?‚Äù ‚ÄúEr-‚Äù ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt... mention that to anyone you don‚Äôt absolutely trust,‚Äù he advises you, lowering his voice. ‚ÄúYou know what that sort of thing means, right?‚Äù ‚Äú...‚Äù You probably should, but... ‚ÄúN-not right now...?‚Äù ‚ÄúAngels can‚Äôt understand shades under normal circumstances. Only certain Angels can, and it‚Äôs usually those who are severely corrupted. Almost every Angel who has spoken to a shade fell to darkness soon after.‚Äù ‚ÄúG-great!‚Äù He continues speaking quietly; urgently. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm terribly sorry to add even more stress on top of an already stressful week, but I was being a little optimistic earlier. Certain individuals are somewhat suspicious that you may have come back somewhat the worse for wear - namely, that you‚Äôve been corrupted into a fallen Angel. After all, the shade had you for well over a day.‚Äù And even before that... you worry. They might be right! ‚Äã
4:00 PM
‚ÄúThe Emissary hasn‚Äôt come out against you yet, but he has asked the primes for their opinions as well. At least, that‚Äôs what I‚Äôve heard - from Ms Fisher, of all people, but she seemed confident. Just... don‚Äôt give anyone a reason to doubt your holiness. Please be careful what you say to the Emissary, the primes, or their representatives. You and I know you haven‚Äôt fallen, but our opinions don‚Äôt matter if spooky grandpa isn‚Äôt convinced.‚Äù ‚Äú... Th-they‚Äôre not considering...‚Äù You hesitate, imagining the guillotine blade gleaming overhead. ‚Äú...‚Äù ‚ÄúNo! Certainly not! ... At least, not that I‚Äôve heard. Just... please be safe. I‚Äôm sure this will all be behind us in a few weeks as long as no one gets too concerned. So until then, just don‚Äôt say anything about talking to any shades, or anything else that could cause trouble. Okay?‚Äù ‚Äú... S-should I lie, then? Isn‚Äôt that more suspicious?‚Äù Yara groans, leaning back. ‚ÄúJessamine, I‚Äôm sorry. I don‚Äôt know what to do. You‚Äôre right; if you get caught lying it would cause even more problems...‚Äù He sighs, covering his face. ‚ÄúI wish everything could have just worked out when you escaped. If that could have been the end of it.‚Äù Bizarrely, you find yourself trying to comfort him now. ‚ÄúI-I‚Äôm sure it‚Äôll work out somehow. Since you told me, at least. It‚Äôll be okay.‚Äù ‚ÄúAh, so positive. I apologize; I should be able to help you more. Maybe I can try to influence the council through the seraphs... 4:00 PM

Mxblah 9/4/2024 9:08 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 160 Aveline is your first visitor, telling you pretty much what Yara already said. You‚Äôre overstressed, there‚Äôs a strange but probably not harmful mutation, and you shouldn‚Äôt use any magic for at least a week. You get another brief examination and some more instructions, then are allowed to stand up and walk around for a bit. You don‚Äôt fall over, which is good and expected. But you aren‚Äôt allowed to leave quite yet. After she leaves, your next visitor is the Emissary (and his guards). You don‚Äôt remember many details of your conversation - you‚Äôre too busy being worried he‚Äôs going to smite you into ash - but you stumble your way through an explanation of what happened. Leaving out the fact that you talked to a shade (two, actually!) and everything relating to the tube, of course. One of the guards writes down everything you say, presumably to put into some report or other paperwork later. The Emissary doesn‚Äôt say much in response. He expresses some brief sympathy about what happened, but doesn‚Äôt imply anything about your holiness - or lack thereof. His neutral expression just adds to your anxiety, especially because it doesn‚Äôt seem forced. He‚Äôs just smiling the same little polite smile as the last time he visited you - under similar circumstances, in fact - and giving nothing away of his own thoughts. Of what his decision may eventually become. Eventually, he leaves with a simple ‚ÄúBe well, Angel Goodall.‚Äù You‚Äôre left to stew on your own for a while. Every sound at the door could be an execution squad, here to take you away for lying. And when it finally opens next, you can‚Äôt immediately discount that possibility. ‚ÄúJessamine,‚Äù he says by way of greeting. Lewis Kin, head of Inquisition. 9:09 PM
‚ÄúS-sir?‚Äù You still haven‚Äôt figured out how to properly address him. It‚Äôs been ages by now. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve read your report to the Emissary. Mr Kin is not an Angel, but he‚Äôs exceptionally good at telling when someone‚Äôs lying. Or, in your case, when someone is leaving out certain parts of the story. He‚Äôs also good at hiding his own thoughts - you‚Äôre certain by now that he did let slip the betrayer‚Äôs gender on purpose - and you‚Äôre certain again today that he‚Äôs purposely letting you know that he doesn‚Äôt believe you. His expressions and inflections between each question are too carefully controlled to be anything else. He knows you‚Äôre lying. But he never calls you on it. Never asks a follow-up question you can‚Äôt give some sort of reasonable explanation for. Never goes into too much detail about how specifically you knew what the shade wanted, if it hadn‚Äôt told you. He‚Äôs protecting you. ‚ÄúThank you for your time,‚Äù he finishes. ‚ÄúMy report, combined with the Emissary‚Äôs, will be what the prime council references in their deliberations that, I‚Äôm sure, you have heard about by now. You will not have to entertain further guests.‚Äù ‚ÄúT-thanks...‚Äù ‚ÄúExpect to hear the decision by tomorrow.‚Äù He nods briefly, then exits abruptly. And that‚Äôs that. You still aren‚Äôt allowed to leave, and apparently no more visitors are allowed after you woke up. You get a tray of food in the evening, but besides that, you‚Äôre left alone. There‚Äôs no more danger of you suddenly dying or exploding or anything, so no one even comes to check on you. A perfect environment to simmer in fear and confusion as you reflect on what went wrong and whether you‚Äôll even live to see the next sunset. ‚Äã
9:09 PM
Honestly, despite your pessimistic tendencies, you‚Äôre reasonably confident you won‚Äôt be executed. No one actively caught you lying (or at least they didn‚Äôt accuse you if they did), and if you‚Äôre reading into Mr Fisher‚Äôs actions right, you have a very powerful prime on your side. So. The rest of it, then. You can speak to shades, and understand them. You ‚Äúcut your strings,‚Äù according to the silver-eyed one. You destroyed human Souls (seriously; how did no one say you committed horrible sins by doing that?). You... probably, somehow may have almost created... Erm, maybe you‚Äôll think about what happened to Mila later. Above all else, you feel different inside. You can‚Äôt really explain how, and it could certainly be due to the trauma of that whole ordeal, but... you really need to figure out what exactly a fallen Angel is as soon as you get out of here, because you‚Äôre pretty sure you are one. Depending on if your Soul looks different or if it‚Äôs otherwise obvious in some way (probably not, since otherwise the Emissary would have noticed?) you may have to hide something. Maybe ask Naoriel for advice. Okay, you don‚Äôt know what to think about yourself. Time to think about Mila. By now, you‚Äôre pretty sure the shade put her in your cell on purpose. Maybe to slow you down, maybe to cause exactly what happened, or maybe for some other reason you can‚Äôt fathom. So. What did you do, then? A corrupted human can retain only their Body and become Mindless darkness. That isn‚Äôt what happened. They can lose only their Soul and become a shade. Closer, but you‚Äôre absolutely certain you sensed a Soul still inside her. So... a corrupted human that loses no aspect has no broad name. According to Brother Cobb, they‚Äôre terribly strong. But according to your own experience, a single Archangel easily destroyed one. Maybe it‚Äôs different because it was just born, but... maybe not. ‚Äã
9:09 PM
She seemed so real. So human, with the real Mila‚Äôs mannerisms. Apologizing too much, even in the maybe fifteen seconds you had to listen. Her hands were... warm. Corruption is cold. That‚Äôs always how it is; you experience Soul energy as warmth and corruption as cold. Is a corrupt Soul still warm... or was this something different entirely? Did you let Archangel Kamiya, one of your two top suspects of being the betrayer, kill a real human? The shade was experimenting with maintaining Souls even after corruption. You don‚Äôt know what it did to her beforehand. Could she maybe... have been a success? ‚Äú...‚Äù What would that mean if it‚Äôs true? For once in recent history, you kind of hope to dream tonight. @Story Notifications Scene 163 ‚ÄúYes. If you think it will help, I‚Äôll do it.‚Äù A relieved exhale. ‚ÄúThanks. Visit the hospital every other day to make sure you haven‚Äôt died, suppressing your anxiety every time that they‚Äôll notice something about your Soul that they hadn‚Äôt previously. It never happens, but that doesn‚Äôt stop you worrying. You overhear that there‚Äôs been a big reorganization in the fourteenth district‚Äôs constabulary. People have been fired; others have been promoted to replace them. It‚Äôs because of you, but the shakeup doesn‚Äôt really make any difference to you, so it‚Äôs hard to care. Administrative penalties won‚Äôt bring anyone back to life. ‚Äã
9:13 PM
Trading some favors with Clarity gets you some more information. Remila, the constable who accompanied you to the mill and was shot from behind, did not survive. That‚Äôs not a surprise, really, but you‚Äôre at least partially relieved to learn that they recovered her Body. She wasn‚Äôt taken and turned into some horrible corrupt monster. It‚Äôs small comfort, but it‚Äôs something. Kate - Mila‚Äôs friend - also survived. That actually surprises you. The mill had been empty by the time Yara‚Äôs group arrived, and most of the workers had been found later in the cistern or nearby. Yara said they didn‚Äôt find any survivors, but apparently a small group managed to escape into the tunnel network similarly to the way you did not long before the Angels arrived. It‚Äôs unclear how they avoided the corrupted creatures lurking in the passages long enough to find their way to the surface hours later, but you feel just a little better if you imagine they followed the trail you cleared out during your own escape. So you go ahead and believe that‚Äôs what happened. Briefly, you consider meeting her in some capacity - or at least passing on a message via Clarity or Yara or someone - but after a few minutes‚Äô consideration, you decide against that idea. You don‚Äôt know her and there‚Äôs nothing you can say about what happened to Mila that would help. Honestly, you don‚Äôt even know how close they were. They could have been just acquaintances; you‚Äôre assuming a lot after just a few minutes worth of eavesdropping. The cistern itself was purged during the fight, so the oily, shiny liquid at the bottom remains a mystery. Whether it was related to the spawning pools or not is a question you probably won‚Äôt be able to answer - unless maybe you can convince a shade to say something. And if you can believe whatever they might say. ‚Äã
9:13 PM
Speaking of, no one finds the shade. After escaping just before the Angels arrived, it truly seems to have vanished. Maybe disappearing into another section of the city, maybe lurking in the tunnels somewhere, maybe even retreating into the wastelands for a while. It‚Äôs impossible to know until it shows up again - and you know it will. Your dreams have been uneasy lately - full of empty rooms and tenuous silences - like you‚Äôre just waiting for something to happen. The silver-eyed shade will return soon, you just know it. But what it‚Äôs going to say, and how you‚Äôre going to react... you have no idea. You recover your permission to use magic after two weeks, when Aveline pronounces your Soul stable enough. It‚Äôs a lot more of a relief than you expected, honestly. Just being able to reach out and see and touch the world - it‚Äôs become such a central part of your identity in such a short time. No longer needing regular checkups, you finally start to relax about someone possibly discovering your fallen Soul. If it was going to happen, it would have by now. Or you could still be fine and you‚Äôre worrying about nothing as usual. Throughout all this, you‚Äôre constantly thinking about the shade‚Äôs offer to Naoriel, and your own part in everything. You‚Äôre important to the shades somehow. They kidnapped you and forced you to murder people. The silver-eyed one almost certainly saved your life. Back and forth and forth and back. Dare you trust them? Even enough to just tell her? You haven‚Äôt even continued your conversation with Yara about being able to speak to shades, though you‚Äôre not sure what he would be able to do about it either. Everything just keeps pressing closer and closer, like you‚Äôre nearing some cosmic breaking point. You feel powerless to change your fate, especially with how many more secrets with terrible consequences you seem to be accruing. No, you still haven‚Äôt forgotten about Phil‚Äôs fortune, even though you definitely should have by now. ‚Äã
9:13 PM
But finally, well past ‚Äúa few weeks‚Äù and nearing mid-August, you feel prepared. Well, prepared enough. You‚Äôve trained with Sister Noll, researched memory recovery techniques, and honed your Mental abilities as best you can. With no obvious deadline looming, you could potentially put this off as long as you want, but Naoriel is getting more antsy as time passes. Something about her dad. So. It‚Äôs time. You‚Äôve read that the best context to do a memory recovery is one strongly associated with that memory; ideally including as much as you can of the original place, people, scenario, and so on. But you can‚Äôt borrow an Archangel or break out of the Cathedra and sneak into Naoriel‚Äôs childhood home (seriously, you absolutely cannot do that!) so you ponder the next best thing. What might remind her of her mother...? [Vote as many times as you‚Äôd like. Elaborate in #story_discussion.] - Maybe if you find a building that looks like a home...? - Maybe if you get her dad to help...? - Maybe if she goes to sleep...? - Maybe if you dress the part...? - Maybe if you act motherly...? - Maybe if you act distant and hateful...? ‚ùì - Maybe if you have a better idea...? @Story Notifications Scene 164 You come up with a bunch of ideas, but most of them are too complicated or don‚Äôt actually seem like they‚Äôd help that much, upon further reflection. So in the end, you decide that it‚Äôs probably best to not worry too much about any of that stuff. Well, most of it. 8:15 PM

For a moment you‚Äôre excited - this is exactly where you meant to be, right? - but it quickly becomes apparent that you‚Äôre totally wrong. You cautiously shuffle closer to the Naoriel in the chair; she‚Äôs dozing lightly, but blinking half-awake every so often to see if the you in the bed has stirred. She doesn‚Äôt seem to notice you you. ‚Äã
8:16 PM

You‚Äôre pretty sure this was just a few weeks ago, when you were in the hospital after your practical - Yara even mentioned he had switched with Naoriel just a few minutes before you woke up. And... now that you consider it, it kind of makes sense that this would be the memory she thought of first. Both of you here, sleeping or drowsing, a bed, not long ago - it‚Äôs a strong connection. You look at yourself again, presumably through Naoriel‚Äôs eyes. Is this really what you look like when you sleep? All squished into the pillow like that, hair half-covering your face. Even with your Angelic beauty, it seems kind of silly. You look away. Okay, this isn‚Äôt what you‚Äôre here for and you don‚Äôt have unlimited time or magic. Naoriel jumps up and quickly pushes back the chair; she literally knocks you over in her haste. Mxblah 9/14/2024 2:34 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 165 You shake your head, quickly dismissing that idea. Although it‚Äôs tempting to listen in, you‚Äôre not here to snoop on Naoriel‚Äôs memories - even if they involve you! She‚Äôs trusting you to do the right thing here, and that means not worrying about stuff that isn‚Äôt your business! So, instead of trying to overhear their quiet conversation by the door, you immerse yourself in the flow of thoughts that shapes the dream. With a few careful nudges, you can guide the stream. Change the focus. Move back in time... there. Using yourself as the pivot point, as it were, you shift the scene back as far as you can. Shapes twist and colors bend; you find yourself back in Hearth Hall, watching a younger pair of you and Naoriel talk about Inquisitors in the cafe. This was ages ago by now - your very first day. Second? Depends on how you count, you suppose. You had been a lot more overwhelmed then, wondering about all the secrecy and hidden motives between the Angels in the common area. It‚Äôs a little uncomfortable to watch happen, honestly; it‚Äôs just a smoothing until there‚Äôs nothing distinct about anyone. 2:35 PM

Naoriel is glowing brightly, her Soul spilling out exactly as yours had years ago. This must have been just after her Ascension. There‚Äôs none of the elation that you might expect; only the fear and confusion that went along with it. Neither of her parents are here, both for obvious reasons, so she has no one to share this moment with aside from the near-stranger of this deacon. And it‚Äôs not as if becoming an Angel will solve her problems; if anything, it will only make them worse. More obvious. Before today, there had been the faint hope that maybe her Soul wasn‚Äôt strong enough to be chosen to Ascend; that maybe she could live a relatively normal life as an ordinary person. But no. She‚Äôs going to be special. And that means more scrutiny; more pressure. More chances to be caught. Naoriel just stares at her hands, trying to keep her composure. The deacon doesn‚Äôt seem to notice, or he just doesn‚Äôt care. ... This isn‚Äôt a pleasant memory. Even though nothing is actually happening, her strong negative emotions drench the whole thing and affect you too. Despair; anxiety; powerlessness. They all drift into you, melding with your actual emotions in subtle ways. You should probably get out of here, fast. You step into the corridor to change the scene. This isn‚Äôt far enough back. Her mother. ‚Äã
2:35 PM
You appear in the corner of a small, fenced-in garden at the rear of a brick townhouse. She clearly hasn‚Äôt seen him much over the past several years. But then, she starts complaining about her mother. How all her classmates have one, but she doesn‚Äôt. It seems like he doesn‚Äôt either, fumbling through an insufficient explanation that just makes little Naoriel even more mad. You‚Äôve lingered here long enough and you‚Äôve got a connection to her mother to work with anyway; it‚Äôs time to move on. You shift the scene back in time again, as far as you can possibly go. ‚Äã
2:35 PM

@Story Notifications Scene 166 ... Not here! With a flash of monotone grey, you‚Äôre dumped out of the stream of memories into... well, nowhere in particular, it seems. There‚Äôs nothing around but smooth grey emptiness in all directions, aside from a rapidly-retreating point of light that was the stream you were just ejected from. It‚Äôs not like there‚Äôs anything here to be a point of reference. 8:52 PM

Mxblah 9/18/2024 8:42 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 167 You wake up. Push yourself into a sitting position; make sure your actual Body is unscathed, as usual. 8:42 PM

There is no furniture; the floor and ceiling are only rough construction materials. Panels are missing in uneven patches. 8:42 PM
‚Äú... That‚Äôs what the other shade said, too.‚Äù ‚ÄúIt chose other methods.‚Äù The wind whips at you briefly, dragging a current of fog into the building. Visibility gets even worse; you have to strain to make out the thing‚Äôs eyes now. ‚ÄúWhat are you going to ask me to do, if I accept your help?‚Äù ‚ÄúBreak the strings of those you can. It will not hold you to a method. Simply removing more puppets from the master‚Äôs control will be payment enough.‚Äù For an instant, you were going to ask what that meant. How to break the strings; what these methods might entail. But... in a flash... you know. Of course you do. That moment of indecision when you were trying to save Mila; that tug at your lower back. You could have broken her strings. You know how. You just didn‚Äôt know what that meant. Now, however... You‚Äôre shaking. The understanding fades. You can‚Äôt. You don‚Äôt even know what you can‚Äôt do. You are an Angel. You cannot commit a sin like that. A sin like what? Or... Can you? Dare you? Would it really be so bad? ‚ÄúIt will meet with the broken puppet, if the cut-string puppet wills it. Does she?‚Äù The shade‚Äôs eyes glint and shift in the mist. ‚ÄúThough, if she does not, it believes the broken puppet is running out of borrowed time.‚Äù [This is a critical point. Mxblah 9/20/2024 7:58 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 168 ‚Äú...‚Äù It‚Äôs not easy, to choose between a grievous sin (but possible recovery for Naoriel) and her near-certain doom through inaction. The shade offers no advice as you work through the decision, seemingly content to just sit in the mist and watch. She can‚Äôt stay out there forever, even if she ends up somehow immune to the poison in the air and somehow able to find enough food and water to stay alive. 7:58 PM

@Story Notifications Scene 170 ... You gasp and stumble back in surprise as you wake up to a blinding glare. Shielding your eyes and blinking away the afterimage, you quickly deduce that you‚Äôre standing on a large wooden platform raised slightly above a wider area filled with seats. The rest of the room is totally dark by comparison. ‚ÄúJessamine!‚Äù Naoriel calls from somewhere in the darkness, but you‚Äôre still addled by the light and can‚Äôt see her. ‚ÄúNaoriel? It‚Äôs... too bright. I can‚Äôt; er, where are you?‚Äù ‚ÄúThere are some stairs to your left. @Story Notifications Scene 171 You hesitate, but slowly make your way over. ‚ÄúYou... had better not try to do anything but look, okay? 8:27 PM

With balance, repair is possible.‚Äù ‚Äã
8:27 PM
You think you get it. You will act as a power source again, like you did with the other shade. If she agrees, you‚Äôll have no other choice than to just trust it. Not using ‚Äúits kind‚Äù - the corruption, presumably - to try to heal half-Angels? ‚ÄúWhat will she become at the end of it?‚Äù you interrupt, unable to stop yourself. You have to know - or at least you have to know what it claims. They both look at you. The shade answers. ‚ÄúThe puppet will become herself. The puppet will not change beyond recognition.‚Äù ‚ÄúWill she be like Mila?‚Äù You just can‚Äôt help yourself, can you? An Angel; your light keeping her together. Balance, perhaps. Until a change. Recognizable, but... ‚ÄúRepairs are inexact. It cannot discount the possibility, though it believes the broken puppet is strong enough to avoid even that change.‚Äù A pause; you don‚Äôt say anything. ‚ÄúAdding more of your kind may help avert such an outcome, but adding too much will destroy the balance. It will calculate with the cut-string puppet ahead of the procedure.‚Äù ‚Äú... Okay,‚Äù you say. Quietly. You‚Äôre not entirely convinced, and it could be lying through whatever shades have instead of teeth, but... there‚Äôs just no way to know. And if the other option is to just let Naoriel die... ‚ÄúI‚Äôll do it.‚Äù ‚ÄúNaoriel?! You - already? You don‚Äôt even want to think about it first?‚Äù ‚Äã
8:28 PM
‚ÄúWhat is there to think about?‚Äù she asks, shrugging for effect. You don‚Äôt believe for a second that she‚Äôs actually as nonchalant as she‚Äôs trying to appear. ‚ÄúI literally have no other option, and with... everything that‚Äôs going on, I don‚Äôt have much longer. There will be plenty of time to change my Mind before the actual operation, right?‚Äù The shade nods. ‚ÄúIt cannot be sooner than three months from cutting your strings. The puppet‚Äôs Soul must stabilize after the change, before further changes can be made.‚Äù She turns back to you. ‚ÄúThere; see? Three months from now is mid-November, and we‚Äôll need a few days off to go into the city and do whatever we need to do, so it‚Äôll actually be even longer. Let‚Äôs do it.‚Äù ‚Äú...‚Äù You actually hadn‚Äôt expected her to agree so readily, and you‚Äôre starting to wonder if maybe you managed to influence her decision anyway. Even after trying so hard to avoid that! ‚ÄúThe festival days at the end of the year. Can that work?‚Äù ‚ÄúYes.‚Äù The shade‚Äôs expression remains inscrutable, but you have to wonder if it‚Äôs as surprised as you. ‚ÄúThere. That‚Äôs when it‚Äôll be, then. Five months to change my Mind. Now-‚Äù She reaches around behind herself. Grasps the tube. Finally slows down for a moment. You and the shade say nothing. ‚Äú...‚Äù She tugs it again, just a little, and gasps in immediate pain. ‚ÄúJ-just a minute...‚Äù Forbidden knowledge. Your eyes widen. You could cut her strings. Your arms tremble; your hands clench. The sin blossoms in your Mind; your Soul is slow to flush it out. You could do it. You could you could you could you- ‚úÇÔ∏è - ‚ÄúLet me do it.‚Äù - ‚Äú...‚Äù - ‚ÄúStop!‚Äù [Requires more than a majority. And then what? Specify in #story_discussion ] (Winner: ) (edited)

Mxblah 9/28/2024 2:39 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 172 You can‚Äôt! Or rather, you won‚Äôt. You struggle silently against yourself for several moments before, finally, the knowledge leaves your Mind and you forget what it was you could have done. This isn‚Äôt for you to do. You can‚Äôt drop that deeply into sin. Something... you‚Äôre not sure how terrible it will be, but something will happen if you do. You will change. Although, given how much more frequent these moments of knowledge have become lately, you‚Äôre not sure you‚Äôll have a choice for much longer. ‚ÄúJess... could you and, er, ‚Äòit‚Äô l-look away for a minute?‚Äù ‚Äú... Yeah.‚Äù The shade doesn‚Äôt say anything, but just follows your lead as you round one of the large pillars holding up a second-floor gallery. Even if you were looking that way, you wouldn‚Äôt be able to see anything. ‚ÄúT-take your time,‚Äù you say nervously, not really sure how to reassure her when you have no real idea what this procedure even does. ‚Äú... Okay...‚Äù Near-silence for a while. There‚Äôs a distracting background hum coming from the spotlight far above, still drifting lazily between the mannequins on the stage. You glance up at it again, still unable to make out any details of who or what might be operating it. Still, the brilliant glare and the obvious metaphor make you fairly certain what it represents. The force that shades call the puppetmaster. God. You wonder what He thinks of all this. Well, as much as He can, anyway, with His Mind still embedded in the planet. Sacrificed to prevent the darkness from gaining a Mind. And yet, standing just beside you is a creature of darkness with a Mind. God‚Äôs sacrifice only slowed it down. So... why hasn‚Äôt anything changed? Why hasn‚Äôt He returned His Mind to the sky and done something different? Is He still preventing the majority of darkness from gaining Minds and something terrible would happen if He returned above? Does He simply have faith in you, collectively, to still win? Or... Can He not? ‚Äã
2:39 PM
You‚Äôve wondered before how God can still communicate to the Emissary without a Mind; how He can maintain His plans with His aspects separated like they are. In the past, you decided that maybe only humans are so fragile to need the three aspects together to maintain themselves, and God can split Himself however He wishes with no ill effect. But maybe, just maybe, humanity is more of a mirror of God than you‚Äôd like to believe. After all, would it really be a ‚Äúsacrifice‚Äù if He could put Himself back together at any time? Cathedra doctrine states that the sacrifice was just of the moment, and that He could always return above to remake the world if He wished. That He simply loves humanity too much to do that without giving you a chance. But if you did that - if you split up your aspects and embedded your Mind in the planet - you would die. And as you are a reflection of God... A horrible, ghastly sound paired with a hitched gasp. Fluid splatters on the floor. One of the tubes above - disappearing into the spotlight‚Äôs gallery - twitches. A thump. ‚ÄúNaoriel!‚Äù You rush around the pillar; the shade follows more sedately. She‚Äôs lying on the ground, blood and clear fluid pooling around her just like when you had done the same thing. But unlike before, there‚Äôs a ragged, gaping wound in her back where the thing had connected. Deep, rich blood spills from her Body. ‚ÄúWh - wait - it didn‚Äôt... last time-‚Äù The shade walks measuredly past you and kneels beside Naoriel. Places its hands on the wound. An indescribable sound, and a patch of fresh skin rapidly grows to cover it. The same symbol: the baseless triangle enclosing a circle. ‚Äú... You did that? Wh-when I... that was you too?‚Äù ‚ÄúIt can seal the break that missing strings leave.‚Äù It stands up again, pats her gently on the head. ‚ÄúThe broken puppet has courage. It will return to repair her. But now...‚Äù ‚Äã
2:39 PM
The shade leaps straight up, twisting in midair to land in the spotlight‚Äôs gallery. The thunk of a blade embedding itself in wood. Naoriel‚Äôs tube falls to the ground beside you, cut cleanly through and still vomiting clear liquid. The shade doesn‚Äôt say anything else, and you somehow know it has left the dream. She‚Äôs stirring, a little. You know the pain must be overwhelming. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt try to move yet,‚Äù you murmur. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs okay. You‚Äôll feel better soon.‚Äù And so, wishing you could do more to help, you kneel like that in the blood and fluid until the dream breaks apart and you wake up. It‚Äôs a little earlier in the morning than you would normally get up, but you do anyway because you obviously need to go check on Naoriel. Surely she won‚Äôt be injured in reality; after all, you never were. You get dressed and hurry upstairs, knocking nervously on Naoriel‚Äôs door. A few seconds of silence give you pause; you did bring the spare key she gave you just in case, but actually using it would be- ‚ÄúJust a minute!‚Äù You exhale, relieved. She‚Äôs not dead or in terrible pain. And when she opens the door and invites you in, you get quick confirmation that her physical Body is as unaffected as yours was. In fact, she‚Äôs feeling better than normal. Energized. In control. You doubt that feeling will last very long, with the primes‚Äô meetings still ongoing. Unfortunately, there isn‚Äôt much you can do about that and there isn‚Äôt anything you can do about her Soul for several more months. You‚Äôll just have to see what happens and hope your operation won‚Äôt be too late. And speaking of (thinking of) poor timing, it‚Äôs Endle Day tomorrow. You‚Äôve gone home for it every year so far and every year has been another disaster of some flavor or another. Are you going to try again this year? - Go home for Endle Day. - Don‚Äôt. @Story Notifications Scene 173 Well, third time‚Äôs the charm, or so they say. Nothing else of particular note happens for the rest of the day. The primes continue their discussion. You don‚Äôt find anything more on the shards. You prepare for tomorrow. That sort of thing. And then, the next morning, you pass through the Cathedra‚Äôs gates and make your way back to Nucarreo‚Äôs central station for the third year in a row. This time, your disguise isn‚Äôt bad at all (compared to ‚Äúmediocre at best‚Äù last time and ‚Äúnot even your spell‚Äù the time before that) so the guards don‚Äôt give you any trouble. They don‚Äôt even seem particularly concerned that you‚Äôll get kidnapped or find a corruption creature to fight, despite your alarming precedent for getting into trouble. Honestly, you kind of expected someone to object to you leaving on your own again. But you suppose no mere human would tell you what to do. The train is crowded, as usual, and you don‚Äôt even get a window seat this time. Instead, you‚Äôre stuck between two boisterous families who are far too excited about getting to their respective relatives‚Äô homes. You just try to block out the noise as best you can as the train rattles along, high above the city you can‚Äôt even see because of the aforementioned seating situation. Oh well. 8:38 PM

8:38 PM
Then, because you‚Äôre incensed and full of energy, you take him up on his challenge, trying to leap three or four inches higher than you did last year - again with no magical assistance beyond your regular perfect Body. You get really close, but, to your embarrassment and Seth‚Äôs amusement, can‚Äôt conclusively make it. It‚Äôs within an inch or so, but you simply don‚Äôt have the strength. Then one thing leads to another and you‚Äôre having another sparring match while your dad nervously guards the entrance to the little park because you‚Äôre still being too reckless to put your disguise back on. Honestly; what‚Äôs with you today? With Body-enhancing magic, you win handily, but when dad finally manages to convince you to calm down a little and refocus on your disguise, Seth ends up winning. No swords-crossed tie this time; he actually squeaks out a 3-2 victory. 8:38 PM
‚ÄúOkay, okay, I‚Äôll be good.‚Äù A pause; everyone gets their water. ‚ÄúActually, I‚Äôm glad you‚Äôre getting so strong. If you‚Äôre aiming to be a soldier, you really do need to be better than me. @Story Notifications Scene 174 The answer, as it turns out, is ‚Äúnot much.‚Äù You consider going out somewhere - whether to catch up with people outside of your family or hunt for corruption creatures is irrelevant - but it‚Äôs kinda late and you‚Äôd need to put your disguise back on and it‚Äôd just be a hassle so... 9:40 PM

The prime council apparently didn‚Äôt have a successor picked out, so the post is temporarily filled by one of the other primes while hurried campaigns are run, hushed deals are struck, and the machinations of politics... well, machinate.
