Mxblah 10/4/2024 9:47 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 175 Weeks pass. The leaves begin to change as September arrives, grows old, and gives way to October. The new head of Inquisition is selected: some bishop you hadn‚Äôt heard of until recently. Arnold Athwood, apparently. A relatively young man, as far as primes go, and one who made his case for the position by aggressively pushing for more transparency and accountability in the Inquisition. That might be good for you (and everyone), but he also claims he will find and capture the betrayer by the end of the year. That also might be good for you, if it weren‚Äôt for the fact that the betrayer will surely take both of you down with her, if he succeeds. In any case, Inquisitors are mobilized in record numbers, and - unusually - publicly so. As someone who‚Äôs been involved with at least one of the incidents, you‚Äôre questioned again by Sims, who has apparently joined their ranks. Perhaps because he was recently a trainee, they think you‚Äôll be more willing to trust him? If so, that doesn‚Äôt work at all; you lie about everything you want to hide, squashing your anxiety with Mind magic and desperately hoping he‚Äôll believe you. Somehow, it seems to work. Sims, it seems, is not very good at detecting lies. You try to push aside the thought of what would have happened if a more experienced Angel had been sent to question you instead and do your best to help Naoriel through the same experience. One of your luckiest breaks so far. But you feel that as the self-imposed deadline looms closer, they might send someone else to try again... ‚Äã
9:48 PM
In the meantime, you‚Äôre still keeping busy with your courses. Sister Noll is having you learn about Mental curses (at your request), which involves some pretty harrowing contests against other Angels as you try to place, block, or remove long-lasting effects. You‚Äôre getting fairly good at defense, but the process of untangling the magic to remove it is a lot harder. And that‚Äôs to say nothing of placing curses yourself - you just feel too bad for your target to get it right. At least Noll doesn‚Äôt push you much on that front; Mind magic doesn‚Äôt work on Mindless darkness anyway, so there isn‚Äôt much reason for you to learn how to harm other Minds unless you‚Äôre aiming for shades. Which you aren‚Äôt. Probably. It‚Äôs a real struggle to stay quiet about all that. Anyway, you spend a lot of time reading about curses throughout late September and early October, and eventually one book in particular catches your attention in a different way. There‚Äôs a brief anecdote midway through a chapter about detection spells, detailing a spiral of ‚Äúthought shards‚Äù that attach to a target‚Äôs Mind and just stay there, possibly for years, until they detect an intruder in any specific memories. Then, the shards break apart and alert the caster. That‚Äôs it. ... Sure seems familiar. You reread the passage a few more times and take several minutes to think back on your memories of the shards in Naoriel‚Äôs Mind. It could fit. A failsafe; a way to know if anyone tried to access any dangerous memories. You know Archangel Kamiya has the skills to cast a curse like this. You know she has the motive. But what you don‚Äôt know is, if all this is true and she knows you were snooping around in Naoriel‚Äôs Mind, why hasn‚Äôt she done anything yet? ... Maybe she has. ‚Äã
9:48 PM
Maybe, somehow, Kamiya was behind the primes‚Äô decision to oust Mr Kin. Maybe she influenced them or asked telling little questions about why the betrayer was still at large. Maybe she has more connections in the council than you thought; after all, this started the day after your spell. But why? Assuming you‚Äôre right (a big assumption, probably), would a new prime even be a good idea? Sure, Mr Kin was shielding Naoriel, but he also wasn‚Äôt going after Kamiya. A new prime wouldn‚Äôt have those restrictions; Mr Athwood even called out the betrayer specifically in his immediate goals! Would the extra danger really be worth it? ‚Äú...‚Äù You hate this; there‚Äôs nothing you can do about anything! You can‚Äôt tell the Inquisitors about Kamiya. You can‚Äôt do... whatever with the shade for another two months at least. You can‚Äôt keep Naoriel or yourself safe except by just staying quiet, keeping your head down, and trying to be as invisible as possible until it‚Äôs time. Somehow, you‚Äôve latched onto the shade‚Äôs procedure as a magic cure for all your problems, even though you rationally know there must be a catch. But... if it works and Naoriel is somehow cured without any major problems, it really will all be over. You can just tell the Inquisitors. Kamiya will be arrested, she‚Äôll accuse Naoriel, and there won‚Äôt be any evidence because she simply is no longer a half-Angel. It‚Äôs perfect. Things certainly won‚Äôt go that smoothly in reality, but you find yourself fantasizing about that perfect sequence of events more than once just to calm down. ‚ÄúJessamine?‚Äù ‚ÄúWA-huh?‚Äù You nearly jump out of your chair as someone says your name close behind you, but it‚Äôs just Erich. You breathe out tiredly and try to calm down. ‚ÄúYou, um, startled me.‚Äù ‚ÄúApologies. I just thought you might want to know the library is closing soon and they‚Äôre asking everyone to leave.‚Äù ‚ÄúHuh? What time - it‚Äôs already that late?‚Äù ‚Äã
9:48 PM
‚ÄúYou must have been quite interested in your research. Mind magic?‚Äù ‚ÄúH-how did you know?‚Äù You‚Äôve been more careful recently, even though there‚Äôs nothing illicit about your reading material. You‚Äôve drawn the mechanics quite well.‚Äù ‚ÄúOh, er, thanks.‚Äù You start to gather your things; Erich helps out after a few moments. ‚ÄúJust studying for my course. And, apparently, you‚Äôre studying spells of long duration. 9:48 PM
You hesitate a brief moment; Erich is coming to you for help? Erich? The guy who was ahead of you the entire time in basic magic, and most of the advanced stuff too? [This is a critical point. Four characters‚Äô fates will be altered.] - Block, contaminate, or otherwise mask anything dangerous when they‚Äôre looking. Sneakily, if you can. [It will be difficult to hide that you‚Äôre doing this.] - Suppress your own memories. Build in a trigger to get them back later. [You risk the trigger failing, or the suppression looking strange to an adept Inquisitor.] - Remove your own memories. Place them in a receptacle outside of yourself to retrieve later. [You aren‚Äôt sure you can do this, and if you do it wrong, you‚Äôll definitely lose them entirely.] - Perform the procedure with the shade immediately, before the Inquisitors read your Mind. [You‚Äôre still a month early, and it will be difficult to hide your absence without a holiday.] - Convince them they don‚Äôt need to read your Mind. [How? Specify in #story_discussion ] ‚ùì - ... @Story Notifications Scene 177 ... You wake up in the morning confused, with a throbbing headache and no memory of last night. You vaguely remember talking with Erich, and Etalyn had been there too for a bit... but that‚Äôs it. Nothing else. Even the memories you do have are vague; almost blurry. What... happened? Your mood improves slightly when you recognize your own handwriting: ‚ÄúNote to future me: you were practicing Mind magic with Erich last night and overdid it a little. I don‚Äôt think you‚Äôll be able to remember much of the night, but it‚Äôs nothing to be worried about; the memories should come back in a week or two. 9:30 PM

Staring at the deep, dark blood left on the ground. Reminding you of the cistern; the shade; your miserable imprisonment. Wondering if you‚Äôve been tainted; if you‚Äôll end up betrayed or the betrayer. Wondering if you‚Äôve become lesser; if you aren‚Äôt quite a full Angel anymore. The Inquisitor shifts in your Mind, drawing attention to the connections you just formed. Why did you think of that? What links those events? Is it just the trauma? The fear? Injury and possible death? Or...? A seal strains; breaks under his power. Linked by an individual, memories return. Exhaustive researching, checking, and cross-referencing Cathedra records. Taking matters into your own hands when the then-prime wouldn‚Äôt help you. Eventually reaching a conclusion that the betrayer and Archangel Maede Kamiya are one and the same. You flinch, closing off your Mind and ejecting the Inquisitor. ‚ÄúWh - huh? Whose... were those my memories? 9:31 PM
‚ÄúI can only search for blocks relating to information I‚Äôm looking for. If you want anything more, talk to the hospital. Now, do you know anything else about Archangel Kamiya?‚Äù ‚ÄúN-no; or... @Story Notifications Scene 179 You want to trust him. It‚Äôs so hard to keep lying to everyone. You just made the choice to finally tell Yara and Etalyn; it should be fine! Erich isn‚Äôt a bad guy! But will it be him? You can‚Äôt know. ‚ÄúShe returns,‚Äù Yara notes as you re-enter your room, somehow relaxed enough to lean back in his chair. ‚ÄúFeeling alright?‚Äù ‚Äú... Physically? Yeah. Are you the only one who feels so nervous you could throw up? Or are they just hiding it? ‚ÄúIf the Inquisitors know about Kamiya, they‚Äôre going to try to capture her soon. And when they do, she‚Äôs going to tell them about me. We just don‚Äôt know when that will be.‚Äù ‚ÄúThe way I see it, we have a few bad options.‚Äù Yara counts them out on his fingers as he continues. ‚ÄúOne. I‚Äôm not saying we should, but we‚Äôre brainstorming here; everything‚Äôs on the table. We could turn Naoriel in. The three of us would be fine, but... dear Ms Fisher would certainly not be. But it would at least prevent an Erejil-style catastrophe, guaranteed.‚Äù ‚Äã
5:32 PM
‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not doing that,‚Äù you say firmly. ‚ÄúSure. I don‚Äôt like it either. Two, then. Your friendly shade has said three months is the minimum time to wait before doing the operation. That puts it at November 13th, just over a month away. And, inconveniently, there aren‚Äôt any holidays in November, so the earliest day you could do it without causing a ruckus would be December 3rd, Sequence Day.‚Äù ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs... a long time to wait when they could come after us tomorrow.‚Äù ‚ÄúIndeed. Three. Now we‚Äôre starting to get into some truly dangerous plans.‚Äù ‚Äú‚ÄòTwo‚Äô wasn‚Äôt dangerous enough?‚Äù you mutter. ‚ÄúThree: Naoriel leaves the Cathedra and hides somewhere in the city until the three months are up. This would obviously cause a huge disturbance and Angels would comb the city looking for you. I‚Äôm not certain how you would be able to hide for that long, especially without our help - as, of course, we couldn‚Äôt know where you went or we would certainly be forced to reveal that information. But it would at least get you away from immediate danger quickly.‚Äù Naoriel shifts uncomfortably. You don‚Äôt like this one either. Yara had called all of them ‚Äúbad options,‚Äù you suppose. ‚ÄúThree-B,‚Äù he continues. ‚ÄúWe fake Naoriel‚Äôs death, and then follow plan three. The advantages are obvious: no one would be searching for a presumably dead Angel. However, how to do so convincingly, and in such a way to avoid problematic investigations... is a fairly difficult problem.‚Äù ‚ÄúIf... if we can figure out how to do it, that might be okay...‚Äù you say quietly. It‚Äôs starting to sink in just how few and how risky your options are. ‚Äã
5:32 PM
‚ÄúFive. Was I on five? Whatever; five: we do this operation early. I can‚Äôt pretend to know what risks are associated with not waiting the full time, and by what you‚Äôve said, I don‚Äôt believe you two know either. As an aside, by the way, I still don‚Äôt exactly trust this shade and its mysterious ‚Äòoperation,‚Äô but these plans are operating on the assumption that it is in fact trustworthy. If it isn‚Äôt, then we really only have plan one available as we can‚Äôt cure Naoriel. Which is why we‚Äôre assuming it‚Äôs fine.‚Äù ‚Äú...‚Äù You don‚Äôt know how to address the aside, so you just speak to the first part of that. ‚ÄúI can maybe try to ask it what happens if we rush, but my guess is that her Soul will break. The way it talked about the operation made it seem like it‚Äôs a really delicate procedure that needs careful balance. I wouldn‚Äôt want to do it with an unstable Soul...‚Äù Naoriel nods. ‚ÄúI still don‚Äôt feel... quite right, yet. I don‚Äôt want to risk that...‚Äù ‚ÄúVery well! Then, it seems we have two main problems. Namely, that we cannot attempt to cure Naoriel until mid-November, and she cannot be within reach of the Inquisition between now and then. So if we don‚Äôt intend to bargain with the Inquisitors or seek help from anyone else in the Cathedra - either of which I would find quite dangerous - it seems our choices are essentially how to get you out of the Cathedra, where to go, and how to meet up later to perform the operation.‚Äù Something occurs to you. ‚ÄúIf I go with her, we wouldn‚Äôt have to meet up later. I could just do it then, before we come back.‚Äù Everyone seems taken aback by this. ‚ÄúY-you want to go with her? Jessamine, that‚Äôs quite admirable, but-‚Äù Yara shakes his head. ‚ÄúApologies; this is a brainstorming session. Quite right; you could go with her. 5:32 PM
Naoriel slides closer to you; lowers her voice. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm really grateful you want to help me so much... but you don‚Äôt have to go that far. You‚Äôd be throwing away your future in the Cathedra just to try something that we don‚Äôt even know will work...‚Äù ‚Äú...‚Äù You try to visualize what that would be like, if you couldn‚Äôt come back here. If the Cathedra branded you a traitor. Would your life just be painfully cut short by an Inquisitor‚Äôs execution? Would you spend years on the run, hiding throughout the city or the wastes to avoid detection? Would you be branded a hero instead, for discovering how to cure half-Angels? Would everything be forgiven? ‚ÄúAh, it‚Äôs already getting quite late,‚Äù Yara notes as the night bell gongs sonorously through the mist. ‚ÄúI would ordinarily suggest we sleep on any major decisions like this, but if we‚Äôre worried about a matter of hours, there may not be time.‚Äù Etalyn‚Äôs been awfully quiet over there in the corner, you note. She doesn‚Äôt seem happy. She usually doesn‚Äôt, but... The cards. Fortune. Destiny. Betrayal. Stop it. You‚Äôve decided to trust them. You can‚Äôt keep doubting everyone [This is a continuation of the critical point started in Scene 176. Four characters‚Äô fates will be altered. Mxblah 10/14/2024 10:06 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 180 In the end, you sleep on it. Poorly. But you need to ask the shade some questions first. You‚Äôre not sure how to ‚Äúsummon‚Äù it into your dreams, and you‚Äôre not convinced you even can. Every time it‚Äôs shown up, it‚Äôs been on its terms. So you just do what seems natural and think about it a lot, hoping that there‚Äôs some sort of mystical connection you can form and that it isn‚Äôt just some spell it has to cast, completely separate from anything you‚Äôre doing. Whatever the case, it seems to work. You appear in the cistern, standing in the cool, thigh-deep water at the bottom of the pit. Gentle currents pull you towards the center, where the floor drops away into darkness. You hurriedly back out of the water and onto dry land, fully aware you‚Äôre dreaming and trying your best to ignore the uncomfortable surroundings to search for the shade. ‚ÄúEvents have moved quickly,‚Äù it hisses from somewhere above you. Silver eyes gleam in the shadows. You‚Äôve rarely been so relieved to see your ostensible mortal enemy. At least it‚Äôs not the orange-eyed one. ‚ÄúYeah. Yes, they have. Er, d-did I bring you here, or did you come on your own...?‚Äù ‚ÄúIt has its informants. It believes the cut-string puppet might require guidance.‚Äù ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs one way to put it...‚Äù You glance around again, not finding anyone else. ‚ÄúDid you not bring Naoriel here too?‚Äù The shade‚Äôs eyes shift upwards slightly. ‚ÄúThe broken puppet is not asleep.‚Äù ‚ÄúWhat? I told her - ugh, she‚Äôd better be rested by morning! Anyway, we‚Äôre trying to make a plan and I need to know a few things.‚Äù ‚ÄúSpeak. Ask.‚Äù ‚ÄúWell...‚Äù ... You‚Äôre awake before the morning bell and meet up with your co-conspirators in the misty chill of sunrise to finalize the plan. Then, as light turns the fog gold, you put it into place. ‚Äã
10:06 PM
Yara and Etalyn enter the cafe for breakfast, ‚Äúcoincidentally‚Äù just a minute before Clarity - they had managed to sneak a peek at the next day‚Äôs schedule by returning to the Center last night to ask a dispatcher a few questions. You and Naoriel wait a few more minutes before following suit, walking in on the three of them in the middle of a lively conversation about how well Clarity could impersonate Etalyn with her transmutation magic. Just as ‚Äúcoincidentally,‚Äù you join up with the group and Naoriel ends up agreeing to be the test subject. After breakfast, Clarity tries a few disguises before getting it almost exactly right on the fourth try, resulting in two near-identical Etalyns regarding each other with very different expressions. At that point, Yara suggests they go see if anyone will notice a difference based on personality alone... but Clarity has to go to the Center for a meeting. She leaves the disguise up and hurries off. Without much time to spare before the transmutation fades, you place your own disguise projection over Naoriel, layering it on top of the transmutation to result in a human-looking Etalyn. Yara does the same for himself and the two head for the front gate as if they‚Äôre going out on a mission together - they often do. Meanwhile, you and the real Etalyn walk over to a secluded corner of the Cathedra grounds behind a temple dedicated to the concept of change. ‚ÄúWall‚Äôs a little lower here,‚Äù she says by way of explanation. ‚ÄúBack in a bit.‚Äù ‚Äã
10:06 PM
Then, when you indicate no one‚Äôs looking, she jumps to near the top of the wall and scrambles straight over. A monk rounds the corner into view in a few moments, checking on the loud, alarm-like ding the wall magically gives off when anyone touches it, but by then you‚Äôre alone and innocently backing away as if you had just leaned on it without thinking. There‚Äôs no way Naoriel could have vaulted the wall like that. Honestly, you‚Äôd think there‚Äôs no way Etalyn could have done it if you hadn‚Äôt just watched her. Unbelievable. After a minute more to placate the monk, you head back to the main gates and confirm the non-presence of any sort of kerfuffle. Beautiful. For such a convoluted plan, everything seems to have worked out perfectly. No one should notice she‚Äôs gone until tomorrow, or possibly even Monday when she has courses again. A few hours later, Yara and the real Etalyn return to the Cathedra. He just nods with a wry little smile as proof that nothing went wrong. Naoriel is out there in the city somewhere, on her own. And none of you have any idea where she‚Äôs going, so you can‚Äôt betray her even if you wanted to. Now comes the hard part: waiting here for a month and a half without knowing how she‚Äôs doing or if she‚Äôs even alive. Hoping to hear back just before it‚Äôs time to perform the procedure. And not telling anyone a single thing about what‚Äôs going on. ‚Äã
10:06 PM
To that end, just suppressing your memories probably won‚Äôt be enough. Even though you hopefully can‚Äôt know where Naoriel is planning to go, you certainly have plenty of other incriminating memories. Chief among them are your several talks with the shade. Maybe the Inquisitors won‚Äôt look for those purposefully due to their privacy restrictions, but last night‚Äôs conversation in particular is far too connected to Naoriel for your comfort. So, you‚Äôre going to try to completely extract that memory so you can‚Äôt possibly give anything away. You might lose it if you screw up, but... that‚Äôs what writing it down is for. You don‚Äôt need to remember the atmosphere or details; just the facts. Unfortunately, you‚Äôve been so busy this morning that you haven‚Äôt had time to gather the ingredients yet, and your instructors typically aren‚Äôt around on Saturdays. So it‚Äôs slow going picking through the storerooms with the help of the monks who are still here, searching for materials that hopefully don‚Äôt look too suspicious. You literally can‚Äôt tell them where Naoriel went, and you need to save yourself too. - Resist. They can‚Äôt do anything too bad to you (probably) and Naoriel needs all the time she can get. Mxblah 10/16/2024 9:55 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 181 You‚Äôre escorted down to the basement of Illim Hall, led into a small, metal-lined room that reminds you of a jail cell, and asked about Naoriel. When you won‚Äôt say anything useful, the Inquisitor instead attempts to view your memories. When you won‚Äôt cooperate with that either, refusing to allow him into your Mind despite several attempts, he leaves along with the guards. Several hours pass. You pace around the room. Knock on the door. Ask the guard outside when you can leave. He doesn‚Äôt know. Ask why you‚Äôre being held here. He says you just need to answer the questions and you can go. Say you aren‚Äôt going to do that. He says he‚Äôll tell them. Several. Hours. Pass. You end up lightly dozing in one of the chairs, just because there isn‚Äôt anything else to do. This is reminding you uncomfortably of your imprisonment in the cistern, and you feel like you might just start breaking things if they don‚Äôt let you out soon. Or at least indicate that something is happening. They can‚Äôt just hold you here forever without saying anything, right? You‚Äôre an Angel, and they can‚Äôt even do this to a regular human! Right? 9:56 PM
Something tells you that playing dumb won‚Äôt get you anywhere. 9:56 PM

Mxblah 10/18/2024 9:06 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 182 ‚Äú...‚Äù You consider saying something; you really do. Being sent to the wastes... if you could maybe help them escape that fate by just providing a little information, would it be worth it? But, after thinking a few moments, you realize that if what he‚Äôs saying is true, that means Yara and Etalyn didn‚Äôt say anything either. They have the same information on Naoriel as you do, and they didn‚Äôt talk. So, if you did now, you‚Äôd be betraying them just as much as Naoriel herself. Well, maybe a little less, but still. So. You stay quiet. ‚ÄúFine. Then you get to stay right here until you change your Mind. We‚Äôll check back in a few days.‚Äù The prime stands to leave. You say nothing. Maybe he wants you to get upset about being stuck here, but it‚Äôs not going to be nearly as bad as the cistern. At least here, you won‚Äôt be forced to operate on anyone. ... You dream of the shade that night, briefly. It appears for only a few moments, just long enough to whisper ‚Äúshe still lives‚Äù and vanish back into the formless shadows that are your backdrop tonight. It didn‚Äôt agree to ferry messages back and forth for you, and it wouldn‚Äôt be a good idea anyway if the Inquisitors do get you to break, but this was the only way you could think of to make sure she‚Äôs still okay without risking interception. Even Angels can‚Äôt interrupt whatever strange, dream-based spell the shade is using here. Not if they don‚Äôt know about it. It‚Äôs a relief in any case. She‚Äôs still okay, which means they weren‚Äôt able to track her directly. If they had, it would have been over already. Now, it turns into hide-and-seek rather than a direct chase. Better for you; better for her. Can she make it a month? You can only hope. ... Can you make it a month? Can Yara? Etalyn? You can only hope. Or, perhaps, pray. ‚Äã
9:06 PM
What do You think about all this? you wonder sometime during the night, when the hallways lights are turned down low and distant metallic groans tickle the edge of your consciousness. Do You think I‚Äôm doing the right thing? Can we save her? God, as always, does not answer. You aren‚Äôt the Emissary. He will not speak to you. But... the Emissary is the Emissary. He can speak to God, at least to some degree. And he commands the primes. So... indirectly, does that mean that God doesn‚Äôt approve of your actions? Since He would have told the Emissary, who would have told the prime, who would have told the Inquisitors? Or does He not think the situation is worth commenting on? Is it too insignificant; beneath His notice? Does He not have enough of a Mind left to make these comments, like you‚Äôve wondered before? Or is the Emissary ignoring Him? Occasionally, you have wondered if the Emissary really can speak to God. If Angels can‚Äôt - even Seraphim don‚Äôt have that ability - what is it about this mortal man that raises him above everyone else? He is human; there‚Äôs no physical difference. The only thing different about the Emissary is that he‚Äôs elected by the primes, and that he‚Äôs the keeper of the Lordstone. The shard of God‚Äôs Body entrusted to the Cathedra that forms its link with the divine. Is that it? But how is he connected to the Lordstone, actually? Just by sitting next to it all day? Would anyone sitting in his chair be able to talk to God, or is there something special you just don‚Äôt know about? There probably is; the Cathedra likes keeping secrets. But if you accept that the Emissary can speak to God and that he accurately carries His will into the world, then you‚Äôd have to accept that God wants you to fail. Wants Naoriel to die. You can‚Äôt accept that. ‚Äã
9:06 PM
So there has to be another explanation. At least one part of that statement has to be false. Either the Emissary can‚Äôt speak to God... or he‚Äôs ignoring Him. One of those has to be true. You‚Äôre sure of it. And you‚Äôve seen the Lordstone; you know it is a real, legitimately magical artifact. You‚Äôre not completely sure it‚Äôs actually part of God‚Äôs Body, but it shines with brilliant warmth in the Soul aspect. It is powerful. You don‚Äôt have any distinct reason to disbelieve it. And, to be honest, the Emissary has kind of creeped you out before. That unnaturally perceptive gaze; the strange way of speaking. The irises of pure gold, the color of powerful magic. The silver-eyed shade. The golden-eyed Emissary. ‚Äú...?‚Äù You‚Äôre not really sure what to make of that connection, but it seems important. ... ‚ÄúMiss Angel?‚Äù the guard calls in, knocking on your door. ‚ÄúAre you awake?‚Äù You had covered yourself entirely in blankets sometime overnight, trying to block the noise and light from the hall, so he can‚Äôt currently see you. Bleary; tired. Annoyed; anxious. You‚Äôre not in a good mood this morning, to say the least. ‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù you grumble, sitting up and letting bedding tumble to the floor. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre, um, free to go.‚Äù He clicks the door open and peeks in, smiling nervously when he catches sight of you. ‚ÄúJust got word a minute ago.‚Äù ‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù you repeat, though less grumpily this time. ‚ÄúAre you serious? I thought the prime said I‚Äôd be stuck here.‚Äù ‚ÄúApparently that decision was reversed early this morning. I don‚Äôt really know, but if you don‚Äôt want to leave-‚Äù ‚ÄúNo! No; I‚Äôll leave!‚Äù You leap up and hurry past him into the hall, before he can change his Mind. There‚Äôs no one else here. No Inquisitors; no primes; no one. ‚ÄúReally? Just... completely free?‚Äù ‚ÄúEr, he did want me to give you these instructions, though. I think you‚Äôre supposed to check in with someone every so often, to... make sure you, er...‚Äù ‚Äã
9:06 PM
You skim the paper. ‚ÄúI need to check in at the Center every four hours to make sure I‚Äôm not running off anywhere, huh? Indefinitely? That‚Äôs-‚Äù You pause; consider your options. ‚Äú-much less annoying than being stuck here forever. I... guess I‚Äôll just go, then?‚Äù The guard nods. ‚ÄúWell, er, thanks.‚Äù And off you go, down the excessively long hallway. Aware that the guard could be watching you walk aaaallllll the way to the staircase. But then, after another few minutes navigating the turns of Illim Hall‚Äôs first floor, you‚Äôre finally back out into fresh air. It‚Äôs midmorning and chilly, but you don‚Äôt have time to worry about the weather. You have to figure out what in the world happened while you were down there. And you definitely have to find out where Yara and Etalyn went. ... And you probably have to go to the Center soon. Every four hours? What if you‚Äôre trying to sleep?! - Be Naoriel, briefly. - Be Yara, briefly. Ô∏è - Keep being Jessamine. (Winner: ) (edited)

Mxblah 10/20/2024 2:26 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 183 Earlier... ‚ÄúI suppose this is where we part ways, then.‚Äù You nod, trusting Yara to read the disguise‚Äôs integrity better than you can. In a few seconds, as he noted, it falls apart. You quickly wrap a scarf around your face to cover your Angelic features. ‚ÄúThanks,‚Äù you say, muffled by the fabric. ‚ÄúI know you‚Äôre risking a lot to help me.‚Äù ‚ÄúHum. So we are. If you want to truly thank me, though, do it by surviving and returning healthy, when the time is right. And do try to avoid turning to the corruption and making us all look like fools, if you can.‚Äù A wry grin, but there‚Äôs more than a hint of legitimate concern there too. ‚ÄúGood luck.‚Äù ‚Äú... I‚Äôll do my best.‚Äù He nods, seeming to consider that matter closed. ‚ÄúWell. See you in a few months. I had better get back before anyone misses me.‚Äù He turns and walks away, not looking back. Breathe. Your name is Naoriel Fisher, trainee Angel. Half-Angel. And now, fugitive from the Cathedra. You check your appearance in a nearby window, making sure you‚Äôre covered up enough to look human unless anyone looks too closely at your unnaturally purple eyes. Good enough. Time to hurry. Yara can‚Äôt help you anymore. Nor can Etalyn, or even Jessamine. She would have come with you, you‚Äôre certain, if it would have made sense. It‚Äôs still a mystery why she‚Äôs gone to such incredible lengths just to try and save you. Even working with a shade... Shake those thoughts out of your head. You need to move. If all goes well, no one will come looking for you until Monday, but you‚Äôre well aware that‚Äôs optimistic. Angels could already be forming search parties to find you, so you need to get out of sight as soon as you possibly can. But that‚Äôs going to be tricky. ‚Äã
2:26 PM
You couldn‚Äôt plan with Jess or anyone else, since they‚Äôre staying behind and knowing where you plan to go is too much of a risk if the Inquisition catches them. They did give you some money, but that‚Äôs about it. You can‚Äôt use disguise magic on your own, or really any spells of much use beyond a few smaller flame bursts or the like. Your Soul is too broken for that. So you just need to hide the old fashioned way, where nobody will think to look and nobody will be able to detect you just by flying overhead. You‚Äôre well aware of how powerful simply looking in the Soul aspect can be, even though you‚Äôre very bad at it. Jess can see you from hundreds of feet away, including through walls, if she‚Äôs careful. Inquisitors will likely be even more effective, though hopefully not that much more given her unusually strong sensitivity to Soul. Anyway, you need to get underground as quickly as you possibly can - literally. That‚Äôs why you‚Äôre currently buying a ticket on the express train direct to the tenth district, and why you already have a destination in Mind. Namely, you‚Äôre going to a mine. It makes sense. You need to get underground, and they‚Äôre always hiring. Smaller workers are in especially high demand to get into tight spaces, and you‚Äôre a perfect fit. You‚Äôre not quite 16, but with your Angelic slow aging, you‚Äôre slightly smaller than a normal girl your age would be. Of course, you don‚Äôt have any parents or documentation available to prove you‚Äôre allowed to work... but one step at a time. You‚Äôve got a plan for that. It‚Äôs not a good plan, but it is a plan. Besides, you really can‚Äôt afford to get rejected anywhere in case that leaves a trail for the Cathedra to pick up. So you might have to go somewhere that cares a little less about proper paperwork. ‚Äã
2:26 PM
The express train runs nonstop to the tenth district, so it‚Äôs not long at all before you‚Äôre walking away from the district‚Äôs central station and heading towards the wall. The tenth district is situated on the outskirts of the city and contains the entrance grates where the Endle River pours into the city. There are a lot of caverns near the river due to - mumble mumble hydrology or something; you don‚Äôt know - so there are a lot of mines nearby as well. The same situation is mirrored in the fourteenth district where the river flows out into the wastes, but the mines there are better regulated due to all the industry. Plus, you don‚Äôt want to go there since Jess was just... yeah, it wouldn‚Äôt be smart. Hopefully, there‚Äôs no immediate reason to expect you to go here. It takes you several hours to walk around the district, get some food and information, and scout out the possible locations that might be willing to hire you. All the while, you‚Äôre stealing glances at the sky and wondering when they‚Äôll notice your absence. Without a good Soul sense, you probably won‚Äôt even notice your pursuers until it‚Äôs too late. ... Really, really hurry. Finally, by early afternoon, you feel confident enough in one small mine‚Äôs lax policies to try going in. You enter the run-down management building, inquire at the desk, and fill out some basic paperwork with names and addresses that you mostly just make up on the spot. They don‚Äôt ask for your parents‚Äô approval - just their names - and don‚Äôt ask for any form of official ID. The manager comes out to look at you - a gruff, grizzled, greasy man that you immediately dislike - and sign his approval. ‚ÄúGood. You‚Äôre probably small ‚Äònough to get in the 800-shaft, easy. When d‚Äôya want to start?‚Äù You try to look like someone who‚Äôs just desperate for money, not desperate to get away from the Cathedra. ‚ÄúToday?‚Äù ‚ÄúHa! Good spirit! Get ‚Äòer down there today.‚Äù ‚Äã
2:26 PM
So. You go down there today. You aren‚Äôt allowed to wear your scarf into the mine due to flammability concerns (or something? He was talking very quickly) and you have to tie up your hair that could otherwise cover it. Luckily, you had thought of that previously and smudged up your face as best you could to try and conceal your features. Hopefully in the low light down below, it‚Äôll be enough. Up here, you just try to stay out of direct sight as much as possible, keeping a careful lookout for anyone staring too long. This would be so much easier if you could just do a proper disguise, but it‚Äôs simply beyond your skill. Maybe the operation will fix that too and you can learn magic properly. Optimistic, but in a situation like this you have to be optimistic. Before the manager leaves you to your training, though, you should probably figure out where you‚Äôre going to sleep. You‚Äôd really like to stay underground even then, for safety, but you‚Äôd be hard-pressed to find any normal lodgings that aren‚Äôt on the surface... - In normal temporary housing nearby. - On the streets or in an abandoned basement or something, if you can find one. Ô∏è - Try to find a cave or something nearby, near the river. Ô∏è - In the mine itself, if you can. ‚ùì - [Or somewhere else. Specify in #story_discussion ] (Winner: Ô∏è ) (edited)

Mxblah 10/22/2024 8:19 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 184 You‚Äôve never actually been in a mine, though Jess did that one time you all went out to various jobs throughout the city and told you about it. Although, now that you think about it, that wasn‚Äôt really a mine so much as an underground farm - she never went down to the real depths. Here, you definitely do. At least you‚Äôre certainly out of sight from any Angels searching for you above, though that‚Äôs small comfort as the elevator just keeps dropping lower and lower. It almost feels like you‚Äôre descending into your own grave. Finally, the descent stops and you follow the hairy older man who is your instructor into the network of cramped, hot, pitch-black tunnels. You‚Äôre both wearing headlamps, but it hardly makes a difference beyond a dozen or so feet. Side passages gape emptily in each wall and the main tunnel winds around massive chunks of solid rock a different color than the rest. You consider asking about them, but don‚Äôt want to draw attention to yourself and just stay silent. ‚ÄúThis is the 800 level,‚Äù your instructor eventually says, slowing to a stop just ahead of another one of those stone chunks with a massive crack blasted through it. You can hear water trickling on the other side, which makes you very nervous. You don‚Äôt know much about caves, but the river is very nearby and you know it‚Äôs above you. The idea of the torrent‚Äôs full force flooding the mine... He retrieves a small item from a pocket before he continues explaining. It‚Äôs a little metallic orb about the size of a fingernail. Very shiny and a grainy greenish-silver color. ‚ÄúThis is a fluxpearl. Used in manufacturing. Very expensive.‚Äù ‚ÄúOkay...‚Äù He takes the pearl back. ‚ÄúThey form in streams like this. In rock like that.‚Äù ‚Äã
8:19 PM
Obediently, you look at the rock and peek into the stream. The crack is extremely narrow and winds crazily in multiple directions, with little dribbles of water seeping from even smaller cracks branching off the main one. You can‚Äôt see any pearls, but your light reflects strangely. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre small enough to fit in there. Yes?‚Äù You really, really don‚Äôt want to go in there. It‚Äôs so narrow and sharp rocks jut out at awkward angles. ‚Äú... What if I get stuck?‚Äù ‚ÄúI‚Äôll pull you out. Go on.‚Äù Maybe you didn‚Äôt quite think this plan all the way through. Gingerly, you grab onto the edges of the passage and squeeze inside, wiggling through the entryway until you‚Äôve made it into the slightly larger area where water starts to drip. It‚Äôs a tight fit, but it is a fit. Water drums on your helmet and trickles down the back of your overalls. Something scuttles nearby and you suppress a shiver. ‚Äú... Good?‚Äù ‚ÄúGood,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúNow turn around and come out.‚Äù Easier said than done. You have to twist in awkward ways to change direction and keep bumping your head on rocks. Thank God for the helmet. But eventually, you manage to crawl back out and emerge into the slightly larger area of the main tunnel. The man nods. ‚ÄúNot scared of tight spaces, I see. That‚Äôs good.‚Äù ‚Äú... Er-‚Äù ‚ÄúNot too scared.‚Äù He chuckles, once. A weird vocalization. ‚ÄúEveryone‚Äôs at least a little scared of the caves. Anyone who‚Äôs not is already gone.‚Äù ‚Äú...‚Äù ‚ÄúWell, you fit. So let‚Äôs learn the equipment and techniques a little more. Then you can go find some pearls.‚Äù ... ‚Äã
8:19 PM
Hours later, you return to the elevator shaft with a number of other miners to wait for the slow carriage to come back down for another trip. Four fluxpearls softly clink against each other in a leather pouch grasped tightly in one hand, and tied to your wrist for extra measure. It had been a hellish experience to gather them, crawling through miniscule, half-flooded tunnels for ages. Jabbed with rocks that seemed almost intentionally sharpened, though you‚Äôre assured they‚Äôre natural. Constantly fighting the urge to retreat out of the enclosed space that could become your tomb if the rock shifts or you make a wrong move or the water gets worse or anything else. Bugs, everywhere. You‚Äôve never seen so many centipedes, and once you got further from the entrance, you turned on your Angelic glow to scare them off. Jess told you about that, and it was nearly the only relief you had that whole time. You‚Äôre exhausted and sore and just about ready to cry when you consider that you aren‚Äôt going back to a nice hot shower and a nice warm bed. No, you thought about that when you were down there; you can‚Äôt stay in any aboveground lodging overnight. What if Inquisitors fly out after dark looking for you? You have to stay below, which... which probably means finding a nondescript cave off the riverbank and sleeping there. No heat, no hygiene, no amenities of any kind. Your Body might be perfect, but this will still take a toll. And you‚Äôll still look absolutely awful after just the first few days - or at least your clothes will. Especially if you‚Äôre going to keep covering them in mud like this. ‚Äã
8:19 PM
In brief, you‚Äôre already miserable and it‚Äôs been less than a single day. Maybe you could quit right away if you‚Äôre going to stay in a cave - the money you brought will carry you a lot further if you aren‚Äôt paying for a room - but you‚Äôll still need food and some other supplies, and you‚Äôre not sure your Mind is up to the task of staying underground all alone for the next month. You‚Äôd go crazy, and that would seriously risk breaking your fragile Soul. Of course, you‚Äôre not doing much better here. There‚Äôs a dark strain from somewhere within. Not quite Body; not quite Mind. You need to be extremely careful with how much stress you put yourself through if you want to even survive the next month, let alone evade capture. Someone‚Äôs staring at you. Actually, a few people. There‚Äôs a group of boys maybe a little older than you who have been whispering and glancing in your direction for a few minutes now while you wait for the elevator with them and a few older miners who don‚Äôt seem to be paying attention. Uncomfortable, you try to shift slightly out of their sight by shuffling along the wall, but the tunnel‚Äôs too narrow for that to work very well. At least the elevator‚Äôs almost back now. It would be nice if you could hear what they‚Äôre whispering about. Almost certainly nothing good, you presume, but it would at least help if you knew they weren‚Äôt suspecting you of being an Angel. You are the only girl you‚Äôve seen all day down here, so maybe you‚Äôre just unusual due to that. Another potential miscalculation; you really don‚Äôt want to stand out in any way. Elevator. Finally. Ô∏è - Try to talk to them a little; see if you can feel out what they‚Äôre like. - Try to get a little closer and listen in. You aren‚Äôt as good as Jess, but you can still hear better than anyone would expect. - Just don‚Äôt get involved. Don‚Äôt stand out. (Winner: ) (edited)

Mxblah 10/24/2024 8:26 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 185 You get a little closer as the group rearranges in preparation for the elevator. They‚Äôre making crude comments about your appearance and presumed skills. You get a little farther away again, squeezing into the elevator to go back up. Great. This is good, you remind yourself. They‚Äôre treating you like a human girl, not an Angel. No one would dare speak like that about an Angel. At least, so you assume. The knowledge doesn‚Äôt improve your mood, regardless. Return above, clean up a little, and leave the mine. You hurry down cold, darkened streets, trying to focus on Soul to get advance warning if anyone is watching from above. No one, or at least no one you can detect. The river flows nearby and you make your way past a lower section of fencing to the bank. Need to find somewhere to hide. Somewhere close enough to not require a long walk, but hidden enough to not be obvious. Of course, it also can‚Äôt be hidden enough that you can‚Äôt find it, in the dark, in the cold, in a big hurry. Oh, this was such a bad idea. It takes you so much longer than you had thought, long enough to very nearly turn back and just find somewhere normal to sleep, flying Inquisitors or not. But you don‚Äôt give up, searching through the muck and stones until accidentally stumbling on a rock and dislodging it into a deeper crevice. Further investigation reveals a passable tunnel you can just about worm your way into, widening out into an appreciably-sized fissure that eventually descends a good distance before opening into a wide, relatively dry cavern. ‚Äã
8:27 PM
You‚Äôve been navigating by your glow this whole time; it‚Äôs otherwise utterly black down here. Two narrow tunnels lead further into the unknown depths and you explore each a short distance before finding massive vertical drops too high to see the bottom even with your light. A pebble dropped into either takes several seconds before clattering onto loose stone below; a dizzying height. But at least nothing‚Äôs going to be climbing up from below to attack you while you sleep. Well, nothing more than the normal assortment of horrible bugs that you find just everywhere in caves like these. Thankfully they still seem to be wary of your glow and flee at your approach. With a groan, you finally sit down on a relatively smooth patch of stone and just do nothing for a minute. Let it sink in that this is your home for the next month or maybe more. That you‚Äôll only be able to leave in order to take a brief journey back to the mine, after which you‚Äôll head straight back down into a different cave. You‚Äôre safe here, probably, but you‚Äôre kidding yourself if you think you can make it a whole month at this rate. At least it‚Äôs warmer here than by the water. You‚Äôre soaked from the spray and covered in muck, but somehow the air feels almost warm here. There‚Äôs almost a draft... coming from below. Those strange vertical shafts are almost breathing, exhaling deep, warm air. You think about what could be lurking down there, and then decide you don‚Äôt want to think about it anymore. As long as it stays down here, you can just appreciate the warmth up here and that can be the end of it. ‚Äú...‚Äù ‚Äã
8:27 PM
You‚Äôre so tired, but you only allow yourself a few more minutes to rest before getting up again. Strip off your outer clothes and scrub off as much muck as you can in the water near the entrance before draping them over various shelves of rock to dry. Lay out a small blanket off the lower cave floor and roll up a portion for a thin pillow. Eat something... you forgot to get anything to eat, you were so wiped out from the mine. You... you‚Äôll survive a single missed meal. It‚Äôs fine. You‚Äôll just get some food in the morning, before going back to work. Water... you don‚Äôt know if you trust the river or the droplets on the cave walls. You‚Äôre probably immune to most diseases you could get from it, but you really don‚Äôt want to push your luck. Thankfully, you did remember to bring a small canister of water and can probably refill it tomorrow. Tired. Hungry. Still cold, despite the warmth from below. Cool air from above keeps sneaking in despite the outflow. You scratch a single line into one of the cave walls. One. One day survived. Only thirty-ish more. ... It has occurred to you that you could just not set up your clock, and simply not go back. You could just buy a bunch of supplies, bring them to this cave, and then hide out here for weeks. Without having to pay for a room, you could probably stretch your funds that far as long as you‚Äôre careful with spending. You wouldn‚Äôt have to go back into that spiky fissure and hunt for fluxpearls again. But you‚Äôd also then just be sitting here, all alone, doing nothing at all, for almost an entire month. You don‚Äôt know if you could handle that. At least at the mine, you‚Äôre doing things. You do get to talk to people, even if you don‚Äôt really like most of them from your brief interactions. ‚Äã
8:27 PM
Indecisive, you hesitate with one hand on the winding key for the mechanism. Ô∏è - Keep working at the mine. - Stay in this cave instead. (Winner: Ô∏è ) (edited)

Mxblah 10/26/2024 7:53 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 186 But after only a few moments, you wind up the clock and set the alarm properly, then collapse into ‚Äúbed,‚Äù exhausted. You can‚Äôt just sit here for a month. You need something to do, even if it‚Äôs even more clambering around underground. At least you won‚Äôt be short of money this way, though gathering the courage to stay on the surface long enough to spend it won‚Äôt be trivial. You wonder how Jess and the others are doing. You may be out of reach (for now) but if the Inquisition figures out they‚Äôre helping you, they‚Äôll be in serious danger. Well. There‚Äôs nothing you can do about it now except stay alive to make sure their risk was worth it. ‚Äú...‚Äù Sleeping on the floor like this really sucks. It‚Äôs cold and uncomfortable and you can still see your glow even with your eyes closed. You‚Äôd turn it off, but then the bugs would come back and you hate that idea even more. A bit of thick cloth draped over your face helps with the light, but now you can‚Äôt turn onto your side or make other sudden moves. A drawn-out sigh. At least you have plenty of ideas for things to buy later. Eventually, you manage to drift off to a fitful sleep. The silver-eyed shade appears briefly in your dreams, as you knew it would, but it still gives you a fright. It‚Äôs just going to tell Jess you‚Äôre still alive, though. Nothing nefarious tonight. After that, you don‚Äôt dream of anything. You rarely do. ... A week goes by. You don‚Äôt see any Angels. Some basic amenities appear in the cave as you spend some of your pay. You improve at spotting fluxpearls, though the squeezes required to grab them don‚Äôt get any easier. Some of the boys are impressed by your agility. Most still comment on your appearance when they think you aren‚Äôt listening, and sometimes when they think you are. No one seems to think you‚Äôre an Angel; just a pretty athletic and pretty pretty human. ‚Äã
7:54 PM
Your escape from the Cathedra isn‚Äôt common knowledge. Unlike when Jess had been kidnapped and the whole city knew, no one is talking about half-Angels or executions or even the primes shifting around. You suppose it would be bad for the Cathedra‚Äôs reputation to admit that its own Angels break its own rules and aren‚Äôt as perfect as one might expect (though didn‚Äôt the new prime say the Inquisition would be more transparent?). But that‚Äôs good for you, as if these miners heard that a half-Angel matching your description was at large, you have no doubt they‚Äôd be able to figure it out. You just aren‚Äôt that good at disguising yourself. ... You‚Äôre worried about your dad. He expected this to happen, or something like it, so he probably has a plan to hide much like you do. He might even be more able to evade capture since his Soul (and appearance, actually) won‚Äôt stand out as much as yours. But if he does get captured, he‚Äôs facing execution. Just like you. And despite how much he put you through just by having you in the first place, you don‚Äôt want him to die. He tried to protect you, as best he could. Aside from that first sin that led to you being born in the first place, it wasn‚Äôt his fault. Your mother, however... Don‚Äôt think about that. You don‚Äôt need the extra stress right now. Later. So. That‚Äôs your life right now. Caves, overhearing uncomfortable statements, and the constant, gnawing fear of being discovered. All things considered, you‚Äôre doing just great. Another scratch on the cave wall. Only twenty-ish days to go. ... ‚ÄúThank you, Angel Goodall. See you in another four hours.‚Äù ‚ÄúHappy to be here,‚Äù you grumble, not happy at all. As it turns out, ‚Äúevery four hours‚Äù really does mean ‚Äúevery four hours,‚Äù even in the middle of the night. It‚Äôs some horrible time in the extremely early morning, it‚Äôs super cold out, you‚Äôre very tired, and here you are in the Center after having to trudge across most of the campus in your pajamas and a coat. ‚Äã
7:54 PM
Whatever. You turn to leave, too sleepy to think much more about it. You‚Äôve been doing this for weeks now; it‚Äôs nothing new. Just supremely annoying. The Center is still busy even at this time of night. The corruption never sleeps, and so Angels don‚Äôt either. Or at least, those with the night shifts don‚Äôt. Well, they sleep during the day, but - get it together, Jessamine. The point is, it‚Äôs not unusual for there to be a number of Angels here talking with dispatchers or rushing out to the city. What is unusual is for there to be angry shouting going on somewhere on the other side of the room. All the people here are on the same side and usually work together without much issue. What‚Äôs the commotion about? You squint across the room, vaguely making out the back of a female Angel being very upset about something. It‚Äôs difficult to muster the energy to care; you just want to go back to sleep. But still, you‚Äôre curious. - Go look. Find out. - Back to bed. Sleep. (Winner: ) (edited)

Mxblah 10/28/2024 8:53 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 187 ‚Äú...‚Äù You hesitate by a desk for a few seconds before resignedly turning towards the shouting. You don‚Äôt have anything terribly important to do today anyway, and it is certainly helpful to know what‚Äôs going on. First off, who is it that‚Äôs doing the shouting? ... It‚Äôs Stella, you think. You aren‚Äôt very familiar with her, but she‚Äôs Yara‚Äôs captain and you‚Äôve met her a few times. She‚Äôs usually very composed, so seeing her like this is unusual and concerning. You sneak a little closer, though it‚Äôs not like you‚Äôre not allowed to be here or particularly hiding from anyone; you just don‚Äôt want to be disruptive. ‚ÄúFine!‚Äù she‚Äôs saying when you get close enough to hear. ‚ÄúThen you can cancel all my shifts, along with everyone under me, until you grow a damn spine and do the right thing!‚Äù The dispatcher she‚Äôs shouting at isn‚Äôt one of the rank-and-file either; the golden stripes on his coat indicate he‚Äôs one of the three shift managers and thus responsible for every Angel‚Äôs assignment for a full third of the day. ‚ÄúYou know I can‚Äôt do that,‚Äù he replies, obviously trying very hard not to shout back. As a mortal man, it isn‚Äôt his place. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll forward your concerns to Prime Athwood, but I don‚Äôt expect any change.‚Äù ‚ÄúTo hell with Athwood.‚Äù There are a few mutters at her language, as there were just a sentence earlier, but no one dares correct her. ‚ÄúWhy isn‚Äôt Barton in charge?‚Äù ‚ÄúPrime Barton has deferred to Prime Athwood‚Äôs authority due to the ongoing investigation surrounding the half-Angel.‚Äù ‚Äú... 8:53 PM
Everyone‚Äôs looking at you. Most of the ordinary dispatchers nearby seem relieved about the distraction. You want to run away. ‚ÄúH-hey, Stella...‚Äù ‚ÄúI‚Äôve got to talk to you, just give me a minute.‚Äù She pivots back to the shift manager, stepping right up to his desk and bending down slightly to be on the same level. ‚ÄúOne day. That‚Äôs all I‚Äôm giving you and your superiors to get your act together, then you‚Äôre facing an Angel mutiny. Tell Athwood; have him arrest my whole team; I do not care. You won‚Äôt have enough Angels to keep anything safe if you do that. I‚Äôll be back this afternoon.‚Äù ‚ÄúI‚Äôll pass along your concerns.‚Äù ‚ÄúGreat. Every four hours.‚Äù ‚ÄúUnbelievable.‚Äù She shakes her head. Her hair is only half-up, you notice, with the rest hanging loosely as if she were interrupted midway through arranging it. ‚ÄúRight. Jessamine, it‚Äôs been weeks; why didn‚Äôt you say anything?!‚Äù ‚Äã
8:53 PM
‚ÄúI, um... s-sorry, it just didn‚Äôt occur to me...‚Äù Honestly, you thought everyone knew already. But now that you think about it, she‚Äôs right. The rumors you heard all just ended with the two of them being sent to the wall, not past it, and you hadn‚Äôt thought to add anything further because the details were mostly the same anyway. ‚ÄúH-he‚Äôd have to fight wasteland beasts either way; I didn‚Äôt know the difference or that you would do anything-‚Äù ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt need to apologize to me. @Story Notifications Scene 188 You still have such a hard time trusting her. Obviously, she cares about Yara a great deal. She‚Äôs willing to look past the half-Angel... thing. Today, for whatever reason, the crystal is still. The specks remain present, and a less-observant Angel than yourself might not even notice anything was different. 2:00 PM
Later, you stand in the Center and watch. Serri‚Äôs here, as is Jun (you said hi but didn‚Äôt talk in any detail), though she still seems concerned enough to keep an eye out in case you start dying again. You won‚Äôt. Hopefully. At the agreed-upon evening bell, Yara and Etalyn are still not here, so Stella and a number of other Angels simply stand or sit around the edges of the room and do not work. Other Angels come and go unhindered, receiving missions and departing for the city. A few, who either haven‚Äôt heard about this or who want more information, stop to talk. Some of those few join the protest. Others do not. Overall, there are at least two dozen full Angels standing here not doing their job (along with you and some of the other trainees). That doesn‚Äôt sound like a lot at first, until you remember that there are only ever about 120 Angels at any given time. Take away the Seraphs, Archangels, and trainees, and there are only maybe around 100 ‚Äúregular‚Äù Angels. A full quarter of those are right here doing nothing. That‚Äôs a lot. The dispatchers get behind quite quickly. Calls go unanswered, with requests for Angels waiting in a queue and concise notices sent back informing the constables that there are not enough resources to respond. Angels who have just returned from a mission but aren‚Äôt injured or exhausted are turned around and sent right back out again, even though they would usually be allowed to rest. Required, even. No one wants an Angel to get hurt due to overwork. But in times like this, it seems the priority is on completing missions instead. ‚Äã
2:00 PM
No one comes to arrest the protestors, and you don‚Äôt even see any Inquisitors around. But it‚Äôs obvious why, when you think about it for a moment: as Angels themselves, they are in fact among those being sent on missions. They don‚Äôt have time to stand and watch you; they must make up for the shortage. However, that‚Äôs not to say you aren‚Äôt being watched at all. Monks take notes and the occasional bishop will speak briefly with a dispatcher or one of the protestors before moving on. Everything is fairly civil, but very tense. The Cathedra is running at a deficit for now, and everyone knows it can‚Äôt keep it up forever. Muttering breaks out on the other side of the room. You stand up and peek over there to see what‚Äôs the matter - oh! A brilliant, glowing Angel with skin of metallic gold strides into the Center. A Seraph, one of only three currently alive. Ordinarily, such paragons would be receiving orders directly from the Emissary - there‚Äôs no need to waste their talents on the normal missions that the Center deals with. But, today, this glorious Angel enters the building, speaks briefly with a few dispatchers and several of the protestors near the door on that side, and... Ah. You had thought he might have been here to join the protest - what a statement that would make! - but instead he picks up six entire missions from the board, all at once, and starts reading through the details. Even the best of the best are here to make up for the shortage of Angels. Which, presumably, means whatever more important business they would normally attend to is going unfulfilled. ‚Äã
2:00 PM
You shiver, briefly. How many Angels have been recalled from the walls to support those in the city? How many Seraphs and Archangels are here, doing ordinary work, instead of whatever it is they otherwise do all day? ... What if the corruption finds out? - Speak to the Seraph. [What would you like to say?] ‚ùî - Speak to one of the nicer, less-busy dispatchers. Where are all these reinforcements coming from? Ô∏è - Don‚Äôt talk to anyone. (Winner: ‚ùî ) (edited)

Mxblah 11/7/2024 9:01 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 192 What you hear when you ask one of the dispatchers those questions does not reassure you. Angels are being withdrawn from all positions and duties to fill demand at the Center. There are enough to make it up, barely, but everything else is more-or-less at a standstill. The two-Angel rule at the walls is temporarily rescinded and some districts end up with only a single Angel guarding their entire border with the wastes. Healers are recalled from the city center hospital and placed on mission duty instead. Higher ranking Angels who would ordinarily be planning, researching, or investigating are now here. Nothing else is getting done. And you just don‚Äôt understand why the primes would allow it. Even you can tell this situation is both not sustainable and extremely dangerous. One shade can often match even a strong Angel in power, and massive sections of the walls are defended only lightly. What happens if two shades attack at once? More? You don‚Äôt get any satisfactory answers and the shift manager on duty doesn‚Äôt seem to want to talk to you. The most you get is that the overall structure of the response isn‚Äôt decided here, which must mean someone higher up is doing the deciding. Prime Athwood is an obvious choice, but what would he gain from doing so? By risking so much? ‚Äã
9:01 PM
A full day passes, then a second. Repeated attempts to talk with the primes are ignored. Archbishops offer incentives to get back to work. By and large, nobody does. The situation worsens as more Angels return from their missions too hurt or tired to go back out. They must rest, which leaves even more missions to go unaddressed; two of these hurt Angels actually side with the protestors, claiming unreasonable expectations that led to severe injuries. Some of the working Angels argue with the protestors, escalating in one case to actual physical blows. The sheer number of other nearby Angels are able to quickly put a stop to the fight, but both participants are removed from the scene unable to take any missions even if they wanted to. You wonder what the ordinary people of Nucarreo think about all this, as their divine guardians simply do not arrive to save them. Something has to break, very soon. The primes, the Angels, the walls, the city; something has to give. This can‚Äôt go on for much longer. Uneasy, you go to sleep on the third day of the protest wondering if something terrible will have happened by the time you wake up. But it seems like that question will have to wait, because you dream of a cave. ‚ÄúJessamine!‚Äù Disoriented, you‚Äôre nearly knocked over by Naoriel as she rushes to hug you. ‚ÄúWoah, woah - what? You‚Äôre - it‚Äôs not time yet! Right?‚Äù The silver-eyed shade is here too, lurking near one of the tunnels leading out of this main room stocked with just enough furniture and provisions to feel slightly more homey than a hole in the ground. ‚ÄúIt is ready,‚Äù it says distantly. ‚ÄúThe cut-string puppets do not have long left.‚Äù ‚ÄúJess, what is going on at the Cathedra? It‚Äôs a mess out here!‚Äù ‚ÄúEr, there‚Äôs a protest - s-sorry, what do you mean by a mess? How bad is it?‚Äù ‚Äã
9:02 PM
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not ‚Äòcombat in the streets‚Äô bad, but smaller issues just aren‚Äôt being addressed. Things like lost Souls, corruption-related sickness, healings, Blessings; anything that isn‚Äôt an actual darkness creature in the city is being ignored. There‚Äôs a lot of angry people around, and when Angels do show up, they‚Äôre mobbed with desperate requests. It‚Äôs only gotten really bad today, but there were some grumblings yesterday. You spend a little bit of time trying to explain the details in more depth, but are interrupted by the shade. ‚ÄúIt cannot hide this spell indefinitely. The cut-string puppets must hurry their conversation.‚Äù ‚ÄúHide? From who?‚Äù ‚ÄúOther shades,‚Äù Naoriel tells you quickly. It‚Äôs the perfect plan and you have total faith that every part of it will go smoothly with no complications whatsoever. Except the opposite of that, but you have to try anyway. ‚Äã
9:02 PM

Mxblah 11/9/2024 5:58 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 193 ‚ÄúI‚Äôm ready,‚Äù you decide. ‚ÄúWhatever happens, it‚Äôll happen tomorrow.‚Äù ‚ÄúOkay.‚Äù She pauses, but not for long. ‚ÄúOkay. Instead, it‚Äôs only the second time you wake up, just before morning bell, that it‚Äôs time to put your plan into action. It‚Äôs a very simple plan, as far as these things go. You gather up the supplies you‚Äôll need (borrowed or requested from various storehouses over the last few weeks), go do your final check-in at the Center, make sure no one‚Äôs following you, and break into one of the smaller temple buildings near the outer wall. You don‚Äôt have to break into the building itself - it‚Äôs open to all - but you do have to use your enhanced strength and one of the tools you brought along to cut a small padlock off the door that leads to the roof. From here, you‚Äôre fairly close to the wall and, having scouted it ahead of time, know where in the city you‚Äôll end up when you... Hm. You hesitate on the edge of the roof. It‚Äôs a long way down and you still aren‚Äôt good at healing magic. Don‚Äôt let nerves get the better of you; Naoriel needs you. Yara and Etalyn need you. In an abstract sense, Nucarreo needs you. A loud ding as you land heavily on top of the wall before scrambling off and dropping to the ground on the other side. Your ankles tingle with pain despite the magical reinforcement you had given your Body, protesting the demands placed upon them. But nothing‚Äôs broken and you‚Äôre out. Time to go, before anyone comes to check on that chime. ‚Äã
5:58 PM
You rush through the city streets, swapping your internal Body projection from enhancement to disguise as you go. Same aspect but different spell, so it‚Äôs easier to do while on the move. You definitely don‚Äôt want to get recognized as an Angel today, not with all the unrest around. Unlike usual, you don‚Äôt go to the city‚Äôs central station to catch your train; there might be monks watching to see if anyone passes by. Instead, you head to a branch station nearby and buy a ticket on the local train to the tenth district. (You‚Äôd take the express, but it doesn‚Äôt stop here since you‚Äôre still fairly close to the central station where it does.) While you wait for it to arrive, you pace the platform anxiously, trying to keep track of everyone nearby and whether they‚Äôre watching you. It‚Äôs a hopeless task; even at this less-popular station, you‚Äôre still close enough to the city center for it to be packed. And you can‚Äôt use your Soul sense to any significant degree with your magic otherwise occupied maintaining your disguise, so anyone sneaking up on you would only have to evade your physical eyes. You feel blind. But despite that, the train arrives on time and you climb aboard without issue. Before long, you‚Äôre rattling off towards your destination. Every station stop feels endless; every stretch of track between takes an eternity. At one point, your train stops briefly on a siding to let the express pass, which just adds further insult. You could have transferred to that one, you think as you watch it disappear into the mist ahead, if you had just gotten off at the last station. Too late to be worth it now. And maybe it‚Äôs for the better; after all, who would expect you to take the slow option? ‚Äã
5:59 PM
You do have to transfer anyway, getting off at a small but busy station somewhere in the tenth district to wait for a much less popular train to your final stop. The air smells of smoke and sweat; a group of men filthy with dirt climb to the platform talking raucously about their shift in the mines. One of them seems to keep glancing your way, but you can‚Äôt be sure as they‚Äôre on the opposite side of the tracks and are generally facing this direction anyway. The train arrives. You depart. You arrive. You descend into the city once again. A sense of unreality grows as you follow the directions you wrote down earlier, winding deeper into a maze of narrow alleys stained with dirt and unknown liquids. It hasn‚Äôt really sunk in what you‚Äôre here to do. What you‚Äôre going to sacrifice by doing it. You‚Äôve just been assuming - hoping - that the Cathedra will be fine with all your transgressions if it means curing Naoriel and solving the whole problem. But, what if they aren‚Äôt? What if you can‚Äôt save her? Are you going to have to go on the run? Live in a cave like she‚Äôs been doing? Be sent to the wastes? Or. An image of a guillotine forms in your Mind, as crystal clear as if it were directly in front of you. The dull chips and scratches in the blade, the worn-down grain of the wood, the subtle flex and scrape as metal presses against the frame. Stains from years of use, unable to be washed out. You stop for a moment, pressing a hand against the wall momentarily as if to remind yourself what‚Äôs real. The image dissolves. But just as quickly, another replaces it. Phil‚Äôs hands; that strange ring on his pinky. The cards and designs on their backs. The broken gear. The sun. The fallen Angel. The spy. ‚Äú...‚Äù There‚Äôs nothing for it but to move forward. You take two more turns and knock quietly on a nondescript wooden door marked with a nondescript blotch of dull green paint. A pause. The door rattles; someone peeks out. ‚ÄúJess?‚Äù she whispers. ‚ÄúWhat did I tell you last night?‚Äù ‚Äã
5:59 PM
‚ÄúThe jelly‚Äôs name is Reginald,‚Äù you say, repeating the nonsensical passphrase from the dream. ‚ÄúCome in.‚Äù Naoriel lets you in and closes the door. You feel sick. The room itself is located down a short hallway and is dull but fairly clean. Faded tiles and an old, broken door hanger thingy indicate this was once a doctor‚Äôs office. The clean sheets atop the table in the center of the room reinforce that perception. The shade does not. It stands in the corner by a countertop, rinsing a metal tool in the sink. You can see the wires from here, immediately remembering the orange-eyed shade‚Äôs procedures. You‚Äôll be doing something very similar here. ‚ÄúThe cut-string puppet has arrived,‚Äù it observes, turning slightly so you can see a silver eye. ‚ÄúIt hopes she has brought sufficient conviction to see this through.‚Äù ‚ÄúI - I have. 5:59 PM

5:59 PM

[Balances towards dark, decreasing the risk of destruction but increasing the risk of transformation.] - Keep it as is. @Story Notifications Scene 194 ‚ÄúIt looks right,‚Äù you repeat. ‚ÄúKeep it as it is.‚Äù ‚ÄúAs she wishes.‚Äù The shade offers you the cool metal rods, now familiar from several times doing this same procedure. ‚ÄúLet her begin.‚Äù A deep breath, held, then released. 3:11 PM

All of your appearances shift to become more human; less Angelic. A moment later, the first Inquisitor does as requested, smothering the light from your Souls under a blanket of muffling magic. You are now disguised or hidden in all three aspects, allowing you to detect others at a range longer than they can detect you. This sort of three-person operation is relatively common with the Inquisition, allowing them to bypass the limitations of one spell per Angel at a time. At least, as long as everyone stays together and is sufficiently talented to hold three targets at once. They are. And it doesn‚Äôt matter if you are or not, since your job is only to focus on Soul sensing. You aren‚Äôt as good as Jessamine, but you are good generally. And if she‚Äôs out in the city, she probably can‚Äôt be using the same spell back on you without breaking her disguise. There are likely other groups of Inquisitors out searching in the same way as yours, though hopefully with less success. You want your group to be the one to find her. Not for the promised rewards; rather, you don‚Äôt want her to get hurt and you don‚Äôt trust some of the other hot-headed Inquisitors to try to resolve matters peacefully first. That‚Äôs one of the reasons you‚Äôre helping them. The other- ‚ÄúFound her,‚Äù you say quietly. ‚ÄúLeft; this way. 3:11 PM
The Inquisitors work quickly. The ticket agents are quickly persuaded to provide all the information you need, including the description of a girl with blonde hair buying a ticket on the local train to the tenth district. Within minutes, someone in the Cathedra has gotten in contact with someone in the railway and further stations along the same line have received new surveillance duties. At roughly the same time, a private locomotive arrives at the station and you‚Äôre off at a much faster pace than the train you‚Äôre racing. With your train shadowing the local and Jessamine‚Äôs presence now just barely within range again, you have some time to think about your second reason. But it‚Äôs not like you need long. You used to have a brother. Thanks to the corruption, you don‚Äôt anymore. You know what happens when the corruption enters a Soul. What it looks like day by agonizing day as the decay spreads and multiplies, despite several Angelic attempts to cure it. Every time, it just grew back stronger and faster. It simply could not be stopped. Once it has a foothold, it‚Äôs over. The best you can do is destroy the infected portion and try to save the rest. Trying to save the whole person is nothing but foolishness. And with a half-Angel, it‚Äôs foolishness that could cost many, many people more than just their brothers. You shake your head as the train slows, waiting for the train you‚Äôre tailing to finish a station stop. You tried to explain. She just didn‚Äôt listen. Bringing up any of this personal experience wouldn‚Äôt have helped; she would have found a way to say Naoriel is somehow different. She‚Äôs stubborn like that when it comes to what she thinks is right. Admirable, except when she‚Äôs just wrong. ‚Äã
3:11 PM
Somehow, it feels like you could have done more before it came to this. You haven‚Äôt talked to her much at all in the last few weeks. Did that vague promise of ‚ÄúI‚Äôll tell you by the end of the year‚Äù give you a convenient excuse to do nothing? Did you really think everything would still be okay by then? Were you just too angry? Thinking about Jessamine always makes you so confused. ‚Äú...‚Äù At some point, one of the undercover constables claims to have seen her getting off her train and remaining at the station for a transfer. From there, it‚Äôs an easy descent to the ground and you can enter the station the normal way, disguised and hidden by the crowd. You don‚Äôt dare get close, but you catch sight of her once. Scanning the platform. Looking for you, probably. Thankfully, your disguises are sufficient and she doesn‚Äôt seem to notice. A train arrives. Jessamine boards. You do too. A few stations down the line, your Soul sense detects her departing, so you do too. But it only takes her a second to grow much more alarmed. ‚ÄúStop,‚Äù she hisses. ‚ÄúI sense a shade nearby.‚Äù ‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù you whisper back. ‚ÄúJessamine knows better than-‚Äù ‚ÄúGoodall may have fallen entirely,‚Äù the Inquisitor hiding your Souls interrupts. ‚ÄúWith a shade and two potentially corrupted Angels, we may need backup.‚Äù ‚ÄúThis has to be some sort of misunderstanding; are you certain it‚Äôs a shade?‚Äù ‚Äã
3:11 PM
The female Inquisitor pauses, sensing again. ‚ÄúNo doubt. That cloud can only be created by darkness with a Mind. If it isn‚Äôt a shade, then it‚Äôs Goodall with the power of one. But if there‚Äôs actually a shade in there, hold back until we have the advantage.‚Äù Agreement. You begin to search. [This is a critical point.
