Mxblah 11/13/2024 9:26 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 195 ... You‚Äôre exhausted. Your hands hurt from gripping the rods, your eyes can hardly focus on the minute detail in front of you, and your Soul strains as you continue to force it out of your Body to perform the surgery. This has been going on for almost an hour. With the orange-eyed shade, you would have been unconscious already. It‚Äôs a staggering effort to stay not only awake, but also coherent enough to not screw up any of the delicate operations you have to carry out. The shade, inscrutable as always, stands just across from you, its darkness mixing with your light just above the table. It shows no signs of tiring, simply wielding its strange tools with precision as you charge them with your Soul. Not for the first time, you wonder how it learned to do this. There aren‚Äôt many opportunities to practice out in the wastes, are there? Naoriel sleeps uncomfortably as her Soul is reshaped. Unlike with the orange-eyed shade, no fragments of broken memories or burned identity litter the floor; every piece you disconnect is melded back into place elsewhere. But such drastic operations are rare; for the most part, you‚Äôre just rearranging and smoothing the strange, harsh curves of light that you still can‚Äôt quite understand the significance of. Modulating the intensity of illumination. It‚Äôs unbearably delicate work. You can imagine how easy it would be to slip up and carve a deep gash. Death would be so simple to produce with these tools that can touch Souls. Although perhaps it wouldn‚Äôt be as easy as you think; even your Soul is fraying a little as it scrapes against hers. An Angel‚Äôs Soul is tougher than a human‚Äôs, and Naoriel has at least half of one. You‚Äôre able to arrange it such that the lost portions are temporary - current emotions and the like rather than anything important - but it still produces a dreadful emptiness. You wouldn‚Äôt have had any idea how to do any of this without the shade. ‚Äã
9:26 PM
And still, you wonder why it‚Äôs helping you. Even now, you have no good answer. ‚ÄúDecrease your output,‚Äù the shade says tersely. ‚Äú... Wha?‚Äù You‚Äôre so out of it, it takes a moment to parse its words. ‚ÄúA-ah... okay.‚Äù The light from your Soul dims. The centerpoint of the colliding waves shifts noticeably to your side; darkness laps over Naoriel‚Äôs form. ‚ÄúThis... doesn‚Äôt look balanced.‚Äù ‚ÄúIt is not. Outsiders interfere. Look.‚Äù It gestures to one of Naoriel‚Äôs hands. The tips of her fingers are slightly transparent, revealing ghostly flesh and bone followed by the sheets beneath. ‚ÄúToo much of hers, from those outside.‚Äù ‚ÄúOutside...?‚Äù ‚ÄúIt is done,‚Äù the shade announces, disabling its tools. Your Soul snaps back to your Body with disorienting force, like you‚Äôve suddenly regained several pints of blood. A headache blooms, briefly. You can think again. ‚ÄúOutside?! T-there are Angels here? Wait, are we actually done? Not just because of-‚Äù ‚ÄúIt is done. All that remained was to polish away any introduced irregularities, but keeping the puppet‚Äôs Soul open in this environment would only introduce more faster than fixing is possible. It is done.‚Äù ‚ÄúShe... she still looks normal... It‚Äôs going to be okay...‚Äù You‚Äôre so relieved you could cry. Aside from the slightly ghostly fingertips (which seem to be slowly returning to full opacity with your decreased output) she looks the same. No monochromatic colors, no strange mutations, and no blobs of darkness collecting on her Body. As soon as she wakes up, everything will be okay... ‚ÄúWait, Angels?! Y-you didn‚Äôt answer; are they here?‚Äù ‚ÄúYes. Increase your output. Once more. Correct. They are nearby, though hidden. Moving; it is difficult to hold the balance stable. The puppet must awaken before her Soul is sealed; she is very fragile currently. Strong changes in this environment may yet cause further irregularities.‚Äù ‚Äã
9:26 PM
It takes you longer than it should to figure out what it‚Äôs saying, since you‚Äôre busy re-attuning to Soul (ow; you‚Äôre almost completely burnt out) and trying to spot any Angels nearby. No luck; you can‚Äôt sense anything through the shade‚Äôs cloud. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs not - when can we wake her up?‚Äù ‚ÄúImpossible. The puppet must awaken on her own. Forced awakening will cause irreparable damage. It estimates many minutes, but not hours.‚Äù ‚ÄúWe - we can‚Äôt - there‚Äôs no time, if they‚Äôre here. C-can you tell how strong they are? How many?‚Äù ‚ÄúNo. His puppets are hidden. But they are close.‚Äù You struggle to come up with a solution. You can‚Äôt fight the Angels, but if they burst in here and see you and a shade looming over an unconscious Naoriel, they‚Äôll probably fight you! In fact, you‚Äôre pretty much doomed if they even see the shade at all, but you‚Äôd bet almost anything they‚Äôll already have figured out it‚Äôs here due to the weird concealing cloud over the area. Can you negotiate? Can you run? Hide? Will they just arrest you on sight? Kill you? There‚Äôs a knock on the door. Freeze. They wouldn‚Äôt do that if they wanted to kill you, right? Giving away their surprise like that? (Or is it a trap?) ‚ÄúJessamine?‚Äù someone calls, muffled through the door and walls. ‚ÄúAre you in there?‚Äù ‚ÄúI-it‚Äôs Erich,‚Äù you realize. ‚ÄúWh-what is he doing here?!‚Äù No one in the room has any answers for you. ‚ÄúJessamine, I just want to talk. I admit there are several Inquisitors nearby, but no one will hurt you or Naoriel if you just come talk to me peacefully. I promise.‚Äù You have an idea. ‚ÄúC-can you keep Naoriel safe if I go out there? Until she wakes up?‚Äù ‚ÄúIt can.‚Äù ‚ÄúH-how long will it take, again?‚Äù ‚ÄúMinutes, but not hours.‚Äù ‚ÄúCan you be any more vague?‚Äù You shake your head, hesitating at the threshold to the hallway. ‚ÄúSorry. I - I‚Äôm going to go stall for time. Please, keep her balanced and safe until she wakes up, then... I don‚Äôt know; I‚Äôll figure it out then!‚Äù ‚Äã
9:26 PM
‚ÄúIt understands.‚Äù ‚ÄúIf you don‚Äôt answer, we‚Äôre going to have to break in. Please come to the door; I know you can hear me.‚Äù Erich‚Äôs voice flows through the beams of the building, carried by some magic to every room. ‚ÄúOkay. Okay.‚Äù You hate the idea of leaving her with the shade. But if it hasn‚Äôt betrayed you so far... and if she‚Äôs currently suffering from too much light instead of too much darkness... and if you can keep the Inquisitors at bay for ‚Äúminutes‚Äù... ... But somehow - even now, amidst all your sin - you still believe you‚Äôre doing the right thing. That‚Äôs enough. That has to be enough. Because if it isn‚Äôt, what possibly could be? ‚ÄúThis is your last chance,‚Äù Erich announces. ‚ÄúYou have twenty seconds.‚Äù ... Please protect us. God, as always, is silent. ‚Äú...‚Äù One more deep breath, before everything comes to a head. You open the door. @Story Notifications Scene 196 Some part of you tries to hold back, but it‚Äôs impossible. You‚Äôve been resisting this impulse for months. Suppressing the urge to the point of physical injury. Now, you‚Äôre spent. There‚Äôs nothing left with which to resist. Distantly, you hear yourself saying something. See yourself slowly easing the door further open; carefully taking a single step outside. That‚Äôs enough. All you need. You reach out. And. Cut. His. Strings. You‚Äôre back in control as soon as you do. The sin falls from your Mind immediately, paralleling Erich as he falls to the ground. Wisps of broken... something linger in the Soul aspect for a moment before dissolving. You cover your mouth in shock. ‚ÄúI - I‚Äôm so sorry; I didn‚Äôt mean to-‚Äù But the Inquisitors were already moving before Erich even reached the ground. Now, an instant later and far too late to stop it, you catch sight of a blast of raw physical power. Dozens of metal rods like spears whip through the air diagonally, arcing from either side to avoid where Erich had been standing. The first one pierces your left arm, grazing bone before passing through and lodging itself between two ribs. The second cracks through your collarbone, embedding itself in your neck. The third- You fall to the ground, too, dozens of spears protruding from your Body and scraping against the pavement. You can‚Äôt even begin to describe what it feels like as your senses flee and your aspects fade into nothingness. You die. ... The sensation of a distant light presses from somewhere far above. Warmth. Compassion. Unbelievably powerful, though not overwhelming. No words are spoken, but somehow you know that it isn‚Äôt your time just yet. ‚Äú!!!!!‚Äù ‚Äã
7:33 PM
You wake up screaming into thick cloth, every nerve in your Body flaring with residual pain that slowly fades over a matter of seconds as you realize you aren‚Äôt injured. But you are bound and lying on the slick, mist-wet pavement. Bloody lengths of metal rattle nearby; your clothes are shredded and drenched in red. The evidence of your death is obvious. One of the Inquisitors from before stands directly overhead, holding an actual spear such that its point hovers just inches above your neck. ‚ÄúStay absolutely quiet and still,‚Äù he instructs you threateningly. ‚ÄúA single move or spell and I will kill you again.‚Äù You try very hard. But you can‚Äôt stop yourself from crying. The Inquisitor doesn‚Äôt stab you for that, but he does keep a very close watch as other Angels move in and out of the mist. You hear shouting nearby. A burst of air rushes past, staggering everyone nearby and nearly sending you sliding down the street. Projectiles - magical and physical alike - streak into the sky, but only momentarily. Someone yells that it‚Äôs getting away. The shade, you can only assume. With Naoriel, you can only hope. Then, temporary silence. Erich is lifted up and rushed away. Minutes pass. The blade never leaves your throat. Finally, some sort of agreement is reached and someone presses something cold and sharp into one of your arms. You tremble, but otherwise don‚Äôt resist. ... You fall asleep. ... And wake up in the Lordstone Cathedral. Nothing feels real. This has to be some horrible dream; you must have passed out during Naoriel‚Äôs operation. Everything since then... The Emissary‚Äôs mouth is set into a hard line and his speech is clipped. Cold. Furious. ‚ÄúJessamine Goodall. You have betrayed the Cathedra, the city of Nucarreo, and God Himself. You are deemed unfit to wield His power as His Angel, and are henceforth stripped of all such authority, rights, and responsibilities. May you never again harm another Soul.‚Äù ‚Äã
7:33 PM
Wait. He‚Äôs... is he- The Lordstone flashes. A deep, sharp crack echoes through the room. The ambient air pressure increases momentarily, and then it‚Äôs over. But it isn‚Äôt over. You feel the same. You can still see the light of everyone‚Äôs Souls. You can still see the frozen Lordstone. You‚Äôre still an Angel. And everyone knows it. ‚ÄúE-Emissary, what - what happened?‚Äù someone asks. Others repeat the question in different formats and overlapping voices. He tried to remove your powers; to undo your Ascension. And he failed. ‚ÄúENOUGH!‚Äù the Emissary shouts, bringing immediate silence to the room. You shiver in the grasp of your captors, not daring to look at him as he searches your Soul with those piercing golden eyes. The next sentence is much quieter. Softer. But still holding the full authority of the closest man to God. ‚ÄúShe is to be executed,‚Äù he says, almost beneath his breath. ‚ÄúThis fallen Angel has stolen a portion of God‚Äôs Blessing. Only through her death may He be once again made whole.‚Äù The silence persists for several seconds more. You would object - scream or cry or say something - but you‚Äôre too stunned to react. ‚ÄúSuch is my decree,‚Äù the Emissary continues. ‚ÄúPrepare the proper methods. Secure her until it can be done. And get this traitor out of my sight.‚Äù ‚ÄúNo,‚Äù you manage to whisper as you‚Äôre hauled out of the room, unheard through the gag. ‚ÄúThis isn‚Äôt fair.‚Äù Fair or not, no one can hear you. ... They lock you in a small cell in some basement. Everything‚Äôs metal and everything glows in the Soul aspect, enhanced with some magic to be more resistant to whatever you might do to try and escape. Two full Angels stand guard outside, though at a distance to avoid any presumed danger from whatever they think you did to Erich. ‚Äú...‚Äù You don‚Äôt feel any compulsion to cut their strings. You can‚Äôt even see them. You don‚Äôt know how. The sin slumbers in the back of your Mind somewhere, invisible but still lurking. ‚Äã
7:33 PM
‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to die,‚Äù you whisper to yourself. It still doesn‚Äôt seem real. Nothing does. Good. ‚Äú...‚Äù How did it turn out like this? You never meant to do anything sinful, or evil, or even just plain mean. You just wanted to save Naoriel. And somehow, that simple, obviously good desire will cost you your life. Both of them. ‚Äú...‚Äù You shudder as you remember the awful pain from all the spears, and the sudden cessation immediately afterwards. They haven‚Äôt even given you any new clothes; you‚Äôre getting blood on the floor and furniture. ‚Äú...‚Äù God saved you. You still received your second chance, despite your sins. What‚Äôs about to happen is too extreme. ‚ÄúD-dear God...‚Äù you breathe, saying it aloud to give some focus to your whirling thoughts. ‚ÄúPlease... tell me.‚Äù A moment‚Äôs pause. You didn‚Äôt expect one. You squeeze your eyes as tightly shut as you can, pressing out all the tears and - and- Oh, what‚Äôs the point? ‚Äã
7:33 PM

@Story Notifications Scene 197 ‚Äú...ear me? Je...‚Äù A rushing, whirling noise fills your ears, like wind whipping past. Hesitantly, you open your eyes, but you aren‚Äôt anywhere in particular. It‚Äôs just dark and cold, with a faint undertone of some metallic scent that reminds you uncomfortably of blood. ‚Äú...most reach y...‚Äù There‚Äôs a voice drifting on the wind, but it‚Äôs snatched away before you can understand what it‚Äôs saying or tell who it might be. Curious, you drift around a little bit, trying to find a spot that‚Äôs out of the wind that you can‚Äôt feel. This not-place reminds you of the grey emptiness you found yourself in when inexpertly navigating Naoriel‚Äôs Mind an eternity ago. But the not-wind is confusing. Plus, whose Mind could you possibly be inside here? ‚Äú...ference. I can‚Äôt...‚Äù It‚Äôs maddening. Not only can you not understand the actual words, but even the fragments you do manage to catch are somehow stripped of meaning. And the not-wind just won‚Äôt stop! Where is it even coming from? You can‚Äôt feel any breeze! ‚Äú...ve up for now, but...‚Äù The voice stops talking. After a while, the wind quiets down too, leaving you alone in the chill darkness. The tang of some sort of blood still hangs faintly in the not-air. It‚Äôs... discomforting, you decide. Not terrifying or anything, but just enough to make you feel on edge. Where is it coming from? It‚Äôs not you, right? ... No, because you‚Äôre not wearing your clothes. Instead, you‚Äôre in a white tunic near-identical to the one you wore years ago on the day of your Calling. Of your Ascension. Perfect, pure white, the better to display your own purity. Although that turned out to be a lie, it seems. ‚Äú...‚Äù The scent of blood is only getting stronger. You need to find the source. ‚Äã
5:50 PM
So off you go from nowhere to nowhere, drifting between points of nothing within a plane of nothing. At times, the not-wind picks up again, but now that you‚Äôre aware of your Body again, it properly whips at your hair and clothes like it‚Äôs supposed to. Unfortunately, the direction is too confused and malleable to give any hints; it could be coming from any direction. Sometimes, it‚Äôs even multiple at once. But the scent of blood gets stronger as you drift further in a certain direction. Eventually, something becomes visible. Stains and streaks of dark, deep red painting walls; floors; a ceiling out of empty nothingness. ‚Äú...‚Äù You touch the floor gently, no longer able to fly now that you have some sort of physical structure for reference. It‚Äôs cool, but not cold. Smooth, but not slippery. Just textured enough to feel perfectly textureless. A generic non-material created from nothing in particular. It makes you uncomfortable, but the blood is still worse. As you proceed into this strange, giant corridor, the blood gets more prevalent. More and more of it is splashed on every available surface. Soon, you can‚Äôt avoid the puddles anymore and have to squelch your way through. You try to go slowly to avoid splashes, but before long it‚Äôs deeper than your sandals. The lower hem of your tunic grows sodden with scarlet. Disturbingly warm liquid flows around your feet. The smell is overpowering now; you have to pull up a portion of fabric to cover your nose. ... What manner of creature could possibly have spilled so much blood? It couldn‚Äôt be a single entity; this must have been the lifeforce of thousands or more. Now, it‚Äôs just scattered across this mystery tunnel in the middle of nowhere. Finally, you reach the end. The tunnel curves gently up a flight of stairs, from which pours a waterfall of rich, dark blood. Bracing yourself against the torrent, you climb. ‚Äã
5:51 PM
Red soaks your clothes. Douses your hair. Coats your skin. It‚Äôs impossible to avoid. You have to stay low and use your hands for grip as well if you don‚Äôt want to be swept back down by the unending flow. You try to keep your mouth closed as best you can, but you still taste it anyway. Tears well in your eyes; not from despair or pain, but to cleanse even more blood that‚Äôs collecting in them despite your squinting. You‚Äôre here. The stairs lead into an enormous circular room, so wide it could fit Nucarreo inside it with space to spare. The ceiling rises impossibly high, disappearing into the gloom far above. And the ultimate source of the blood spills from a distant sphere hanging from three chains connected to the walls by equidistant anchors each the size of a city block. It‚Äôs an unending crimson waterfall. The center of the cylindrical room thunders with blood churned to foam by its long fall. Hundreds of stairwells much like this one accept gentle flows out into their own tunnels. It‚Äôs all you can do to just stand here and take it in as the endless river tugs at your calves. ‚ÄúWhat-‚Äù You gasp awake in your cell, breathing quickly and shivering with paradoxical warmth - like a fever. The cold metal floor and wall you fell asleep on quickly leech the heat away, but the memory of it stays. You‚Äôre still covered in blood, but it‚Äôs dried and your own instead of fresh and that of some unbelievably enormous sphere. What... did that mean? What was that tunnel? The sphere? All that blood? Was it just a dream, or did it mean something terribly important? ... Hours later, someone brings you some food. They don‚Äôt talk to you or answer any questions. Without anything else to do, you eat it. It doesn‚Äôt make you feel any better. Hours later, someone else arrives at the window. You expect it to be another tray of bland nothing in particular, but that expectation is shattered when the someone says your name. ‚Äã
5:51 PM
‚ÄúOh dear, Jessamine, you‚Äôve gotten into quite the situation, haven‚Äôt you?‚Äù You scramble to your feet with a swishing of bedding. ‚ÄúY-Yara?!‚Äù He winks. ‚ÄúThe one and only.‚Äù ‚ÄúB-but, you were - how - did they let you... how are you here?!‚Äù ‚ÄúAthwood had us released as soon as you were captured. @Story Notifications Scene 198 A breath. You‚Äôre aware of the guard presumably listening in on your conversation just down the hall. You probably shouldn‚Äôt say anything that could make the situation even worse. But... Honestly, how much worse can it get? Plus, Erich deserves to know. ‚ÄúI cut your strings,‚Äù you say. ‚ÄúBut I don‚Äôt know what that means, exactly.‚Äù ‚ÄúThen you had better explain it inexactly.‚Äù ‚ÄúWell...‚Äù You hesitate, not really sure how best to arrange your thoughts and guesses. ‚ÄúF-first, I just want you to know that I did the same thing to myself, too. Months ago now; during my practical. I still don‚Äôt know much about strings or anything, but... it‚Äôs not going to kill you, or drain your powers, or corrupt you, or anything like that. At least... I‚Äôm pretty sure.‚Äù He doesn‚Äôt say anything. You get it; you haven‚Äôt finished explaining yet. ‚ÄúDid... you know that shades-‚Äù Another hesitation. Yara‚Äôs warning from back then drifts into your Mind. You shouldn‚Äôt reveal you can talk to them... but really, at this point, does it even matter? Another breath. ‚ÄúI can talk to shades. Y-you probably can now, too. Back during my practical, I had this dream about a factory...‚Äù You don‚Äôt tell him everything. You try to avoid the fact that shades call you puppets of God, and how that metaphor might imply something very scary about your connection to Him. But you explain the tube, some of the shade‚Äôs conversations, and what you had to do in the cistern. Some of this isn‚Äôt new - your time in the cistern and the operations you performed - but some of it you‚Äôve never shared with anyone. You just... if you‚Äôre going to die tomorrow (today? What day is it? When will it happen?) - or even if you aren‚Äôt - you just... need him to understand. ‚ÄúSo,‚Äù he says after you‚Äôve talked for longer than you probably should have. ‚ÄúWhy, then? And how, if you know.‚Äù ‚Äã
8:45 PM
‚ÄúI... don‚Äôt know how I did it. I...‚Äù One more hesitation. You really shouldn‚Äôt reveal this, if you want any hope of the Emissary changing his Mind. But, after the failed revocation of your powers... you don‚Äôt think he will anyway. And, again. You need Erich to understand. You could say the shade made you do it, or that you just blacked out and had no idea what you were doing. But the truth is that you did know. You had felt that sensation before. You knew it was getting harder to resist. You could have told somebody, but you didn‚Äôt. It‚Äôs not entirely your fault, but you aren‚Äôt blameless for this happening to him. You can‚Äôt carry the guilt of lying about it, even if you could get away with it. ‚ÄúSometimes, ever since I removed that tube from my back, I‚Äôve... gotten this compulsion. It... happens more with people I know well, I think, but.‚Äù A pause; you try to meet his eyes. It‚Äôs too hard; you look away. ‚ÄúI can see their strings, in the Soul aspect. Little strands of light, just above their heads. Like the tube I told you about, but thinner. It‚Äôs...‚Äù Breathe. The sin stirs in the back of your Mind. Your vision changes. You‚Äôve slipped into Soul without even thinking about it. Erich doesn‚Äôt have strings anymore, but Yara does. Etalyn does. You‚Äôre sure the unknown guard Angel down the hall would, if you could see that far. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs like this knowledge that just shows up in my Mind. I just know how to do it. I know I need to do it. ‚Äú... Until yesterday, I could hold back. As long as I fought it, it would go away on its own. But yesterday... I just couldn‚Äôt stop it. I‚Äôm... sorry. I don‚Äôt even know what I did, but...‚Äù A pause as you gather your thoughts. No one interrupts you. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll help you fix it. However I can, I‚Äôll make it right somehow. I don‚Äôt know if I can put the strings back or if that‚Äôs even a good idea, but I‚Äôll make it up to you. Somehow...‚Äù No one‚Äôs saying anything. Steeling yourself, you raise your head to look into the corridor. ‚Äã
8:45 PM
Erich has turned away. You can‚Äôt see his face, but his voice is quiet. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll hold you to that,‚Äù he murmurs. ‚ÄúHowever long it takes.‚Äù Then, in a louder voice. ‚ÄúJessamine, I have decided that you are foolish, stubborn, and occasionally paranoid. But you are not corrupt. You have a lot to make up for, so I fully expect you to live long enough to do so. Is that clear?‚Äù ‚Äú... I don‚Äôt think I get to make that decision,‚Äù you admit. ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt have to.‚Äù He nods to Yara, then to Etalyn. ‚ÄúBest of luck, you two.‚Äù Then, another nod to the guard, but no more words. He walks purposefully down the corridor and out of view. You‚Äôre not sure what just happened or what convinced him, but you feel like that conversation could have gone a lot worse. ‚ÄúSo... should I interpret that as a threat, or...‚Äù the guard asks from a distance. Etalyn tells him to shut up and he chuckles (nervously?) before falling silent again. The two of them stay only a little longer, but they do their best to reassure you before they go. The Angel strike ended yesterday when Yara and Etalyn were returned from the wall, but Stella and a number of those who participated still oppose the execution. There are a number of challenges to the decision making their way through the Cathedra‚Äôs layers of bureaucracy. Events can‚Äôt proceed for weeks at least, even with the fastest legal route. And you still have friends trying to help you out. It does help. A little. ... That night, you dream about wind again. More fragments of distant voices, but you can tell even less than last time. Blood stains your skin and clothes, manifesting from nowhere in particular. You can‚Äôt find your way back into the tunnel with the enormous sphere, nor are you sure you want to. It‚Äôs another restless night. ‚Äã
8:45 PM
In the morning, three Angels approach your cell. One wears a white outfit trimmed with silver, one wears white trimmed with gold, and one wears all black with no trim. All three have neutral, ceremonial masks designed to anonymize the... the... The hope you felt yesterday completely evaporates. Your heart rate triples. Anyone in the city could immediately recognize the garb of an executioner. Your executioner. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs time,‚Äù the silver-trimmed Angel says. ‚ÄúMay the Lord watch over you.‚Äù - Resist! These guys are going to kill you! - Scream and yell and demand answers! This is too early! - Stay quiet and composed. Don‚Äôt give them the satisfaction. (Winner: ) (edited)

Mxblah 11/21/2024 9:03 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 199 For a few moments, you‚Äôre paralyzed by fear. But those moments pass quickly. ‚ÄúW-w-what?! Now? It‚Äôs - you have to go through the whole process! It‚Äôs too early!‚Äù ‚ÄúIt was a unanimous decision,‚Äù one of the Angels says flatly as they bind your wrists. ‚ÄúChallenges can be overruled quickly with no objection.‚Äù ‚ÄúWhat?!‚Äù you repeat as you‚Äôre bundled into the hallway and forced into a march. ‚ÄúUnanimous? Of what group? What about a trial? What about process? What about the law?!‚Äù ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs no higher law than God.‚Äù ‚ÄúBut God doesn‚Äôt want me to die!‚Äù ‚ÄúTell Him that when you meet Him.‚Äù This goes on for a little longer, but you honestly don‚Äôt know much about the law surrounding executions - just what Yara claimed yesterday. And it seems you can scream and struggle all you want, but all it‚Äôs going to do is annoy your captors and encourage them to add more restraints. You‚Äôre keenly aware of your heartbeat. Far too fast, it demands that you find some way to escape. You can‚Äôt. The Cathedra grounds are eerily empty. Mist swallows any sound you care to make. The sun glares at you overhead, a dull, pale blur high above. Like God‚Äôs eye, watching over you as the silver-clad Angel said. Half-formed ideas race through your Mind. You could cast a spell. Incapacitate the guards, like you did at the garage above the cistern. Sure, you could hardly handle three regular humans, but three Angels... nevermind. You could try saying - saying what?! Just run - where?! HOW?! A platform has been constructed in the circular plaza near the Cathedra‚Äôs center, between the actual Center and the Lordstone Cathedral. It looms from the mist, bearing the implement that will take your life. You‚Äôve seen it in your dreams. Your imagination. Now, in reality. ‚Äã
9:03 PM
The guillotine stands tall and weathered, an obelisk of vulgar death contrasting violently against the backdrop of the city‚Äôs most holy locations. It‚Äôs worn. Chipped and stained, but well maintained even after years of disuse. The last time an Angel was executed was... It doesn‚Äôt matter. The next time is today. Seeing the blade drains your energy. You feel almost hypnotized by the tiniest details, your struggles reduced to a state of docile near-paralysis. You wonder what it will feel like, as the sheet of metal cleaves through your neck. The murmurs of a crowd grow louder as you‚Äôre dragged closer, and you snap somewhat out of your trance. Monks, priests, bishops, and even regular staff are present, somberly waiting to witness the execution of one who should have been their hero. But you hardly even take note of the ordinary humans, because dozens of Angels are present too. Most wear stoic expressions, hiding whatever emotions they may feel. Some say a short prayer as you approach. Others, more of a curse. Desperately, you scan the crowd for anyone you know, not sure if their presence would make you feel better or worse. ... Oh... worse... Serri can‚Äôt bear to look at you; she‚Äôs one of the few willing to openly show her tears. Jun, by her side, grips her hand to steady her... or himself. Clarity says nothing. Her normally vibrant demeanor is still. Silent. Even her attire - always with a splash of color despite the Cathedra‚Äôs regulations - is perfectly monochrome. All white. She‚Äôs pure. Why aren‚Äôt you? Sims, grim but almost... satisfied to see such a corrupted Angel be brought down. Denn manages to catch your eyes and says something quietly before making the sign of the matan. A prayer. A blessing. Erich... is right at the front. Just before the podium. He slowly, gently shakes his head. No speech. No blessing. Not even the grace to look sad. So much for his words yesterday. ‚Äã
9:04 PM
But... you can‚Äôt find Yara or Etalyn anywhere. Or Stella, you belatedly realize. Do they just not want to watch? Or... The guard yesterday. ‚ÄúShould I interpret that as a threat?‚Äù he had asked. Did he? Have they locked your friends away again to prevent any possible interference? You‚Äôre brought onto the platform. Forced to your knees. This can‚Äôt be real. Smooth, aged wood locks around your neck. Prime Athwood stands beside the device. He‚Äôs saying something to the assembled crowd, but you can barely hear him over your heartbeat and the sound of blood rushing through your Body. Something about justice and how he hates having to do this and all the words words words. This cannot be real. The black-clad Angel steps to the other side of the machine. Rests their hand on the lever that will end your life. No. The silver and gold-clad Angels kneel before you, their backs to the crowd. Two of them, to avoid any mishearings or dishonesty. The gold-clad one speaks, this time. ‚ÄúDo you have any final words you wish to pass on?‚Äù You‚Äôre so far removed from the world that it‚Äôs difficult to interpret the question. But when you do, everything finally makes sense. This is real. ‚Äú... I-‚Äù you begin, barely audible even to yourself. ‚ÄúD-do...‚Äù ‚ÄúSpeak, then.‚Äù ‚Äã
9:04 PM
What feels like every memory you‚Äôve ever had races through your Mind. What could you possibly say right now that would have any kind of impact? That would mean anything? @Story Notifications Scene 200 ‚ÄúI never wanted to hurt anyone... I was only trying to help.‚Äù A shaky breath. You have so much more you want to say, but your thoughts are all jumbled up and you just can‚Äôt- Is that shouting? The gold-clad Angel looks up, concerned. Is that...? What‚Äôs going on?! ... Run. It isn‚Äôt, but some civilians jump out of your way like it might be. Others avoid you as if you are the pack of beasts. You‚Äôre going too fast for your cloak to hide your Body properly, but you try to adjust it with one hand anyway. You will not be too late. You will not. 12:35 PM

The shade stayed with you, unwilling to risk leaving the city with the Cathedra on such high alert. Besides, you had to plan with it as well. 12:35 PM
Of course, they immediately arrest you. You expected nothing less. But, conveniently, a pair of Angels wearing the signature blue badges of the Inquisition just so happen to have been walking nearby. The two come to the gate, investigating all the shouting, and helpfully take custody of the dangerous fallen Angel that the ordinary humans at the gate wouldn‚Äôt be able to handle. The three of you rush towards a platform near the Cathedra‚Äôs central square; even from here, you can see the guillotine and a certain Angel locked within it. Members of the large crowd between you and the platform begin to turn towards the commotion. A group of Angels led by Stella hurry from the side of the Center building, nearby, and arrange themselves around your group. Yara drops his disguise and switches targets with urgency. It‚Äôs not visibly obvious what he‚Äôs doing, but you know from the plan that he‚Äôs holding the guillotine‚Äôs blade in place from a distance so even if someone throws the lever, it can‚Äôt fall. Etalyn positions herself beside you, one hand on her sheathed blade. Several real Inquisitors emerge from the crowd to face the Angels surrounding you, hands on their own blades. Prime Athwood and the three executioners, on the platform, look over at you. Everything slows down. ‚Äã
12:35 PM
‚ÄúOkay, you‚Äôre up,‚Äù Etalyn says calmly, nodding towards the crowd while keeping a careful watch on the nearest Inquisitors. ‚ÄúI sure hope you‚Äôre ready for this.‚Äù ‚ÄúMe - me too.‚Äù You take a step forward, letting your cloak fall fully off your shoulders. Revealing how you‚Äôve changed. Murmurs; mutters. Discomfort; fear. What have you become, they wonder. You‚Äôd like to know that too. ‚ÄúMy name is Naoriel Fisher,‚Äù you say, your voice echoing across the nearly-silent square and enhanced in volume by a nearby Angel‚Äôs magic. The former because the ceremony is not yet complete, and the latter because of Stella‚Äôs group holding them back. And Angels should not fight other Angels unless there is no other option. You have time. You made it in time. Now, you just have to be convincing. Mxblah 11/25/2024 12:26 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 201 ... ‚ÄúI am a half-Angel.‚Äù You can hardly believe your senses as Athwood shouts something nearby. Naoriel is here? And - and she‚Äôs- Facing the crowd and seemingly looking right at you still locked in the guillotine, Naoriel continues to speak. ‚ÄúI am not a danger to anyone here. Look at me. Past my Body, which has been changed by the rite that purified my Soul. I am not going to explode or fall to the corruption. I have not fallen. Look at me and understand.‚Äù Without much ability to do anything else, you take her advice along with (hopefully) the rest of the Angels present. You look. Physically, her appearance is quite a shock to anyone who hadn‚Äôt seen the results of your attempt to save Mila earlier this year. Her Body is drained of color; entirely greyscale but otherwise identical to her former appearance. You‚Äôre a little too far away to properly see her eyes, but even from here you can tell they‚Äôre almost entirely black. Were you closer, you‚Äôd bet you would be able to see images of distant stars slowly drifting through them. Like what you‚Äôve been told is above the mist. This, you‚Äôve seen before. You‚Äôre dismayed that the operation apparently hadn‚Äôt been as smooth as you thought - or something happened afterwards - but you were at least sort of prepared. No, the part that catches even you off-guard are the... stripes? Arcing across her Body in strange, twisting patterns are two curves that vary in width between two to four fingers wide. One is dark, like the fuzzy shadow that a shade‚Äôs Body is made of, while the other is bright; a soft white glow that basically looks like if a shade were made of light instead of darkness. The full extent of the curves is unknown due to her clothing, but together they cover maybe a fifth of her visible skin. ‚ÄúWhat happened...?‚Äù you murmur, but she did ask to look past her Body. So you do. Switching your vision to Soul takes several seconds, but when you do... ‚Äã
12:26 PM
She‚Äôs stable. Different, but stable. You can‚Äôt sense any strong corruption (that can‚Äôt be explained by being near the shade) or any of the fracturing instability that had previously worried you so much. The quality of her inner light is subtly different somehow, but it‚Äôs not dark. It‚Äôs not cold. She still feels like an Angel; just one with a very unusual appearance. If they just give her a chance, this could work. ‚ÄúAngel Jessamine Goodall did this. She saved me. She learned how to cure half-Angels. You should be congratulating her and learning how she did it, not trying to kill her.‚Äù ‚ÄúYou worked with a shade to bring this about,‚Äù Prime Athwood shouts from the platform, just to your right. ‚ÄúAny work these creatures perform is unholy and dangerous. This folly must be extinguished before you trick anyone else!‚Äù ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs true,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúWe worked with a shade. But if you can just get Jessamine out of danger and be reasonable about this, we can explain how and why. Just because the corruption was involved doesn‚Äôt mean the outcome is corrupt as well. Please, just release her and we can talk.‚Äù ‚ÄúAbsolutely not! This fallen Angel has committed crimes and will meet justice because of them. Your matter will be handled separately when your own corrupt deception is revealed.‚Äù One of the Angels next to her - wait, that‚Äôs Yara! - whispers something and Naoriel reluctantly nods. ‚ÄúIf you insist, I can explain in brief right now. But it‚Äôs not long afterwards that a second messenger rushes up from a different direction, out of breath and panicked. And even as she‚Äôs racing up the platform stairs heedless of everything going on, the Cathedra‚Äôs bells begin to toll. ‚Äã
12:26 PM
It‚Äôs a pattern you haven‚Äôt heard before, but one that you‚Äôve definitely memorized. The messenger confirms it an instant later. ‚ÄúA f-full attack on the wall in the tenth district,‚Äù she reports breathlessly. ‚ÄúAt least twenty shades. At least two hundred Mindless creatures. Already at least one breach; requesting immediate Seraph and Archangel support.‚Äù A pause. Then an explosive burst of movement. Athwood pivots away from you immediately, shouting orders as he runs towards the Center. The one Seraph within earshot spreads his wings and takes flight, angling towards the wall. A handful of winged Archangels follow suit. The remaining regular Angels begin forming into groups based on ability, captains yelling for their squads and breaking off for the train station. Naoriel is almost forgotten in the mess, swept up in the crowd along with Yara, Etalyn, and most of Stella‚Äôs group. As for you... ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt need to walk you back to your cell, do I?‚Äù the executioner asks as they unlock the guillotine and - blessedly - pull you free of imminent death. ‚ÄúI will be needed at the wall.‚Äù ‚ÄúN-no; you don‚Äôt need to,‚Äù you reply. ‚ÄúI - I‚Äôll stay here?‚Äù ‚ÄúGood enough. Prove your half-Angel friend right, would you? I‚Äôd rather not have to do this again.‚Äù Then they‚Äôre off. The silver and gold Angels follow soon after, presumably also powerful fighters needed to repel the assault. Off-balance, confused, and more than a little frightened, you crouch down next to the guillotine as if worried someone is going to spot you and decide you should probably be locked up. Then you have a slightly better idea and hop down off the platform to not be so obvious. ‚Äã
12:27 PM
W-what should you do? Everyone‚Äôs running around with their predefined role in this chaos, but you don‚Äôt have one. None of the trainees should - except possibly Erich, since he‚Äôs apparently involved with the Inquisition? Actually, that though finally sparks something resembling a plan and you push into the crowd looking for Serri. Erich is probably gone by now, and you saw Naoriel running off with Yara‚Äôs group so she‚Äôs probably not here either. But Serri was close to the front and shouldn‚Äôt have left yet... if you can find her. How are there still so many people here? Shouldn‚Äôt everyone have scattered by now? Where are all these ordinary humans coming from? ... More to the point, this is bad. Really bad. On top of the already-obvious consequences of such a massive attack on the wall at all, the timing cannot be a coincidence. And Athwood at least will try to blame you or Naoriel for it; you‚Äôre sure of that. He might be right, honestly. How much do you really trust the silver-eyed shade? Was Erich leading the Inquisitors to you the foretold betrayal or do you still have more to endure? Is it somehow using the unrest in the Cathedra - caused by you - to break into the city? Finally, the flood of people slows and you‚Äôre able to see around the square again. Just about everyone has left; there are no Angels remaining besides you. Where did everyone go? Where did your friends go - wouldn‚Äôt they have wanted to come help you? Did you miss some obvious signal that told everyone where to meet? Is the entire Cathedra going to the walls to fight? Surely not; even twenty shades... You pause to think about it. That‚Äôs a lot of shades. That‚Äôs more than you honestly thought even existed. You‚Äôre used to thinking of them as one or two - ‚Äúthe silver-eyed shade‚Äù or ‚Äúthe orange-eyed shade‚Äù - not a whole group. Together... what would they be capable of? How many Angels will die to stop them? ‚Äú...‚Äù ‚Äã
12:27 PM
You should do something useful. You have to help in this crisis, but you‚Äôre not sure what to do or even where to go. Seriously, how did everyone else get away without you noticing where they went? Were you really that late to be released? At - at least the executioner was kind enough to let you out. You briefly imagine still being stuck in the guillotine, now in a mostly-deserted square, at the mercy of any random person who walked by and maybe wanted to pull the lever. Enough thinking. Time to do something. Ô∏è - Go to the Center. It‚Äôs the most likely place to find someone who knows what‚Äôs going on and where you can be useful. - Go to the Cathedra gate nearest the train station. If you want to go to the wall, that‚Äôs the place to do it. ‚ùì - Or somewhere else...? [Suggest in #story_discussion ] (Winner: Ô∏è ) (edited)

Mxblah 11/27/2024 10:17 AM
@Story Notifications Scene 202 The Center. That‚Äôs where everyone will be. Or, if not, someone will be there who can tell you how to help. Decision made, you rush off in that direction. Outside the gates, you can hear locomotives quickly departing the Cathedra station, presumably on their way to the outer walls carrying more reinforcing Angels (without wings of their own). Maybe that‚Äôs where you‚Äôll go, if the dispatchers think that‚Äôs best. But, honestly, you‚Äôre worried they‚Äôre going to tell you to just stay here and do nothing. Or send you back to jail. And then when everyone comes back, nothing will have changed with your situation except that they‚Äôll trust you even less after such a tragedy. You need to have the opportunity to help! To prove that you really aren‚Äôt a monster! There are still people in the Center, thankfully. Not many Angels - and those who remain are primarily trainees or younger ones who graduated recently - but plenty of human staff coordinating the response. You look around for anyone you know, but are spotted by someone with a clipboard before you can find anyone. ‚ÄúGoodall!‚Äù the clipboard person exclaims, dramatically ticking something (you, presumably) off their list. ‚ÄúWhere have you been?‚Äù ‚ÄúEr - just outside? It - it‚Äôs only been a minute; in all the chaos, I didn‚Äôt-‚Äù ‚ÄúNevermind that! Do you currently have a duty assigned?‚Äù ‚ÄúNo-‚Äù ‚ÄúAre you willing and able to destroy corruption creatures?‚Äù ‚ÄúYes?‚Äù ‚ÄúDesk C, over there. You‚Äôre going out to the city and I don‚Äôt give two hoots what that Athwood fellow thinks about it! Go! Hurry!‚Äù Forcibly shooed in that direction before you can respond, you hustle over to the indicated desk. Slightly buoyed by the unknown clerk‚Äôs faith in you, but similarly terrified by the scale of the disaster. They‚Äôre sending you out? A trainee? A potentially fallen Angel? Someone who was seconds away from being executed and who should probably still be in jail right now? ‚Äã
10:17 AM
Don‚Äôt question it. If you question it, someone might decide you‚Äôre right. It‚Äôs a short line; there are only two Angels ahead of you. Still no one you know, though you crane your neck and look around. There aren‚Äôt many Angels left at all, actually. Is everyone being sent to either the walls or the city? A minute or so later, it‚Äôs your turn. The frazzled dispatcher does a double take when she notices who you are, but decides not to question it either. ‚ÄúTrainee, huh? But you‚Äôre certainly no ordinary trainee... How about... seventh district perimeter, right by-‚Äù You suddenly flinch, your Body briefly convulsing with a powerful shiver. The Center falls silent; everyone else felt it too. Someone starts to voice a question: ‚ÄúWhat was-‚Äù The sudden wrenching sound of heavy wood splintering apart doesn‚Äôt answer that question, but the huge, armor-plated corruption beast leaping into the room and crashing through a desk (and the dispatcher sitting at it) does. Chaos. More beasts plow through the large room‚Äôs multitude of doorways. The few Angels remaining begin to fight, channeling magic or bringing weapons to bear. Ordinary humans scramble to run, but there‚Äôs nowhere to run - the beasts are everywhere. A heavy beast charges right at you; you react on instinct and throw yourself aside to dodge the trampling hooves. An instant later, the screaming starts. You turn, switching aspects as you start to get a grip on the situation. Thrust your hands at the creature and burn it badly enough to get its attention. Distract it from the dispatcher you had just been speaking to and lead it away as you sprint to anywhere else. Don‚Äôt look back. You can‚Äôt tell how bad their injuries are. You just know that fighting this many beasts by yourself is hopeless; you need to team up with the rest of the Angels in this room. ‚Äã
10:18 AM
‚ÄúHow?! Where did they come from?!‚Äù someone shouts as you finally reach the group, finding a brief window of safety now that someone else can cover your back. You don‚Äôt have a weapon, obviously, so you stand slightly behind those who do and aim to burn the creatures away with just your Soul. It‚Äôs so cold; even just being near them is enough to hurt. But you can‚Äôt give up just from that. ‚ÄúFigure it out later! Just kill them for now!‚Äù someone else yells back. A reasonable response, except this is the Cathedra. The center of the city; the most well-defended place in Nucarreo. How in the world did Mindless darkness get all the way here? It must have come from the wastelands, but how did it get all the way through the city without anyone noticing? Or... those pools of tar; ‚Äúspawning pools,‚Äù the conjecture was. Did that ever get resolved? Oh, God, you can‚Äôt remember and this is just distracting you! Maybe that second person is right after all. Your little group of five Angels does a reasonable job holding off the darkness creatures. None of you get badly hurt, no one‚Äôs too tired yet, and you‚Äôre managing to make your way across the room to encircle ordinary staff within an expanding ring of protection. Several beasts have already been slain by the others‚Äô weapons or reduced to ash by your powers. Treacherously, you almost start to believe you‚Äôll manage to pull it off. And in fact, you do. After what feels like forever but was only a few minutes in reality, the last of the beasts dissolves into ash, then smoke. The room is destroyed, but clear. None of the Angels in your group are seriously hurt, though most have lesser wounds from teeth or claws. There‚Äôs a pause; the second Angel to speak raises his voice. ‚ÄúIs everyone okay? If you‚Äôre hurt, please call out so we can help you.‚Äù ‚Äã
10:18 AM
Several cries of pain answer his request. You‚Äôre about to head in that direction when there‚Äôs another, more severe chill. You spin, choking out some sort of warning, but there‚Äôs nothing you can say that will help. ‚ÄúShade! Th-that way!‚Äù Angels scramble to reposition as you‚Äôre proven immediately and horribly correct. The shadow-like creature stalks through one of the broken doors and you‚Äôre immediately struck by how tall it is compared to the other shades you‚Äôve seen. Are they actually shadows of specific people? Stop it! Focus! This is almost certainly the first shade anyone besides you has seen in-person, since no one in your group is very experienced. The oldest Angel here only graduated three years ago. Even with five of you, you‚Äôre almost certainly outmatched. Please be the silver one please be the silver one please- It turns towards you, snapping its legs together smartly. Its eyes are deep, dark blue. ‚ÄúHello, little puppets,‚Äù it rasps. ‚ÄúBad luck.‚Äù A long, thin blade materializes from darkness - identical to its Body, except less fuzzy; more reflective - in each hand and it walks quickly forward. ‚ÄúIt is in quite a hurry today. No time to play...‚Äù Ô∏è - Help your fellow Angels fight the shade. - Talk to the shade. Try to convince or trick it to stop. - Convince everyone to run. At least that way, someone should be able to escape. - Just run when you have a chance. This isn‚Äôt a fight you can win. (Winner: ) (edited)

Mxblah 11/29/2024 12:18 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 203 ‚ÄúS-stop!‚Äù you exclaim, stepping forward to stand between the shade and the rest of your group. ‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre in a hurry, then stopping to fight is only going to slow you down more. You don‚Äôt need to...‚Äù It‚Äôs a weak argument - what if its purpose is simply to kill? - but it‚Äôs the best you could come up with in the handful of seconds you had. ‚ÄúYou can understand that thing?‚Äù someone asks incredulously. ‚ÄúWeren‚Äôt you listening before?‚Äù someone else answers. ‚ÄúShe was working with a shade! Is this your shade, Jessamine? Is it... friendly?‚Äù No and probably not, in that order, but you don‚Äôt dare to answer that right now. The shade in question pauses. ‚ÄúInteresting. You must be the one it has heard so much about. It doubts the success of the other‚Äôs plan, but it supposes it may gain by allowing the attempt. This one may live.‚Äù It gestures behind it with one blade, through the broken-open door. ‚ÄúExit.‚Äù You swallow, already anticipating the response you‚Äôll get. ‚ÄúIt... says we can leave.‚Äù ‚ÄúWhat about the wounded here? What is it doing here at all? What‚Äôs it going to do if we just leave it alone?‚Äù Yeah. That. It cares little for which.‚Äù Ah. You misunderstood. ‚ÄúIt, um, it says th-that...‚Äù That what? That only I, specifically, can leave, and everyone else has to die? There has to be some other way! 12:18 PM
This is the first time you‚Äôve ever seen a shade really fight. It‚Äôs so fast, and it can disappear and reappear elsewhere near-instantly. You only take in the violence in short, snapshot-like bursts. A fountain of blood as two legs are sheared off in a single blow. Effortlessly, the dark blade passing through flesh and bone with only a hint of resistance. Overlapping blasts of magic, confused, dispersing in multiple directions. Too slow to track their target. Light in the room becomes dim; it blends into the created shadows. Can appear from anywhere. It‚Äôs nothing but a pair of eyes and an unending, guttural cackle. You try to help, but it‚Äôs just so fast it seems impossible; you risk hitting someone else with every potential blast. And even just standing this close while attuned to Soul saps your strength with the constant, debilitating chill. You try to at least brighten up the room to dispel the shadows, but somehow you just can‚Äôt gather enough composure to even create a light. It can‚Äôt have been more than half a minute by the time you stumble back towards the doorway it had indicated previously. Fresh blood dots your clothing. All four other Angels lie on the ground, very, very dead. The shade languidly turns to face you. Somehow, there‚Äôs blood adhering to its semi-corporeal form too. It has no mouth, but one of the splatters paints the suggestion of a deranged smile. At least, so it appears to you. ‚ÄúRun along now, little puppet,‚Äù the shade rasps almost liltingly, before returning to a harsher tone. ‚ÄúOr die.‚Äù You can already see the beginning of a second chance‚Äôs glow on the ground. Flesh reattaching; regrowing; refilling with blood and life. You should stay; help - you could maybe- ‚Äã
12:18 PM
The shade swings one of its blades, so fast you can hardly see it. Your left shoulder erupts in pain; blood trickles towards your elbow. Panicked, you backpedal while looking down to see a cleanly circular slice of missing flesh, right at the edge. You can barely make out a sliver of bone beneath the blood. And, as if to garnish the wound, a perfectly-cut segment of your hair flutters towards the ground. In a single strike. ‚ÄúIt will not miss again.‚Äù You run. There‚Äôs nothing you could have done. You have to believe that. ‚Äú...‚Äù Things are hardly better outside. The grounds are overrun by Mindless darkness, Angels fighting against the beasts, and panicked humans running in all directions. Nowhere is safe. You don‚Äôt know where to go; what to do. Your left arm hardly works - the joint refuses to move properly - and blood continues to flow, coating your hand in scarlet. You don‚Äôt know enough of the right sort of magic to do much but dull the pain and start to accelerate your Body‚Äôs natural healing, but something about the wound rejects your magic. Corruption. You burn it away, hiding in a small garden area to tend the wound, and manage to stanch most of the bleeding. You won‚Äôt die, but that‚Äôs about it. The question ‚Äúhow?‚Äù keeps spiraling around your Mind. How could this possibly have happened? How did all this corruption get here? How are the shades - you have to assume more than one - here? How did no one sense anything wrong? How did they know so many Angels would be at the wall? How is there so much darkness that they can attack like this in two places at once? You‚Äôre working yourself up into a panic by thinking about all that. You need to focus on what you can do here and now. Destroy the darkness. Save people. That‚Äôs what you can do, right? That‚Äôs what you‚Äôre meant to do. ‚Äã
12:19 PM
A pause. You realize what building you‚Äôre hiding beside. This is the Lordstone Cathedral, and you‚Äôre in that garden where you sat - an eternity ago - to calm down before meeting the Emissary for the first time. The Emissary. The Lordstone. G-God (literally?) - what if...? You hurry to the main doors, noting to your alarm that the heavy wood is badly scratched and has definitely been forced open. There‚Äôs a gap wide enough for you to just slip inside. The entrance chamber is empty of allies and enemies alike, but it‚Äôs not empty of evidence of battle. Furniture has been destroyed. Blood has been spilled. Ash drifts in the wake of your passage: the remnants of burned-away darkness creatures. The inner doors are closed, but also badly damaged. You can‚Äôt hear anything from inside. Are you too late? You have to find out... right? You cautiously open the door just a little and peek inside. Relief, to an extent. You aren‚Äôt too late; the Emissary is there along with his two guards. But ash drifts in this inner chamber too; Mindless darkness made it all the way to the stairs leading to the Lordstone itself. One of the Angels is badly hurt, with a bloody gash all the way down his torso. The other is injured too, and is trying to stabilize the first. The Emissary watches from just behind his chair, one hand on the Lordstone as he mouths silent words. ‚Äã
12:19 PM

@Story Notifications Scene 204 ‚ÄúE-excuse me,‚Äù you call hesitantly, slipping into the inner room and pressing the door closed behind you. ‚ÄúHow can I help? @Story Notifications Scene 205 You have to fight someone. You have to pick a side. Either support the Emissary and the Cathedra - and help destroy the shade, kill Naoriel, and presumably preserve the city‚Äôs fragile and imperfect status quo - or help usher in a new, uncertain era by destroying the Lordstone. You don‚Äôt know for sure that‚Äôs what ‚Äúcutting its strings‚Äù will do, but... come on. Bad, bad. You don‚Äôt want to hurt anyone. You don‚Äôt want to kill anyone. You don‚Äôt have enough information to know what will be the best option, or if there‚Äôs some third path to take. Excuses. No, they‚Äôre not excuses. You‚Äôre important, somehow. The Emissary thinks the shade needs you for your Soul sensitivity. The other shade thinks you‚Äôre needed for the silver-eyed one‚Äôs plan. Your opinions, therefore, must carry weight. Surely, there has to be some way that doesn‚Äôt involve bloodshed. There isn‚Äôt. You silence that quietly doubting voice in your head and declare it. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not going to fight anyone. I‚Äôm not going to help anyone kill anyone else. If you want me to help either of you, I need-‚Äù What do you need? Knowledge? You wouldn‚Äôt understand it. A promise? You couldn‚Äôt trust it. Mxblah 12/5/2024 10:04 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 206 ‚Äú... I‚Äôll trust you.‚Äù Pushing aside the paranoia and dreams of betrayal, you do your best to believe that Naoriel is telling the truth. That somehow, as a stable hybrid of sorts, she might be attuned to both God and the corruption. That she learned from the shade since your capture. That... as your friend, she would never lie to you at such a critical juncture. And that‚Äôs that. The Emissary - leader of the Cathedra and potentially the most important man alive - is easily dispatched. How could it go otherwise? He‚Äôs a feeble old man without any combat training and you and Naoriel are Angels. All it takes is for you to duck out of the way of his first swing before Naoriel can whack the blade out of his hand. Another brief application of blunt force ends the fight and he joins the wounded Angel unconscious on the floor. The Lordstone looms before you. An obelisk of divine crystal, displaying the gently shifting sky somewhere far above. At least, it usually would. At the moment, it‚Äôs frozen. Though you still seem to be the only one who can notice. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt see them,‚Äù Naoriel whispers. ‚ÄúDo it, Jess. Please, before anything else happens.‚Äù ‚Äú... I don‚Äôt know how. Not right now; you have to tell me.‚Äù ‚ÄúWhat? But I don‚Äôt know-‚Äù ‚ÄúJust say what I have to do. It doesn‚Äôt need details; I just...‚Äù You can‚Äôt describe it, really. The sin won‚Äôt manifest from your thoughts alone. ‚Äú...‚Äù One final pause. ‚ÄúCut the strings.‚Äù You know. The sin rises. You can. You must. You will. An outstretched hand. Your fingertips touch the Lordstone. Smooth, warm... alive. Everything goes white. ‚Äú...‚Äù You can feel everything. It‚Äôs overwhelming. Fear and pain and fury and hopelessness and desperation and triumph and - you can‚Äôt keep up. There‚Äôs too much; you miss a million sensations in the time it takes to process one. The city churns with emotion; if you move back a little and unfocus, it feels almost like one gigantic Mind. ... Wait. ‚Äã
10:05 PM
Something perceives you. Something distant, something unbelievably massive, and something far beyond your ability to even see, let alone comprehend. But even so, you‚Äôre touching it. A piece of it. A piece of Him. The force of God‚Äôs attention is so blindingly bright that you can‚Äôt bear it. His Mental gaze burns you even through miles of bedrock. Just this tiny portion of Him simply looking at you is nearly enough to kill you. An instant more and you would have been burned to ash just like the Mindless darkness beasts you destroyed earlier today. But something breaks. A connection snaps. You‚Äôre flung back into your Body with only fleeting echoes of His presence. You fall away from the Lordstone, Naoriel narrowly catching you before you fall down the stairs. ‚Äú-o okay? Jessamine?‚Äù ‚ÄúI...‚Äù You feel like your Mind has been boiled. There should be steam leaking out your ears. ‚ÄúY-yeah. Did I - whoa.‚Äù The Lordstone is no longer frozen. The patterns upon its surface accelerate, already whirling so quickly it‚Äôs difficult to distinguish one star from another. The golden tendrils are gone, as is the massive string. And - as you look around the room - the other Angels‚Äô strings are gone, too. For better or for worse, you‚Äôve done it. You‚Äôve cut everyone‚Äôs strings. ‚ÄúCan... you see that too?‚Äù you ask, gesturing to the spinning patterns on the Lordstone‚Äôs surface. ‚ÄúYeah... Do you know what it means?‚Äù ‚Äú...‚Äù It connects Him to His Mind... it ties Him to this world. Words the Emissary had said only minutes before. Your memories are nearly whited-out by a brilliant light; you can hardly remember anything after you touched the crystal. But... something about a Mind... ‚ÄúNo. I... I don‚Äôt.‚Äù ‚ÄúIt announces the age‚Äôs end,‚Äù the shade announces. ‚ÄúPuppets no more.‚Äù ‚ÄúPuppets no more...‚Äù you repeat. Nothing seems different yet, but at the same time... ‚ÄúWhat will change?‚Äù ‚Äã
10:05 PM
‚ÄúIn the course of time.‚Äù The shade seems to have regained a portion of its cohesion; its legs are mostly back in the proper shape. ‚ÄúBut presently, it will be departing. And it suggests these two follow.‚Äù Immediately, it makes good on its word and turns to leave the building. ‚ÄúW-wait, what? Why?‚Äù Naoriel follows quickly behind. ‚ÄúJess, think for a minute. What did we just do? And how are the Archangels going to respond to that when they get back, very soon?‚Äù ‚Äú... I see your point.‚Äù You hurry to catch up with them, jogging out of the Lordstone Cathedral and leaving nothing but destruction in your wake. You don‚Äôt dare to check if Nicholas is still alive on the way out; you don‚Äôt want to know. You couldn‚Äôt help him either way. The chill air outside is distressingly normal. The Cathedra is quieter now, but you can still hear the sounds of battle in the near distance. The Center is in ruins. Many other buildings haven‚Äôt fared much better. You hurry along. No one stops you at the gate. There‚Äôs no one left to do so. No one stops you in the main street, though you do spot a line of constables in the mist. Someone seems to notice, but they don‚Äôt approach. You don‚Äôt blame them. Instead, you disappear into Nucarreo‚Äôs alleyways. Turn. Sprint. Turn. Pause. Run. Turn. It feels like you‚Äôre underwater. Just grasping occasional impressions from the surface world. Everything feels so normal here, when you know it isn‚Äôt. You might be the number one criminal in the city, now, and you‚Äôre in the company of a half-Angel and a shade. Time winds on. The sun rises and sets. You find yourself in a cave. Nothing seems real. You answer Naoriel‚Äôs occasional words without thinking about them. Some food appears. You don‚Äôt know what it is. It doesn‚Äôt matter. The shade vanishes somewhere. You don‚Äôt care. What have you done? The sin is gone. Somehow, you know it won‚Äôt come back. You don‚Äôt know how you cut the strings. You don‚Äôt know the true effects of your ultimate... betrayal. Huh. ‚Äã
10:05 PM
Was it you the whole time? The fallen Angel? The betrayer? Have you betrayed the city, your friends, and yourself? It‚Äôs probably impossible to know. What have you done? The brilliant, blinding echoes of God‚Äôs light still linger in your Mind and Soul, a branded, unfading reminder of your sin. What did you see, during your brief time with Him? There‚Äôs nothing left but burning white. You should rest. It‚Äôs late. There will be a lot to do tomorrow. Too much. But how can you sleep when you see His light every time you close your eyes? [This scene has no choices. The next and final update for Angels of Nucarreo will be the epilogue.]
Mxblah 12/6/2024 9:08 PM
@Story Notifications Epilogue ‚ÄúYou really think this guy‚Äôs gonna tell us anything useful?‚Äù Etalyn asks, glancing briefly up at the sky in distaste before stepping back under the platform‚Äôs roof. ‚ÄúAssuming he‚Äôs there at all?‚Äù ‚ÄúOf course!‚Äù Yara answers without hesitation. ‚ÄúMy dear, I saw him in a dream. The most trustworthy source of information!‚Äù ‚ÄúSo you‚Äôve got no idea.‚Äù ‚ÄúNone at all! But that‚Äôs what makes the adventure an adventure, doesn‚Äôt it?‚Äù ‚ÄúS‚Äôpose so.‚Äù Bells ring as their train approaches, slowing to a stop. ‚ÄúDamn sun,‚Äù she grumbles as they wait for passengers to disembark. ‚ÄúHow‚Äôs it so hot already? It‚Äôs March.‚Äù Yara only chunkles; they both know how. The mist is gone; it vanished overnight only a week after the Cathedra was invaded. Only hours after the Lordstone itself dissolved into flakes of ash. The weather has been much more intense ever since, with the sun hotter, the storms stronger, and the chill of winter fiercer. Priests urge the populace to remain calm, but as Angels, these two are well aware that the Cathedra has no idea what will happen next. At least the corruption has been fairly quiet in the meantime, with attacks few and small. Optimistic Angels believe that enough shades were destroyed in the assault to throw the darkness into disarray. Pessimistic Angels believe it‚Äôs merely biding its time, preparing something truly devastating. ‚ÄúNo Ascensions this Calling Day either,‚Äù Yara notes quietly as he peruses the newspaper he picked up in the station. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs four ceremonies and five months of silence.‚Äù ‚ÄúWonder when they‚Äôre gonna stop trying,‚Äù Etalyn muses. ‚ÄúIf nothin‚Äôs happened by now when we‚Äôre down fifty-some Angels, it just ain‚Äôt gonna happen.‚Äù ‚Äú... Perhaps.‚Äù ‚ÄúYou think He‚Äôs gonna come back?‚Äù Yara sighs, leaning towards Etalyn (or perhaps just away from the sun). ‚ÄúAdmittedly, no. I don‚Äôt. But if we just admit that we‚Äôll never again have any new Angels... Hum. It feels like giving up, perhaps.‚Äù ‚Äã
9:09 PM
‚ÄúJust means we‚Äôve gotta take the fight to the corruption before we run out.‚Äù A faint smile. ‚ÄúStill no progress on your assault plan, then?‚Äù She grumbles in frustration. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre all just so timid! We‚Äôre not gonna get anything done just sitting here and waiting!‚Äù ‚ÄúNow that, I agree with.‚Äù A lull in the conversation as the train rattles past a series of construction projects. There are a lot of those near the city center, these days. Even though the big attack on the wall had been a mostly-fake distraction - enhanced in severity by corrupted guards responsible for sounding the alarms - several other attacks had legitimately occurred to draw attention away from the Cathedra. Mindless darkness rose from hidden caverns much like the cistern discovered last March, requiring Angels to dispatch. There had been a lot of damage. ‚ÄúSo, tell me again ‚Äòbout your dream? And the guy we‚Äôre gonna be findin‚Äô, too.‚Äù ‚ÄúI‚Äôm afraid there‚Äôs not much to tell; it was dreadfully short. I was simply sitting in a market that I recognized from the sixth district, having my fortune told by a peculiarly-dressed oracle.‚Äù ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre all peculiar,‚Äù Etalyn grumbles to the side. ‚ÄúPeculiar because he was dressed so normally, I should say. Anyway, instead of ordinary pictures on the cards, I first drew a portrait of Jessamine, then of Naoriel, then of their silver-eyed companion. At that point I grew suspicious that I was dreaming, and the oracle simply told me to find him. Then I awakened. And found you. And persuaded you to accompany me. And here we are!‚Äù ‚ÄúSo it could‚Äôve just been a normal dream?‚Äù ‚ÄúDefinitely,‚Äù he says with conviction. ‚ÄúBut we‚Äôll never know unless we try.‚Äù ‚ÄúAnd if we do find a clue about them...?‚Äù ‚ÄúOur little secret,‚Äù he winks. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm afraid those at the top are perhaps a little bit too... absolutely furious to be trusted with information on the whereabouts of our dear missing friends.‚Äù ‚ÄúAnd you‚Äôre still calling them ‚Äòfriends?‚Äô Even after they - y‚Äôknow - did all this?‚Äù ‚Äã
9:09 PM
‚ÄúWell, I might admit to being a tad miffed myself. But I fully believe that those two would never have purposefully brought harm to the city. They may have been deceived, or forced, or even been wholly unaware of the true consequences. Or perhaps we‚Äôre all being played for fools and one of them can turn the mist and Callings back on. We‚Äôll never know until we find them, hm?‚Äù ‚ÄúS‚Äôlong as you‚Äôre okay with me giving ‚Äòem both a good whack for causin‚Äô all this trouble.‚Äù ‚ÄúOh, by all means! Never did I say I considered their situation blameless. Just perhaps more nuanced than a guillotine could determine.‚Äù After a few more minutes, the pair disembarks their train at the sixth district central station. As predicted, a number of market stalls fill the nearby square. Yara peers out at the crowd. ‚ÄúQuite popular today, it seems.‚Äù ‚ÄúOracle. That your guy?‚Äù Etalyn asks, pointing to a flashy booth advertising ‚ÄúFortune Telling! Most accurate readings this side of the planet!‚Äù The oracle himself, contrasting with the booth, looks very normal. Average height, maybe a little pudgy. Sandy hair and a tan vest over a collared shirt and dark brown trousers. Like a banker might wear. ‚ÄúOoh hoo!‚Äù Yara immediately sets off down the steps. ‚ÄúExactly as predicted! You see? Never doubt the dreams.‚Äù But Etalyn catches his arm before he can get away. ‚ÄúHold on. Just be a little careful, okay? If that dream was real, then someone‚Äôs got some powerful magic. Maybe this guy, maybe someone else. But the last time you got a dream like that was from a shade, so just, y‚Äôknow. Eyes open.‚Äù ‚ÄúWide and unblinking,‚Äù he agrees. ‚ÄúNow, let‚Äôs check this intriguing fellow out, shall we?‚Äù ‚ÄúYep. Let‚Äôs go get ‚Äòim.‚Äù The oracle looks up as the two disguised Angels approach, shuffling a deck of ornately-designed cards. ‚ÄúAh, a lovely young man and a lovely young lady; shall I perform a compatibility reading for you?‚Äù ‚Äã
9:09 PM
‚ÄúNo need!‚Äù Yara declares flamboyantly. ‚ÄúFor we! Are already a couple.‚Äù Etalyn, despite her normal demeanor, can‚Äôt help but smile just a little at how pleased he was to say it. ‚ÄúMy, oh my! How wonderful. Well then, how can I help you today?‚Äù ‚ÄúI saw this stall in a dream,‚Äù he says straightforwardly. ‚ÄúDear oracle-‚Äù ‚ÄúYou may call me Phil, if you‚Äôd like.‚Äù ‚ÄúOur dear Phil, we are searching for two highly remarkable individuals. Dream-you suggested that real-you may hold some information. Do tell, how correct was he?‚Äù Phil laughs heartily. ‚ÄúMy! I‚Äôll certainly do my best to live up to these lofty expectations. Locating divinations aren‚Äôt my specialty, but you could certainly do much worse. If you‚Äôll just say the name of one of these remarkable individuals, we can shuffle the deck and get started.‚Äù ‚ÄúJessamine Goodall,‚Äù Yara declares without hesitation. ‚ÄúJessamine-? The Jessamine Goodall?‚Äù ‚ÄúThe one and only.‚Äù ‚ÄúWhat a curious pair you are. Very well; let us begin.‚Äù Phil shuffles the deck with rapid precision, then holds out his hands. ‚ÄúPlease, choose your first card. And let‚Äôs see if we can‚Äôt track her down...‚Äù (~) ‚Äã
9:09 PM
Conclusion Hey, thanks for playing! This story‚Äôs dead protagonist tally ends up at a remarkable zero - or a half, if you count our dear Jessamine‚Äôs first death and revival? Not for lack of trying, it seems, particularly at the end. Ah well, I‚Äôm glad all the (important) Angels lived through the prologue and get to have more adventures in the sequel: End of Nucarreo. The title might change as I consider the plot in more detail, but that‚Äôs the working title I‚Äôm using for my outline draft at the moment. I rewrote this epilogue entirely after finishing the whole darn thing - it was 1500 words in the first draft. It was also a lot more passive, with the narrator telling you most of the same things, and I really didn‚Äôt like it. I‚Äôm much more satisfied with Yara and Ets (our favorite Angelic not-a-couple-but-now-definitely-a-couple) actually going out and doing something instead of some voice in the sky saying it. So the delay did help there. But what happened to Nicholas? Lewis Kin? Maeve Kamiya? Serri? Erich? Seth? ... Jessamine and Naoriel??? Well, I suppose you‚Äôll have to wait till the sequel to find out! (Okay, I‚Äôll give a one-sentence minimal-spoilers statement of what happened to the first character that someone asks about in #story_discussion - Jess, Nao, and the shade excepted - so all of you raving fans of Father Turner better move quick to find out how he‚Äôs doing.) So, what‚Äôs next? Disappointingly (or not, depending on how you feel), it‚Äôs not going to be Angels of Nucarreo 2: more Angels, more Nucarreo. I‚Äôve been working on this story for well over a year now and the document is so long that it sometimes crashes Google Docs when I open it on mobile. I need to write in a different universe for a while. We haven‚Äôt run out of votes or motivation yet, so it‚Äôll be business as usual - I‚Äôll put up some new prompts in a bit, we‚Äôll vote, and then we‚Äôll have a new story. Hooray! ‚Äã
9:09 PM
I‚Äôll be archiving the current #story_updates channel and creating a new one for the next story in the next few days. The new set of starting prompts will then be put up ‚Äúsometime soon,‚Äù probably next week sometime. Thanks for sticking around and engaging with what‚Äôs probably been my favorite story to date. Let‚Äôs keep it up for a good while yet! ~ Shaun / @Mxblah
